projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: The whole SERIES OF ALL that hath been Transacted in the HOUSE OF PEERS, Concerning the Popish Plot, wherein is contained, the most MATERIAL PASSAGES in both HOUSES of PARLIAMENT, Relating to the full Discovery thereof.
London Printed 1681.

HIs Majesty sitting in His Royal Throne, Adorned with His Royal Crown and Ornaments, (the Peers being likewise in their Robes) commanded the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, to give the House of Commons notice, That it is His Majesties pleasure, that they attend him presently with their Speaker; who being come, His Majesty made the Speech following,
I Have thought the time very long since We parted last; and would not have deferred your Meeting by so many Prorogations, if I could well have met you sooner.

The part which I have had this Summer in the Preservation of Our Neighbours, and the well-securing what was left of Flanders, is sufficiently known, and acknowledged by all that are abroad; and though for this cause I have been obliged to keep up my Troops (without which Our Neighbours had absolutely despaired) yet both the Honour and Interest of the Nation have been so far improved by it, that I am confident no Man here will Repine at it, or think the Money Raised for their Disbanding, to have been ill employed in their Continuance; and I do assure you I am so much more out of Purse for the Service, that I do expest you should supply it.
How far it may be necessary (considering the present State of Christendom) to reduce the Land and Sea Forces, or to what degree, is worthy of all Our serious Considerations.

I now intend to acquaint you (as I shall always do with any thing that concerns Me) that I have been informed of a Design against my Person, by the Jesuits, of which I shall forbear any Opinion, least I may seem to say too much or too little, but I will leave the Matrer to the Law, and in the mean time will take as much Care as I can to prevent all manner of Prastices by that sort of Men, and of others too who have been tampering in a high degree with Foreigners, and contriving how to ineroduce Popery amongst us.
I shall conclude with the Recommending to you my other Concerns.
I have been under great Disappointments by the Defects of the Poll-Bill.

My Revenue is under great Anticipations, and at the best, was never equal to the constant and necessary Expence of the Government, whereof I intend to have the whole State laid before you and require you to look into it, and consider of it, with that Duty and Affection, which I am sure I shall always find from you.

p.hi: It was moved upon occasion of his Majesties Speech, that an humble Address may be presented to his Majesty, for a day of Fasting and Humiliation for the farther discovery of the horrid design against the sacred person of his Majesty, whereupon a form was drawn up and read and approved of, but the house thought fit to divide it into two Addresses as follows.

We your Majesties most Dutiful and Loyal Subjects the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and 〈…〉 in Parliament assembled having been acquainted by your Majesty, that there is Information given of a horrible design against your Majesties sacred life (which God long preserve) and being very sensible of the fatal consequence of such an attempt, and the dangers of the subversion of the Protestant Religion and Government of this Realm, which God of his Infinite Mercy hath hitherto prevented and we hope will prevent for the future, do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that a Solemn day of Fasting and humiliation may be appointed to implore the Mercy and Protection of God Almighty to your Majesties
Royal person, and in you to all your Loyal Subjects, and to pray him to bring to light more and more all secret Machinations against your Majesty and your whole Kingdom.

div.p: A Message was sent to the house of Commons by the Lord Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas, and Mr. Justice Jones, to deliver the aforesaid Address to his Majesty to the House of Commons, and Desire their concurrence thereunto.

div.head: The Second Address to His Majesty was as follows.
div.p: We your Majesties most dutiful and loyal Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, having been acquainted by your Majestie that there is Information given, of a horrible design against your Majesties sacred life (which God long preserve) are humble Suitors to your Majestie, that you would vouchsafe to communicate to us (as far as your Majesty shall think fit such papers as have any tendency to the Discovery thereof) or of any other design against the Protestant Religion, as it is now Established in the Church of England, That we may use our Utmost endeavors, to serve your Majesty according to our bounden Duty and Allegiance.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with the white Staves do attend His Majesty from this house, to present their humble Address concerning papers relating to the discovery of the horrible Design against His Majesties most sacred life.

The Messengers sent to the house of Commons with the Address, return with this Answer. That the Commons agree with their Lordships in the Address to be presented to His Majesty for a Fast as it was sent down, filling up the blanck with the word (Commons)

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty to know his pleasure, at what time both houses may wait on him with their humble Address for a Fast.

div.head: Die Martis 22. Octobris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Treasurer Reported that in Obedience to the Commands of this House, he and the rest of the Lords with white Staves, have attended His Majesty upon three particulars.
1. That he would be pleased to give Orders for the Printing and Publishing his Speech and the Lord Chancellors.
To which His Majesties answer was, that he had given Order for the same already.
2. That His Majesty would Communicate to this house such Papers as have any tendency to the Discovery of the horrible design against His Majesties life.
Concerning which His Majesty said he would give Orders.
3. To know His Majesties pleasure what time both houses may wait upon him to present him with an humble Address for a Fast.
To which His Majesties answer is, that he will be ready in the Banquerting-house at White-hal, at three of the clock this afternoon to receive the same.

A message was sent to the house of Commons by Sr. Timothy Baldwyn and Sr. William Beversham to acquaint them that His Majesty hath appointed this afternoon at three of the clock for both houses to attend him in the Banquetting-house at White-hall with their Address for a fast.

div.head: Die Mercurii 23. Octobris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Chancellor signified to the house that one of the Clerks of the Councel by direction from His Majesty attended with such Papers as their Lordships desired, concerning the discovery of the horrid design against the person of His sacred Majesty, whereupon the house directed John Walker Deputy to the Clerk of the Parliament presently to go forth, and receive them from the Clerk of the Councel according to a List.

The Lord Chancellor Reported, that he did yesterday present to His Majesty the Address of both houses for a Fast.
And His Majesty was pleased to give this Answer, that their Lordships should hear from him speedily concerning a day.

Lords Committees appointed to consider of the Papers transmitted from the Councel by His Majesties directions, concerning the discovery of the horrible design against His Majesties sacred person, or of any other design against His Majesty, or His Kingdom by introducing Popery, whose Lordships or any Seaven are to meet this afternoon at four of the clock, and afterwards De die in die in the Princes Lodgings with liberty to adjourn into this house if they think sit, and have Power to send for persons, Papers and Records as they shall see cause. And the Committee at the opening of the Committee are to examine the particular Papers by a List, and likewise to examine them again at the rising of the Committee, and to seal them up in a bagg.
The Committee likewise have Power to examin Witnesses concerning the Murther of Sr. Edmondbury Godfery, and make Report to the house.

It being moved that an Address might be presented to His Majesty for the Banishing of Papists from the Cities of London and Westminster. These Lords following were appointed to draw up such an Address and Present the same to the house presently.

div.head: M. Winton, E. Bridgwater, E. Essex, E. Shaftsbury, Vis. Hallifax.
div.p: THe M. Winton Reported that the Committee have prepared a Draught of an Address intended to be presented to His Majesty for Banishing Papists from the Cities of London and Westminster. Which is offered to the consideration of the house, the same being read was approved of, the Tenor whereof followeth.

We your Majesties most Loyal and Obedient Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temperal in Parliament Assembled, considering the great present danger wherein your Majesties sacred person is involved, together with the Religion and Government of your Majesties Kingdom, and being sensible of the fears of your Majesties Loyal Subjects, by teason of the great & more than usual concourse of Popish Recusants to your Citties of London and westminster and your Royal Pallace, at a time that justly giveth so much jealousy, the Parliam • nt now
sitting do most humbly beseech your Majesty, that you will be pleased forthwith to Issue out your Royal Proclamation strictly to command and enjoyn all Popish Recusants and all as are justly suspected to be such, within six days to depart the said Citties of London and Westminster and the liberties thereof, and not to come within Ten Miles of the said Citties. And that the Statutes for restraining such persons to come to the Court, or depart from their houses above five Miles may be put in Execution.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with white staves be and are hereby appointed to attend His Majesty from this house, with their humble Address concerning the removal of Popish Recusants from His Majesties Pallace, and Citties of London and Westminster and the liberties thereof.

div.head: Die Jovis 24 Octobris 1678.
div.p: ORdered that the Clerk of the Parliament, do prepare a List of the names of such Lords, as have not taken the Oath of Allegiance, and give the house an account thereof to morrow Morning.

Lords Committees appointed to examin and take Informations concerning the Constables and other Officers in London and Westminster, and the adjacent Parishes of Middlesex. Whether they or any of them be Papists or so Reputed, and make Report thereof unto the house.
Their Lordships or any five of them to meet to morrow at four of the Clock in the Princes Lodgings, and to adjourn as they please.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sr. John Trevor, and others to acquaint their Lordships that the Commons had prepared an Address to be presented to His Majesty, for removal of Papists from the Citties of London and Westminster, to which they desire their Lordships concurrence.
The said Address was read and agreed to with the addition of these words (otherwise then at the Councel Board)

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sr. Miles Cook, and Sr. John Haskins. To let them know that the Lords agree to the Address, for the removal of Papists with a small addition, to which the Lords desire the concurrence of the House of Commons.
The Lord Chancelor reported, that in answer to the address of both houses concerning the keeping of a Fast, His Majesty is pleased to appoint Wednesday the 13 Day of November next for that purpose.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temperal in Parliament assembled, That the Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, be and is hereby appointed to Preach before the House of Peers in the Abbey Church at Westminster, on Wednesday the 13th. Day of November next being the day appointed by His Majesty, for Solemn Fasting and Humiliation, to Implore the Mercy and Protection of God Almighty upon the Kings Majesty and His Kingdom.

div.head: Die Veneris 25. Octobris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Viscount Stafford acquainted the house that he was informed, that there was a Warrant Issued out from the Lord Chief Justice of England to apprehend him, which he thought fit to acquaint their Lordships with, and submitted himself to their Lordships Judgment.

The Lord Chief Justice (being present) was commanded to give the house an account of the business, who said last night about nine of the Clock, he received a letter from the speaker of the House of Commons; Dated from the speakers Chair, to come to the House of Commons about business of great concernment, accordingly he attended the House of Commons, where the speaker told him that the House of Commons had received Accusations of High Treason, against five Lords and some Gentlemen, and desired him to Issue out his warrants for their apprehension, the persons were the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, the Lord Arundel of Warder, the Lord Peter, and the Lord Bellasis. And upon this Issued out his Warrants for their apptehension, having taken the Examination of Titus Oats upon Oath, that the E. of Powis and the Lord Arundel were brought to him this morning in Custody, and he advised them to render themselves to the Gate-house where now they are.
Upon this the Examination of Oats was read, whereby it did appear that the Lord Viscount Stafford was charged to be in a conspiracy of Treason against the King.
The Lord Viscount Stafford denied the fact and after this withdrew, and after a while the house was Informed that his Lordship would render himself to the Lord Chief Justice.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sr. William Hickman and others, to acquaint their Lordships that they agree to the Amendment their Lordships have made in the Address to be presented unto His Majesty, for removing of Papists from London and Westminster, and have made some additions to the said Amendment, to which their Lordships concurrence is desired.
The said Addition was read and agreed to.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do wait on His Majesty, from this house to know what time His Majesty will please to appoint, that both houses may attend him to present their humble Address to His Majesty, for the removal of Papists from London.

The Lord Bishop of Rochester Reported that the Committee for examining the Papers relating to the horrid design against His Majesty, do find that Sir George Wakeman, notwithstanding the matters against him, goes abroad, which the Committee leaves to the Judgment of the house, whether it be not fit h • be apprehended.
The house was Informed that Sir. George Wakeman, is apprehended.

His Lordship farther Reported, that they find that Whitebread and Micho having been sick and not able to be removed have a Guard upon them, and Dr. Warner was appointed to Visit them, but no account hereof given.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Dr. Lowre and Dr. Warner be and are hereby appointed to visit Mr. White alias Whitebread, and Mr. Micho, being sick near Wilde-house, and gave this house an account to morrow morning in what conditions of health they find them.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, That Sir. Edward Carteret Gentleman Usher of the Black Rodd, attending this house together with Sir. William Beversham, and Sir Samuel Clark, two of the Masters of Chancery, now attending in this house be and are hereby required to repair immediatly to the house and chamber of Mr. Langhorn, now Prisoner in Newgat, and seize such Papers Letters or other Writings as they shall there find, and forthwith bring them to this House.

div.head: Die Sabbati 26. Octobris 1678.
div.p: Dr. Lowre and Dr. Warner gave the Houses this account, that according to their Lordships Order Yesterday, they have visited Whitebread and Micho, and they do find them in a very low Condition and Danger of their lives, if they should be removed out of their Beds.

The House being Informed, that the Lord Bellasis having all his Papers seized by vertue of the L. C. Justices Warrant, he desires that the said Papers may be sealed up in a bag and brought into this House, which was Ordered, and the like Order to be for all the Lords, who are apprehended by vertue of the warrant from the Lord Chief Justice.

The Lord Chancellor acquinted the House that the Duke of Ormond Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, being Informed of the dangerous design here against the person of His Majesty, and His Government, hath secured the person of Peter Talbot in Ireland, and hath issued out a Proclamation against Priests and Jesuits, and hath taken examinations in the business; which his Lordship hath transmitted to His Majesty, who is ready to communicate the same to this House by one of the Clerks of the Councel who attends at the Door, and accordingly Sir. Phillip Loyd was called in, and at the Bar delivered the said examinations.

The Lord Bishop of Rochester Reported, that the Committee for perusing of Papers for Discovery of the Horrid Design against His Majesties person, are of Opinion that His Majesty may be moved, that such Letters of Mr. Colemans as the Committee have read and sealed up by themselves, may be transmitted to the House of Commons speedily.
Agreed that these Papers be taken immediatly out of the Bag, and delivered to His Majesty by the Lord Bishop of Rochester.

His Lordship further Reported, that the Committee are of Opinion, that Mr. Coleman a Prisoner in Newgate may be speedily examined. And upon consideration hereof the House named, these Lords to the Committees appointed to go immediatly and examin Mr. Coleman, and such other Prisoners as are now committed to Newgat for Treason, and to use all incouragement to them, for further discovery and make Report to the House.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Gentleman Usher of the Black
Rodd do send one or more of his Officers with William Sorocoale to search the House of James Thompson and to seize such Papers and Writings as they shall find there, and bring them before this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that James Thompson be and shall stand committed to the Prison of the Gate-house at Westminster, for dangerous words by him uttered, there to remain during the pleasure of this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf-

The Lord Treasurer gave the House an account that he hath attended His Majesty to know his pleasure, what time he will appoint both Houses to wait on him to present the Address, for removal of Papists from London and Westminster, and His Majesty hath appointed this afternoon at three of the Clock in the Banquetting House at White-hall for that purpose.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons, by Sir. Timothy Baldwyn and Sir. William Beversham to acquaint shem, that the King hath appointed this afternoon at three of the Clock in the Banquetting-house at White-hall to receive the Address of both Houses, for the removal of Papists from London and Westminster.

The Lord Peter being in the House took notice that he heard of a Warrant issued out against him by the Lord Chief Justice of England, and he desired to know the cause of it, hereupon the House directed the Lord Chancellor to acquaint his Lordship, what account the Lord Chief Justice gave the House yesterday, and upon what ground he issued his Warrant, for apprehending him and several other Lords for High Treason, his Lordship withdrew himself, and the House made these Orders following.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rodd attending this House, do forthwith take the Lord Peter into his Custody, and carry him in safety to the Tower of London for Treason, wherewith he is charged, there to remain till he shall be discharged by due course of Law, and this to be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Constable of His Majesties Tower of London or his Deputy do receive the Body of the Lord Peter, for Treason, wherewith he is charged, and keep him in safe Custody within the said Tower till he shall be discharged by
due course of Law, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
Ordered that this House do sit this Afternoon, and the House be put into a Committee, to consider what advice is fit to be given His Majesty, for the better preservation of his Person.

Ordered that on Munday next, this House will take into consideration the way according to the course of Parliament, of arresting and restraning a Peer of the Realm, sitting the Parliament and of taking Examinations against him in cases of High Treason, and of the procedings to be had against such Peer.

div.head: Die Sabbati 26 Octobris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p: ORdered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Persons who have seized, and given to this House an account of some of the Papers of James Thompson, be and are hereby authorized and required to take a File of Musketeers with them, and sieze and carry to the Lord Bishop of London such Books and Printed Papers as are in the House or Chambers of • he said James Thompson, to be disposed of as his Lordship shall think fit. And that they likewise seal up such Trunks as are in the said James Thompsons Study or Chambers, and bring them to this House, and that such Persons as pretend to have any concern therein, may be present with the Clerk of the Parliament at the opening thereof, and examine the Papers in any of them contained.

The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure to consider what advice is fit to be given His Majesty for the better preservation of his Person. The House was resumed, the Earl of Bridgewater reported shortly the Heads which were proposed in the Committee, to which the House agreed, and made the ensuing Order.

Ordered that the Duke of Monmouth, Lord Chamberlain of His Majesties Houshold, Earl of Bridgewater, Earl of Clarendon, Earl of Essex, Earl of Bath, Viscount Newport, Lord Bishop of Rochester Lord Mainard, and Lord Butler of Moor Park, or any three of them are hereby appointed a Committee to prepare an Address to be presented to His Majesty,
in order to his taking care for the preservation of His Majesties Person, according to the Heads agreed on in this House, and make report thereof unto this House with all convenient speed.

Lords Committees appointed to go immediatly and examine Mr. Coleman, and such other Prisoners as are now committed to Newgate for Treason, and to use all incouragement to them for further discovery, and make report to the House.
The Lord Treasurer, Earl of Clarendon, Earl of Essex, Earl of Shaftesbury, and Lord Bishop of London, or any three of them.
The Committee for inspection of the Papers and Letters are to meet on Monday Morning at Nine of the Clock.

div.head: Die Lunae 28. Octobris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Chancellor acquainted the House, that His Majesty having been attended with the Address of both Houses, for the removal of all Papists from the Cities of London and Westminster, His Majesty is pleased to give this gracious Answer, that he will give order speedily for issuing out a Proclamation as is desired, and will take care that the Lieutenancy for the Militias shall have Orders to be ready accordingly.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir John Knight and others, who brought a Bill entituled an Act for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament; to which the Commons desire their Lordships concurrence.

The Duke of Monmouth reported, that the Committee for drawing up an Address to His Majesty, as the humble Advice of this House to His Majesty for the better preservation of his Person, have prepared a draught for that purpose, which being read was agreed to with an Addition.
The said Address followeth.

We your Majesties most Dutiful and Loyal Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, considering the dangers your Majesties Royal Person is daily exposed to by the great resort to your Pallace and the Parts adjoyning, where you are pleased to entertain your self, of persons
heretofore not admitted to that liberty. And reflecting upon the wicked Conspiracies and Villanous Designs of the Papists lately discovered, do in most humble manner beseech your Majesty to give Effectual Orders, that the following points within and without your Royal Pallace may, for the preservation of your Sacred Person be duly and exactly observed.
That all possible care be taken to hinder all Papists from coming to Court, excepting only the Menial Servants of the Queen and Dutchess, allowed by the Articles of Marriage.

2. That the like care be taken that all such as are imployed in your Majesties Guards do receive the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, and take the Oathes and Test enjoyned by Law: And that a Reward be offered in such manner as your Majesty shall think fit, to those who shall discover any who having taken the Sacrament and Oathes aforesaid, have since turned or hereafter shall turn Papists or hear Mass.
3. The like care to be taken that no Papist be imployed in the preservation of your Majesties Diet, of any kind whatsoever.

4. The like care to be taken concerning the numerous resort of your Majesties Subjects to the Chappel of Sommerset house, and to the Chappels of Ambassadors and Forraign Ministers, and that the Chappel at St. James's, lately used for Mass, being so separated from your Majesties Pallace there, as that access to it cannot be prejudicial to your said Pallace, may be used for the ease of the Parish of St. Martins in the Fields, for the Service of God, by the use of the Liturgy of the Church of England, and Preaching there.

5. And because there is usually a great concourse of mean and unwarranted people, frequenting your Majesties privy Galleries, and privy Lodgings and Rooms adjacent; That your Majesty be pleased to cause a severe restraint to be made thereof, and none admitted there but such as your Majesty shall be pleased to qualifie thereunto, and in order thereunto, to cause the Officers of your Houshold to wait in their proper stations; that the Locks of the doors of your Majesties Palace be changed, the Keys delivered to none but such only as shall be given them by the Lord Chamberlain, according to a List Signed by your Majesty. That all persons forbidden as aforesaid, be made to abstain from following your Majesty in St. James's Park, and that all the private Doors there, be walled up.

And generally that the Rules and Orders of the Houshold, established by your Majesties Royal Father of Blessed Memory,
be strictly observed, or with such variations as your Majesty in your great Wisdom shall be pleased to think fit.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with the white Staves, and the Lords Committees, who prepared the Address of advice for the preservation of His Majesties person, do attend His Majesty from this House for presenting thereof.
Ordered that the Lord Chief Justice of the Kings-Bench, is appointed to go with the Lords that are appointed to examine the Prisoners in Newgate, to assist them in the said Examinations.

The House being informed, that there is some Timber ahd other Materials laid up in some Room or Celler under part of the Court of Requests, which may be of dangerous consequence. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord great Chamberlain of England, to take special care that the said Timber and other Materials, be forthwith removed, and that for the future, no Timber, Fire-wood, Coals or any other Goods, be lodged and kept in any of the Rooms or Cellars under any part of the House of Peers, nor in any of the Rooms or Cellars under or adjoyning to the Princes Lodgings, the Painted Chamber or the Court of Requests.

Whereas Divers Books and Papers belonging ro James Thompson now Prisoner in the Gate-house, have been seized and carried to the Lord Bishop of London's House. It is this day Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Bishop of London, do cause all such of the said Books as are Popish Books, and ought not to be uttered here, to be publickly burned at the Old Exchange in London, between the Houres of Twelve and One of the Clock of such a Day as his Lordship shall appoint. And that the Sheriffs of London and Middlesex, do take care to provide such Guards as that there may be no disturbance at the burning of the said Books.
It appearing to this House that William Sorocoale hath don very good service to His Majesty and this House, in seizing James Thompson and his Papers and Popish Books.

It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord High Treasurer of England, to represent the said W • llam Sorocoales said service to His Majesty, that he may be rewarded as His Majesty shall think fit.

Ordered that the Considerations of the present Dangers the Kings Majesty and the Kingdom is in, and how to present the same be proceeded in, to morrow Morning the first business and nothing to Interveen.
Ordered that the Lords appointed to Examine the Prisoners now in Newgate for Treason, do make Report to this House of what they have don therein to morrow Morning.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that this House will take into Consideration, the way according to the Course of Parliament, of Aresting and Restraning a Peer of this Realm sitting the Parliament; and of taking Examinations against him in cases of High Treason; And of the proceedings to be had against such a Peer, on Munday the 4th, Day of November.

div.head: Die Martis 29. Octobris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Treasurer Reported, that he and the rest of the Lords Committees have been twice at Newgate to Examin the Prisoners, and gave the the House an account thereof, the Examinations were read as followeth.

According to your Lordships Directions, we went yesterday in the Evening to Examin some of the Prisoners that are in Newgate for High Treason, in plotting and contriving the Death of His Majesty. Namely Thomas Jeninson, Edward Petre and William Ireland, who were one after another brought before us. And they do all obstinately deny their knowledg of any such Plot or Design, and would not make the least Confession of any thing Relating to it. Although according to the Authority we had, we promised not only a Pardon, but likewise a Reward to him that sh • uld Confess in Truth.

When Edward Petre was before us, we shewed him the Letter Directed to William Timstall, warning him to be at the Congregation in London the 24th. of April last, which he owned to be his hand writing, but as to the Design of the said meeting, he denies that he knows of any other then that of Choosing an Officer to send abroad.

To William Ireland likewise we shewed some Letters and Papers (found among those that were seized) which he owns to be his hand, but denies that which was sent to Winsor to Mr.
• ennyfield, which he said was forged.

When we had done with these three Prisoners, we sent for Mr. Edward Coleman, who being brought before us; We put him in mind that when the day before, when he was charged by us for forged pretended letters in the Name of His Royal Highness, he then told us that if any such Letters were that they were not forged, we therefore now shewed him a draught of a Letter to be sent to Father Oliva, which he owned to be his hand and saith that it was from her Royal Highness the Dutchess, and that he prepared it by her Order.

We then shewed him a Letter drawn as from His Royal Highness to father Le-Chese; which he likewise owned to be his hand, and that he shewed it to His Royall Highness. But that His Royal Highness rejected it, and he confest he had no Order from His Royal Highness to prepare it, but that he did it upon his own head.

Being asked whether he delivered a Letter to His Royal Highness from father Ferrier, he said Sir. William Trockmorton brought it, and he said he is sure he delivered one Letter from Ferrier to His Royal Highness, and saith His Royal Highness was acquainted with his Correspondence with Ferrier and S. Germain, not perhaps with every letter but in general.

He denied that ever he had any Correspondence with father Le-Chese, but by St. Germain, but he was convinced to the contrary when a Letter from Le Chese to him was produced, acknowledging the receipt of his long letter of the 29th of September 1674.

Being asked of his going over to Brussels, he confest he was sent thither by His Royal Highness upon father Patricks coming over from the Inter-Nuntio there with an imperfect story, and that from that time the Correspondence was carried on all along, he said the L. Arundel of Warder knew of his going, and that His Royal Highness was acquainted with the summ and substance of the Correspondence with the Inter-Nuntio.

After this we likewise offered him (as we were directed) that he should be pardoned and rewarded if he would discover it, by making a Franck Confession of what he knew. And to induce him to it, we told him that without any further Confession there was enough in his Papers for the Law to take away his life, but we could not make him own the knowledg of any thing further, but that he had been Guilty of a great many follies.

Whereupon it was asked him what made him desire to speak with His Majesty and His Royal Highness, when we sent for him the day before. To which he answered, that it was to
know how he should Govern himself, as to naming the Duke.

Mr. Coleman being likewise asked on Sunday, why he had taken such liberty of speaking of the Kings Ministers, and Reproaching some of them with breach of faith, and promises with his Royal Highness in Order to any of those ends which he expected should be promised by them, and whether he knew or had heard of any such thing concerning them or any of them, whom he had mentioned in his said Letters, he answered he had not, but had been foolish in that as well as in other things in delivering his own Opinion, and that he had no other ground for it.

We further observe to your Lordships, that neither William Ireland, nor Thomas Jennison (who were examined yesterday) nor Smith, whom we examined last Sunday, will own any knowledg of the Congregation of the 24th. of April last, only Edward Petre, upon whom the knowledg of it was proved by his own letter to William Tunstal.
After Debate this Question was proposed.
Whether these Papers should be Communicated to the House of Commons presently at a Conference in Order to the joint advice of both Houses.
Then this previous question was put, whether this question shall be put, it was Resolved in the Negative.
These Lords following desired leave to enter their Dissents if the question was carried in the Negative, and accordingly entred their Dissent.
(Essex)
(Shaftesbury)
Hodie prima vice licitá est Billa, An Act for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The Duke of Monmouth gave the House this account, that he and the rest of the Lords have presented the Address yesterday to His Majesty, who takes it very kindly from their Lordships. And His Majesty said he had don most of the things already, the rest he will do what shall be convenient.

The House being informed, that the Lord Bellasis now a Prisoner in the Prison of the Kings Bench by warrant of the Lord Chief Justice of England for Treason, is so ill that he cannot without danger be removed. It is Ordered by the Lords
Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Sir Charl's Scarborough be and is hereby appointed to go and visit the said Lord Bellasis, and give this House an account to morrow Morning in what conditioh of health he finds him.
Ordered that the consideration of the present danger the Kings Majesty and the Kingdom are in, and to present the same, be proceeded in to morrow Morning the first business, and nothing to interveen.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that His Majesty be humbly desired from this House, that the Lord Bellasis now Prisoner in the Prison of the Kings Bench by vertue of the Warrant of the Lord Chief Justice of England for Treason, being (as it is informed) so ill that he cannot be removed, may have a Guard set on him there, and that notice be taken of the Names of all such Persons as shall come to visit his Lordship there.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that His Majesty be humbly moved from this House, that Collonel Roper and such other Officers as are sent to be Prisoners in the Prison of the Kings-Bench by Warrant of the Lord Chief Justice of England for Treason, be forthwith removed to be Prisoners in His Majesties Tower of London.

div.head: Die Mercurii 30. Octobris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Bishop of Rochester Reported from the Committee appointed to inquire into the Horrid Design against His Majesty, that their Lordships are unsatisfied with the delivery of some papers to Mr. Colcman, by one Captain Berkeley which were not read at Councel, who was examined at the Committee and now attends at the Door.

His Lordship Reported farther, that the Lord Annesley Eldest Son to the E. of Anglesey Lord Privy Seal informed the Committee, that Titus Oats told him he could say something to the House towards the Clearing of His Royal Highness the Duke of York, from the Aspertions which were cast on him, and that Titus Oats is attending in the Lord Chancellors Room.

Upon which Captain Berkley being called in, gave an account to the House, that he delivered those papers to the Duke of Monmouth, and receiving them again from the Duke of
Monmouth, did give them to Mr. Coleman, pleading his ignorance of the way he ought to have proceeded in, for which he is very sorry. Upon which (the House satisfied that the Duke of Monmouth did give the said papers to His Majesty, who perused them and returned them to the Duke of Monmouth,) the Lord Chancellor by Command of the House, gave him publick Reprehension for his indiscretion, and so he withdrew.

Then Titus Oats being called in, was sworne at the Bar, and required to answer to what he is now called in for concerning his discourse with the Lord Annesley last Night about the Duke of York, he spake to this effect. That he was informed that Mr. Coleman had highly Impeached the Duke of York by letters; to which he said he thought the Duke was wholy innocent, for these Reasons.

1. Because they have a Counterfeit Seal of his and her Royal Highness, and that he was sent into Spain with Credentials under that Seal, being asked where that Seal is, he said it is in the Custody of Richard Strange the late Provincial of the Jesuites, that the party who signed his Credentials writt James, but he was not then so well acquainted with the Jesuites as to know who it was.

2. Because in February or March last, a proposal was made by the Fathers at Gant, that they wondred the Duke was not acquainted with it, to which, Answer was made because his love was great to the King his Brother, that he would not be true to them though he was a very good Catholick.
3. Because there was a Letter writt to Blundel saying, they longed to see the Duke trappanned into the business.

4. Because there were a parcel of Letters at Windsor to be delivered to His Royal Highness, that he might burn them, thereby to draw the Duke into the Plot. This he said he was not certain of, but Meredith Loyd said they brought them to the Duke for that purpose, and he would bring him hither to Attest it.

5. He said [being askt] that he carried no Letters into Spain signed James by the Duke, but the Credentials he had to Spain with him were signed and sealed in his presence by the Jesuites, James, and the Counterfeit Seal, so that he was received like a kind of Ambassador. both as from the Duke and the Society.
6. Because they have made Officers of State and War without the Dukes Privity.
Then he was commanded to withdraw.

Upon consideration of what Titus Oats had said, he was
called in again and told by the Lord Chancellor, that the House hath directed he shall be heard again, to morrow a Nine of the Clock. And the Lords do expect that by the Oath he hath now taken, he should go through with what he hath to say, and therefore he should prepare himself to deliver the whole truth of what he knows concerning the design against the Kings person, and the Government of this Kingdom.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Nathaniel Thompson who is now in the Custody of William Sorocoal, for Printing Popish Books, for James Thompson shall stand Committed to the Prison of the Gate house at Westminster during the pleasure of this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
Ordered that the Earl of Shaftsbury is added to the Sub Committee, for examining the Murther of Sir Edmond-Bury Godfry.

This day Dr. Scarborough gave the House an account, that he did visit the Lord Bellasis this Morning, and finds him in good health, and that his Lordship is ready to be removed as their Lordships shall think fit.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House that the Lord Viscount de Stafford; And the Lord Bellasis and Colonel Roper and his Son, and Mr. Ratcliff being Prisoners in the Prison of the Kings Bench, by Warrant of the Lord Chief Justice of England for Treason, may be removed to remain Prisoners in His Majestis Tower of London.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees appointed to examin papers relating to the Horrid Design against His Majesty, do proceed this afternoon in reading the papers before them, and so return them to Sir. Philip Loyd to be delivered to the King.

div.head: Die Jovis 31. Octobris 1678.
div.p:
ORdered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House,
that the papers of Mr. White-bread and Mr. Micho, which havè been read at the Còuncel Table may be by His Majesty Commanded, brought before the Committee appointed to examin papers relating to the Horrid Design against His Majesty, and also that the Clerks of the Councel, may bring the Minutes taken by them upon the examination of Titus Oats, and others before the Councel concerning this Matter.
Ordered that the Committee for examining Papers and Letters, do meet to morrow Morning at Nine of the Clock, and finish the reading of them if they can.
The Earl of Essex and the Lord Bishop of London are added to the Sub Committee, for examining concerning the Murther of Sir. Edmond▪Bury Godfry.

Ordered that the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the papers of Mr. Neffo, which by Order of the Lords Committees appointed to examin papers relating to the Discovery of the Horrid Design against the King, were last Night brought into the Custody of the Clerk of the Parliament, shall be peruscd by Sir Edward Carteret Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, and one of the Clerks attending this House (the said Mr. Neffo being present with them) to the end that an account of the said papers may be given to this House.

Titus Oats being appointed to attend the House this Day, to give an account of what he knows concerning the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and the Government; was called in, who at the Bar made a long Narrative of it. In which a long time being spent and he wearied, humbly desired leave (there being much behind) that he might retire to refresh himself, upon which he had leave to withdraw. And it was Ordered that he shall be heard, what he hath further to say in the Afternoon.

div.head: Die Jovis 31. Octobris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p: TItus Oates being at the Bar, is directed to proceed in giving an account of the Commission given to several Lords and o • her Persons, for Officers Civil and Military.

Upon which he proceeded in a particular Narrative thereof with some Circumstances, tending to make out the truth
thereof, and then was Commanded to withdraw, but stay without.

Then upon Consideration had hereof the Lord Chancellor, by directions of the House Caused him to be called in again, and told him that the Lords expect not his entring into particular Circumstances, but if there be particular Persons concerned of what quality soever they be, the House expected he should name them, but he named none, but those he had mentioned in his Narrative, nor could name no other Person.
Then being commanded to withdraw he humbly desired he might have a Guard, in regard it is late and dark and that he goeth in Danger, and so withdrew.

Upon Consideration had whereof and of his present Condition in White-hall, he was called in again and told by the Lord Chancellor, that the House takes very well what he hath done; And to the end he may be freed from those Persons, who may come to discourse with him purposely to undermine, so as to invalid his Testimony concerning this business, he is to defend himself with this answer. That he is under the command of this House, not to discourse with any Persons concerning this Matter, and is further told that the house hath recommended to the Duke of Monmouth to take care of the safety of his Person, and to the Lord Chamber-lain of His Majesties house-hold for better accommodation of Lodgings, and to the Lord High Treasurer of England, for supplying him with necessaries.
Upon which giving the House his humble thanks, he withdrew.
Ordered that this House will proceed to debate and consider, what is fit to be done for the further preservation of His Majesties Person, the first business to morrow Morning.

Mary White upon Oath deposed at the Bar, that about Christmas last she did hear Richard Langhorne say, that if one thing did hit, his father would be the third Man in the Kingdom, hereupon the house made this Order.

Upon Oath made at the Bar, that Richard Langhorne Son to Mr. Langhorne now Prisoner in New gaete, hath uttered dangerous words, It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Sir. Edward Carteret Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House or his Deputy, do forthwith Attach the Body of the said Richard Langhorne, and bring him in safe Custody to the Bar of this house, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with the white Staves do wait on His Majesty from this House humbly to desire His Majesty, that Sir. William Goreing and Sir. John Gage now Prisoners in the Prison of the Kings Bench for Treason, may be removed to remain Prisoners in His Majesties Tower of London. And that the Lord Arundel of Warder and the said Sir. William Goreing and Sir John Gage may by His Majesties Order be kept close Prisoners there, and not suffered to come each at the other, and not to be suffered to have either Pen, Ink or Paper, till further Order.

Whereas, William Lord Peter stands committed by this House to the Tower of London for Treason, wherewith he is charged. It is this day Ord • red by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Constable of the said Tower, his deputy or deputies do take care that the said Lord Petre be kept close Prisoner and not suffered to come to the other Prisoners, nor to have the use of Pen, Ink or Paper, till further Order.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Sergeant at Arms attending this House, his Deputy or Deputies do forthwith attach the Bodies of Mr, Preston in Duke-street School-master, and the School-master in Warwick-street, William Smith the School-master of Islington, Mr. Webster a School-master, Mr. More a Book-seller in Duke street, and his brother a Book-seller in Holborn, and Seize all such Popish Books as are in the Custody of the said More or his Brother, and bring the said Persons in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, to answer all such matters as shall be objected against them, on his Majesties behalf, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Constable who hath seized a Trunck and Papers out of the hands of Mrs. Thompson, Wife of James Thompson now Prisoner in the Gate house, be and is hereby required to bring and deliver the said Trunck into the Custody of the Clerk of the Parliament, and for so doing this shall be his Warrant and Discharge.

div.head: Die Veneris Primo Novembris 1678.
div.p: ORdered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that all the Muster Masters of the several Regiments of His Majesties Guards, be and are hereby required to attend the Lords Committees appointed to enquire into the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person, to morrow at eight of the Clock in the forenoon in the Princes Lodgings neer the House of Peers.

The Lord Bishop of Rochester Reported, that it is the Opinion of the Lords Committees for examination and inspection of the Letters and Papers concerning the Horrid design against His Majesties Person, that it is fit that Mrs. Saunders in Wilde-street and the Master of the White-horse Tavern in the Strand, be Examined by the Lord Chief Justice of England, concerning the meeting of the Jesuites at their Houses in April or May last, hereupon it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Chief Justice of England, be and is hereby desired to send for Mrs. Saunders in Wilde-street and the Master of the White-horse Tavern in the Strand, and Examin them as to any meetings or convents of Jesuites or other Persons whatsoever, at their or either of their Houses in April or May last, or before or since, and of any other matter relating to the Horrid design against His Majesties Person and His Kingdom, and to give an account thereof to this House.

The Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House, acquainted thi • House that he was informed, that on Wednesday Night last there was heard great Knocking & Digging in the Earth in some Cellars neer adjoyning to this House, which disquieted many of the Inhabitants in the Old Pallace, whereupon these Lords following are appointed a Committee, to Examin the persons, who heard a Noise of Knocking and Digging Earth on Wednesday Night last between Twelve and Three of the Clock neer this House, and their Lordships are to desire Sir. Thomas Chichl • y to appoint some persons skilful in mining to watch and use their utmost endeavor to make a discovery thereof, and Report to the House.

Richard Langhorne (who was sent for last Night in Custody) being brought to the Bar is asked, what he meant by these Words (if one thing hit his Father would be the third Man in the Kingdom) And whether he knew Mary White, who had sworne she heard him speake these Words, he denyed that he
spake such Words, or that he knowes Mary White.
Then the said Mary White being called for and not attending, he is Ordered to withdraw and she to be sent for.

Next Mark Preston, Mr. Smith, Dennis Glisson, Mr. More and Mathew Turner (who were sent for in Custody) Being brought to the Bar, Titus Oates is called in & asked, what he had to say to the Persons at the Bar, who looking on Marke Preston said, he was a Romish Priest, and being asked how he knew it, he said he had been at Confession with the said Marke at Wilde-house, and that he had Confessed to the said Marke Preston as a Priest. All which the said Mark Preston denied, alleadging he is a Married Man and hath Children, and is no Priest, and being asked when and where he was Married, he said he was Married abovt 11 Years since in Mr. Langhorns Chamber in the Temple by a Priest, who went by the Name, of Mr. Le feare, upon which Richard Langhorne being called in, is asked if he knowes Marke Preston (at the Bar) who said he knows him, and had known him several Years, and that he had been his Tutor.

Then Titut Oates looking on Mr. Smith, said he knew him not, but had heard by a Gentleman [Mr. Kirby] of the Guards that Mr. Smith had spoken very unseemly Words against the Kings Person, which words Smith wholly denied to have spoken.

Next Titus Oates said of Dennit Glisson that he heard by Dr. Tongue that the said Glisson being a School-master did instil ill Principles into Children, and that he said there is no Learning in Cambridg and nothing but Debauchery in Oxford, Glisson denied any such Words, and he is a Protestant and hath a Licence from the Lord Bishop of Londons Chancellor to be School-master, which he produced.

After this Titus Oates Charged Mr. More (at the Bar) to be a seller of Popish Books, and that he had told him (the said Oates) in August last, that he had Five Hundred Pound Worth of Popish Bookes in Sommerset-House, to which Mr. More said he had been imprisoned in the Gate-house already, for that fault of selling Popish Bookes, Oates said More sold him one of Godwins Bookes against Dr. Stllingfleet, and told him he had Four hundred of them.

Titus Oates also Charged Mathew Turner with saying to him the said Oates that upon a search made for Popish Bookes, he and his Brother Mt. More had been too nimble for the Searchers. And the House being Informed, that there was a Trunck of Books found in a House of Office at Turner's House, he is
asked what they were, and he said they were Welsh Bookes of Popish Devotion.
Then the said persons being all Commanded to withdraw, the House made these Orders following.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mark Preston who was this day brought to the Bar by the Sergeant at Armes attending this House and Charged with Treason, be forthwith carried to New-gate, there to remaine in safe Custody till he shall be discharged by due course of Law, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. Smith who was brought to the Bar to answer such matters as should be Objected to him on His Majesties behalf, shall be and remaine in the Custody of the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House till further Order be given concerning him.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled▪ that the Persons who have seized a Trunck of Bookes at the House of Mr. Turner a Booke-seller in Holhorne (which the House are Informed are Popish Bookes) do forthwith carry the said Trunck of Bookes to the House of the Lord Bishop of London, to be disposed of as his Lordship shall direct.

Then Titus Oates and Richard Langhorne being called in, Langhorne denied that he knew Titus Oates, who to convince Langhorne of the contrary, told him, that he brought Letters in November 1677 to his Father from his Sons in Spaine, and that this Richard Langhorne told him when he Knockt at the Door with the said Letters, that his Father was at Dinner and Desired him to Meet his Father at his Chamber at Night.

Oates said further that this Richard Langhorne Received a Commission from his Father Mr. Langhorne in Oates his presence to be carried to the Lord Arundel of Warder, that Richard Langhorne did put it in his Pocket, but whether he delivered it or no, Oates knowes not.
Then Langhorn being asked whether his Father did draw any Writings for the said Lord Arundel, he said he did not know of any.

Upon which they being withdrawne, it was Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Richard Langhorne now in the Custody of the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House, shall be by him Conveyed to the Prison of Newgate, the • e • o remaine a Prisoner
for Treason, wherewith he is charged until he shall be discharged by due course of Law, and that the Keeper of Newgate take care that the said Richard Langhorne be not permitted to come at his Father now a Prisoner there, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

Upon reading the Petition of Bridget Lady Petre wife of William Lord Petre now Prisoner in the Tower, taking notice of the restraint put upon his Lordship by this House, and praying that she may be admitted to be with her Husband in such manner as this House shall think fit. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Lady Petre may be admitted to come to the said Lord Petre if she think fit, provided she remaine with his Lordship under the same confinement he now is Ordered until further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

div.head: Die Veneris Primo Novembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p: A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir. Henry Capel and others, to desire a conference touching matters of high concernment, Relating to the preservation of His Majesties person, the safety of the Government, and the Protestant Religion.
The answer returned was that this House agrees to a conference, and appoints the same to be presently in the painted Chamber.
The Commons being come. The House was adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords went to the conference, which being ended, the House was resumed.

The Lord Chancellor Reported the effect of this conference, which was managed by Sir. Robert Sawyer, who said that the House of Commons, after examinations of several persons and papers, many of which papers His Majesty did acquaint the House of Commons with, and had been communicated to your Lordships and Deliberate consideration had hereupon, came to this Unanimous Resolution.

That upon the Evidence, that has already appeared to
this House, that this House is of opinion there hath been and still is a damnable and hellish Plot contrived and carried on by the Popish Recusants for the Assassinating and Murthering the King, and for subverting the Government, and rooting out and destroying the Protestant Religion.

The House of Commons being very sensible of imminent danger both of the King and Kingdom are in, do think it their duty to acquaint your Lordships therewith, and do pray your Lordships will be pleased to take it into your serious and speedy consideration, what remedies are fit and suitable to be applyed for preserving the Kings Person and preventing the alteration of Religion and Government; to which the Commons shall readily concurr •• they doubt not of your Lordships concurrence, to such remedies as have or shall be by them proposed to your Lordships for the effecting of this great end.
Ordered, that this House agrees with the House of Commons in this Vote nemine contradicente.
Ordered, to have a conference with the House of Commons to acquaint them with the concurrence of this House, and the sense of this House thereupon as followeth.

The Lords have considered the Vote of the House of Commons communicated to them at the conference, and have most readily and unanimously concurred with them nemine contradicente: And their Lordships are very glad to see that zeal which the House of Commons have shewed upon this occasion, and do fully concurr with them that the most speedy and most serious consideration of both Houses are necessary for the prevention of the imminent dangers.

In order whereunto their Lordships have resolved to sit de die in die both Forenoon and Afternoon, and desire that the Commons would do so too, and when their Lordships shall have well considered of full and proper remedies for those dangers, they will be ready to communicate them to the House of Commons, and will also take in good part what ever shall be communicated to them by the House of Commons, and will suffer nothing to be wanting on their parts which may preserve a good understanding between both Houses, which is absolutely necessary to the safety of the King and Kingdom.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Edward Low, and Sir John Francklyn, to desire a present conference with the House of Commons in the Painted Chamber upon the subject matter of the last conference.
The Messengers return with this answer, that the House of Commons agree to give their Lordships a present conference in the Painted Chamb • r.

The House was adjourned during pleasure and the Lords went to the conference, which being ended, the House was resumed, and the Lord Chancellor gave the House this account. That he had delivered at the conference what he was directed, at which there was a very great expression of joy.

div.head: Die Sabbati Secundo Novembris 1678.
div.p: ORdered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the four Clerks and all other Servants belonging to Mr. Edward Coleman, be and are hereby required to appear before the Lords Committees appointed to examine the horrid design against His Majesties Person on Monday next at Eight of the Clock in the Forenoon in the Princes Lodgings near the House of Peers.

Ordered that the Lords Committees who were appointed to examine Mr. Coleman and other Prisoners in Newgate for Treason, be and are hereby appointed to go to the Tower and examine the Lords who are Prisoners there for Treason.

The L. C. Justice reported, that according to the Order directed to him he hath sent for and examined Mrs. Saunders, who saith she hath kept the house Five or Six Years, and that Whitebread and Micho are there, she knows no other, she hath heard of Fenwick, and she hath seen Oates in the Spring of the year come to Whitebread, but is obstinate, and will confess nothing more then what your Lordships knew before.
That the Master of the White▪horse Tavern in the Strand is dead, and his Wife is Married again to one that is no Vintner, and they are gone from thence.
That he hath heard of a Drawer in that Tavern who is a Papist, and his Lordship will send for him and examine him.

The Earl of Essex Reported from the Committee to inquire after the noise of digging in the night, that upon the report of Sir Christopher Wren and Sir Jonas Moor, that the Vaults and Cellars under and near this House are of such a nature that there can be no assurance of safety, and the only remedy at present is that the Cellars of the Houses near this House and the Court of Requests, may be cleared and a passage made out of one into the other, so that Soldiers and Sentinels
may walk day and night there and have a trusty Officer over them.
Hereupon the House made this ensuing order.

Upon report made by the Earl of Essex from the Lords Committees appointed to inquire into the insecurity of this House, by reason of the Vaults and Cellars under and near it of what hath been offered to them for the better securing of the sitting of the Parliament.

It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that all the Cellars and Vaults under and near adjoyning to the House of Peers Painted Chamber, and Court of Requests be forthwith cleared, and that all Timber, Firewood, Coals and other Materials of what kind soever be removed out of the said Cellars and Vaults, and that passages be forthwith made through all the said Cellars and Vaults to the end that Soldiers and Sentinels with trusty Officers over them, may continually night and day walk to and fro and watch in the said Cellars and Vaults till further Order, and that Mrs. Dehaure who liveth in a Brick-house in the Old Palace-yard, adjoyning to the Court of Requests, be and is hereby required forthwith to quit her habitation in the said House, to the end that a Guard may be kept therein till further Order, and it is further Ordered, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord great Chamberlain of England, or in his absence to the Surveyor General of His Majesties Works, to take special care that the said Cellars and Vaults and the house in which the said Mrs. Dehaure liveth be speedily cleared, and that the said passages be made in the said Cellars and Vaults for the purposes aforesaid.

Commissary John Baynes being sworn gave the House this account that he knows not of any Soldier in the three Troops of Horse Guards, who have not taken the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and received the Sacrament according to the usage of the Church of England. And Commissary David Crawford upon Oath said, that all the Officers of Foot in the Guards have taken the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance and test, but they had no orders concerning private Soldiers.

They both said that some Popish Officers are cashiered who have not taken the Oaths, and that they cannot give any account of any others come into the places of the Popish Officers that are removed till the next Muster.
They gave in the names of several under Muster-masters who are not in Town but residing at their several charges.

div.head: Die Lunae Quarto Novembris 1678.
div.p: UPon reading the Petition of Lievtenant William Sorocoal shewing that he and his Family are in danger of their Lives, by means and assaults made on his Wife and Servant, for the service he hath done in apprehending several persons by Order of this House, and praying the direction of this House for his safety. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said William Sorocoale and such other persons as have been Sworne at the Bar to testify concerning this matter, shall be examined by the Lords Committees appointed, to examine the horrid design against His Majesty, and their Lordships are to make Report thereof unto this House.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees appointed to examine the Lords who are Prisoners in the Tower for Treason, shall also examine such other persons as their Lordships shall think fit, who are now Prisoners in the Tower for Treason, and also Sir. Ellis Leighton now Prisoner in Newgate, and that the Lord Chief Justice of England do assist their Lordships at such times as their Lordships shall appoint, and that one of the Clerks of His Majesties Privy Councel is to attend their Lordships in this Business.

div.head: Die Lunae Quarto Novembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p:
THis House being moved, that the Lord Arundel of Warder now close Prisoner in the Tower of London, being a material witness in a cause, wherein the Duke of Norfolke, the Earl of Peterborough and the Lord Mowbray are concerned may be examined in perpetuam rei memoriam. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that notwithstanding the restraint under which the said Lord Arundel now is, one Master of the Court of Chancery, and two Examiners of the Court of Chancery, be and are hereby Authorized to Repair to the Lord Arundel of Warder
in the Tower ro administer the Oath, upon which his Lordship is to be examined and to examine and cross examine the Lord Arundel, on the behalf of both parties in the said Cause, upon such Interrogatories as shall be prepared for that purpose, but not to discourse with the said Lord Arundel upon any other business whatsoever, and for their so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

Upon Report made by the Lord Bishop of London, that William Smith now in the Custody of the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, having by Order of this House attended his Lordship, and there proposed the bringing of a Person before this House, who can discover much of the Jesuites Lands and Money, and that the said William Smith is a Protestant and Poor, and that his Licences to teach a School is revoked, and that if he may have his liberty is not in a Capacity to do harm.

It is Ordered, that the said William Smith have liberty to find out and bring the said discovery before the Lords Committees appointed to examine papers concerning the Horrid Design against His Majesties person, on Wednesday next at Eight of the Clock in the Forenoon in the Princes Lodgings near the House of Peers, and that he giving security to be of good behaviour be discharged from any further restraint, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered. by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that His Majesties Atturney General give this House an account of the reason of the penning of the Proclamation, for Banishing of Papists from London and Westminster as it is now penned, on Wednesday the sixt day of this Instant November at ten of the clock in the Forenoon.

Upon complaint made to this House, that Lieutenant William Sorocoale hath placed Guards of Soldiers and seized goods of some persons without any Order or Authority, for that purpose. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said William Sorocoale presume not hence forward to sieze any persons Goods, or set Guards on any persons House, without the Order of this House or of the Lord Chief Justice of England, or some other Justice of peace as he will answer the contrary to this House.

Upon information given to this House that there is a Trunck of papers siezed or secured at a Coffee-mans house in Swan Yard over against Somerset house by Dr. Chamberlaine, which may have papers of dangerous consequence in it▪ it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament
Assembled, that the said Trunck be forthwith brought before the Lords Committees appointed, t • exam 〈…〉 witnesses concerning the Murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey
•• be by their Lordships perused and an account given thereof to the House.

Upon reading the petition of Mathew Turner Book-seller, shewing that being brought before 〈…〉 use, and upon examination discharged, Lieutenant William Sorocoale continueth Guards upon his house, which he humbly prayeth may be discharged. It is thereupon Ordered th 〈…〉 Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that i • there yet remain any such Books at the said Matthew Turners house as ought to be siezed, they be forthwith carried to the Lord Bishop of London to be disposed of •• hi • Lordship shall direct, and that the Guard commanded by Lieutenant William Sorocoale now at the house of the said Matthew Turner, be forthwith removed as the said William Sorocoale will answer the contrary to this House.

Ordered. by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the L. Chamberlain to the Queens Majesty, do cause a List to be made of such Servants belonging to Her Majesty as are Papists, and to be brought into the House of Peers, on Wednesday the sixt of this instant November at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon

Ordered▪ by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Major of the City of
• o • d • n, do cause a List to be made of all such Foraign Merchants, Traders in London as are Papists, and send the said List to the House of Peers, by Wednesday the sixt of this instant November at ten in the Forenoon.

Ordered, that a List be prepared, and made of such Servants belonging to Her R • yal H • g • ness of York as are Papists, and to be sent into the House of Peers on Wednesday the sixt of this instant November by ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.
Ordered, that this House be put into a Committee presently to consider of such proposals, as shall be Offered for the preservation of His Majesties person, and the safety of the Kingdom.

And accordingly the House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure, the House being resumed, the Earl of Bridge waeter Reported that the House had considered of some heads of proposals in Order to an address to be presented to His Majesty, and the Committee desired, that the House would give leave, that the House may be put into a
Committee again on Wednesday Morning next, to consider of more proposals which the House agreed to, and Ordered the same accordingly.
Three proposals were read and agreed to but to be further perfected.

div.head: Die Mercurii 6. Novembris 1678.
div.p: ORdered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod or his Deputy go and seize the Person of Sir Robert Walsh, with what Papers are about him and also such Papers as are in his Custody, and bring him and them in safe custody to the Bar of this House to answer such things as shall be objected against him, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

This House being informed, that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod hath according to order seized the Person and Papers of Sir Robert Walsh, It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the said Sir Robert Walsh shall remain in the Custody of the Gentleman Usher till further Order, and that he be brought with his Papers before the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Papers concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person, to be Examined by their Lordships to Morrow at Eight of the Clock in the Forenoon, for whose Custody this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do from this House attend His Majesty, humbly to desire that His Majesty would be pleased to give orders, that Guards of Soldiers with trusty Officers over them may be appointed to be and Watch, day and night during the sitting of the Parliament in the Cellars and Vaults under and near the Parliament House, which are fitted for that purpose.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that Mary White who hath formerly appeared at the Bar as a Witness against Richard Langhorn Junior, be and is hereby required to give security before some one of His Majesties Justices of Peace, to be returned into the Court where the said Richard Langhorn shall be brought to Tryal
that she will appear to give Evidence at the Tryal, and also where she shall be found from time to time till after the said Tryal.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that Mrs. Coleman Wife of Edward Coleman now Prisoner in Newgase for Treason, be and is hereby equired to appear before the Lords Committees appointed to examine Papers concerning the horrid design against His Maj • sty to Morrow at Eight of the Clock in the Forenoon in the Princes lodgings near the House of Peers.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Keeper of the Prison of Newgate, be and is hereby required to bring the body of Richard Langhorn Junior (now a Prisoner in his custody) to the Bar of the House of Peers, to Morrow at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, and for so doing this shall be his sufficient Warrant.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that Mrs. Langhorn Wife of Mr. Langhorn now Prisoner in Newgate, Mary Plunner and Mary White, be and are hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House to Morrow at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

This House being moved that some notice may be taken of the translation of the Proclamation, for Banishing Papists from London and Westminster, published in the French Gazett, in which it differeth from the Proclamation published in the English Gazett: It is ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that it be and is hereby referred to the Lords Committees appointed to examine Papers relating to the horrid design against His Majesties Person to consider thereof, and send for and examine the Translator and Licencer thereof and make report unto the House.
