Master Attorney General being advised with about the Proclamation for the removal of Papists from the Cities of London and Westminster, the Lords were satisfied that the said Proclamation, was according to the Address of both Houses of Parliament, and the Directions which he received from His Majesty.

The House being moved, that the granting of Licences by the Lords of the Council to Persons to stay in Town might be explained, it was proposed, that Persons not being Traders and Forreign Merchants, Traders and such Persons as the Lords of the Council shall for prudential reasons grant Licenses to, to stay in Town, should not have the Oathes mentioned in the Proclamation, for Banishing Papists from London and Westminster, &c. tendred to them which was ordered accordingly.
And that the Commissions to be issued to the Justices of the peace for tendering the said Oaths be limited to that purpose.

Then the House declared, that all Peers, Peers Widows (who have not since Married to Commons) and the Wives of Peers ought to enjoy the Priviledge of Parliament, and not to be comprehended within the penalties enjoyned by the Proclamation, for Banishing Papists from London and Westminster.
Pursuant to which last Declaration, the House being moved on the behalf of the Marchioness Dowager of Worcester, the ensuing Declaration was granted to her.

The Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, do declare that Margaret Marchioness Dowager of Worcester, as she is a Peeress of this Realm ought to enjoy priviledge of Parliament, and not to be comprehended within the penalties enjoyned by the Proclamation, for Banishing Papists fron London and Westminster▪

p.hi: The House further Ordered, that no Licences be granted to Papists to come into the Kings presence or Court.

div.p: The House being moved that some Boys belonging to the Charterhouse in London, may be examined in order to the further discovery of the horrid design against His Majesties Person, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that it be and is hereby referred to the Lords Committees appointed to examine Papers concerning that matter, to send for and examine such Boys and other Persons from the Charterhouse, and elsewhere as their Lordships shall think fit, and make Report thereof unto the House.

div.head: Die Jovis Septimo Novembris 1678.
div.p: The Lord Bishop of Bath and Wells Reported, that the Committee for Examination of Papers concerning the hortid design against His Majesties Person, have Examined Jerome Boateman Servant to Edward Coleman now a Prisoner in Newgate, concerning two Letters which have been supprest directed to Mr. Coleman, which two Letters the said Jerome Boateman confesses he received, and delivered them into the hands of Mrs. Coleman, who sayes she does not remember that any Letters were delivered to her.
His Lordship further reported, that the Committee further desires one Whitehall may have his Oath given him in order to his examination concerning M. Coleman, which was presently done.

Lieutenant Sorocoale gave the House an account, that he hath apprehended one
• ohn Blundel, by Warrant of a Justice of Peace upon a suspition of Firing Lyme-house, the House gave directions
that the said Blundel should be brought to the Bar, and at the same time Mr. Titus Oates should be present, to know whether he knows him to be that Blundel the Romish Priest which he mentioned in his Narrative.

Next Richard Langhorn the younger was brought to the Bar, and Mary White was produced as a Witness against him, who being asked whether she did know the said Richard Langhorn, and what she had to say concerning him, she answered that she did know the said Richard Langhorn, and she did hear the said Langhorn say he did not doubt, but if one thing hit, his Father would be the third Man in the Kingdom.
Langhorn confessed he knew the said Mary White but denyed he spake any such words, and said, why should he say any thing to her who was an Enemy to Catholicks.

Then Mary Plunner upon her Oath said, that she was told by Mrs. Langhorn (Mother to the said Richard Langhorn) that she went lately to her Sons Chamber, and found him very jovial, whereupon she asked him how he could be mer • y seeing there was a Warrant against him, upon the account of bringing the Commission to his Father to be Judge Advocate, he replyed he did not fear, nor would he fly, at which Mrs. Langhorn said none but a Prince could make Generals. To which he said let them bring it to that.
Then Mrs Langhorn said she was at her Son Richard Langhorns Chamber, and he said to her those words as Mary Plunner hath deposed.

The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure to consider the Bill for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disab • ing Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament, the House was resumed.

Then John Blundel was called in, and Titus Oates was asked whether he knows the said John Blundel, and whether he be not that person he mentions to be the Romish Priest in his Relation, he answers he doth not know this Person, and he who he mentions is Nicholas Blundel.

This John Blundel confessed himself to be a Romish Recusant, but denyed he had any hand in the Burning of Lyme-house, so there being no other Accusation against him, the House Ordered that he be discharged for this matter.
Ordered, that to morrow Morning this House be put into a Committee to proceed further in the Consideration of the Bill, for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Powle and others, to acquaint their Lor 〈…〉
Commons had prepared an humble Address to be presented to His Majesty, to which they desire their Lordships concurrence.
2. To put their Lordships in mind of the Bill brought up from the House of Commons concerning the preservation of His Majesties Person and Government.
The said Address was read, and it is Ordered that this Address shall be taken into consideration to morrow Morning.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do wait on His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be gratiously pleased to grant His Royal Pardon to Titus Oates, for what he hath done and confessed concerning himself, for which be is lyable to the severity of the Laws of this Kingdom.

Whereas upon some Information given to this House by the Earl of Clarendon, that there might be some Papers of dangerous consequence in the custody of Sir Robert Walsh, he with all his Papers were seized Yesterday by order of this House, and is now in the custody of the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, upon reading the petition of the said Sir Robert Walsh this day praying his relief: It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that he be and is hereby discharged from his present restraint for this day, and he is hereby required to attend the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Papers concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person, to morrow at Nine of the Clock in the Forenoon in the Princes Lodgings, whose Lordships are to peruse his Papers, and to consider whether there be any cause for his further restraint, and make Report unto the House.

Ordered, That Richard Langhorn be returned to the Prison of Newgate, and the Keeper of Newgate was called in, and charged he should have a great care of this Prisoner, and not suffer any Person to speak with him.

div.head: Die Veneris Octo Novembris 1678.
div.p:
THe Lord Treasurer Reported, that himself and the oother Lords went yesterday according to their Lordships order, to Examine some of the Prisoners in the Tower, and the first they had before them was Sir John Gage, who owns
the Examination, which was taken of him by Sir Thomas Stringer to be upon Oath, and that the Paper which they shewed him (which was put into their hands from Sir Thomas Stringer) was a copy of his said Examination, but he denyes that he was Examined by the Lord Chief Justice, or that he ever received any Letter or Commission whatsoever from Mr. Oates, or that he knows any thing of any Plot against His Majesties Service or against the Government.
Sir William Goring was before them next, who likewise denyed any kind of knowledg of those things which he was accused of, or that he knew any such Man as Mr. Oates.

They then sent for the Lord Arundel of Warder, whom they first Examined as to his being privy to Mr. Colemans going to Brussels to the Popes Nuntio, and urged to him that the Letters to Coleman from the Nuntio, did give a caution that none should be trusted with the business but his Royal Highness and the Lord Arundel, yet his Lordship did absolutely deny that he knew any thing of the Transaction, between Coleman and the said Nuntio, or of Colemans errand into Flanders, but said, it is likely he took his leave of him before he went.

His Lordship did own Coleman was twice with him that day Colemans Papers were seized, that the first time they discourst of indifferent matters, the last time (which was about Six in the Evening) Coleman spoke of his Papers being seized, and that thereupon his Lordship advised him to follow his Papers and render himself.

Being askt, his Lordship further declared he never saw Mr. Oates in his life, and that he never was at Mr. Langhorns Chamber but once, and never saw him but that time, and that he never did any business for him, and that he was so far from having any acquaintance with Mr. Langhorns Sons, that he did not know Mr. Langhorn was Marryed until he lately askt the question. And as for his Lordship receiving any patent, Commission or any Power from Forreigners, he saith he never did, but hath a parent for Count of the Empire, and for the place of Master of the Horse to her late Majesty the Queen Mother, and never had any other.
His Lordship further declared, that he never had any thing to do with any Jesuit, but that he knows most of those that are in Prison.

The Lord Petre was the last that their Lordships Examined, and they acquainted his Lordship with Mr. Oates his depositions against him, that he had received a Commission for Lieutenant General, from Mr. Oates in Mr. Langhorns Chamber, in the presence of Mr. Langworth, and that Mr. Langworth gave his
Lordship joy thereupon, all which his Lordship did utterly deny or that he knew Mr. Oates or had ever seen him, or that he ever saw Mr. Langhorn, or was at his Chamber or knew where his Chamber was, his Lordship indeed did acknowledg that be kn • w Langworth, and that he had lately heard that Mr. Oates had been a • his House, but that he had never heard of his name until Michaelmas Eve last, when his Lordships House was Searched for Mr. Langworth.

And as for his offering any thing to Persons that should change to the Romish Religion, his Lordship doth absolutely disown it, as also that ever he had any Commerce with Mr. Coleman about any matter of business.

This is the summ of what their Lordships had to acquaint the House with besides an humble Supplication of the said Lords, which they desired their Lordships would acquaint the House with, in regard they cannot Petition the House, being debarred from the use of Pen, Ink, and Paper, which is, that this House would be pleased to remit their close Imprisonment, and that they might be permitted to walk in the Tower for their Health, which is in danger by their present close restraint.
Their Lordships further giving the House an account of some irregularities, which they observed in some of the Officers belonging to the Tower, the House made the Order following

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty from this House, humbly to acquaint him, that the House of Peers having received Information of the insecurity of His Majesties Tower of London▪ and of keeping Prisoners there by reason of the carelesness of the Officers in not attending the duty of their places in the Tower as they ought, do therefore humbly b • seech His Majesty tha • he would please to give such order for the bet • er securing his said Tower, and the Prisoners there as His Majesty shall think fit.

The Lord Treasurer reported, by His Majesties directions that Yesterday one William Bedloe was Examined at Whitehall, concerning the Discovery of the Mu • ther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, and that His Majesty had given Order he should be brought to give this House an accou • t thereof, who being brought to the Bar and ha • his Oath given him, made a large N • rrative to this Effect▪ That he was born in Monmouth-shire and was of he Church of England till within these two Years, that by perswasion and promises from the Jesuits he was drawn over to them, that he is not in Orders, he knows that
Sir Edmondbury Godfrey was Murthered in Sommerset-house on the Saturday by Charles Walsh and 〈…〉
Lee phaire Jesuits, and two Lay-men, one a Gentleman that waits on the Lord Bellasis, the other an underwaiter in the Queens Chappel, that he saw the Body of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey after he was Murthered before he was carried out, and Le phaire told him he was Stifled between two Pillows: And he was offered Two Thousand Guinneys to be one of the three to carry out the Body, which was kept either in the Room or the next where the Duke of Albemarle lay in State, that the Chair-men who carryed out the Body on Monday at night at Nine of the Clock, are Retainers to Sommerset-house, but he knows them not, he saith that Walsh, Le phaire and Pritchard told him that the Lord Bellasis imployed them in this business, he saith further that Walsh and Le phaire informed him that the Lord Bellasis had a Commission to Command Forces in the North, the Earl of Powis in South-wales, and the Lord Arundel of Warder had a Commission from the Pope to grant Commissions to whom he pleased, that Coleman had been a great Agitator in the design against the King, and that he asking the Jesuits why they had not formerly told him what they had designed concerning the Kings Death, they answered him that none but whom the Lord Bellasis gave directions for were to know of it, he desired he might have time to put the whole Narrative in writing (which he had begun) and being asked if he knew Titus Oates, he denyed it.

Hereupon, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Gerard of Brandon, and the Lord Butler of Moor Park go immediatly to Sommerset-house, and make strict search there in all the Rooms for Armes and Papers, and for Charles Walsh and Le phaire and other suspitious Persons, but in the Queens Closet Cabinet and Council Chamber they are not to remove Papers nor Writings, only to seal up those that are in the Council Chamber. And that a Guard be set on the House of Mr. Choquee, and at the Savoy both at the Water-gate and upper gates thereof till his House be Searched, and that he be presently apprehended, and that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attend their Lordships in this service.
The Earl of Clarendon was appointed by this House to wait on Her Majesty, to acquaint her what directions this House hath given for the Searching of Sommerset house.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lord Gerard of Brandon, and Lord Butler of Moor Park, shall in the search they are now in at Sommerset-house, search for and seize 〈…〉
P • i • ha • d a Jesuit
of whom the Lords have Information that he is there.

The Lord Bishop of Rochester Reported, that the Committee for Examining of Papers have had Sir Robert Walsh before them this Morning, and having perused his Papers and Examined him, the Committee cannot find he is any way guilty of the design against His Majesty, therefore the Committee are of opinion that his Papers be returned to him, excepting a very few that are fit to be retained concerning other Persons, which may be made use of as occasion shall require, and that they find no cause to keep Sir Robert Walsh in longer restraint.

His Lordship further Reported, that the Committee have had account of Papers of Whitebread and Micho, and have delivered them to Sir Philip Loyd causing a List of them to be entred into the Clerks Book of the Committee.

Upon Report made by the Lord Bishop of Rochester from the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Papers concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person, that upon perusal of the Papers of Sir Robert Walsh, seized and brought before them by Order of this House, they find not any cause of detaining Sir Robert Walsh any longer in Custody, although they think fit to keep some of his Papers for the service of the House, it is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the said Sir Robert Walsh be, and is hereby discharged from any further restraint concerning this matter.

Upon reading the Petition of Nathaniel Thompson Printer now Prisoner in the Gate-house, praying that he may have his liberty, and be brought before this House where he will give the true reason why so many Popish Books are Printed, and shew the means how to prevent it, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the said Nathaniel Thompson be brought with his Keeper before the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Papers concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person, at such time as their Lordships shall appoint to hear him (and receive in writing) what he proposeth in his Petition and make report thereof to the House.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled, that the Lord Petre now close Prisoner in the Tower the Treason, by Order of this House shall henceforth have such liberty within the said Tower for his bealth as other Prisoners in the Tower have, till further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament
Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty from this House humbly to desire him, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order that John Lambert, now a prisoner may be examined upon such maatters relating to the Discovery of the Plot as His Majesty shall think fit, and perticularly as to any Commission by him received from the Pope or his Authority.

Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House or his Deputy or Deputies do forthwith attach the Bodies of all such Persons as are Men Servants to the Lord Bellasis where ever they can find them, and bring them in safe Custody to the Bar of this House to answer such matters as shal be there Objected against them, and this shal be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House, that the Letters of Mr. Coleman of the 29th. of September 1675. to father Le Chese, and another of his to father Le Chese, wherein he owns the sending of the said Letter, and Monsieur Le Cheses Letter, whereby he owns the receipt thereof, which have not been read in this House, may by His Majesties Order be brought hither, and His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, that the Tryal of the Lords, and other Prisoners for Treason may be expedited; and that in the mean time the Lord Bellasis may be a close Prisoner.

The Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled do declare, that Isabella Marchionesse Dowager of Winchester, as she is a Peeress of this Realm, and thereby ought to enjoy priviledge of Parliament, is not to be comprehended within the penalties enjoyned by the Proclamation for banishing Papists from London and Westminster.

div.head: Die Veneris Octavo Novembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p:
THe Earl of Clarendon Reported, that he hath waited on Her Majesty to acquaint Her with what this House Ordered in the Morning concerning the searching of Sommerset-House, which Her Majesty takes as a respect, and delivered
to his Lordship the Keys of Her Closet at Sommerset-House, which his Lordship delivered to the Lord Butler, who having Viewed Her Majesties Lodgings returned them to Her Majesty again.
Ordered, that the House be put into a Committee to morrow Morning to consider the Bill, for the more effectual preservation of His Majesties person, to be the first Business and nothing to intervene.
Sir George Charnocke Sergeant at Arms, acquainted the House, that he had apprehended some Servants of the • ord Bellasis, and had sent to search for more at his house in the Country.

Then Edmond Bedford the Cook, and Richard Midgley the Porter, were brought to the Bar and asked several questions, but the House finding they could say nothing material dismissed them at the Bar, but Mr. Dent Servant to the Lord Bellasis to be examined at the Committee for the Discovery of the Murther of Sir Edmond-Bury Godfrey.

div.head: Die Sabbati Nono Novembris 1678.
div.p: HIs Majesty sitting in His Royal Throne adorned with His Royal Crown and Ornaments (the Peers being likewise in their Robes) gave command to the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod to let the House of Commons know, that it is His Majesties pleasure they attend him presently, the Commons being come with their Speaker, was pleased to make this Gratious Speech following.

p.hi: I am so very sensible of the great and extraordinary care you have already taken, and shall continue to shew for the safety and preservation of my person in these times of danger, that I could not satisfy my self, without coming hither on purpose to give you all my most hearty thanks for it &c.

div.p:
Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order that His most Gratious
Speech made this day to both Houses of Parliament, in the House of Peers may be printed and published.
The Lord Treasurer Reported, that the Lords with white staves have attended His Majesty with four Addresses from this House.
The first concerning some Letters of Mr. Colemans to Mr. Le-Chese and his Answer, which His Majesty will give Order, shall be brought to this House so soon as may be.

Also to desire in the same Address concerning the Lord Bellasis, His Majesty hath given Order that he shall be close Prisoner, as also concerning the expediting the Trial of the Lords and other Prisoners for Treason, His Majesties answer is that as soon as the papers to make out the Evidence, which are now in the House of Commons can be had and methodized the Tryals shall be expedited.
To the second Address concerning John Lambert, His Majesty hath given Order for it.
To the third Address concerning a Royal Pardon to Titus Oates His Majesty hath given directions for it.
To the fourth Address 〈…〉 the insecurity of the Tower His Majesty intends to send directions • his day about it.

The Lord Gerard and the Lord Butler Reported, that according to the Order of this House they have searched all the Roomes in Sommerset-House and find no Jesuites, no • other suspitious Persons nor any Arms excepting a Case or two of Pistols, which belong to Sir John Arundel and Mr. Bernard Howard.
That they had seized some papers, which they had put into the Guard Chamber.

That in searching Mr. Choquees House they have found several Chests of Cartrages with some powder belonging to them, which are put into the hands of Captain Copley, who being called in gave the House an account of three Chests of Cartrages loaden with powder of several sorts, which are used in Fire works or Solemnities.

Choquee was called in and confessed he had in his house some Fire-works of his own making, some whereof he had layn by him about Eighteen years, which he designed to sell when there were shew of Fire-works at any solem • ity: and he had hope His Majesty would have bought them of him, he further saith, that about a Month ago a Constable searching his house did see them, and knowing for what use he kept them did let them alone, and that the Lord Craven knew he had such in his house, and so did several other Lords of this House know he had these Fire-works to be used upon days of solemnity.
Upon which the House discharged Captain Copley and Monsieur Choquee from any further attendance concerning this Matter.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Solliciter and others to acquaint their Lordships, that the House of Commons had prepared an Address to be presented to His Majesty, to which they desired their Lordships concurrence.
The said Address was Read,

The House being made acquainted, that Thomas Bedingfield one of the persons named in the said Address hath Rendred himself, the House Omitted him and Added the names of Le-Fair, Charls Walsh and Pritchard.
Then the Address was Read again with the Addition and Amendment, and was agreed to.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that Sir John Gage, and Sir William Goreing now close Prisoners in the Tower, may for their health sake enjoy the liberty of the Tower, as other Prisoners usually have there.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Andrew Hacket and Sir Samuel Clerk, to return the Address intended to be presented to His Majesty, and to let them know that the Lords agree to the Address with the Alterations and additions, and desire Concurrence thereunto.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Joseph Tredenham and others, to let their Lordships know that the Commons agree to the amendment and alterations, made by their Lordships in the Address.
The Tenor of which Address is as followeth.

Your Majesties most loyal and dutiful Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons in Parliament assembled, do humbly beseech your most Sacred Majesty to issue out your Royal Proclamation, that certain Persons called George Conyers, Symonds, Charles Walsh, Le phaire Pritchard and John Cattaway, who stand charged as Persons guilty of the Damnable and Hellish Plot for the destruction.

The House was adjourned into a Committee, to take into Consideration a Bill for the more effectual preservation of His Majesties Person, the House being resumed, the Earl of
Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee had spent much time in the debate of the first enacting clause of this Bill, and had not concluded any thing upon it, therefore desire another day, and the House appointed Monday Morning next, for the continuing this debate concerning the first clause.
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Walter and others, to desire a conference concerning the not issuing out Commissions in pursuance of the Proclamation against the Papists.
The Answer returned was, that this House will give a conference as is desired, and appoints the same to be on Monday Morning in the Painted Chamber at Ten of the Clock.

div.head: Die Lunae Undecimo Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Chancellor desired their Lordships directions, concerning the issuing out of the Commissions to Justices of the Peace, for administring the Oathes unto Papists in pursuance to the Proclamation, to that end (he said) he had caused to be prepared Six Commissions in general Terms, and Six Commissions with the limitations directed by this House, the several forms of the Commissions being read and considered of, the House directed the Lord Chancellor to seal the General Commissions without the limitations, they being most agreeable to Law, hereupon the Lord Chancellor withdrew and sealed the General Commissions accordingly.

The Lord Chancellor acquainted this House that His Majesty hath been informed by an Officer of the Guards, that William Bedloe hath somewhat to inform their Lordships of very great importance, hereupon the House was willing to hear him.

The said William Bedloe was called in and heard, what he could say concerning the further Discovery of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person, and after he had been heard, It is Ordered, that the said William Bedloe shall attend the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Witnesses concerning the Murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, whose Lordships are to Examine him, and receive from him such further additions as he shall give under his hand to his former Examinations, and make Report thereof to the House.

Lords Committees appointed to inspect the Cartrages
which were found in Monsieur Choquees house in the Savoy, and to be satisfyed of the numbers of them, and to try them whether they are adopted only for Fireworks, or may be used to dangerous designs, and have power to send for what Persons they think fit, to give them the best information concerning them or the nature of them.

The Lord Treasurer Reported, that the Lords with white Staves have waited on His Majesty, to know what time His Majesty will please to appoint for both Houses to wait upon him, to present the humble Address of both Houses for issuing out a Proclamation, for apprehending several Priests and Jesuits, and His Majesty hath appointed this Afternoon at three of the Clock in the Banqueting House at Whitchall for that purpose.
The Lord Chancellor acquainted the House, that His Majesty hath delivered to him those Papers which their Lordships desired in their Address might be communicated to them.

list.item: 1. Mr. Colemans Lettre to Monfieur Le Cheese Confessor to the French King dated 29th. September 1675.
2. Another Letter of Colemans to Le Cheese, written immediatly after that of the 29th. of September 1675.
3. A Letter of Le Cheese of the three and Twentieth of October 1675. acknowledging the receipt of Colemans long Letter.

div.p: These Letters were read.
And after a long debate concerning the agreeing with the House of Commons in the Address to His Majesty, for the Printing of these Letters, the Question being put, it was resolved in the Negative.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Serjeant Maynard and others, to put their Lordships in mind of the Bill for the more Effectual preservation of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament; which they conceive is so effectual for the good of the Kingdom.

The House of Peers being satisfied by a Report made from the Committee before whom William Bedloe was Examined, that Thomas Plessington a Servant of the Lord Bellasis now a Prisoner in the Gate-house, being brought Face to Face with William Bedloe before their Lordships, he declared that the said Thomas Plessington was not one of the Persons that Murthered Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, It is thereupon Ordered; by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament assembled,
that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be gratiously pleased to give Order for the discharge of the said Thomas Plessington, from the restraint he is under upon this account.

div.head: Die Martis Duodecimo Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Marquess of Winton. Reported, that the Committee appointed to take Examinations for the Discovery of the Murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, have spent many days therein, and do present the House two Examinations of Mr. William Bedloe, and some Examinations of several other Persons.

His Lordship said, that the Lords Committees did conjure William Bedloe to speak nothing but truth, and he did in the presence of God as he should answer it at the Day of Judgment, assure all to be true he had deposed.

The Lords caused him after he had distinctly read every sheet to set his hand to every sheet, and the Lords are of Opinion that he hath been very careful and exact in his Testimony, in not accusing any one further then he had perfect memory of, and of what he knows of his knowledge or from the mouthes of others.

The Lords have many other Examinations concerning the Death of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey not yet perfected, and therefore they think fit yet to keep them private, when perfected will make Report of them to your Lordships.
This Report only relates to William Bedloes Testimony, and some others I have taken upon Oaths, a Justice of Peace to confirm his Testimony.
Mr. William Bedloe saith he hath sent for a Person to Town, who when he comes will be able to give an account of the truth of several particulars, which he hath sworn to.
Then the Examinations taken November the Eighth 1678. at the Committee of Lords for enquiring into the Murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey were read as followeth.

William Bedloe being sworn in the Lords House was called in and Examined, saith on his Oath that this Examinant being treated with by Mr. Le Phaire and Mr. Walsh Jesuits, about the beginning of October last▪ they off • red him a reward of Four
Thousand Pounds, if he would be one of the Four or Six that should kill a Man that was a great obstacle of their design. He this Deponent promised to be one to do it upon their giving him notice, afterwards (viz the Fryday before Sir Edmondbury Godfrey was missing) Mr. Le Phaire met him this Deponent about Four of the Clock in Grays-Inn-walks, and appointed to meet him again in the same place about Four of the Clock the next day to do that business, that upon taking the Sacrament to do it, he this Deponent should have the Money paid to himself or to any Friend he should name, but he this Deponent not liking the design failed of meeting him; the next Night after being Sunday he met Mr. Le Phaire again by accident in Fleet-street, going into Red-lyon Court about Five of the Clock, Mr. Le Phaire then desired him not to fail of meeting him the next Night (being Monday) about the same hour at the Palsgrave Head Tavern, that he might imploy this Deponent in some other special business, but this Deponent came rarer than the time appointed and so failed to meet him, but left word at the Bar of that Tavern that he would meet him at Eight of the Clock in the Cloister of Sommerset-house Court, and accordingly betwixt Eight and Nine of the Clock, this Deponent came thither and found Le Phaire walking there, who said he had staid almost an hour for him. They past the time there about half an hour, Le Phaire telling him how much the Church of Rome and the Pope were obliged to him, and what rewards he should have for his secrecy and fidelity to them.

Afterwards he desired him this Deponent to walk into the midst of the Court, where he the said Le Phaire might say something to this Deponent, and no Body over hear it, and there he told this Deponent that the Person who he was to Kill was Killed, and that his Body then lay in Sommerset-house, and that he did believe that the excuse which this Deponent had made him before for not coming to the Murthering of him was real, and that he knew his fidelity was such, that he should have half the Reward, if he would help to carry the Body to a place where they had chose to lay him.

This Deponent asked to know first, who were to be the Persons that were to go with him, Le Phaire told him they were himself, Mr. Walsh the Lord Bellasis Gentleman, Mr. Atkins (Pepis Clerk) and one that he hath often seen in the Queens Chappel, and did believe to be one that belonged to the Chappel. Then Le Phaire brought this Deponent by the Hand in the dark through the Entry into that Room which he shewed the Duke of Monmouth, and knocked softiy with his Finger at the Door, and when it was opened Le Phaire led this Deponent into it which was dark, Le Phaire then pulled a dark Lanthorn from under his Coat
and shewed a small light in the Rome, where this Deponent saw the Persons before named, of whom this Deponent knew Le Phaire, Mr. Walsh and the other Person he saw often in the Chappel, and the other two owned themselves the one to be the Lord Bellasis Servant, and the other to be Mr. Atkins (Pepis Clerk).

And this Deponent saith, that they did agree to carry the Body in a Chair to the corner of Clarendon house, and there to put him in a Coach to carry him to the place where he was found, having concluded this they agreed to carry him off at Eleven of the Clock the same night, then some of them turning about they throwed off a Cloak that lay upon him, and shewed this Deponent the Body. This Deponent asked them who it was, they told him it was an old man that belonged to a Person of Quality, who had taken some Examinations tending to the Discovery of their design, this Deponent asked them further, why it was not more proper to Kill the Person of Quality himself, they answered no, for this man had the Examinations in his own Custody, and that their design of getting him thither, was to get him to send for them by fair means or fowl, and then they did not question but the next Examination would be so contrary to that, it would appear upon their Tryals two several Stories, and when they should be brought to Tryal upon the latter Examination, they would produce the former to contradict it, that it might seem partiality to the World, upon which reasons the Deponent seemed satisfied, and asked them where they Killed him, they told him at Sommerset house.

Then this Deponent begged their pardon for half an hour and he would wait on them again, but this Deponent went away and came no more, but the next day about Eleven of the Clock this Deponent met Le Phaire by accident, crossing Lincolns-Inn Fields, and then they went together unto the Grayhound Tavern in Fleet-street, Le Phaire (putting his Cane up to his Nose) said he had something to say to him, Le Phaire there charged this Deponent for not coming the last Night according to his promise, this Deponent told him he was unwilling to come because he knew the Person. Le Phaire asked him then who it was, this Deponent told him it was Justice Godfrey, Le Phaire then acknowledged it was so, and he was willing to dispense with this Deponents not coming, if he would assure him of his Fidelity.

This Deponent then asked Le Phaire how they got him thither and where they found him, Le Phaire told him that himself, Walsh and the Lord Bellasis Gentleman met him by the Kings head Inn in the Strand, crossing the street about Five of the Clock, and told him that if he would please to go with
them so far as Strand bridge, they would bring him to a place near St. Clements Church, where there were a Company met, principal Plotters of that design against the King, and there (if he would go presently he might take them and the principal of their Papers, he answered that he thought it not convenient to go himself, but he would send his Warrant and the Constable, they told him if he did make so much delay they might be gone, and that if he would walk up so far as Strand bridge, one of them would go and call a Constable to him there, and he might give his Order presently, whereupon he walked with them so far as Sommerset-house, and there they made a halt, then told him it would be less observed if he walked in Sommerset-house then to stand in the street, and thereupon two of them walked in with him, and the other pretended to go call a Constable, and when they had walked a turn or two in the Court, two more persons came forth and shoved him into a Room, and when they had him secure there, they held a Pistol to him, threatning if he made a noise they would shoot him, but if he would answer their Expectations they would do him no harm. Then they asked him to send for those Examinations he had taken about those that were committed, he answered they were not in his power for he had sent them to Whitehall, upon that and his refusing to answer other questions they seized him and stifled him with a pillow, and so they thought he had been dead but coming into the Room sometime after they found him strugling, and then they strangled him with a long Cravat, (which Cravat the Deponent saw the Monday at Night about his neck) then this Deponent asked Le Phaire why they carryed him into the Fields, and what they designed by it, he answered that they had made a Wound in his Body and laid his Sword by him that it should seem he had Killed himself, and that they did not question that the discovery o •… Killing him would ever have been made, neither did they doub •… but their design would have its effect, then Le phaire told thi •… Deponent that as he would be answerable to Christ Jesus at the last day, he should be faithful to the cause and so they parted.

The same time Mr. Atkins being called in before Mr. Bedloe, Mr. Bedloe saith that he is in all things very like the Perso •… he saw in the Room with Sir Edmondbury Godfries dead Body, and he doth verily believe it was him that owned himself to be Pepis his Clerk, but because he never saw him before that time he cannot positively swear it, but he doth verily believe him t •… be that man.
The further Examinations of William Bedloe being sworn at the Bar.

The Lady Abbis of the English Nuns in Dunkirk, sent me to St. Omers with a Letter to Sir John Warner and the other Jesuits, which Letter I opened and found in it I was recommended (a man wholly fit to be imployed in the design) then those Jesuits sent me to Antwerp to Father Worsley, to be informed by degrees of the part I was to have in it, when he had as he thought confirmed me to secresie, he sent me to Doway with a Letter in a Language I did not know, where the Monks after several ways sifting me declared to me, that now was a design in hand to make England happy both to Body and Soul, and that being just to the cause, I should not only enjoy infallibly Heaven, but raise my self and my Family to a fortune equal to what I should expect, if I continued faithful to the end. Then they sent me to England to Father Hartcourt a Jesuit lodging in Duke-street with a Letter in Latin, after they had given me the Sacrament Four times upon the charge of secresie, when I came to London I was provided for by Mr. Hartcourt, what he imployed me in was to fetch and bring Post Letters, which I did in abundance for Four Moneths time, then he sent me to Paris, I being sent for by the Monks there, who immediatly sent me again for England with a very great Pacquet of Letters, and directed to Mr. Vaughan of Courtfield in Monmouth-shire, the rest that were inclosed were to Mr. Vaughan of Upper Rose, to Mr. Milborn of Monmouth, to Mr. James near Monmouth, to Mr. Charles Winter, and to Mr. Cbarles Price, who is Steward to my Lord Marquess of Worcester, their Order was as Mr. Vaughan told me to consult with some others, and to send their result over by Mr. Pritchard, that at Rome and all places beyond the Seas the business went on very well, as they did not question but that it did aswel in England and Ireland, after Mr. Vaughan had told me this, I came for London where I staid conversing with Mr. Hartcourt, Mr. Le Phaire and other Jesuits till Winter was over, then they sent me to St. Omers, from thence to Doway, where Mr. Gage the Rector of the English Colledge, there told me after he had confirmed what great rewards were designed for me, and how much I had merited from Christ and the Blessed Virgin, that in a Year or something more they did not at all question but to be established at Christ Church Colledge in Oxford, and to see England flourish in the true Religion of Rome. Then I demanded what they would do with the King, he answered they would keep him well in a Convent,
then I demanded who should govern in Chief, then he told me there should be a tender made to one of the Crown, if he would acknowledg it from the Church, but they did believe he would not accept it, and then the Government should be left to some Lords that the Pope would appoint, which Lords names he would not tell me but said I should know it from the Monks at Paris, when I came there they sent me to Spain, with Letters to the Rector of the Colledge of Irish Jesuits at St. Jagoe, and they sent me with a Letter to be given to Mr. Hartcourt in Characters, since which time I have been in England, and from Le Phaire and Walsh, Pritchard and Lewis, I have understood that the Lords who were to govern, were my Lord Arundel of Warder as Chief, my Lord Bellasis as General with Mr. Thimbleby of Ernham with several others, whereof Sir 〈…〉
Ratcliffe was one was to command in the North, and to receive from Flanders ten thousand Men to be landed at Bradlington Bay, and the first thing they designed was by a correspondency they had in Hull to surprise that Garison, and that my Lord Powis joyned with my Lord Petre, Mr. Vaughan of Upper rose, Mr. Charles Winter, Mr. Charles Milborn of Monmouth, and Chancellor James near Monmouth, were to meet at a certain place in Radnorshire in Southwales with another Army, and to march to Pembrook-shire to meet with Twenty or Thirty Thousand Men, who were to land at Milford haven from the Groin in Spain, which Army was to be Religious Men and Pilgrims from St. Jagoe in Spain. Upon this design being just ready to be put in Execution the design against the Kings Person was discovered, when immediatly comes Mr. Le Phaire to me, and made me take the Sacrament with a great Benediction to continue secret to the cause. Then I demanded of him and Mr. Lewis another Jesuit, why they did conceal the design against the King from me, and they both answered me it was my Lord Bellasis Order, that none should know it but these that were to be the Actors in it. Then I asked of them how and where it was to be done, they said it was designed several ways, and at several times, but the certain way they pitched upon was in his Morning walks at New Market, and that Mr. Conyers had taken it upon him to do it, and Mr. Keines to Kill the Duke of Monmouth, Pritchard the Duke of Buckingham, Mr. Knight my Lord Shaftesbury, Mr Oneale my Lord Ossery, and one whose name I have forgotten the Duke of Ormond, and when these persons were Killed they did not question the power of the rest or their Councels, but that they should our do them, for they would give such great pay that all sorts of Ma • e contents, and People that depended on their
fortune would be ready to serve them, but whatever should happen, their power as they had laid it would be sufficient, for they had Forty thousand men ready in London, besides those that would on the Alarum be posted at every Ale-house door, to have killed the Soldiers as they came out of their Quarters. Then I asked them where they were provided with Money to answer all this, they said that my Lord Stafford, and Mr. Coleman, and Ireland had money enough to go through all this, and that several Gentlemen in England had great summs to contribute to it, then I asked them what place they would secure in the West, they told me the Castle of Chepstow was to be delivered up to Mr. Charles Winter, by the Governor Captain Spalding, and my Lord of Worcesters Steward Mr. Charles Price, then I told them I did believe that my Lord of Worcester, and the Earl of Shrewsbury, and the Duke of Norfolk had a great part in this design; they told me no, for they durst never attempt to discover it to either of them, and to many more they could wish to favor them, and that Mr. Charles Price had told them they should never attempt my Lord of Worcester, for he knew it would be impossible to bring him to it, but that they would be discovered if he knew it, then I asked him why they gave such great credit to Mr. Price, they said because he had been one of the principal Persons in contriving the design, and one whose Wise Councels was the most observed in England. I answered I thought him a man fitter indeed for a Councellor than a Soldier, they said it would not appear so if I knew what good and ingenious Arms he had presented all the Lords concerned with, but that his own Councel was what they had builded much upon, and they thought him one of the wisest men in Orders in the World.

After this discourse we parted, and about two days after I met Mr. Le Phaire, who told me I should receive the reward of Four Thousand Pound being one as would Murther a man, and that it was my Lord Bellasis Order for what ever they had employed me in, aswel in all other matters as in this, and more they have always told me, that when their design was to be begun, we should all receive our Commissions from my Lord Bellasis with a benediction from the Pope annexed to it, and when I have often demanded of them how they would establish the Government, they always answered securely enough, for they did intend utterly to extinguish all sorts of People, that would not really be converted to the Church of Rome, and to prove it, persecute their neerest Relations that were obstinate, I have no more to say to what I can now remember, but then
was I solicited to murther, which account I have given in to the Committees of Lords.

And further, that I have been assured by Mr. Le Phaire, that Mr. Conyers who had undertaken to kill the King, is the Lord Bellasis Confessor, and that Mr. Le Phaire hath often told me that Mr. Le Phaire just now came from my Lord Bellasis with such and such Orders; and also that Mr. Le Phaire hath often told me, that when any person that was concerned in the Plot was imprisoned, that by one means or other, they would kill them before they should come to their Tryals, though they burned the Prisons where they were in Custody, and that Gernsey and Jersey were to be surprized by a power from Brest and other places of France, and that several French Ships have lain in and about the Channel all this Summer upon the same occasion. And further, Mr. Le Phaire, Mr. Pritchard, Mr. Lewis, Mr. Kains, and Mr. Walsh in England, and Mr. Letham, Mr. Stapleton, Mr. Sheldon, and Dr. Gage Rector of the English Colledge in Doway, and others have often told me that there was not a Roman Catholick in England of any Quality or Credit, but was acquainted with this Design of the Papists, and had received the Sacrament from their Father Confessots to be secret and assistant in the carrying of it on.

November the 9th 1678. Captain Hawley, Ensign of the Kings Regiment of Foot gards, being called in to the same Committee of Lords, and sworn by the Lord Marquess of Winchester, as a Justice of the Peace; in the presence of the said Committee informed their Lordships, that he was upon the Guard at Sommerset-house that Saturday that Sir Edmondbury Godfry was missing, and as he was walking with Mr. Francis Russel in some Room wherein the State stands within the Guard-Chamber; two elderly men came to one Dukes, who was also in that Room, and immediately after Mr. Dukes came to this Deponent, and Mr. Russel, and told them that they must withdraw, for that the Queen desired to be private, and saith that this was about five of the Clock.
The Information of Henry Berry, Porter of the Gate at Sommerset-house, taken by the Right Honourable the Marquess of Winton. this 11 day of November 1678. as followeth, viz.

That about the 12, 13, or 14. of October last, this Deponent had Orders to tell all persons of Quality that came to the Gate, that the Queen desired to be private, and that the Prince came to the G • te, but could not be admitted, and
this Deponent saith, that the Queen continued so private for two days.

The Informations of Mrs. Diana Salvin, and Mrs. Elizabeth Salvin taken as abovesaid, who being sworn, say, that they do both know Mr. Le Phaire, and Mr. Walsh, and have seen them with Mr. Bedloe at their house, and that Mr. Walsh hath twice said Mass at their house. when Mr. Bedloe hath been present, and that Mr. Bedloe did acquaint them of Ten pound which Mr. Le Phaire lent unto Mrs. Hern of Essexstreet.

John Saunders being sworn and examined by the Right Honorable the Lord Marquess of Winton, one of the Justices of the Peace for the County of Middlesex, saith, that this Deponent hath seen Mr. Le Phaire in company with Mr. Bedloe, and that he was bound with Mrs. Hern unto a Shooemaker for Ten pound, which money Mr. Le Phaire brought, and took the Bond in the Shooemakers name, and Mr. Le Phaire was a witness unto the same Bond together with Mr. Bedloe.

The Information of Alexander Oldis, taken the 12. of November, 1678. before the Right Honourable the Marquess of Winchester, one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace for the County of Middlesex; he saith, that he in the company of William Bedloe, about Six Weeks since did hear Mass said in the house of Mr. Salvin in Essex Buildings, by a middle sized man, with Pockholes in his Face, he wears a Perriwig which he put off when he put on his Vestments to say Mass, he knoweth not his name.
The Examination of Charles Atkins Esquire, taken upon Oath before me one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace for the County of Middlesex, and Liberty of Westminster, this First of November 1678.

Saith, that in Derby house being in discourse with Samuel Atkins (Clerk to Mr. Pepis Secretary of the Admiralty) the said Samuel did say, that Sir Edmondbury Godfrey had very much villified his Master, and that if he lived long, would be the ruin of him; upon which the said Samuel did ask this Examinant, whether he did think Childe to be a man of Courage and Secresie, to which this Examinant replied, that the said Childe had been at Sea, and had behaved himself very well as he had been informed; upon which the said Samuel did bid this Examinant send the said Childe to his Master Mr. Pepis, but not to him the said Samuel, for that he would not be seen to know any thing of it. This Examinant did endeavour to find out the said Childe, but did not meet
with him till the day after (this discourse had happened betwixt him and Samuel Atkins) at the three Tobacco Pipes in Holbourn, where this Examinant did tell Childe, that Secretary Pepis would speak with him, and the next time that this Examinant did see the said Childe (after that he had given him that direction) he the said Childe did endeavour to engage the said Examinant to joyn with him in the murther of a man. The particulars of which this Examinant hath declared before the King and Council, Wednesday last past.
Taken before me one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace, for the County and Liberty above mentioned, P. Howard.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with the white Staves do wait on His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be graciously pleased to grant his general pardon to Mr. Bedloe.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with the white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be graciously pleased to grant his Royal pardon to Diana and Elizabeth Salvin, who upon their Examinations have confessed (among other things) that they have been at Mass, and that they the said Diana and Elizabeth Salvin, being to be further examined as witnesses, may be licensed to stay in Town, they having behaved themselves very well before the Lords Committees, who have examined them.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, his Deputy or Deputies shall forthwith attach the Bodies of Mr. Charles Price, Mr. Vaughan of Upper Rose, Mr. Vaughan of Court-field, Mr. Thimbleby of Ernham, Captain Spalding Deputy Governour of Chepstow, Mr. Charles Milborn of Monmouth, Councellor James near Monmouth, and Mr. Charles Winter, and bring them in safe Custody to the Barr of this House, to answer such matters as shall there be objected against them on His Majesties behalf, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do wait on His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to direct, that the Tryal of Samuel
Atkins, Mr. Childe, and Edward Coleman may be expedited.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. Colemans Letters, and Mr. Le Chese Letters communicated to this House by His Majesty, may be delivered to His Majesties Attorney General, in order to the forming his progress, and preparing his evidence against the Prisoners to be tryed for Treason.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with the white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that Mr. Biston late Servant to the Lady Bellasis, described to wear a black Perriwig, and black Whiskers, round Faced, pretty plump in Body, of middle Stature, may be added to the persons to be Summoned by His Majesties Royal Proclamation, for which both Houses presented their humble Address to His Majesty.

Upon Information given to this House, that there hath been an attempt made by some persons to blow up or burn Sir George Wakemans Stables. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Hay and other materials in the said Stables and Haylofts belonging to them, be forthwith removed, and a diligent search made for what may be found there. And it is further Ordered, that the two next Justices of the Peace to the place, be, and are hereby required to see this Order Executed, and give a speedy account thereof to this House.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. William Snow, and Mr. James Noble, go with all convenient speed, and cause a Brick or Stone Pavement lately laid in some part of Mr. Edward Colemans house to be taken up, and search made what they can find there; and if there be any Papers or Writings, that they Seal them up, and bring them away with them to be brought before this House. And that they require the Assistance of His Majesties Workmen, Masons, or Bricklayers to assist them in this Service, and one of the Clerks attending on this House is to be present with them, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Lord Chancellour acquainted the House, the Address of both Houses for Issuing out a Prociamation for summoning Conyers and others to render themselves, was yesterday presented to His Majesty, who received the same very graciously, and said he would take it into his speedy care.

Upon Information of William Sorocoale, that he having sound a Priest and other Papists in the same house in the City of London, and that he went to a Justice of the Peace for a Warrant, and he ordered him to go to my Lord Mayor, which he accordingly did, but his Lordship told him he would grant no such Warrant, till he had summoned the parties before him.

Then Sibel Matthews upon Oath made at the Bar, said that she living with Mr. Vanderpeck, lay one night at Mr. Clouds in Broadstreet, where there was a Priest, and she carrying a Note to Mr. Cloud, the Priest being in the house was desired to read it, and she scrupling at his reading of it, Mr. Cloud told her she need not fear, for he would do righteous things, for he was a Priest, and that he lodged up two pair of Stairs forwards, and he lay there a great while, and the Maid shewed her the Room, and she saw his Cross and Pictures which the Maid told her he bowed to.
div.q: Whereupon the House made this Order following.
div.p: Upon Information given to this House by William Sorocoale, that applying himself to the Lord Mayor of London for a Warrant for the apprehending of a Popish Priest, and that the Lord Mayor refused to grant out his Warrant for that purpose. It is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Mayor of London shall have a Copy of the said Information, of which he is required to send this House an account in Writing, on Thursday next at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Martis 12. Novembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p:
THe House was adjourned into a Committee, to proceed in the consideration of the Bill, for the more effectual preservation of the Kings Person and Government. The House was resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater reported, that the Committee have made a further progress in this Bill, and desires the House may be put into a Committee
again on Thursday Morning next to proceed therein, and to be the first business, and nothing to intervene, which is ordered accordingly.

div.head: Die Jovis 14. Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe House being informed that the Lord Mayor of London was attending their Lordships pleasure at the door, he was called in, and being come to the Bar, the Lord Chancellour did let him know the Information of William Sorocoale against him, to which his Lordship said, that William Sorocoale had told the truth, but not the whole truth, for he did come to him for a Warrant to apprehend a Romish Priest, but could not tell his name, only told him the Priest was at one Mr. Clouds house, his Lordship told Sorocoale he knew the man very well, and offered to send for him while Sorocoale was present, and accordingly he did send for Mr. Cloud, but Sorocoale would not stay till he came.
He knew Mr. Cloud to be a very honest man and of good repute in the City, and that he was now attending at the Door.

He humbly desired their Lordships to consider how much business he is under in the Government of the City in this Juncture of time, and expressed his loyalty to the King and his Government, and the Religion of the Church of England, and that he should make it his business to have a care of the City.

Then he being withdrawn, and the House having considered of what the Lord Major had said, he was called in again, And the Lord Chancellor by the directions of the House told him, they did not intend he should have had the trouble in this busie time, to come in person but to have sent his Answer in writing, that they were very well satisfied with what he had done in this business, and that the Lords look upon him as a Person that deserves respect, for his care in the Government of the City, and gives him thanks for it, and further told him that William Sorocoale had misrepresented his Lordship to the House, for which he should have a reprehension and so his Lordship withdrew.

Then Mr. Cloud was called in, and asked why he keeps a Chappel and a Romish Priest in his House, he denyed both,
being asked of what Religion he was of, he confessed he was a Roman Catholick, but he was ready to take the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, hereupon the Lords made the ensuing Order.

Whereas Mr. Cloud of Broad-street in London, appearing this day at the Bar, was Examined by this House, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Commissioners for the City of London, authorized for that purpose, be and are hereby authorized to send for and tender the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy to the said Mr. Cloud.

The Lord Marquess of Winton Reported, that the Committee appointed to Examine concerning the Murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, hath received Information that one Mr. Powel a Merchant of London hath been missing for many days, and none of his Relations can tell what is become of him, that his Lordship as a Justice of the Peace, hath taken several Examinations, by which there is great presumption that he is Murthered, and by those Examinations one Woodward, and Adam Picket are strongly suspected to have a hand in his Murther, therefore it was desired that the same Committee as Examiners concerning the murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, may have Power and Authority to Examine concerning the murther of the said Powel, and that the said Woodward and Picket may be secured, and brought before the Committee at three of the Clock this Afternoon.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Witnesses concerning the murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, be and are hereby Authorized and Impowered to send for, and Examine and secure such Persons as they shall find cause relating to the Discovery of what is become of one Mr. Powel a Merchant, who hath been for some days missing, and of whom there are strong presumptions that he is murthered, and to make Report thereof to the House.

Ordered, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, his Deputy or Deputies, be and are hereby required to attach the Bodies of Mr. Woodward and Adam Picket, and bring them in safe Custody to the Lords Committees appointed (amongst other things) to inquire into the Murther of Mr. Powel who hath been long missing, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The House being moved, that some account may be speedily given to this House of some number of Horsemen armed, riding through some parts of the North riding of York-shire,
and of several meetings of Papists in those parts, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the speedy care of Sir Christopher Wivel and Sir Richard Grimes, being Deputy Lieutenants and Justices of Peace there, to inquire into this matter and give the House an account thereof.

This House being moved, that some account may be speedily given to this House of some Horsemen Armed, Riding through the West Riding of York shire, and of several meetings of Papists in those parts. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the care of the Lord Lieutenant of the West Riding of the County of York, to direct that Henry Lord Fairfax, Sir John Kage and 〈…〉
Ramsden Esquire, being Deputy Lieutenants and Justices of the Peace there do inquire into this matter, to the end this House may have a speedy account thereof.

Whereas Mr. Thimbleby, who was to be taken into Custody by the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, hath this day appeared at the Bar denying what is charged on him, It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Mr. Thimbleby shall stand Committed to the Prison of the Kings Bench, there to remain in safe Custody till further Order, and that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House or his Deputies take care to convey him to the said Prison, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, that the Lord Arundel of Warder now close Prisoner in the Tower for Treason, may for his health have the liberty of the Tower with a Keeper, who is not to suffer any persons to discourse with his Lordship privately.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Dunbarton, the Lord James Douglas, Collonel Mackarty and Collonel Dungan be, and are hereby permitted to stay in Town till further Order.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend the Queens Majesty from this House, with their humble thanks to Her Majesty for her care and readiness to give them satisfaction, in the late search made at Sommerset-house.

William Green upon Oath given him at the Bar deposed,
that about August last he brought a Letter to one Collins a Popish Priest sent to him out of Flanders, wherein there was this passage that there would be a War between England and France, whereupon Collins replyed we should have War enough at home, this Collins he said lived in the Spanish Ambassadors House.

Upon this the House Ordered, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to send to the Spanish Ambassador, desiring him that Collins an English man and a Priest, and Dominick Mac. Quir. alias Gnevara, may be delivered to such Person or Persons as His Majesty shall think fit, and that Mr. Green may go along with the Messenger who shall be sent, he knowing the said Collins when he seeth him.
The Lord Chamberlain Reported, that the Lords with the White Staves, had presented His Majesty with Five Addresses.
1. That the Tryals of Samuel Atkins, Mr. Child and Edward Coleman, may be expedited.

p.hi: To which His Majesty returns this Answer, that he will expedite their Tryals.

div.p: 2. That William Bedloe may have a general pardon.

p.hi: To which His Majesty gives this Answer, that he will give him a general pardon as is desired.

div.p: 3. That His Majesty would be pleased to give a pardon to Diana and Elizabeth Salvin, for their hearing of Mass.

p.hi: To which His Majesty gives this Answer, that he will give them a pardon as is desired.

div.p: 4. That Mr. Bistons name may be inserted in the Proclamation against Conyers and others.

p.hi: The Kings Answer is, that he by his Secretary has commanded Mr. Attorney to do it.

div.p: 5. That the Scottish Regiment may be speedily removed Forty miles from London.

p.hi: His Majesties Answer is, that he will give speedy Order for the removing of that Regiment.

div.p: Upon Report made by the Earl of Shaftesbury, from the Lords Committees appointed to inspect the nature of the Cartrages, lately taken in the House of Monsieur Choquee, that it is fit the said Cartrages should be secured, It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Master of the Ordinance shall forthwith send for and take into his Custody the said Cartrages, and keep them in safe Custody in the Tower of London.

The House was adjourned into a Committee to proceed in
the further consideration of the Bill for the more effectuai preserving of His Majesties Person, the House was resumed, the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee have been in further consideration of the Bill for the preservation of His Majesties Person, and desire the House may be put into a Committee to morrow Morning to proceed therein, and that it may be the first business, and nothing to intervene, which was ordered accordingly.
Ordered, that the Lord Culpeper is added to the Committee appointed to Examine the Murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey.

div.head: Die Veneris 15 Novembris 1678.
div.p: UPon Report made from the Lords Committees, appointed to inspect the nature of the Cartrages, lately taken at Mr. Choquees house, that they ought to be secured being not fit to be kept by any private Person, though intended only for Fire-works, which Cartrages are since secured in the Tower, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased by his Order in Councel to publish, that all Persons who have any Cartrages or Fire-works in their Custody, be required to give notice thereof to the Councel Board, within 〈…〉 days after the publication of the said Order.

Then the House was adjourned into a Committee to proceed in the consideration of the Bill, for the more effectual preserving the Person of the King, the House was resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater Reported that the Committee have proceeded further upon the Bill, and desire the House would appoint another time for the House to be put into a Committee, to proceed in the consideration of that Bill, and the House Ordered to morrow Morning, and to be the first business.
Then the Lord Chancellor Reported, that the Lords wi • h White Staves had presented to His Majesty two Addresses from the House.
1. Concerning the Lord Arundel of Warder, to have • he liberty of the Tower for his Health.

p.hi: To which His Majesty returns this Answer, that he had given Order for the same, with those restrictions their Lordships desire.

div.p: 2. Concerning His Majesties sending to the Spanish Ambassador, touching Collins and Dominick Mac. Quir.

That His Majesty sent Mr. Secretary Coventry to the Spanish Ambassador to demand them, and the Ambassador promised to send them when and where His Majesty pleased, expressing himself so sensibly of the occasion upon which they were demanded, that if be knew his own Son were ingaged in it, he would deliver him up.
The next Address was to give the Queen thanks, for her care and readiness to give the House satisfaction for their late search at Sommerset-house.
To which Her Majesty returns this Answer.

That Her Majesty was very sensible of the civility of the Lords to Her, and she should be extreamly glad to contribute any thing on Her part to the Discovering of this Horrid Fact, and the more because she hears it was alledged to be done at Sommerset-house at the time she was there, she hoped the Lords would continue their good opinion of her when any of her concerns came before them, which she would be ready to deserve from them upon all occasions.

div.head: Die Sabbati 16. Novembris 1678.
div.p: ORdered, to have a conference with the House of Commons, about granting Licences to Papists to stay i • Town.

Lords Committees appointed to consider what Papers and Letters are fit to be collected, and put into Mr. Attorney Generals hands, to enable him to prepare the whole Evidence for the Tryal of Edward Coleman, whose Lordships are to finish their meetings for that purpose by Thursday next. D. Cumberland, L. Privy Seal, &c.
Their Lordships or any Three of them to meet this Afternoon, at Three of the Clock in the Lord Privy Seals lodgings, and to adjourn as they please.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament
Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty would be pleased to send to the House of Commons, for such Papers and Letters as may be necessary for the perusal of the Lords Committees appointed to collect what is fit for perfecting the Evidence against Edward Coleman.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give leave that Titus Oates may name to His Majesty two Persons such as His Majesty shall approve off, to be with and attend the said Titus Oates upon his necessary occasions, and that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order to the Lord Treasurer, that such allowances of Money may be made to the said Titus Oates as his necessary occasions shall require.

The Lord Marquess of Winton Reported, that the Committee have Examined several Persons, and by what appears to them Mr. Powel is Murthered, therefore their Opinion is, that an Address be made to His Majesty, that he would please to give Order for issuing out a Proclamation, promising a Reward to him that shall discover the Murther.

Hereupon it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to issue out his Royal Proclamation, for a Reward to any Person that shall discover what is become of Mr. Powel a Merchant, who hath been missing some time, and of whom there is strong presumption that he is Murthered.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that His Majesties Attorney General be, and is hereby appointed to prepare a Bill for the attainders of to be brought in this House, therein setting a day for the said persons to come in, and that then notice may be taken of the said Bill in the Proclamation, to be issued for summoning the said persons to appear and render themselves.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give order for the speedy removal of all Popish Families out of the Tower of London.
The Lord Chancellor acquainted the House, that the Spanish Ambassador had sent those two persons, which he promised His Majesty to deliver up.

One was William Collins an Irish-man entertained by the Spanish Ambassador, the said Collins being brought to the Bar and asked whether he knew one William Green, to which he said, no, then William Green being called in, the said Collins looking upon him confessed he knew the said Green, who repeated what words he heard the said Collins say (being the same Information he gave this House the 14th of November instant) which words Collins denyed, the said William Green further deposed, that the said Collins hath confest to him that he was a Romish Priest.
Hereupon the House Ordered as followeth.

Whereas William Collins appearing this day at the Bar of this House, was there charged with uttering words of dangerous consequence, it is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House, or his deputies shall forthwith convey the said William Collins to the Prison of the Gate-house at Westminster, there to remain a Prisoner till further order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The other Person was one Dominico Gnavara alias Mac. Quir, who being brought to the Bar, said, he was Born in Spain and not naturalized, there being no charge against him, and being a Spaniard, It is Ordered, that he be returned to the Spanish Ambassador.

Then the House was adjourned into a Committee to proceed in the consideration of the Bill, for the more effectual preserving of His Majesties Person &c. The House being resumed, the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Comittee have made a further progress in this Bill, but many clauses are yet behind, therefore the Committee desires that the House may be put again into a Committee on Monday next to proceed in the said Bill, and that it may be the first business, which the House ordered accordingly.

div.head: Die Lunae 18. Novembris 1678.
div.p: HOdie prima vice licita est Billa, an Act requiring the Persons therein named to render themselves to Justice, and in default thereof to attaint them of High Treason.

The Marquess of Winton Reported, from the Committee for the discovery of the horrid design against His Majesty, that the opinion of the Committee is, That an Address be made to His Majesty for a Proclamation of a General pardon, and Reward to such as shall come in, and make further discoveries of this horrible design of the Papists.
2. That an Order may be issued out to search all the Papists Houses and Lodgings, and other suspected places in the Savoy after the Body of Mr. Powel.
3. That Sir Ellis Leighton may not be discharged until Mr. Oates be heard against him.
4. That the Proclamation to be issued for Mr. Powel, may contain in it a General pardon, and a plentiful Reward to the Discoverer.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be gratiously pleased to issue out his Royal Proclamation of a General Pardon, and a Reward to every such Person or Persons, as shall make any further Discovery of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that Sir Ellis Leighton now Prisoner in Newgate may not be discharged out of Prison, before such time as he shall be brought Face to Face with Titus Oates, before the House of Peers.
