Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that H • s Majesty will be pleased, that in the Proclamation which this House hath prayed His Majesty to issue for a Reward to any Person that shall discover what is become of Mr. Powel, who hath been missing sometime, and of whom there are strong presumptions that he is murthered, there may be also a Declaration of His Majesties General Pardon to such Person or Persons
as shall make such discovery, and that the reward may be so considerable as to encourage them thereunto.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House, be and is hereby required forthwith to make a strict search in all the Papists Houses and Lodgings, and other suspected places in the Savoy for the discovery of the Body of Mr. Powel, who hath been sometime missing, and of whom there are strong presumptions that he is murthered, and that the Duke of Monmouth be desired to appoint a sufficient Guard to assist him in this Service.

The Earl of Essex Reported, that the Committee appointed to prepare such Papers as are most requisite to perfect the Evidence for the Tryal of Edward Coleman, do find that there are certain Letters of Mr. Colemans with Cyphers, which cannot be decyphered but by Mr. Coleman himself, therefore it is desired that Mr. Coleman may be sent for, and brought to attend the Committee to morrow Morning to try whether he will discover the Cyphers, and that he may be brought with a good Guard.

2. That there are several Papers and Letters taken which were Mr. Godwins, amongst which it is very probable there are some of Mr. Colemans Letters, which have not been yet perused, therefore, it was desired that those Papers may be brought to the Committee.

It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Edward Coleman now a Prisoner in Newgate for Treason, be brought by the Keeper of Newgate before the Lords Committees to peruse Letters and Papers to morrow at Nine of the Clock in the Forenoon, in the Lord Privy Seales Lodgings near the House of Peers, and that the Duke of Monmouth be desired to send a sufficient Guard of Soldiers to assist the Keeper of Newgate, in this service of bringing and returning Edward Coleman

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will please to give Order, that the Papers of Mr. Godwin, now in the Hands of the Clerks of His Majesties Privy Councel, may be brought before the Lords Committees, appointed to consider of and prepare the Evidences for the Tryal of Mr. Coleman.

Next the Duke of Monmouth acquainted the House with two Examinations, one concerning the Sentinels at Sommerset-house, another taken by Mr. Loyd concerning the discovery of Sir Edmondbury Godfries murther, it is Ordered, by the Lords
Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Examinations of several Soldiers taken by the Duke of Monmouth, and the Earl of Clarendon, and read in the House this day, be and are hereby referred to the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Witnesses for the discovery of the murther of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, to proceed thereupon as they shall see cause.

The House was adjourned into a Committee, to consider further of the Bill for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty, the House was resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee has gone through the Bill, and have appointed a Sub-Committee to word those Amendments they have made, and then to Report the whole altogether. And the Committee desires the House would appoint Mr. Justice Atkins, and Mr. Justice Jones to assist their Lordships herein, all which was Ordered accordingly, and any three to meet this Afternoon at three in the Princes Lodgings.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Secretary Coventry and others, that the Commons in Parliament Assembled, reflecting on the imminent dangers wherein the Kingdom is involved, by the restless conspiracies of Popish Recusants against His Majesties Person, and the Religion and Government establisht do find themselves necessitated, to remind your Lordships for a speedy proceeding on the Bill before you entituled, an Act for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament, without which they think themselves unable to prepare any effectual remedies to prevent the Evils that hang over us.
The Lord Treasurer Reported, that the Lords with white Staves had presented Three Addresses to His Majesty.
1. For the removal of the Popish Families out of the Tower of London.
Which His Majesty hath already given directions for.
2. That which concerns Titus Oates, His Majesty will take Order he shall have servants and supplies for his necessary occasions, towards which he hath already had some Money.

3. As to the Address of a Reward to such Person or Persons as shall discover what is become of Mr. Powel, who hath been sometime missing, and of whom there are strong presumptions that he is murthered, His Majesty looks on this as imperfect, supposing the Reward is not intended to be given to such as shall discover where he is if Living, and having withdrawn himself upon his own occasions, but if he be murthered or detained
by any Persons that are guilty of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person or Government.

div.head: Die Martis 19. Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe House being moved, that a blank Order of Attachment of some Persons suspected to be guilty of the horrid design against His Majesties Person may be issued, and that the Lords Committees for Examining Witnesses in Order to the Discovery of the said horrid design against His Majesties Person may be intrusted to insert the names of the Persons to be Attached, as also of the Persons who shall Execute the said Order to prevent a discovery and escape of the said Persons, upon consideration had thereof, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that such a blank Order of Attachment, shall be issued so as among the names to be inserted, the said Lords Committees insert not the name of any Peer of this Realm to be attached by vertue thereof.

The Lord Carington being in his place, acquainted the House that he was informed his name was spoke of in the House of Commons, as if he had been guilty of the horrid design against His Majesty, which he abhors, and that His Lordship hears there is a Warrant out against him from the Lord Chief Justice of England, his Lordship pleaded his innocence and submitted himself to their Lordships pleasure.

Hereupon the House sent to the Lord Chief Justice to come, that they may receive an account from him of the business, who being come did let the House know that being sent for Yesterday by the House of Commons, he took the Examination of William Bedloe upon Oath in the Speakers Chamber, who (among other Persons) accused the Lord Carington to be with several other considerable Persons, in a confederacy for raising money and men to carry on the design against the Kings Person and Governmenr. And that William Bedloe said in his Examination he knew the Lord Brudnel and that he is in the Conspiracy, and that the Lord Brudnel told Bedloe he was then going into the North to further it, and that the Lord Carington was to raise Five Thousand Pound, and a proportionable number of men to joyn therein with the Lord Bellasis, that the Lord Chief Justice did issue out his Warrant for
the Lord Carington to come before him, and delivered it to the high Constable, who was to seek the Lord Carington late last night and early this Morning, but could not meet with him, that the Lord Chief Justice did intend to come yesterday to give this House an account of his proceedings, but the House was up.

After consideration had hereof, the ensuing question being put, whether that the Lord Carington should be Committed to the custody of the Black Rod, upon the Information given by the Lord Chief Justice, it was resolved in the Affirmative.

Upon Information received this day from the Lord Chief Justice of England, concerning the Lord Carington a Member of this House, It is resolved by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Lord Carington shall stand Committed to the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House, there to remain in safe custody till further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

This Day Charles Price, who was one of those Persons sent for to be taken into custody by the Serjeant at Arms, about the late horrid design was brought to the Bar, and being asked whether he knew Mr. Spalding the under Governor of Chepstow Castle, he said he did, then he was told, that he was charged with confederacy to deliver up Chepstow Castle to the Earl of Powis, which he denyed, was Ordered to withdraw, whereupon the House made this Order.

Whereas Charles Price, who was to be taken into custody by the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, hath this day appeared at the Bar denying what is charged on him, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Charles Price shall stand committed to the Prison of the Kings Bench, there to remain in safe custody till further Order, and that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, or his Deputies take care to convey him to the said Prison, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Lord Chancellor told the Lord Carington what the House had resolved concerning him, and upon what grounds, and asked him whether he had any thing further to say at this time, and his Lordship said not, only submitted himself to their Lordships pleasure.

Then the House was adjourned into a Committee, to proceed in the further consideration of the Bill, for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty, the House was resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the House have spent some time in consideration of the said Bill,
and are now ready to Report the same when the House shall please to appoint, and the House Ordered the said Report to be made to morrow Morning.

Upon the Petition of the Earl of Powis now a Prisoner in the Tower for Treason, praying that some Writings of his (which being seized are now in the custody of the Clerk of the Parliaments) may be viewed, and that such of them as relate only to private Persons settlements and concerns may be restored to him, It is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Sir Andrew Hacket Knight one of the Masters in Chancery, be and is hereby Authorized and appointed to peruse the said Writtings and sort them, so that what of the said Writings shall appear to be only of private concern, to particular Persons settlements of Estates, may by order of this House be delivered to the Earl of Powis, or such Person as he shall appoint to receive the same.

The Lord Treasurer Reported, that the Lords with White Staves have presented to His Majesty the second Address for a General Pardon, and considerable Reward to be given to such Person or Persons as shall discover what is become of Mr. Powel, who hath been sometime missing, and of whom there are strong presumptions that he is murthered. His Majesty observes this Address to be imperfect in the same manner as the first Address was, but His Majesty understanding what your Lordships mean by it, if it be left to him, will do thereon what shall be fitting, which the House agreed to.
The Lord Treasurer acquainted the House, that Mr. Oates had sent to him for Two Hundred Pound, whereas he hath had paid him already One Hundred and Twenty Pound, to supply his necessities.
The House left it to His Majesty.

div.head: Die Mercurii 20. Novembris 1678.
div.p: Hodie secunda vice licita est Billa, an Act requiring the Persons therein named to render themselves to Justice, and in default thereof to attaint them of High Treason.

The Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee have spent many days in consideration of the Bill, for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Kingdom, wherein
the Committee have made several alterations, and his Lordship shewed the grounds and reasons thereof, which were offered to the consideration of the House,
The Amendments were twice read as followeth.

1. sk 21 l, leave out from (right) to (shall) in the 32 l and read (every person that now is or hereafter shall be a Peer of this Realm or Member of the House of Peers, and every Person that now is or hereafter shall be a Member of the House of Commons.)
33 l leave out the word (first)

2 sk 25 l After (beginning) add and that from and after the said first day of December, no person that now is or hereafter shall be a Peer of this Realm or Member of the House of Peers, shall Vote or make his Proxy in the House of Peers, or sit there during any debate in the said House of Peers, until such Peer or Member of the House of Peers, shall first take the said several Oathes, nor any person that now is or hereafter shall be a Member of the said House of Commons, shall vote in the said House of Commons, or sit there during any debate in the said House of Commons after their Speaker is chosen, until such member shall from time to time respectively, and in the manner following take the said several Oathes and make, subscribe, and audibly repeat the Declaration aforesaid.
32 l. leave out (before he take his place in the said House of Peers.)
4 sk. 14 l. leave out (and shall be disabled from thenceforth to sit or vote in either House of Parliament, or make a Proxy in the House of Peers) 21 l. instead of (Administror) read (Administrator.)
30 l. After (lye) add (and every Person that now is or hereafter shall be a Member of the House of Commons so offending, shall be disabled from thenceforth to sit or vote in the House of Commons.)
5 sk 7 and 8 l. leave out (and subscribing the said Declaration.)

15 l. After (Parliament) add (provided that nothing in this Act contained shall be deemed, construed or taken to seclude or restrain any Peer or Member of the House of Peers, who shall take the said Oathes of Supremacy and Allegiance from sitting or voting or making his Proxy in the said House of Peers, nor shall any such Peer or Member of the said House of Peers, as shall refuse to take the said Oathes of Supremacy and Allegiance, or either of them in our any other penalty; forfeiture or disability
then such as are expresly and particularly by this present Act inflicted, and imposed any thing in this Act contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding)
7 sk 4 l. After (now is) read (or hereafter shall be.)

5 l. After (Majesty) add (nor to such servants of the Queen as Her Majesty shall under her hand and seal frem time to time for that purpose think fit to nominate, the persons so nominated, not at any one time exceeding the number of Nine of her Women Servants, and the number of Twelve of her Men Servants, nor to such Persons as are or shall be Servants, attending upon Her Royal Highness of York being Italians by Birth, nor to such Servants of Her said Royal Highness, as she under her hand and seal shall from time to time for that purpose nominate, the Persons so nominated Men or Women not exceeding Ten in number at any one time. And be it further enacted by the Authority aforesaid, that no person to be nominated for the future being a Popish Recusant, shall be capable of serving the Queens Majesty in the places of Chamberlain or Master of the Horse to Her Majesty, other than the present Master of the Horse, but from thenceforth such person shall be utterly disabled from serving Her Majesty in the said places or either of them.
Upon debate of these Amendments, the Question being put whether to agree with the Committee in the Amendments of the first Paragraph, it was resolved in the Negative.
Then the rest of the Amendments were read, and those Amendments which have any Relation to the Amendments in the first Paragraph were not agreed to.
The word (Adminstrator) for (Administror) agreed to.
The Amendments concerning the Queens and the Dutchess of Yorks Servants are agreed to

After this a proviso was offered to the House to be added to this Bill, which was read twice (viz) provided always that nothing in this Act contained, shall extend to his Royal Highness the Duke of York.
And after debate this Question was proposed whether this proviso read twice shall be made a part of the Bill.
Then this previous Question was put whether this Question shall be now put, it was Resolved in the Affirmative.
Then the main Question was put whether this proviso read twice shall be made a part of this Bill, it was Resolved in the Affirmative.
Hodie tertia vice licita est Billa, an Act for the more effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The Question being put, whether this Bill with the Amendments
and proviso now read, shall pass, it was Resolved in the Affirmative.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Captain Archbald Duglas be and is hereby Authorized, and permitted forthwith to pass hence on his direct way to Flanders without the let, stay or interruption of him in his Journey, and passage thither by any Person or Persons whatever. And this shall be a sufficient warrant on that behalf.

Upon Report from the Lords Committees for Examining Persons in Order, to the discovery of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, that Le Lieure (for the apprehending of whom a warrant hath been issued by the Lord Privy Seal and Marquess of Winton) resideth in His Majesties Royal Palace at St. James's, so that the warrant cannot be Executed, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Chamberlain of His Majesties Houshold do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, that the said Lieure may be brought before the said Lords Committees.

The Marquess of Winton acquainted the House, that Mr. Bedloe had informed the Committee for Examining of Papers, that the place where he is lodged in Whitehall is under ground and damp, which is a great prejudice to his Health, therefore desires he may be accommodated with a better Lodging, the Lord Chamberlain of His Majesties Houshold told the House he will use the best care he can to provide a better Chamber for him.

div.head: Die Jovis 21. Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe Lord Marquess of Winton Reported two Examinations, one of Oliver du Fiquetts, the other of Francis Verdier, which were read as followeth.

1. La Columbiere Jesuit and Preacher to the Dutchess, hath for the space of three moneths had frequent Communications with Mr. Coleman, who came every day to communicate with him in his Chamber from Eleven in the Morning till midday.
Further, that Mr. La Columbiere sent his Servant Lieure to stay in the Country for the space of two moneths and an half, and took to his Service the Nephew of Mr. Coleman betwixt Thirteen and Fourteen Years old. And after that Mr. Coleman was put in Prison, Mounsieur La Columbiere took his Servant again and sent away the Nephew of Mr. Coleman and went to live in the Country, Further I know that Mounsieur La Columbiere hath great Correspondence with Father Le Chese, and with Cardinal Bovillon.

2. Monsieur La Columbiere told me to induce me to his Religion, that if I made so much difficulty the King would not hinder me to make choice of the Roman Catholick Religion, seeing he knew very well that the King was a Catholick in his Heart.

3. Furthermore, when I represented to him that the Parliament would not suffer pervertion in England, Monsieur La Columbiere said to me, that if the Parliament opposed Roman Catholicks, the King would dissolve it, and further that the Parliament should not be always Master, he told me also that I should see in a little time all England changed, which also was confirmed to me many times by his Servant.

4. And as I had a design to go study at Oxford in order to be a Minister, he turned me from it in representing to me that if I went to study at Oxford, I should fill my mind with the Errors, which the Divinity of Oxford teacheth contrary to the Holy Scripture, and if I would return into France, he would by the means of Father La Chese Jesuit and Confessor to the King of France place me to study in the Colledge of Clermont, and also that he did write to Paris to a Jesuit in the absence of Father La Chese, whose answer I read my self in Monsieur La Columbiers Chamber, and also that he had told the Duke of York that he had turned me from my purpose of being a Minister, and said that his Highness exprest much satisfaction in it, which surprized me much, but then Monsieur La Columbiere told me that I ought not to wonder at that, seeing his Highness was a Catholick and received often the Sacraments, this also was confirmed to me by his Servant.

5. Moreover Monsieur La Columbiere hath received many abjurations in his Chamber as well of French as of English, and also I spoke in his Chamber with an English Gentleman whom he sent into France to pervert by means of Cardinal Bovillon.

6. That Monsieur Drevill a French man carryed to Monsieur La Columbiere an English Merchant to pervert him, whom
Monsieur La Columbiere was to send into France and his Family to the Cardinal Bovillon.

7. That Monsieur La Columbiere sends secretly Priests into Virginia, amongst others Maccarty an Irish Priest, who was carryed by La Columbiers Servant, and by his Order to Monsieur La Choquee who lives at the Savoy, and also La Columbiere told me that he desired to go thither.
This is all that I can affirm upon Oath.
8. Furthermore, that La Columbiere hath made Mass to be said at Mr. Robert Angiers by Macharty every Sunday and Holy day and also in the Country.

9. That La Columbiere hath seduced Monsieur Salamon a Minister at the Savoy to put him into a Convent, and another Person that was come with an intention to enter into the Ministry, La Columbiere hath sent them into France, and gave them money in Picardy in his Servant Lieures house, and then they were to pass to Rome by the means of Cardinal Bovillon.
This is all I can affirm upon Oath, and in the presence of the parties.

closer.dateline:
Capt & jurat.
Novemb. 16. 1678. coram me Winchester.

div.p: Francis Verdier saith that about Five or Six Moneths since he was at Columbiers Chamber with Mr. Fiquet, and there heard the said Columbiere speak to Mr. Fiquet perswading him to become a Catholick using Arguments for it, whereupon the aforesaid Fiquet said though all were true that he urged, yet it was not fit for him in this Country while the King would not permit it, to which the said Columbiere replyed that the King would not take it ill if the said Fiquet should turn Catholick, for that the King was himself a Catholick in his Heart.

closer.dateline: Sworn this 19th day of November 1678. Anglesey.

div.p: Whereupon the House made the ensuing Order.

Upon Report made from the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Persons for the discovery of the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, that upon the Examinations of Oliver Du Fiquet and Francis Verdier taken upon Oath, it appeareth, that La Columbiere (a Jesuit and Preacher to the Dutchess) now Prisoner in the Kings-Bench hath held frequent and long communications with Mr. Coleman, and hath great correspondence with Father Le-Cheese
and with Cardinal Bovillo, and that he hath endeavored to pervert the said Oliver Du Fiquet, and Francis Verdier and others to the Popish Religion, using Arguments of a dangerous nature for that purpose, and hath in his Chamber received many abjurations of Persons as well French as English, and that he hath secretly sent Priests into Virginia, of whom Maccarty an Irish Priest was one, all which matters being of dangerous consequence, and in opposition to the Peace and Government of this Kingdom, it is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, that the said La Columbiere may be Banished out of this Kingdom, and all other His Majesties Territories and Dominions whatsoever.

Upon Report made from the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Persons for discovering of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, that Thomas Morgan who came out of York shire to inform of the design to Burn His Majesties Fleet, hath been Wounded and in danger of being murthered (by persons yet unknown) since his coming to Town, and is in want of necessaries, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do wait on His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House that His Majesty will be pleased to give order to the Lord Treasurer, to consider of the present necessities of the said Thomas Morgan, and to make such allowance of money for supply thereof as shall to His Majesty seem fitting.

The Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee have considered the Bill for attainting Conyers and others, if they do not come in by a certain day, the Opinion of the Committee is that the name of Beeston be left out of the Bill, he having rendred himself, and with this Amendment the Committee think fit the said Bill be engrossed.
The House agreed with the Committee in this report and ordered the Bill to be engrossed

Whereas Thomas Biston alias Beeston, being one of the Persons required by His Majesties Proclamation (for apprehending certain offenders therein named, and for the better security of His Majesty and his Government from dangers arising from Popish Recusants) to render themselves to Justice, did before the issuing of the said Proclamation render himself to the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Persons for the discovery of the horrid Plot against His Majesties Person and
Government, where he was Examined and acquitted by their Lordships, and the House of Peers upon Report made thereof, have g • ven Order for the leaving the name of the said Thomas Biston alias Beeston, out of the Bill of Attainder of the Persons therein named now depending in this House, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Thomas Biston alias Beeston, be and is hereby discharged from any further attendance concerning this matter▪ and hath liberty to repair to his Charge as a Soldier for taking the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy and Test, and receiving the Sacrament of the Lords Supper according to the usage of the Church of England.

The House being informed, that Captain Francis Spalding Deputy Governor of Chepstow Castle was attending without, he was called in, and being brought in by the Serjeant at Arms, he was told that he is accused for being a Papist, and for having been at Mass in Sommerset house, to which he said he is not a Papist, and that he hath not been at Sommerset-house these seven years, but once to see the Captain of the Guards about a year and half since, and being asked whether he knows Mr. Charles Price, he confessed he did, but being charged with a Conspiracy to render up Chepstow Castle to the Earl of Powis he denyed it, and further said he knows not his Lordship nor ever received any Letter from him.

Then William Bedloe being brought to the Bar with him, said, that Captain Spalding was to deliver up Chepstow Castle to Charles Winter for the Earl of Powis, and being asked how he knew it, he said Sir Henry Tichborne told him so at Paris about two years since, and Walsh and Le Phaire told him so also, and that Captain Spalding told him three years since upon the Road travelling with him toward Abergavenny, that the Lord Brudnel had got him into Chepstow Castle upon that Design, to which Captain Spalding said he never heard any thing of the delivery of Chepstow Castle to Charles Winter till now.

Then James Bedloe (Brother to William Bedloe) being called in and sworn, said he saw Captain Spalding at Mass in Sommerset-house about three years ago, and being asked whether he saw him kneel or beat his Breast▪ he said he saw him in the posture of bowing as other People were with his hand on his Breast.

Then Captain Spalding denyed this Accusation, and said, that he goes to Church, and that about Four years since he received the Sacrament and Test, and hath a Certificate of it, but he cannot say he hath received the Sacrament since.
Upon which they being withdrawn the Lords made this following Order.

Whereas Francis Spalding, who was to be taken into custody by the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, hath this day appeared at the Bar, denying what is charged on him, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Francis Spalding shall stand committed to the Prison of the Kings-bench, there to remain in safe Custody till further Order, and that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, or his Deputies take care to convey him to the said Prison, and this shall be a sufficient warrant on that behalf.

Whereas Charles Winter was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Armes, and there heard what he had to say in answer to those matters wherewith he was charged by William Bedloe, after consideration had thereof, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Charles Winter be and is hereby discharged from any further restraint concerning the same, and this shall be a sufficient warrant on that behalf.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Bridgewater from the Lords Committees, for Examining the Journal of this House, that upon Examinations thereof, their Lordships find that the Narrative made by Titus Oates at the Bar on the one and Thirtieth of October last, of the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, is only mentioned in the Journal, and not entred at large in such manner as he then related it, and that therefore their Lordships desire the direction of this House concerning this matter, it is thereupon Ordered, that the said Narrative made by Titus Oates on the said one and Thirtieth day of October last shall be entred at large, and inserted in the Journal as a part of the business of that day.

Upon reading the Petition of Nathaniel Thompson Printer, now Prisoner in the Gate-house, for Printing Popish Books acknowledging his Offence, and with sorrow begging pardon for the same, and praying that he may be restored to his Liberty, without which his Wife and Children will be ruined, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Nathaniel Thompson shall appear and give good security before the Lord Chief Justice of England, for his the said Thompsons being of the good Behavior according to the Act concerning Printing, and that thereupon the said Nathaniel Thompson be discharged from his present Imprisonment, and this shall be a sufficient warrant on that behalf.

The House being moved, that the Lady Brudnel Wife of
the Lord Brudnel, now Prisoner in the Kings-bench, by warrant of the Lord Chief Justice of England may have have leave to come to Town, and remain with her Husband the Lord Brudnel, it is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lady Brudnel be and is hereby authorized and permitted to come to Town, and abide with her said Husband the Lord Brudnel in the Prison of the Kings bench, without restraint as a Prisoner

William Bedloe at the Bar, complained of a mistake in his pardon granted to him by the Kings Majesty, and that by the omission of the word (non) before (molestetur) he was • yable to further trouble, upon which the Lord Chancellor •• ld him, that if there were such a mistake, it might be rectifyed in the Kings presence, and the Pardon should then be sealed again, but upon Examination of the patent before His Majesty by his Attorney in this House, it appeared that the Pardon is as it ought to be, and that the mistake arose from the misreading of (volentes) instead of (nelentes) upon which the Lord Chancellor declared to him at the Bar, that the Pardon is good and as it ought to be, and so caused it to be delivered to him at the Bar.
Ordered, that this House will be in a Committee to morrow Morning, to consider of heads for a Bill, for the better securing the Protestant Religion, and to be the first business.

div.head: Die Veneris 22. Novembris 1678.
div.p: UPon Report made by the Earl of Essex from the Lords Committees, appointed to inspect Mr. Colemans and other Persons Papers and Letters, that their Lordships have not power to deliver Papers or Letters over to the Kings Attorney, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Lords Committees have hereby power given them to deliver over to His Majesties Attorney General, such Papers and Letters as they shall find necessary for his use, in order to his preparing Evidence against such Persons as are to be tryed.

The Earl of Essex further Reported, that the Lords Committees
in perusing of Mr. Colemans Letters had found some Letters, written in a mystical expression which were read.

The House was adjourned into a Committee to consider of heads for a Bill, or Bills for securing the Protestant Religion, the House was resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Commmittee finding the Order for this business not large enough desires the former Order may be renewed, that the same words may be exprest viz. to consider of such proposals, as shall be offered for the preservation of His Majesties Person and the safety of the Kingdom, and securing of the Protestant Religion, which Ordered, then the House was again put into a Committee for that purpose, and after some consideration the House was Resumed.
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Powel, &c.

1. To let their Lordships know that the Commons have prepared an Address to be presented to His Majesty, for using some part of the Militia of the Kingdom, to which their Lordships concurrence is desired.
2. To put their Lordships in mind of an Address to His Majesty, for Printing some of Mr. Colemans Papers.

The aforesaid Address was read, and Committed to these Lords following, to inspect and consider of the statutes for the Militia, in relation to the number of days for keeping up the Forces of this Kingdom, and to make Report thereof to the House to morrow Morning.
Lord Privy Seal.
Lord Great Chamberlain, &c.
And all Lords who are Lords Lieutenants.
Their Lordships or any three of them to meet at three of the Clock this Afternoon in the Princes Lodgings.

div.head: Die Sabbati 23. Novembris 1678.
div.p:
THe Lord Chancellor acquainted the House, that Mr. Secretary Coventry hath sent him a Pacquet of Letters directed to John Grove, which His Majesty hath read, and if the House please they may be delivered to the Lords Committees, for Examination of the discovery of the horrid design against
His Majesties Person and the Government, that they may make such publick use of them as they see cause, which was Ordered accordingly.

The Earl of Peterborough Reported, the opinion of the Committee appointed to inspect and consider the statutes for the Militia, in relation to the number of days for keeping up the Forces of this Kingdom in one year. That upon inspection of the Acts for the Militia, the Militia cannot be kept up above Twelve days in one year, and therefore Four days to be for principal Musters, and two and two, and two and two (viz) Eight days on particular Musters, and of the Twelve days in many Counties the Lieutenants have already exercised and Mustered their men some of those days in this present year, not but that by His Majesties directions (as appears by the statutes) they may be kept up longer, but their Lordships do not find that there is any power to raise money to maintain them.

Ordered, to have a Conference with the House of Commons to acquaint them with what their Lordships have done therein, and to let them know that this House will be ready to joyn with them herein, so far as they can by Law.
The Lord Marquess of Winton Reported, an Examination taken by him, which was read viz.
Joseph Francklyn living on the Bank-side near the Falcon in Southwark Glasier sworn, and Examined before my Lord Marquess of Winton the two and twentieth day of November 1678.

That Thursday the seventh of November he found a Letter in Chancery-lane, directed to the Duke of Norfolk to advise him to be out of Town, for there should be such a stroak to the Enemies of the Church as never any the like since the Creation, that in the Afternoon he carryed the said Letter to the Councel.

That the very same night two men pretending to be the Duke of Norfolks Servants, one of them came to this Deponent first, and told him there was one at the Falcon Tavern desired to speak a word or two with him, this Deponent asked him who it was, and he said it was the Duke of Norfolks Chaplain, and this Deponent refusing to go, he told this Deponent he must go, and begun to make a bustle about his door and called for an Officer, but afterwards there came a Person with him in a Ministers habit, who asked this Deponent, if he was the man that found the Letter directed to the Duke of Norfolk, and after some discourse about it, they told this Deponent that it was a dishonor to their Lord, and should be of
ill consequence to him this Deponent, and that the Devil had not rewarded his Servants well this bout.

dateline.hi: Capt. & jurat dic & Anno pred. coram me Winchester.

div.p: Upon reading the Examination of Joseph Francklyn taken by the Marquess of Winton, and by his Lordship reported to the House concerning a Letter, and some passages betwixt the said Joseph Francklyn and Mr Cuthbert Brown Chaplain, and Richard Revel Footman to the Duke of Norfolk concerning the said Letter, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Joseph Francklyn, and Christopher Mitchel, and Anne his Wife, and such other Persons as the said Francklyn can produce, who heard the said passages be and are hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House, on Monday the Five and Twentieth day of this instant November at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, at which time also the said Cuthbert Browne, and Richard Revel are also required to attend this House.

The Earl of Essex Reported, that the Lords Committees have collected some of the most principal Papers of Mr. Coleman, and have delivered them to Mr. Attorney General to be made use of at the Tryal of Mr. Coleman, also his Lordship Reported, that the Committee desires that they may have liberty to peruse the Papers and Letters of those Lords who are in the Tower.

Hereupon It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Persons and Papers, concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, be and are hereby impowered to peruse all the Papers and writings, of the Earl of Powis, Lord Arundel of Warder, and Lord Bellasis Prisoners in the Tower, which being seized are now in the Custody of the Clerk of the Parliaments, and to give the House an account thereof▪

His Lordship further Reported, that William Bedloe had been with the Lords Committees, and that the name of Charles Milbourn for George Milbourn is mistaken. Ordered that the said George Milbourn be Attached.
Ordered, that the Lord Viscount Hallifax is added to the Committee for inspecting Mr. Colemans Letters.
A Letter of one John Zeal a Prisoner in Newgate, formerly a P • ge to Sir Francis Ratcliffe read, wherein he chargeth Sir Francis Ratcliffe for speaking dangerous words some years ago.

A Letter of John Wolmer written to Mr. Harris is read, informing that at Stratford upon Avon two persons were staid there, who having been offered to take the Oath of Allegiance refused to take it, one his name is John Gerard supposed to be a Priest and had come from the Lord Carington's house, the name of the other they cannot learn.
Ordered, that this Letter is referred to the Lords Committees for Examinations to be made use of as they shall see cause.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House or his Deputy or Deputies, do forthwith repair to Stratford upon Avon in Warwick▪shire, and bring thence the Body of Mr. John Gerrard supposed to be a Priest, and one other person mentioned but not named (in a Letter dated there the Twentieth of this instant November) and subscribed Simon Cale Major, John Wolmer, in which it is recited that they were in Custody there for refusing the Oath of Allegiance, and bring them in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Marquess of Winton Reported, that a Priest was brought before the Committee for Examinations, who pretended that he belonged to the Spanish Ambassador, who their Lordships are Informed hath Forty Eight Priests belonging to him, therefore their Lordships desire that the Spanish Ambassador may be moved to give a list of his Chaplains to this House.

Hereupon it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to desire every Forreign Minister now residing here, to give to His Majesty a List of the number and names of such Priests as he shall own to be his Chaplains, and the places of their abode.
A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Samuel Clerk, and Sir John Hoskins, to desire a present Conference in the Painted Chamber concerning the Address concerning the Militia.

The Lord Privy Seal Reported, that the Mannagers of this conference have delivered what they were commanded to the Commons, and told them their Lordships will be ready to joyn with them so far as the Law in this case extends.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees for Examining Persons and Papers, concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, are hereby appointed • o
prepare an Address to be presented to His Majesty, for the seizing and apprehending of all Jesuits and other Popish Priests, expressing the grounds and reasons thereof at this time, and that they may be tryed, but that after that Tryal the Execution may be respited till His Majesties pleasure may be further signifyed, and Report the same to the House on Monday Morning.

The House was adjourned into a Committee to consider of proposals, for the better preservation of His Majesties Person and Government, and securing the Protestant Religion, the House being resumed, the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee desires that a Bill may be prepared for the more speedy conviction of Popish Recusants, that the Refusal upon tender of the Declaration may be a conviction, hereupon the House Ordered, that the Lord Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas, be and is hereby appointed to prepare a Bill for the more speedy conviction of Popish Recusants (viz.) that the refusal upon tender of the Declaration recited in the Bill now depending in Parliament, Entituled an Act for the more effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament, shall be a conviction, and that every Justice of Peace be impowered to tender the said Declaration.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir William Jennings and others, to desire a Conference concerning the Amendments sent from their Lordships in the Bill, for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty &c.
Hodie tertia vice licita est Billa, an Act requiring the Persons therein named to render themselves to Justice, and in default thereof to attaint them of High Treason.
The Question being put whether this Bill shall pass, it was Resolved in the Affirmative.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Samuel Clerk and Sir John Hoskins, to deliver the Bill requiring the Persons therein named to render themselves to Justice, and in default thereof to attaint them of High Treason, to which the Lords desire the concurrence of the House of Commons.

The House was adjourned during pleasure and the Lords went to the conference, which being ended the House was resumed, then the Lord Chancellor Reported the effect of the conference, which was, that the House of Commons agrees to the proviso added by their Lordships to the Bill, for the more effectual preserving of His Majesties Person and Government, but as to the Amendments concerning the Servants of Her
Majesty and the Dutchess, they do not agree for these Reasons following.

p.hi: That both Houses having declared by their Vote, that the Kings Person is at this time in danger from Popish Conspiracies, it would not only be most dangerous to His Majesties Person, but inconsistent with such a Declaration to admit any Popish Recusant to have Residance in his Pallaces and such familiar access into His Majesties presence.

div.p: That all Popish Recusants being by His Majesties Proclamation issued at the desire of both Houses, required to depart Ten Miles from the Cities of London and Westminster, we cannot think it advisable to admit them now to continue in His Majesties Houses, where they may be of greater danger than in any other place.
That the design of this Act being for a further security against all Popish Recusants, the Commons cannot think it reasonable to allow any of them priviledge contrary to the Law already in being.

Your Lordships amendments, excepting by general words such a number of Servants of the Queen and Her Royal Highness, it will follow that if any Peers of this Kingdom or Members of the House of Commons be nominated by them, they will thereby be still capable of sitting and voting in the House of Peers or House of Commons, without taking the Oathes or Test.
As to the Amendment of the word (Administrator) being miswritten, the Commons do agree.
Upon consideration of the abovesaid Reasons, the Lords agreed to have a conference with the House of Commons, and propose unto them in the Sixth sk ten l, to leave out the words (or Queen.)
In the 7 sk 1 l, to leave out the proviso concerning the Queens Servants.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Samuel Clerk and Sir John Hoskins, to desire a present Conference with the House of Commons in the Painted Chamber, concerning the matter of the last Conference.
The Messengers return with this Answer, that the Commons will give a present conference as is desired.
The House was adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords went to the Conference, which being ended the House was resumed.
The Lord Mainard Reported, that the Lords with the white Staves presented to His Majesty two Addresses from this House.
1. For the Banishing of La Columbiere out of His Majesties Dominions.
Which His Majesty sayes he hath given Order for.
2. For some Allowance to be given to Thomas Morgan for his present subsistance.
His Majesty hath Ordered a piece of Money to be given him.

The Lord Chamberlain Reported, that he hath presented to His Majesty the humble Address for sending to every Forreign Minister, now residing here to give into His Majesty, a List of the number and names of such Priests as he shall own to be his Chaplains, and the places of their abode.
His Majesty sayes he will give Order for it accordingly.

Ordered, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, his Deputy or Deputies shall forthwith Attach the Body of Mr. George Milbourn of Winnerston near Monmouth, and bring him in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, to answer such matters as shall be objected against him on His Majesties behalf, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient warrant.
Hodie prima vice licita est Billa, an Act for the discovery and more speedy conviction of Popish Recusants.
This day Joseph Francklyn and others on his behalf, as also Mr. Cuthbert Brown Chaplain, and Richard Revel Footman to the Duke of Norfolk being summoned to attend, were called in.

Joseph Francklyn sworn, said, he did find a Letter in Chancery lane on Thursday Fortnight in the Morning directed to the Duke of Norfolk, and did open it at a Coffee house in Holborn, and afterwards the same day carryed it to the Privy Councel, and that that night one who said he was the Duke of Norfolks Servant came to him by the Falcon on the Bank-side, and told him, that the Duke of Norfolks Chaplain would speak with him at the Falcon Tavern, but he refusing to go, the said person told him he must go and called for a Constable, but then Mr. Brown the Chaplain came to his House, and asked whether he found the said Letter, and carryed it to the Councel, he owned it, Upon which the said Brown told him, it was ill done to shew it in a Coffee-house, it should be of ill consequence to him, and that the Devil had not befriended his Servants this bout.
Christopher Mitchel and Anne his Wife, sworn, averred they heard the said words uttered by Mr. Brown the Chaplain.

Then Richard Revel being Examined, said he went to Joseph Francklyn by the Duke of Norfolks direction, to inquire about the Letter (but by Order of the Duke to use him with
all kind words) and not to give any threatning Language, and told him the Dukes Chaplain would speak with him at the Falcon Tavern, but Francklyn refusing to go without an Officer he offered to call for a Constable, but before any came he called Mr. Brown.

Then Cuthbert Brown being Examined said, that having occasion to go to Southwark, the Duke desired him to speak with Francklyn about the Letter, but remembers not that the Duke gave him any particular Instructions.

That coming to Francklyn, he asked him if he was the man that found the Letter directed to the Duke of Norfolk, and delivered it to the Councel, Francklyn owned it, upon which he told him it might be of ill consequence to the Duke and not Francklyn, and denyes the words the Devil has not befriended his Servants this bout.

Upon consideration had thereof the said Guthbert Brown and Richard Revel being called in again, the Lord Chancellor by directions of the House, told them, that they had overacted their parts in this business, and not behaved themselves with that discretion that became them, and warned them to be more cautious for the future and so they were discharged.

Upon Report made by the Marquess of Winton from the Lords Committees, appointed to Examine Persons and Papers for discovery of the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, and their Lordships have perused all the Papers and Writings of the Lord Bellasis now Prisoner in the Tower, which being seized, were by Order of this House brought and delivered into the Custody of the Clerk of the Parliaments, and find not amongst them any Papers and Writings, but only such as are of private concernment. It is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Papers and Writings, may be delivered to the Lord Bellasis, or such Person or Persons as his Lordship shall appoint to receive the same, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient warrant.

The Serjeant at Armes gave the House an account, of what Prisoners are in his Custody Attached by Order of this House, it is Ordered that they be brought to the Bar, at such time as William Bedloe may be then present.

div.head: Die Martis 26. die Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe Marquess of Winton Reported, from the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Persons and Papers concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, the deposition of William Smith as followeth.

William Smith Wine-cooper being Sworn and Examined, saith, that Yesterday was sevennight betwixt Eleven and Twelve of the Clock, Mr. James Hoare of the Mint in the Tower, very importunately held this Deponent by the hand, and would make him go to Dinner with him to a Friends House of his who lives in Goodmans Fields, and this Deponent saith, that about three or four of the Clock after Dinner, the said Mr. Hoare took this Deponent again by the hand, and most importunately desired this Deponent, to go along with him to Mr. Thomas Beacons house a Merchant in Headen-yard in the Minories, and when this Deponent came first into the House there were about Seven or Eight men going out of a Room, when this Deponent and Mr. Hoare came into it, who went presently out of it, only Mr. Beacon stayed and entertained this Deponent, and Mr. Hoare very kindly, where they had brought two Bottles of Wine, and both the said Mr. Beacon and Mr. Hoare did return every glass of Wine to this Deponent, with these words, confusion to the Pope, and did both of them express a very great kindness unto this Deponent, and Mr. Hoare did often kiss him, and taking him by the hand said (Will) thou art a very honest man, I dare trust thee with any thing, and told this Deponent, that he had Two Hundred Blunderbusses and other Armes at his House already. This Deponent then being willing to go away, and as he was going to the Door he found it locked, and the said Mr. Beaeon pretended it was out of kindness to keep him there, but this deponent did observe the said Mr. Beacon and Hoare to whisper often together, and afterwards Mr. Hoare said there is one of the Hereticks, whereupon this Deponent desired earnestly to go forth, and begged of him for Gods sake to let him goe, but Mr. Beacon told this Deponent he should go and see his house first, in the mean time Mr. Hoare slipped forth of the Rome and after Mr. Hoare was gone, Mr. Beacon carried this Deponent to a Door of a Rome, and being opened, this Deponent saw about a dozen men as he believeth all in disguise, standing in a cluster and whispering together, Mr. Beacon then did thrust this Deponent into them saying, there is a Heritick for you, whereupon this Deponent
with being great earnestness upon his knees that they would let him go, and after a little time they did let this Deponent go, but told him if he talk of this or make any Discovery of it, he this Deponent should not live, and this Deponent further saith, that several times since, Divers Persons have come to his house, and told him that such and such Persons have been at Taverns to speak with him, but this Deponent being afraid to go himself hath sent some body to inquire who they were, and could never meet with any, that this Deponent doth apprehend it was a Design only to Trappan him forth and do him mischief.

closer.dateline: Capt. & Jurat. 26. Novembris 1678. Coram me Winchester.

div.p: whereupon the House made the ensuing Order.

Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House his Deputy or Deputies be and is hereby required immediately to repair to the house of Mr. Beacon a Merchant in the Minories, and to the house or lodging of Mr. James Hoare the younger in the Tower, and make a diligent search, for Arms in the said places, and seize and secure such Arms as he or they shall find there and give this House an account thereof, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Then the Lord Treasurer gave the House an account of the order directed to some of the Deputy Lieutenants of the North and West Ridings of York-shire in Informations, which his Lordship hath received here, which are read, viz.

The information of Thomas Scott of North Oaram in the County of York Clothier, taken upon Oath the 20th. Day of November 1678. Before us, three of His Majesties Justices of the Peace, for the West Riding of the County aforesaid.

Saith that being at Dighton neer Hothers Field in the West Riding aforesaid, on the the 3d. of November Instant, and going out of the house, where he then was, between the hours of Ten & Eleaven of the Clock in the Night, there passed Men riding by him towards Leedes three and three a Brest, to the Number of 200 and upwards to the best of his judgment, and how many more there might be in company this informant cannot tell, in regard they were going fast by as he came out of the House. but whether they were Armed or No this Deponent cannot depose it, being then very dark, and this informant further saith, that he hath been told, that they were seen by several Persons in that Town besides himself that Night, and that they went towards Leedes.
The information of Thomas Palmer of Hunslett Hall, and Edward Walmsley his Nephew of the same, taken upon Oath before us the 22th. Day of November 1678.

These informants say that upon Sunday in the Night (towards morning) being the third Day of this Instant November as they lay in their Beds (their house standing very neer the Road) they heard a great Noise of Horse passing by, whereupon the said Thomas Palmer rose and looked out of the Window, but it was so dark that he could see nothing, nor here any man speak or make the least noise, and these informants both of them say, thas there was so great a Number of Horse, that they were about half an hour in passing by, and they perceived as they passed by (they going so very near the Window) that they were not ordinary horses, such as Pack horses and those that usually pass on that Road, but lusty, able and well spirited horses as they thought by the stomping and noise of their feet, and further saith not.
Then the Duke of Monmouth gave the House an account of an information he had received out of Buckingham shire, which was likewise read as followeth.

The infomation of Thomas White of Aston Clinton Husband-man, taken upon Oath before me Georg Russel one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace, for the County of Buckingham shire November the 24 th. 1678.

That upon Wednesday the 20th. Day of this instant November 1678. the said Thomas Whlte and Henry Dancer of the aforesaid Aston Clinton, being about the houre of seven a clock in the Night a Birding in the Meadow called Chicken Mead, in the Parish of Aston Clinton, the said Thomas White did discover coming towards them over the said Meadow (the Moon then being about half an hour high) several men on Horseback, and thereupon called to his Companion Henry Dancer to look upon them, which the said White and Dancer both did whilst the greatest part of them passed by, and the said White said that they marched in a brest together, those that came formost, and immediately after them one other Ranck within four or five yards and so one ranck or range after another with great Silence, till they were all gone by, which they judged to be between Sixty and Eighty, and when they were gone about three Quarters of a Furlong beyond the said White and Dancer, they made all a stop together in the said Mead, and the said White and Dancer being
then afraid got through a hedge, and so went away from the said place leaving them there, not knowing what they were, nor whence they came, and the Wind being somthing high could not hear any thing they said.

The above said Thomas White and Henry Dancer are both of them reputed by their Neighbours who are well known to me, to be sober, honest men, and not likely to cause any such story if it were not true, and is therefore believed by all that have heard it.
Then the Duke of Monmouth let the House know that His Majesty hath seen this Examination, and hath given order to send out some horse to inquire after those persons.

Upon Report made by the E. of Essex, from the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Persons & Papers, for the Discovery of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person & Government, that their Lordships have perused all the Papers a • d Writings of the Earl of Powis now a Prisoner in the Tower, which being seized were by order of this House brought and delivered into the Custody of the Clerk of the Parliament, and find not any Papers or Writings in the least relating to the horrid design, they being Papers meerly of private Concern, it is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Papers and Writings may be delivered to the Earl of Powis, or such Person or Persons as his Lordship shall appoint to receive the same, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Booth and others, who brought up a Bill intituled an Act for preserving the Peace of the Kingdom, by raising the Militia and continuing them in Duty for 42 Dayes.
To which the Commons desire their Lordships concurrence.
2 To desire a Conference touching the matter of the late Conference.
The answer returned was, that the Lords will give a Conference as is desired, and appoint the same to be presently in the painted Chamber.
Hodie prima vice licita est Billa an Act for preserving the Peace of the Kingdom, by raising the Militia and continuing them in Duty for 42 Dayes
The same Lords as mannaged the last Conference are to be Reporters of this.
The House was adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords went to the Conference, which being ended the House was resumed.
The Lord Chancellor Reported the Effect of the Conference as followeth.
That the House of Commons do not agree with their Lordships in that matter, nor form as was delivered at the last Conference and that for these reasons,

That it is contrary to the constant method and proceedings in Parliament, to strike out any thing in a Bill, which hath been fully agreed and passed by both Houses, and it would make the work endless, and might also be of dangerous consequence, if that method should be deserted and changed.

In the amendments proposed to the Bill by your Lordships, to which the Commons have disagreed the Number of the Queens Servants to be Excepted out of the act was limited, but by leaving the Queens name out of the Bill, She may have them without number, so that what is now Offered is worse than what the Commons have already disagreed to, & consequently hath not the nature of an expedient.

That by experience it is found, that the act intituled an act for preventing Dangers, which may happen from Popish Recusants proved ineffectual to remove Papists from Court, by reason there was no express mention'd of the Queens Servants.

The Scope of the Bill relateth not onely to remove Papists out of both Houses of Parliament, but also from the Court, as appeareth both by the preamble and body of the Bill, and the Danger of His Majesty may reasonably be supposed to be chiefly in his Court and the safety of his person, the Commons think ought more to be considered, then any respects to any person whatsoever.
Therefore the Commons say they cannot agree with your Lordships, neither in the expedient nor amendments.
The Lords taking the matter of the aforesaid Conference into consideration; and well weighing what great concernment this Bill was of, came to these Resolutions following.
It is agreed to insist on that amendment (or hereafter shall be)

The question being put whether any number of men Servants, that are the Kings Subjects and Roman Catholicks shall be insisted upon to be the Queens Servants, and be part of the Bill, it was Resolved in the Negative.
Agreed to insist that the Queen shall have Nine women Servants Roman Catholicks.
Agreed to insist that the Dutchess of York shall have Five women Servants Roman Catholicks.
And these expedients to be proposed at a Conference with the House of Commons and Offered as new Amendments, and the old Amendments to be laid aside.
Ordered, To have a Conference with the House of Commons this Afternoon.

div.head: Die Martis 26 Novembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p: HOdie secunda vice licita est Billa, an Act for the better discovery and speedier conviction of Popish Recusants.
Ordered, that the consideration of this Bill is committed to the same Committee appointed, for the Bill concerning the Militia.
The Serjeant at Arms gave the House this account, that he hath searched the houses of Mr. James Hoare and Mr. Beacon, but can find no Arms in neither of their houses.
The House was adjourned into a Committee to consider of the proposals for the preservation of the Kings Person and Government, and securing the Protestant Religion.

The Lord Chancellor Reported, that he had delivered to the House of Commons at this conference the new Amendments, made by their Lordships concerning the Servants of Her Majesty and Her Royal Highness, which the Commons will consider of.

Ordered, that the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Justices of the Peace, Constables Church-wardens and other Parish Officert, entrusted with the execution of His Majesties late Proclamation, commanding all Persons being Popish Recusants or so Reputed, to depart from the Cities of London and Westminster and all other places within Ten Miles of the same, be and are hereby strictly required to give a speedy account to this House what they have done in persuance thereof, and particularly that those therein concerned by this day sevennight give an account, of the Names of what Papists as well House-holders as Inmates and Lodgers are now in London, Westminster and Southwark, and the respective liberties thereof, and of what Nations the said Papists are.

div.head: Die Mercurii 27. Novembris 1678.
div.p: THe Earl of Essex Reported, that the Committee have perused the Letters directed to John Grove, and find nothing therein worthy to have notice taken thereof, therefore it is Ordered, that the said Letters be delivered according to the Direction.
The Earl of Essex Reported, that the Committee have considered the Bill for preserving the peace of the Kingdom by raising the Militia, and do think it fit to pass as it is without any amendments.
Hodie tertia vice licita est Billa, an Act for preserving the Peace of the Kingdom by raising the Militia, and continuing them in duty for two and forty days.
The Question being put whether this Bill shall pass, It was resolved in the Affirmative.

The Earl of Essex Reported, that the Committee have considered the Bill for better conviction of Papists, and do think it fit to pass with some Amendments, which they have made and being • ead twice were agreed to, then some other Amendments were offered to the House, which being read were agreed to, and the Bill Ordered to be Engrossed with these several Amendments.

The Lord Marquess of Winton Reported, that the Committee for Examinations sent for Mr. Beacon Merchant in Headon Court in the Minories, to attend them the last Night, and he not coming then was summoned again this Morning at Nine of the Clock, but he doth not appear, it is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House his Deputy or Deputies, do forthwith attach the Body of Mr. Beacon a Merchant in Headon Court in the Minories, and bring him in safe Custody to the Bar of this House to answer such matters as shall be objected against him, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

To Sir George Charnock Knight Serjeant at Armes attending this House, his Deputy and Deputies, and to all His Majesties Ministers and Officers Civil and Military to be aiding and assisting in this service.

Ordered, that Dr. Lower and Dr. Warner, be and are hereby appointed to visit Mr. White alias Whitchread, being sick near Wild-house, and give this House an account to morrow Morning in what condition of health they find him.

Upon the Information of William Sorocoale and Isaac Baxter Constable, that a Warrant being issued by the Lord Marquess of Winton, as a Justice of Peace to apprehend a suspitious Person, Mr. Hoare a Justice of the Peace came with many men in his Company, and being drunk stroak the Constable, and abus • d him in words in the Execution of his Office, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House his Deputy or Deputies, do forthwith Attach the Body of Mr. James Hoare the younger, and bring him to the Bar of this House in safe Custody to answer such matters as there shall be objected against him, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant in tha • behalf.
To Sir George Charnock Knight Serjeant at Armes attending this House his Deputy or Deputies.

The House being informed of a Quarrel which happened lately between the Earl of Pembrook and the Earl of Dorset, it is Ordered that the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod do give notice to the Earl of Pembrook that he attend this House presently, and that Mr. Loyd and the Footman be summoned to appear presently to give this House an account thereof.

In the mean time the Earl of Dorset gave the House an account, that on Wednesday last late at Night the Earl of Pembrook sent one Mr. Loyd, who told him that the Earl of Pembrook desired him to speak with him at Mr. Lockets house, the Earl of Dorset asked whether the Earl of Pembrook was sober, and was answered yes, and when his Lordship came he found the Earl of Pembrook in a low Room, who told him that he had done him an injury, therefore he would Fight him, the Earl of Dorset a • ked him where and when, the Earl of Pembrook told him now, in this R • om, and then laid violent hands upon him, and the Earl of Pembrooks Footman took away his Sword from his side, but Mr. Lord closed in, and parted them and so his Lordship got loose from him.

The Earl of Pembrook being come standing in his place, the Lord Chancellor told him what an account the Earl of Dorset had given to the House, the Earl of Pembrook said he remembred no such thing, but confessed he desired to speak with the Earl of Dorset about business, and had no intent of Fighting, and that the Earl of Dorset had two men with him, and that his own Servant took his Sword away, the House directed the Earl of Dorset to relate again in the presence of the Earl of Pembrook what passed between them. Then both these Lords withdrew themselves.

The House taking this business into consideration, and how
much the honor of this House was concerned therein, made these Orders following.

For the better preservation of the Peace, and preventing any mischief which may happen between the Earl of Pembrook and the Earl of Dorset, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Earl of Pembrook and the Earl of Dorset, be and are hereby confined to their respective Houses or Lodgings till further Order, and that they or either of them send not any Message or Write to the other during their confinement.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. Loyd an Officer in Sir Charles Wheelers Regiment, and the Footman who waited on the Earl of Pembrook, and the two Footmen who waited on the Earl of Dorset to Lockets Ordinary on Monday Night last, and Robin the waiter at the said Ordinary, be and are hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House to morrow at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

Then the Earl of Pembrook, and the Earl of Dorset were called again to their places, and the Lord Chancellor declared to them what the House had Ordered, and laid on them the Commands of the House not to resent any thing further concerning this business.
The House was adjourned into a Committee, to consider what advice to give His Majesty concerning the continuing the English Forces in Flanders.
The House was resumed.
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Robert Spencer and others, to desire a conference concerning the Subject matter of the last conference.
The Answer returned was, that the Lords agree to a conference and appoints the same to be presently in the Painted Chamber.
The same Lords who mannaged the former conference are appointed to Report this conference.
The House was adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords went to the conference, which being ended, the House was Resumed.
Then the Lord Chancellor Reported the effect of the conference.
That the Commons agree with the Lords in the first amendment, with the Addition of these words viz. (not exceeding Nine in number.)
The Commons do agree with the Lords in the first Paragraph of the second Amendment, for reducing the number of Women Servants of the Queen to Nine.
But as to the allowing of Five Women Servants to her Royal Highness the Dutchess of York, the Common • do not agree.
Ordered, that this House agrees with the Commons in the Amendments made by them.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Timothy Baldwyn and Sir John Hoskins. 1. To acquaint them that the Lords do agree to the Amendments offered at the last conference in the Bill, concerning the preservation of the Kings Person.
2. To let them know, that the Lords have passed the Bill for preserving the Peace of the Kingdom by raising the Militia, and continuing them in duty for two and Forty days.
3. To acquaint them, that the Lords do intend to send to His Majesty to signify to him, that the aforesaid Bills are ready for his Royal Assent.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to acquaint him from this House, that the B • ll entituled an Act for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament, and the Bill entituled an Act for the preserving the Peace of the Kingdom by raising the Militia, and continuing them in duty for two and Forty days are ready for His Majesties Royal assent, and are Bills which requi • e Expedition.

div.head: Die Jovis 28. Novembris 1678.
div.p: HOdie tertia vice licita est Billa, an Act for the better discovery and more speedy conviction of Papists.
The Question being put whether this Bill shall pass, it was resolved in the Affirmative.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir W ••
liam Beversham and Sir Samuel Clerk, to deliver them the Bill
for the better discovery and the more speedy conviction of Papists, and desire there concurrence thereunto.
The Lord Treasurer Reported, that the Lords with white Staves have acquainted His Majesty, that both Houses have passed two Bills ready for his Royal Assent.
The Earl of Ess • x Reported an Information given to the Committee for Examinations by Mr. Oates, which was read (viz)
The Lord Marquess of Winton acquainted the Committee, that being in the Court of Kings bench at Mr. Colemans Tryal, and happening to stand near Mr. Oates, his Lordship asked him these two Questions.

list.item: 2. Whether he was under •• strai • t.

div.p: To which he answered that he had his Papers returned to him, but he was under restraint and desired his Lordship, that he would be pleased to acquaint the Committee, that he had something material to say to them, of all which the Lord Marque • s informed the Committee, and their Lordships thereupon sent for him, who confirmed all this upon Oath, and upon the same Oath declared that the Lord Marquess then asked those and no other questions of him, and further saith, that he believes all the Papers are returned unto him, and as to his restraint that both his own Servants were put away, that he is permitted to speak wi • h no body not so much as his own Father, unless a Clerk of the Councel be by to hear what they say, that he is permitted to write no Letters nor Billets to any one, nor to receive any Letters but what the King shall first see, that his Ward coming to see him had his Pockets searched and his Papers taken forth, and his own Servants Pockets were searched and put from him, and the Key of his Chamber taken from his Servant, That on the last fast day he desired to speak with the King privately, but His Majesty was pleased to command him to do it before the two Secretaries, and that then he did decline to make a perfect Narrative because Secretary Williamson was present. That some time after Mrs. Elliot came to him to let him know that the King would speak privately with him, and accordingly he attended the King on Sunday last Mr. Secretary Coventry being pr • sent where he made a full Narrative in writing, Mr. Secretary Coventry then gave him his Oath to the truth of the same.

That Mr. Oates desired the Committee that they would be pleased to move the Lords House, that he may be freed from his restraint in Whitehall, and from his being in that place, and
have the like liberty of other His Majesties Subjects, he giving such security as the Law requires for the prosecution of his Evidence.
That he further desires some supply of Money, in regard he was out of purse about Eighty Pound on his own account about this business, since the Eleventh of August last.
That there hath been but one Hundred and Twenty Pound as yet paid him, and that he is at present in great want.
That he desireth a Copy of his Depositions, which he gave into the Councel on Monday and signed on Thursday last.
That he desireth his pardon may be renewed to this day.
After some debate, it is Ordered, that this Debate is adjourned to the Afternoon.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by the Lord Cavendish, to let their Lordships know that the House of Commons intend to sit this Afternoon, upon matters highly concerning the Kings Majesty and his Government; and they desire the Lords would sit likewise.
The Answer returned is that this House will sit this Afternoon.

div.head: Die Jovis 28. Novembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p: THe House Resumed the Debate concerning Mr. Oates.

The Earl of Clarendon being speaking in the debate the House was in concerning Titus Oates, took notice that the Marquess of Winton said, he lyes, he lyes, of which words the House requiring the Marquess of Winton to give an account, the Marquess of Winton denyes not the words but begs the pardon of the House, that he was talking of other things while the House was in debate, and said he did not intend the words against the Earl of Clarendon, and if he have offended the House, he is forty for it, and begs pardon for it.
Ordered, that the Marquess of Winton and the Earl of Clarendon do not go out of the House until the House be adjourned.
A message brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Thynn and others, to desire a conference about matters concerning the safety of the Kings Person and his Government.
The Answer returned was, that the Lords will give a conference as is desired, and appoint the same to be presently in the Painted Chamber.

The Lord Chancellour reported the effect of the conference that upon hearing the Testimony of Mr. Oates, and William Bedloe, they are in amazement, when they consider in what danger the Person of the King is, and his Government; whereupon they have prepared an Address to be presented to His Majesty, to which they desire their Lordships concurrence.
The said Address was Read and Ordered to be taken into consideration to morrow morning.
Ordered, That Titus Oates, and William Bedloe do attend this House to morrow, at Nine of the Clock in the Forenoon.

Ordered, That the Clerk of His Majesties Privy Councel, in whose custody the Depositions lately taken at the Councel Board are, which concerns the Queens Majesty be, and is hereby appointed to bring the said Depositions before this House to morrow at Nine of the Clock in the Forenoon.
