Ordered, That all the Judges be present in this House to morrow at Nine of the Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Veneris 29. Novembris 1678.
div.p: SIr John Nicholas delivered four Papers at the Table, viz.

list.item: 1. The Examination of Titus Oates taken by Mr. Secretary Coventry 24 November 1678. Signed Titus Oates.
2. The further Examinations of Titus Oates taken before the Councel 25 and 26 of November 1678.
3. The Report of the Earl of Bridgewater, and Lord Butler (Earl of Ossory) upon view of Sommerset-house with Titus Oates read in Councel 26 November 1678.
4. The Examination of William Bedloe taken before the Councel 27 November 1678.

div.p: Titus Oates being called in at the Bar, desired he might be heard a few words before he was sworn to speak to the main business, which being granted to him, he complained of the restraint he is under, and being debarred of the liberty of his friends coming to him, and of conversing with any body in private, and that no English man ought to be restrained, unless accused by one or more witnesses, and prayed that the restraint might be taken off, that he might be enabled to give his evidence more chearfully, and that the House would be pleased to Address to the King for that purpose, and that his pardon may be renewed, because he is under misprision of Treason: To which the Lord Chancellour told him that the House would take his condition into consideration, and then being sworn, he was told by the Lord Chancellour, that the Lords have received an Address from the House of Commons in part upon evidence by him given there, and that the House expects he should give an account what that is, which hath begot such an astonishment in the House of Commons, as is expressed in the Address. Upon which, Titus Oates said, That in July last, he saw a Letter from Sir George Wakeman to Richard Ashby alias Thimbleby; in this Letter he gave him an account of the proposals made for destroying the King, and declared his liking thereof, provided his Reward might be answerable, and told him the Queen consort did approve of them, which were to poyson the King; and being asked whether he knew Sir George Wakemans hand writing, he said, no, but Thimbleby told him it was Sir George Wakemans Letter.

That in the same July, a Messenger came with a Letter to William Hartcourt for him, and John Keynes, Basil Langworth and John Fenwick to attend the Queen at Sommerset-house, which they accordingly did, taking him with them, Hartcourt telling him he must go, when they were there, having passed by the presence, he was left in an Anti-chamber, and they went into another Room, but the door not being quite shut, he heard a Woman say, That she would no longer indure these affronts, but would revenge the Violation of her Bed, and assist in propagating the Catholick Religion.
He saith he heard the words spoken, and when the Fathers came out, he being desirous to see the Queen, was introduced by Langworth or Fenwick, and saw no woman there but the Queen with these Fathers.

He said further, That the Queen had given several sums of money to Corker a Benedictine under the notion of charity,
which he believes was only to pervert the Kings Subjects in their Religion, and that if Irelands papers be again searched, it will be found that several of them have had monney upon that account, and some so small shares as two or three shillings, and that he himself had had several sums. That as a circumstance to induce a belief that the Queen was ingaged in this business, he saith be saw Micho's Letter to the General of the Iesuites, wherein was mentioned of Four thousand at one time, and One thousand at another time given by the Queen, which he cannot say upon his Oath, but believes was given upon this account. Upon which a Complement was sent to the Queen, Duke and Dutchess of Five hundred Masses, Six hundred and odd pair of Beads, and One thousand one hundred and fifty Acts of mortification as a return for former favours; Whitebread being then Provincial, he refers himself to the Letter which may be found amongst Micho's or Whitebreads Papers.

Then being asked whether this is all he had to say in reference to the Queen, he said this is all as to matter of Information, saving only that he added, that the Queen holds correspondency with the Bishop of Rome, and the General of the Society of Iesuits.

Then being asked whether Mrs. Elliot came first to him from the King, or he did send her first to the King about his speaking with the King; he said she came first to him, and told him the King would speak with him, but whether she came from the King he knows not, but saith he never desired her to speak with the King

He saith further, that when he went to the King on the 13. instant, the King was dis-satisfied with what he said, and because there was one present, whom he believed to be an Enemy to the King and Kingdom, he did not speak so freely as otherwise he should have done.

Then being asked why he said (the last time he was here) that he had no other person to accuse being then required to name them (if any such were) of what quality soever, he said that he had no more to name, meaning of this House before whom he then was, and that he then desired that he might not be further pressed to say any more in prejudice of the evidence he was to give.

Then being ask • d why he concealed this matter so long, he said, It was because the Queen was the Wife of the Kings bosom, & he had not then acquainted the King with it, and therefore thought not fit to mention it before a publick Councel, and if therein he erred in his judgment, it was not his intention so to do.

Then he said this Plot was designed in 1670. he believes it was so in 1666. Further he could swear that their own Records say it was designed upon the Kings coming in, in 1660. And being asked why he knowing this matter of the Queens being in it in July and August last, did not acquaint the King with it till November; he said, that the Queen was not to act till all other practises failed, and that then she was to have further notice. And being asked how he knew that the Queen had not notice in all this time, he said it was to be done when the King should take Physick, which was not done because of his going to New market, and being told that if he had mentioned this matter of Sir George Wakemans Letter so fully at the Councel as he hath done now, Sir George had then been taken in custody. To this he said, that he had been up all the Saturday and Sunday at night, and had attended the Councel so long, that he was ready to faint, and that the weakness of his body so confounded his memory, that he forgot to mention that Letter.
Then being commanded to withdraw, Mrs. Elliot was sent for.

Then William Bedloe being called in, and Sworn, is told of the occasion of his coming hither upon the Address now brought up from the House of Commons, and that his whole knowledg concerning this matter is expected from him, upon which he said that about the end of April or beginning of May 1677. There was a Consult held in the Chappel Gallery at Sommerset-house▪ where were present the Lord Bellasis, Mr. Coleman, 〈…〉 Le-Phaire 〈…〉 Pritchard 〈…〉 Sheldon and
〈…〉 Lathan, and two French Abbots and the Queen, (and he thinks the Lord Powis) that he was below in the Chappel with
〈…〉 Walsh and others at the same time, and when the Consult was over, Coleman came down and told Walsh and him that the Queen wept much before they could bring Her to it, but the French Abbots by their Arguments had prevailed.

Then he said that he was afterwards dispatched by Coleman with Letters for France, and that he overtook Stapleton at Cambray, for whom he had Letters, which Letters Stapleton read by a Key or Cypher which he had in his hand, that Stapleton (after he had read them) said I am glad they have brought Her to it, our party growes Stronger and Stronger, and Bedloe asking who was meant by Her, Stapleton said the Queen, and that he received this Letter from Coleman in his own house.

Then being asked whether he knew the Lord Bellasis, he said he did, and had seen him at his house in St. Albones Square
about three years since, and said he had no more to say of any Person either in or out of this house then he had already charged.

p.hi: Then being asked where he stood in the Chappel, when the Consult was above, he said he came in from the water Side through the Room, where the Priests put on their Vestments, and standing below, he saw the Queen look over the Railes of the Gallery.

div.p: Then being asked whether he knew Mr. Oates, he said he remembred he had seen the man at Vallidolid about a Month before Micbaelmas last was Twelvemoneth, but knew not that he was concerned in this Business, and that he went there by the name of Ambrose, and that when he was formerly asked here if he knew him, he denied it, because he knew him not by that name of Oates, and had not then seen him here.

Then Mrs. Elliot being come is called in, and sworn, and is asked whether Mr. Oates sent her first to the King or the King sent her first to Mr. Oates, she said the Lady Gerara of Bromley told her Dr. Tong would speak with her, who told her coming to him that Mr. Oates must needs speak with the King privately, and being asked whether Dr. Tong told her what it was about, she said that by the words he spoak, she guessed the Queen was concerned, but she did not here him say why or wherein, and that she went to the King before she spake with Mr. Oates at Dr. Tongs desire.
After this the Papers that were brought in from the Councel were read as followeth.

Mr. Oates doth inform that in the Moneth of July he saw a Letter from Sir George Wakeman, in which Sir George did assure Richard Thimbleby to whom it was directed, that the Queen would assist him to poyson His Sacred Majesty, and in the latter part of July Mr. Oates did wait upon Iohn Kaines, Bazil Longworth William Harcourt and Iohn Fenwick to Sommerset house where the Queen then was, and in an Anti-Chamber did here the Queen say that She would not take those affronts any longer that had been done unto her, but would revenge the violation of Her Bed, now the Deponent, being presented before Her Majesty saw no living soul there, but Her Majesty, and those fathers with whom he went to Sommerset house, and the Deponent did hear the Queen say that She would assist them in the propagation of Catholick Religion, and hath by Corker the Benedictine Monck given several sums of money to pervert His Majesties Subjects as Mr. Oates doth verily believe, and several sums have been so used by the Jesuites in Her Majesties name, and 5000. pounds hath been paid to the Jesuites by Her Majesty in order
to Destroy the Person of His Majesty and subvert Religion and Government, as appeared by several instructions from the Queen to the Jesuites, as the Jesuites themselves have confessed to Mr. Oates.

postscript.p: This information was given upon Oath to me the 24th. of November 1678.

div.p: Titus Oates appeared before His Majesty in Councel, and being Sworn on the holy Evangelists saith.

That in the Moneth of July last he saw a Letter written from Sir Georg Wakeman to Richard Ashby, alias Thimbleby advising him for his health, being troubled with the Gout, to take a pinte of milk in the morning and a pinte at night, and also 100 stroakes of the Pump every day while he continued at the Bath.

That in the same Letter Sir George Wakeman did declare his good liklng of the proposals about poysoning the King provided good termes might be had, and added that the Queen would give her assistance in that work.

That in the same Moneth of July there came a messenger to have some of the fathers to attend at Sommerset-house, who were John Keines, William Hartcourt, John Fenwick, and Bazil Langworth, the messenger was one Sir Richard or Robert he knowes not whether, being a man of middle Stature, and about Forty four or Forty five years of Age and a Nimble man.

That being at Sommerset-house they went all into an Anti-Chamber that he himself and some others (whom he remembers not) were in the Room without, but that he being curious to here what passed within, and the Door not being quite close, listned and did here a womans voice, (though he saw not who it was) to say that she would no longer endure those affronts but would revenge the violation of Her Bed, and would assist in taking away the Kings Life, and propagating Catholick Religion.
That upon opening of the Door he desired one of the fathers he might see the Queen, and being admitted he doth on his Salvation declare, that he saw no body but the Queen and the said Fathers.

Mr. Oates being afterwards asked if the Queen saw him when he was presented, he said She did and took as much notice of him as one of her ranck usually doth of such as he was, being then in another habit then at present, but he thought She gave him a gratious smile.

That the Queen under the notion of Charity hath given to Mr. Corker several sums of money in order to pervert His Majesties Subjects in their Religion, and that if Mr. Irelands Papers be again examined it will appear that there was made distributions of this Charity, and some so small as two or three Shillings, whereof he himself has had some share.

That as a Cicumstance to induce a belief that the Queen was ingaged in this matter, he saies he saw a Letter which Micho had prepared to the General of the Jesuites wherein was mentioned of Five thousand pound given by Her Majesty, Four thousand pound at one time, and One thousand pound at another, which he cannot swear was for this end but verily believes it was, and being asked how he came to see that Letter, he saies Micho the Secretary of the order consulted with him about a Latine Phraise, and he advised him to put a word into the Dative case as being better Latine.

That as to the question why he concealed this important matter so long, he answered that he had much distrust with himself in his judgment about the discovering it, and that once he intended to disclose it upon Sir George Wakemans business at this Board, but was willing His Majesty should know it first in private.

And further upon this account and the objection that Pickering was imployed to have killed the King with a Pistol and Silver Bullets, and that he had been disciplined with twenty Stroakes for having failed (which was before the Consult in April last as near as he remembers) it appeared the business was committed to others hands to be executed, he answered hereunto that the matter had been designed in the year 1670. and that he knew Her Majesty (let her vertues be what they will) held correspondence with the Bishop of Rome and the General of the Jesuites by hands of the Jesuites here, but that She was not to Act until they judged things to be ripe, and he further said that endevours were used that the Queen should not be engaged in this business till all other meanes failed.

p.hi: He further added as to the said question of his being so long silent in a matter of that dangerous consequence, that he was unwilling to communicate any thing of the Queen to any publike Court, but only to the King himself in private, to prevent the danger She being the wife of his Bosom.

div.p:
He saies he cannot remember the precise day when these words were spoken, but that it was on a week day not on •
Sunday and a day of some Solemnity just before high Mass.

And as to the place where he heard the same, he saies he
never was there before nor since, but thinks he shall know the Room again if he sees it.

Being put in mind that he had declared at the Bar of the House of Peers, that he had no more to say against any Person of Quality, he answered his meaning was that he had no more against any of that House before whom he then was, and prayed their Lordships to remember that he then desired he might not be further pressed to say any more to the end his Evidence might not be superceded.

And being further questioned how it came about that he could not give an account of the precise day when those words were spoken, having in other things referred himself to his Papers, he declared that he had not committed this thing to Writing, not daring to trust more with it then his own Soul, yet he hopes he may recollect something as to the very time and would Examine his Papers, but that they are in the custody of Mr. Thomas Howard.

Being asked whether he knew Bedloe before, he said 'tis like he had seen him but not by that name, but that if he had seen him 'twas in Spain, and as going by the name of Williams, but that he never knew him as concerned in this business.

Mr. Oates being asked how many several hands he could write, did answer, that he never had been taught any but had learnt of himself, and did write differently according as his Pen was, and that when he saw a hand that pleased him he endeavored to imitate the same.

Being further demanded, why he had omitted so material a thing against Sir George Wakeman, as the dangerous Letter written by him to Thimbleby aforementioned, for nothing appears of it in the first minutes taken at the Councel board against Sir George Wakeman, he answered that he was at that time faint and week, and had been up two Nights together, nor could he then have said that he saw Sir George write such a Letter, but that he saw a Letter signed George Wakeman in Thimbleby's Chamber.

And further reminded the Lords, that he did declare that when the Consult was held by the Benedictines, when Sir George was contracted with, that he was sick of the Stone and not there, but that he afterwards found the contents of their proceedings in their Entry Book.

Touching which it was told him, that he had indeed made mention of such an Entry Book at the Bar of the House of Commons, but no mention of it at this board, to which he
replyed that it was an omission occasioned by his weakness at that time.
Mr. Oates hearing this his Information read did further declare that it was on St. James's Day, or a day before or after that he heard the words herein before mentioned,
div.closer: Titus Oates. Report of the Earls of Ossory and Bridgewater read in Councel November the 26th. 1678.

div.p: We went by His Majesties directions to Sommerset house and tooke M. Howard and M. Oates with us in the Coach, when alighted at the Door we tooke Mr. Oates between us and asked him, whether that time that he mentions he came into the house that way, and he answers us yes, and shewed us forward to the Guard-Chamber Door, that he went in there and when we were come into the Guard-Chamber he remembred that Room, and so he did the presence Chamber, for he said he remembred the Cannopy, but when we went into the next Room he began to doubt, so we went back again with him into the Guard-Chamber, and he again asserted his coming in that way, but we were again come into the presence Chamber, he began to speak of a paire of Staires that he had gone up but he could not find them, all the Doors were opened and we went with him through the Queens Bed-Chamber through several little Rooms and opened the Gallery Door, which he said he had never seen before, and that those little Rooms were none of them the Room he lookt for, but stil talkt of a paire of Staires, and when he came out again into the Room next the Bed-Chamber he set one of the leaves of the Door in the posture he said the Door that he stood at was in, but said that was not the Door he had stood at, but still talkt of a paire of Staires but could not find any. We shewed him the Stairs that go to the Garden by the Chappel and went with him down to the Bottom, but he said they were not the Staires he meant, when we came up again to go away he again said he remembred the Guard Chamber, and when we went out of the Guard-Chamber into the walk between that and the Court-Yard, we carried him to the further end of it, and went up with him at that Door, but he immediately said that that was not the way he had come, in all the search he made for a pair of Staires, he said the Staires he sought for were a light paire of Saires, and the Rooms they went to had great Folding Doors and were high large Rooms.

Mr. Bedloe being called in before His Majesty in Councel, and told by the Lord Chancellour that His Majesty had given Mr. Attorney General order forthwith to prepare his pardon for all concealments of any manner of Treason, from the beginning of the world to the 28. day of this instant November, and that His Majesty did desire to be informed of all the heads of the Treasons he can discover and make proof of.

And thereupon taking his Oath on the Holy Evangelists, saith, That about the latter end of April, or the beginning of May last was a Twelve-moneth, about Six of the Clock in the Afternoon, there was a consult held in the Chappel-Gallery at Sommerset-house, where were present the Lord Bellasis, and (he thinks the Lord Powis) Mr. Coleman, Le Phaire Pritchard Lathan and Sheldon and two French-men in orders, whom he took to be Abbots, and two other Persons of Quality, but did not see their Faces, and others, and amongst them the Queen, and further that Coleman and Pritchard told him after the Consult that the Queen wept at what was proposed there, but was over perswaded to consent by the Strength of the two French-mens Arguments, that he was below walking the Chappel at the time of the Consult with others, of whom be remembers onely a short fat man who was the Chappel Keeper and Mr. Walsh, that after the Consult the Queen came through the room where the Priests dress themselves, and that he then observed some alteration in Her Majesty.

That he was afterwards dispatcht by Coleman with Letters for France, and that Le-Phaire and Pritchard went with him to Graves-end, That he went by Cambray and there overtook Stapleton for whom he had Letters, which Stapleton read by a Key or Cypher which he had in his hand he standing at a distance, that after Stapleton had read them he said, well I am glad they have brought her to it, we are now better backt then ever, but this Deponent saith he did not know who they meant by her, and that Stapleton further added that they got ground every day, and that it was better and hundred Heretick Kings should be destroyed, then that the Catholick Religion should not be propagated, and says that the Contents of those Letters were about subverting the Government.

This Deponent further saith, that he did not call any thing of this foregoing information to mind till Mr. Coleman did this day aver upon his Tryal, that he had never seen his Face before in his life, and being asked what it was that lay upon Spirits that made him desire a further pardon, for which the House of Commons had made an Address to His Majesty,
he said he knew nothing of it but by some of the Yeoman of the Guard who attended him, but that he desired it least he might have forgotten any thing, and that by a further pardon his mind would be at more ease to recollect circumstances.
The Deponent further saith he cannot remember any thing of substance more at present, and that he knowes nothing more that is considerable of any other Persons.

Being asked if ever he was at my Lord Westmorlands, he said he was there about this time Twelvemoneths as he was going to my Lord Brudnels, and that my Lord Brudnel came thither whilst he was there, and that he was like to have had a quarrel with him he then going by the name of Bennet, and that he was never at the Lord Westmorlands but once.

Being asked if he was not here in Prison the last year, he saies he was in the Marshalsea for his Brothers Debts, and that Harcourt and Le-Phaire sent him moneys as soon as they came to Town that released him.

We your Majesties most Loyal and Dutiful Subjects, the and Commons in Parliament Assembled, having received informations by several witnesses of a most Desperate and Treacherous Design and Conspiracy against the life of your most Sacred Majesty, wherein to their great Astonishment the Queen is particularly Charged and Accused, In discharge of our Allegiance and out of our affections and care for the preservation of your Majesties Sacred Person, and consequently of the whole Kingdom, do most humbly beseech Your Majesty that the Queen and all Her Family and all Papists and Reputed or Suspected Papists, be forthwith removed from your Majesties Court at White hall.

The House having heard the information of Titus Oates and William Bedloe took into consideration the Address brought from the House of Commons concerning the removal of the Queens Majesty, and Her Family from Wite-hall, which was read and after a long Debate.
The Question being put whether to agree with the House of Commons in this Address, it was resolved in the Negative.

The House received an account that Dr. Lowre and Dr. Warner have visited Mr. White bread, and they find that his former distempers have left him, and that he hath now onely a Certain Ague, and their Opinion is that he may be removed safely upon his intermitting days, hereupon it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, or his Deputy and Deputies taking with them such Soldiers as shall be necessary, shall to morrow attach the Body of Mr. White, alias
White-bread and carry him forthwith to the Prison of Newgate, there to remain in safe Custody till he shall be delivered by due course of Law, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
The Lord Marquess of Winton gave the House an account that he did see a Bull derived from the Pope, which is now in the hands of a member of the House of Commons, which is of dangerous consequence.

Hereupon a message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir John Coel and Sir Samuel Clerk to let them know that the Lords are informed, that there is a Bull from Rome, which was found amongst the Papers of Ireland a Jesuite, the Lords desire that they may have a sight thereof, it being in the hands of one of their members.
The Earl of Essex informed the House that there is one Daniel Maccarty a Jesuite apprehended by the Sheriff of Norfolk, and is now in the Prison at Thetford, whereupon the House Ordered as followeth.

Upon information given to this House that one Daniel Maccarty a Romish Priest is now under Custody in Thetford in the County of Norfolk, It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House or his Deputy or Deputies shall forthwith repair to Thetford aforesaid, and bring thence the Body of the said Daniel Maccarty in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
The messengers sent to the House of Commons, Return with a Paper Being a Faculty from Rome, which the Commons pray may be returned to them so soon as their Lordships have proposed the same.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Charl's Cotterel and others, who acquainted their Lordships with an information they have received from Franckford, which they thought fit to Communicate to their Lordships in this juncture of Affaires.
The said Papers was read as followeth.
Monsieur Valkeiner Resident of Holland at Franckford writes thus to the States, November the 11 or 21 1678.

Some days since a Jesuit coming from Rome Arrived at Basel with intent to go for England, who being in discourse with certain Merchants there, is Reported to have said that there was something Designed in England against the King, whereof he be lieved he should heare the effect before he should get to his Journeys end, and that for the going through with that Design he shou • d
find more than one thousand Jesuits in England, during this discourse the Post brought News of the discovery of the Conspiracy in England, whereupon the Jesuit withdrew and suffered himself no more to be seen.

div.head: Die Sabbati 30. Novembris, 1678.
div.p: HIs Majesty sitting in his Royal Throne, adorned with his Royal Crown and Ornaments, (the Peers likewise being in their Robes) commanded the Gentleman Usher of the black Rod to signify His Majesties pleasure to the House of Commons, that they attend him presently,
The Commons being come with their Speaker, the Clerk of the Crown read the Titles of these two Bills, and the Clerk of the Parliaments pronounced His Majesties pleasure concerning them.
1. An Act for the more effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.
Le Roy le Veult.
2. An Act for preserving the peace of the Kingdom by raising the Militia, and continuing them in Duty for two and forty days.
Le Roy à Aduisera.
After this His Majesty made a short Speech to this effect.

He told the Lords and Commons that he did not refuse to pass this Act for the dislike of the matter, but the manner, because it puts out of his power the Militia for so many days, if it bad been but for half an hour, he would not have consented to it, because of the ill consequences it may have hereafter, the Militia being wholly in the Crown, and so far as he is enabled by Law to raise the Militia, if they will enable him with money to pay them, he shall imploy such of them as he thinks fit, and are necessary for the safety of himself and the Kingdom.

p.hi: His Majesty said he had passed the other Bill, which is of very great importance, of which there may be ill consequences hereafter, but he was willing to oblige them, who have thought it fitting at this time, and hopes that they will be careful to give him all due satisfaction for the future.

div.p: This day the Lord Chancellour by Intimation from the Duke of Norfolk, acquainted the House with a doubt that was concerned in Law, that if there was not an immediate proceeding to take the Oaths, and Declaration prescribed in the Act Entituled for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament; It would be questionable whether there could be a House of Peers on Munday to supply that defect, and though the Lords were of opinion that it was not of absolute necessity so to do, and that there would be no danger of Dissolving the House by omitting it. Yet nevertheless for avoiding of all Scruples and Objections that might otherwise be made: some of their Lordships did immediately take the said Oaths, and make and subscribe the Declaration with resolution to repeat the same on Munday, which being done, the House was moved to take notice of the good service of the Duke of Norfolk herein before his withdrawing, which their Lordships took very well from him, and Ordered that a Memorial thereof be entred in the Journal of this House for the honor of his Grace.

Then these Lords following did take the Oaths, and make and subscribe the Declaration in the pursuance of the Act, for the more effectual preserving the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The Lord Audley a Member of this House, taking his leave of their Lordships, and expressing his great duty to His Majesty, and the Welfare and Peace of this Kingdom, to the great satisfaction of the whole House. The House commanded the Lord Chancellor to recommend the Lord Audley from this House to His Majesty for his favour and grace, considering his antient descent, and the great actions done by his Ancestors in France in former times, and the small Estate and Fortune left to his Family, by reason of his Fortune spent in that Service by his Ancestors.

Upon reading the Petition of Sir Ellis Leighton Knight prisoner in Newgate, representing his ill condition of health, and that he is restrained from friends and necessary attendants, and praying that he may have Pen, Ink and Paper, and access of friends and servants. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Sir Ellis Leighton shall, and may during his present sickness have (besides these persons already allowed to come to him by His Majesties order) the attendance of a Servant, and the use of Pen, Ink and Paper, for making of his Will and other Settlements, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Lord Chancellor acquainted the House, that there is one Robert Pugh a Romish Priest apprehended in Wales, and that the Lord Arch-Bishop of Canterbury had delivered to him a faculty sent to the said Pugh from Rome, by Cardinal Barbarino in the year 1650. being of the same tenor of that found amongst Irelands Papers, which the House Ordered should be safely kept, to be made use of at the Tryal of the said Pugh, as evidence of his being a Priest.
A Letter written to the Lord Windsor from Sir John Packington was read, giving him an account what course is taken in Worcestershire against the Papists.
The Earl of Northampton communicated a Letter and Examination out of Warwickshire giving an account of Affaires there.

Ordered, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House, that so far as the Militia of this Kingdom may be imployed by Law, His Majesty will be pleased to improve it for the security of His Majesty and this Kingdom.

Upon information given to this House that a Person was taken at Gargrave in Craven on Wednesday the 12th. instant, on whom were found many Letters to be delivered to one Mr. Standish, which Person was examined by Mr. Marsden a Justice of the Peace. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Mr. Marsden be, and is hereby authorized and required to peruse the said Letters, and to send such of them to the Clerk of the Parliament, as are in Characters or Cyphers, if any such be, or relate to any design against His Majesty, or the Subversion of the Government, or the Protestant Religion.

Upon information given to this House by the Marquess of Worcester, that _____
Lloyd a Popish Priest was lately apprehended in Penline Castle in the County of Clamorgan, and stands now Committed to the common Goale of the said County: It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said _____
Lloyd shall remain in the said Goal, in order to his being Tryed at the Assises for the said County, according to the Laws of this Kingdom.

Upon reading the Deposition of Dominico Gratiano, now Prisoner in Newgate in the City of Bristol (at the suit of Josephus Georgerine, who stiles himself a Grecian Bishop) sworn to before Ralph Olliffe Alderman of the said City, on the 26. instant, concerning words uttered by the said Josephus Georgerine. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Sheriffs of the County and City of Bristol be, and are hereby required to take special care, and give order that the said Dominico Gratiano may be forthwith sent up from the City of Bristol, in safety to attend the House of Peers, and this shall be a sufficient warrant on that behalf.

div.head: Die Lunae secundo Decembris. 1678.
div.p:
The Names of the Lords, who this day took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and Subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Late Act of Parliament, entituled an Act for the more effectual preservation of his Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament, beginning with the youngest Barons first.
THomas Lord Butler of Charles L. North & Grey. Moor-Park.
Richard L. Arundel of Tr.
John L. Fretchvile.
George L. Delamer.
Charles L. Cornwallis.
Charles L. Wotton.
Charles L. Gerard Brand.
Edward L. Rockingham.
Charles L. Lucas.
Jacob. L. Astley.
Thomas L. Culpepper.
Richard L. Vaughan.
Richard L. Byron.
Thomas L. Leigh.
Edward L. Herbert Chr.
William L. Howard Esq
William L. Maynard.
John L. Paulet.
John L. Lovelace.
Ford L. Grey, de Werke.
Foulke L. Brooke.
James L. Chand • is.
William L. Paget.
Ralph L. Eare.
Thomas L. Windsor.
Charles L. de Grey.
Robert L. Ferrers.
Thomas L. Morley.
George L. Berkley.
William L B. of S. Davids.
Thomas L. B. of Exon.
John L B. of Oxon.
Thomas L. B. of Lincoln.
Humphrey L. B. of Bangor
John L. B. of Chester.
Peter L. B. of Bath & Wells
John L. B. of Gloucester.
Guy L. B. of Bristol.
Peter L. B. of Ely.
John L. B. of Rochester.
Joseph L. B. of Peterbor.
Nathaniel L. B. of Dur.
Henry L. B. of London.
Francis Vic. Newport.
George Vic. Hallifax.
Thomas Vic. Fauconberg.
William Vic. Say & Seal.
Lewis E. of Feversham.
John E. of Guilford.
Anthony E. of Shaftsbury.
Robert E. of Aylisbury.
William E. of Craven.
John E. of Bath.
Arthur E. of Essex.
Henry E. of Clarendon.
Henry E. of St. Alban.
Nicholas E. of Scarsdale.
Robert E. of Sunderland.
William E. of Strafford.
Henry E. of Peterborough.
Thomas E. of Rivers.
John E. of Mulgrave.
Robert E. of Manchester.
Charles E. of Westmorland.
Gilbert E. of Clare.
William E. of Denbigh.
James E. of Northampton.
Philip E. of Leicester.
John E. of Bridgwater.
James E. of Sarum.
Charles E. of Dors. & Mid.
James E. of Suffolk.
William E. of Bedford.
Theophilus E. of Hunt • ng.
Anthony E. of Kent.
Awbrey E. of Oxon.
Henry E. of Arlington, L. Chamberl. of His Majesties Houshold.
Robert E. of Lindsey, L. High Chamberl. of England.
Henry Marq. of Dorchest.
Henry Marq. of Worcest.
Charles Marq. of Winch.
James D. of Monmouth.
Christopher D. of Albemarle.
Arthur E. of Anglesey L. Pr. Seal.
Thomas E. of Danby L. High Trea. of England.
Heneage L. Finch L. high Chancellor of England
William Arch-b. of Canterbury.
Rupert D. of Cumberland.

The House was informed by some Lord • that they had taken notice that the Lord Wharton did not kiss the Book, when he took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy this day, and so hath not legally taken the said Oaths, his Lordship being gone out of the House was called in, and being in his place the Lord Chancellor told him that the House was of Opinion that he hath not taken the Oaths this day in a legall manner, because he did not Kiss the Book.

To which his Lordship said, that he had been allowed to do as he did this day at several times in this House when he did take the Oaths, and presently withdrew, and then the Lo • d
Wharton being withdrawn the House made the following Order.

For as much as this day the Lord Wharton did not take the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy in due form, not having kissed the Book, yet having Subscribed the Declaration as if he had taken the said Oaths, it is Ordered that the name of the Lord Wharton be put out of the Roll of Subscription to the Declaration.
And immediatly his name was put out of the Roll at the Table.

It was averred in the House that the Earl of Leicester and the Earl of St. Albans did not pronounce some words in taking the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy and making the Declaration this day, their Lordships did Offer to take the same for the satisfaction of the House, which they did accordingly.

The House was also acquainted that the Marquess of Dorchester did not say some words in taking the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy and making the Declaration this Day, whereupon the House Ordered that his Lordship should take the said Oaths and make the Declaration again to morrow Morning.

It is this Day Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in parliament Assembled, that the Lord Carington now under the Custody of the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod attending this House (his Lady being sick in the Country) hath hereby liberty given him to repaire to his house in Oxfordshiere to remain under Confinement, not to remove from thence till the pleasure of this House be further signified, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, that the Lords Committees for Examining Persons and Papers, for the further discovery of the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, be and are hereby impowered to peruse and methodize such Papers and Letters and other Writings, as their Lordships shall Judge to be necessary for Evidence at the Tryal or Tryals of all, or any of the Persons now in custody or Prison for any thing relating to the said horrid design.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased, to give Order that such Papers and Letters as were by the Lords Committees for Examining Papers, delivered to his Majesties Attorney General to be used at the Tryal of Edward Coleman, and are since by His Majesties
Order delivered over to one of the Clerks of the Councel, may be transmitted to the said Lords Committees, for their further perusal in Order to the Tryals of other Persons now in custody.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Luke Earl of Fingal in the Kingdom of Ireland, be and is hereby authorized and permitted forthwith to repair to any of His Majesties Sea-ports of this Kingdom, and to pass with two Servants viz. Edmond Barry and Christopher Archbold from thence to France or Flanders without the let, stay or interruption of any Person or Persons whatsoever, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon reading the humble Petition of Henry Gilmans, Peter Demulder, Lewis Casteels, Thomas Ael Brechts, Giles Bowens, Jan Slaiter, Jan Leisens and Giles Malnoe, Artificers, Natives of the Spanish Netherlands now Prisoners in the Gatehouse at Westminster, shewing that being setled for several years in following their respective Trades in St. Martins Le grand, they are Imprisoned for not being willing to take the Oath of Supremacy, and Praying that they may be set at liberty to follow their several Trades, or have time to prepare for their return to their own Country, upon consideration had thereof, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Henry Gilmans, Peter Demulder, Lewis Casteels, Thomas Ael Brechts, Giles Bowen, Jan Leisens and Giles Malnoe, be and are hereby discharged from their present Imprisonment, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Earl of Essex Reported from the Lords Committees, appointed to take Examinations concerning the discovery of the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, that they had brought before them Richard Vaughan and John Vaughan, who were sent for before them by Order of this House, therefore the Committees desires that the said Persons may be brought to this Bar to be Examined, and at the same time William Bedloe may be present to offer what he hath to charge them, hereupon it is Ordered, that the said Richard and John Vaughan be brought to this Bar to morrow Morning, at which time William Bedloe is to be present.

The Lord Treasurer Reported, that the Lords with White Staves have attended His Majesty with the Address, humbly to desire him that he will be pleased, that so far as the Militia of this Kingdom may be imployed by Law, His Majesty will be pleased to improve it for the security of His Majesty and this Kingdom,
to which His Majesty says he will take care for the doing thereof.

div.head: Die Martis 3. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THe House was made acquainted, that the Lord Wharton was ready and willing to take the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and make and subscribe the Declaration, and that the Lord Marquess of Dorchester was ready to take the Oathes, and repeat the Declaration according to the Order yesterday.

This day these Lords did take the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act Entituled, an Act for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

Mr. Richard Vaughan and his Son John Vaughan, being this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Armes, William Bedloe was called in, who being asked by the Lord Chancellor what he had to say to those person • , he looking on Richard Vaughan, said, I brought this Gentleman a Letter from the Monks at Paris, the matter whereof was for Richard Vaughans holding a consultation for carrying on the design for subvertion of the Government, and that there was inclosed in the Pacquet a Letter directed to the Earl of Powis, and that Richard Vaughan sent a Letter back by him to his Daughter a Nun at Pontois. To which Richard Vaughan said that he never received any Letters from France by William Bedloe, only that William Bedloe came to him and told him he had seen his Daughter in France, and had a Letter from her to him but it was lost by the way, and saith that he never saw the Earl of Powis, but confessed he had a Daughter a Nun at Pontois.

Then William Bedloe, being asked, how he knew that the Letters
were about a consultation for carrying on the design for the subversion of the Government, he said he never carryed any Letters to or from England but he opened them by the way and read them, and that he offered to Richard Vaughan to carry the Letter to the Earl of Powis, but Richard Vaughan would not permit him, but undertook the delivery of it himself.
Then being asked what he hath to say to John Vaughan, he could not charge him with any thing, only he had been Informed, that John Vaughan was to command his Fathers Money and men.
Upon this they being withdrawn the Lords made the following Orders.

Whereas Richard Vaughan was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, and there charged by William Bedloe upon Oath with matters relating to the carrying on the design against His Majesties Person and Government, it is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Richard Vaughan shall stand committed to the Prison of the Kings-bench, there to remain in safe custody till further Order, and that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House or his Deputy and Deputies take care to convey him to the said Prison, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Whereas John Vaughan was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, for matters charged against him by William Bedloe, and heard what he had to say, upon consideration had thereof, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Vaughan giving good security before the Lord Chief Justice of England, to appear when he shall be thereunto required, shall be immediatly discharged of his present restraint concerning this matter, paying his Fees, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on this behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees for Examining Persons and Papers, are hereby impowered to Examine James Hoare the younger and Mr. Beacon, and also John Gerard and Thomas Oakley, being all under the Custody of the Serjeant at Armes attending this House this Afternoon at Four of the Clock, and give this House an account thereof, as also of what their Lordships find in the Papers seized when the Sweeds were seized by William Sorocoale, which Sweeds were this day discharged at the Bar.

This day the Justices of the Peace delivered in a List of
what Papists they find within the Liberties of Westminster, and also the Justices of Peace within the County of Middlesex, delivered in a List of what Papists they find within their Liberties.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order for a special Commission, to be directed to such Persons as His Majesty shall think fit, for taking an account of the Papists that reside within His Majesties Court at Whitehall, and the Verge thereof and Sommerset-house.
William Sorocoale was called in, and received the reprehension of this House for his misbehaviors and irregular proceedings, and was charged not to meddle in any business whatsoever for the future.

A Letter was read written to the Lord Windsor from Worcester dated the 30th. of November 1678. by the Major of Worcester concerning Mr. Powel and one Whitaker, who is charged for speaking scandalous words, viz. That there were not above Five Bishops in England that were Protestants, and those were London, Oxon, and Exon, and two more. And that there is one Barnesley a Priest under custody in the City of Worcester, hereupon it is Ordered as followeth.

Upon Information given to this House by the Lord Windsor, that one Mr. Edward Whitaker of London, stands committed in the City of Worcester for some unbecoming words by him there uttered, as it is certified in a Letter to his Lordship signed John Tyas Major, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Mr. Whitaker shall give Bail before the Major of the City of Worcester for his appearance before the Lords in Parliament, within Eight days after such Bail given, and be thereupon discharged from his present commitment, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon Information given to this House that one Barnesley a Romish Priest is now under custody in the City of Worcester, it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, or his Deputy or Deputies shall forthwith repair to the City of Worcester, and bring thence the Body of the said 〈…〉
Barnesley in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon reading the Petition of Francis Point His Majesties Tapistry maker and Thomas Point two Merchants of London,
shewing that by His Majesties encouragement, they have brought into this Kingdom to the City of London, several Families of Tapistry makers, some of which being Roman Catholicks, are now obliged by His Majesties Proclamation to quit the same to the ruin of their Families, and prejudice to the taking of Commodities of the growth of this Kingdom, and praying that their condition may be weighed, upon consideration had thereof, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Petitioners and such Persons imployed by them in making Tapistry as are of the Romish Religion, shall not be molested by His Majesties said Proclamation nor lyable to the penalties thereof.
The Earl of Clarendon Reported, from the Committee for Examinations an Examination, which was read as followeth.

Mr. Rigmagden Servant to the Lord Arundel of Warder being Examined whether the latter end of the last Session of Parliament he did not Inquire after the Lodgings of all the Lords, and the Lodgings of the Members of the House of Commons.
He denied possitively that he inquired after the Lodgings of any Lords or of the Members of the House of Commons.

Mr. William Snow was sworn and examined, saith upon his Oath that himself and James Noble after the end of the last Sessions went to the Lord Arundels, to ask for Money as they usually do to all the Lords, and this Deponent did then meet with Mr. Rigmagden, and the said Mr. Rigmagden did inquire of him for the Lodgings of all the Lords, and also the members of the House of Commons, this Deponent desired to know why he did ask, the said Mr. Rigmagden told him because he had a business to bring into Parliament the next Session.

James Noble being sworn and examined saith, that at the end of the last Session William Snow and he this Deponent went to the Lord Arundel of Warders house to ask for Money according to their usual Custome, and Mr. Rigmagden did then ask this Deponent, where all the Bishops did lye and all the Lords and their names, also he did ask this Deponent where all the Members of the House of Commons did lodge, and this Deponent not liking such an enquiry said he had nothing to do with them.
Mr. Rigmagden after those two witnesses were Examined confessed he enquired after the Lodgings of the Bishops, and none others.
The Lords then asked Mr. Rigmagden what business he had to bring into Parliament.
He answered, it was for Mr. W • ld.

Their Lordships asked what Mr. W • ld •
business was, he answered he could not tell.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Clarendon from the Lords Committees for Examinations, concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, of the Examination of Mr. Rigmagden Servant to the Lord Arundel of Warder concerning matters proved upon Oath against him, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House or his Deputy, shall forthwith Attach the Body of the said Mr. Rigmagden, and deliver him into the Prison of the Gate-house at Westminster, there to remain in safe Custody till further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House his Deputy and Deputies, be and are hereby authorized and required forthwith to Attach the Body of Sir Francis Ratcliffe, and bring him in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, to answer to such matters as shall be there objected against him on His Majesties behalf, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

div.head: Die Mercurii 4. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day John Earl of Rochester took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made an subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act Entituled, an Act for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.
John Parl of Rochester.

The House being moved, that White alias Whitebread a Prisoner in Newgate being sick, may have the necessary helps of a Nurse to tend him, and a Physitian to come to him during his Sickness, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Mr. White alias Whitebread shall and may during his sickness have a Nurse to tend him, and that Dr. Lowre may have free access to him a • a Physitian, during his sickness as often as occasion shall require,
and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The House being moved that Dr. Fogarty being sick in the Prison of Newgate, may have the necessary helps of a Nurse to tend him, and a Physitian to come to him during his sickness, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Dr. Fogarty shall and may during his sickness have a Nurse to tend him, and that Sir Alexander Frazier may have free access to him as a Physitian during his Sickness, as often as occasion shall require, and that the said Dr. Fogarty may have use of Pen, Ink, and Paper, for writing a Note or Notes for Money or such necessaries as he wants, which he cannot have without a Note under his hand, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon Information given to this Housc, concerning Captain Francis Spalding Deputy Governor of Chepstow Castle, that neither be nor any of his Officers nor any of the Soldiers under him (except one) in that Garrison have received the Sacrament of the Lords Supper at Chepstow within three years last past, and that Captain Spalding hath not come to Church there for the last Five or Six Moneths, except on the 13th day of November last, and hath declared that he can and will be ready to take any Oath that can be devised, and that he hath a Dispensation for so doing, and that the Garrison at Chepstow Castle hath used the Country very ill, upon consideration had thereof, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord Bishop of Landaffe, calling to his Assistance Thomas Lewis of St. Peeres Esquire, William Keymish Esquire, Sir Herbert Evans, Thomas Morgan of Lansore Esquire, and Thomas Herbert of Uske Esquire: To inquire into the Information aforesaid, and to send for and Examine such Persons as they shall think fit for finding out the truth of the matter of Fact, and to give this House an account thereof so soon as his Lordship with conveniency can.

Ordered, that the Lords Committees appointed to Examine Mr. Edward Colemans and others Papers, be and are hereby impowered to use such means as they shall think fit, for the finding out the two last years Papers and Letters to and from the said Edward Coleman, which are not yet discovered.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that His Majesties Attorney General is hereby appointed to deliver to the Lords C • mmittees for Examining Papers, or such Person as they shall appoint to receive
them all such Papers and Letters, as are in his hands to be by their Lordships perused in order to the Tryals of such Persons as are now in Custody, concerning the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government.

Upon Report from the Lords Committees, to whom it was referred to Examine John Gerard and Thomas Oakley, who for refusing the Oath of Allegiance were brought up from Stratford upon Avon, by the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, under whose Custody they now are, that their Lordships judge it fitting that the said John Gerard and Thomas Oakley be continued in Custody, It is thereupon Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Gerard and Thomas Oakley shall stand committed to the Prison of the Kings Bench, there to remain in safe Custody till further Order, and that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, his Deputy or Deputies take care to convey them to the said Prison, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The House being moved on the behalf of Sir George Charnock Knight Serjeant at Armes attending this House, concerning his demanding Fees upon the discharge of any person out of his Custody, who is or shall be apprehended by him by Order of this House, It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that all such Persons as are or shall be so discharged out of his Custody, shall pay all such Fees as are justly due to him, and all other the Officers attending the Service of this House.

The House was adjourned into a Committee, during pleasure to consider of further Heads for the preservation of His Majesties Person and Government, and securing the Protestant Religion, the House was resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee of the House had agreed of some heads, which he is directed to Report.

p.hi: That the House be desired to make an Address to His Majesty, that he would be pleased to call again on the Forreign Ministers residing here for an account of the numbers, names, and places of abode of the Priests that do attend them respectively.
That an Address may be made to His Majesty, that Order may be given for preventing the scandalous resort of numbers of His Majesties Subjects to Ambassadors Chappels.

That an Address be made to His Majesty for a Proclamation, for tendering the Oathes according to Law to all Lawyers, Physitians, and Apothecaries, who are Popish Recusants by a day to be prefixed, in Order to the speedy Execution of the Laws against them.
That a Bill be prepared for the more speedy conviction of Gunsmiths, Armorers, Cutlers, Book-sellers, and Printers, who are Popish Recusants.
That the matter of sending Children abroad to Forreign Seminaries, may be considered at the next meeting of the Committee.
That a Message may be sent to the House of Commons, to put them in mind of the Bill sometime since sent down, for the better discovery and more speedy conviction of Popish Recusante.

div.p: All which Report the House agreed to.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to call again on the Forreign Ministers residing here for an account of the numbers and names, and places of abode of the Priests, that do attend them respectively.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, for some effectual means of preventing the scandalous resort of numbers of his Subjects, to the Chappels of Forreign Ministers residing here.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order for sending out a Proclamation, for tendering the Oathes according to Law, to all Lawyers, Physitians, and Apothecaries, who are Popish Recusants by a day to be therein prefixed in Order to the speedy Execution of the Laws against them.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. Justice Atkins be and is hereby appointed to prepare a Bill to be offered to this House, for the more speedy conviction of all Gunsmiths, Armorers, Cutlers, Book sellers, and Printers, who are Papists.
A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Timothy Baldwyn and Sir Andrew Hacket, to put them in mind of the Bill, for the speedy conviction of Popish Recusants.

div.head: Die Jovis Quinto Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Phillip Earl of Pembrook and Mountgomery took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in persuance of an Act entituled, an Act for the more effectual preserving of His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either Houses of Parliament.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order to the Lord Lieutenant of his Kingdom of Ireland, that Martin French an Augustine Fryar now at Galloway in Ireland may be safely sent thence hither, and may be well treated in his coming being to be examined as a witness before the House of Peers.

Upon reading the information of Henry Thorne taken upon Oath before Sir Thomas Smith one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace, for the County of Suffolke concerning great numbers of arms by him seen in the house of Richard Tasbrough Esquire in the County of Suffolke and other matters in the said information expressed. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Henry Thorne and Thomas Thorne his brother Servant or late Servant to the said Richard Tasbrough be and are hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House within Four Days next after notice given to them respectively of this Order, as they or either of them will answer the Contrary at their Perrl.

Upon reading the information of Henry Thorne taken upon Oath before Sir Thomas Smith one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace, for the County of Suffolk concerning great numbers of Arms by him seen in the house of Richard Tasbrough Esq in the said County of Suffolk and other matters in the said information expressed. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at arms attending this House his Deputy or Deputies do forthwith attach the Body of the said Richard Tasbrough, and bring him in safe Custody to the Bar of this House, to answer such matters a • shall be there objected against him, and this shall •• a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Keeper of Newgate or his Deputy shall bring Sir Ellis Leighton now his Prisoner in Newgate being sick to the Bar of this House, to be examined there on Saturday the 7th. Day of this instant December at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Titus Oats be and is hereby appointed to attend this House on Saturday the 7th. Day of this instant December at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, at which time Sir Ellis Leighton is to be Examined at the Bar.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by the Lord Cavendish and others to let their Lordships know, that they have matters of great importance to impart to their Lordships, therefore they desire their Lordships will sit a while longer.
The answer returned was, that their Lordships will sit a while longer.
The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure to consider of further heads for the preservation of His Majesties Person and Government, the House was resumed.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Wharton &c. that the Commons of England in Parliament Assembled, having received Information of Divers Traiterous practices and designes of a great Peere of this House, Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, have commanded him to impeach the said Henry Lord Arundel of Warder of Treason and other high Crimes and Misdemeanours, and he did here in their names and in the names of all the Commons of England impeach the said Henry Lord Arundel of Warder of Treason and high Crimes and Misdemeanours.
They have further commanded him to acquaint your Lordships, that they will in convenient time Exhibit to your Lordships the Articles of the Charge against him.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Mainard and others, that the Commons of England in Parliament Assembled, having received Information of Divers Traiterous practices and designes of a great Peere of this House, William Earl of Powis, have commanded him to impeach the said William Earl of Powis of Treason and other high Crimes and Misdemeanours, and he did here in their names and in the names of all the Commons of England impeach the said William Earl of Powis of Treason and high Crimes and Misdemeanours.
They have further commanded him to acquaint your Lordships, that they will in convenient time Exhibit to your Lordships the Articles of the Charge against him

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Thynne &c. that the Commons of England in Parliament Assembled, having received Information of Divers Traiterous practices and designs of a great Peere of this House, John Lord Bellasis have commanded him to impeach the said John Lord Bellasis of Treason and other high Crimes and Misdemeanours, and he did here in their names and in the names of all the Commons of England impeach the said J • hn Lord Bellasis of Treason and high Crimes and Misdemeanours.
They have futher commanded him to acquaint your Lordships, that they will in convenienr time Exhibit to your Lordships the Articles of the Charge against him.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Phillip Warwick, that the Commons of England in Parliament Assembled, having received Information of Divers Traiterous practices and designes of a great Peere of this House William Lord Peter have commanded him to impeach the said William Lord Peter of Treason and other high Crimes and Misdemeanours, and he did here in their names and in the names of all the Commons of England impeach the said William Lord Peter of Treason and high Crimes and Misdemeanours.
They have further commanded him to acquaint your Lordships, that they will within convenient time Exhibit to your Lordships the Articles of the Charge against him.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Scroope How &c. that the Commons of England in Parliament Assembled, having received Information of Divers Traiterous practices and designes of a great Peere of this House, William Lord Viscount Stafford have commanded him to impeach the said William Lord Viscount Stafford of Treason and other high Crimes and Misdemeanours, and he did here in their names and in the names of all the Commons of England impeach the said William Lord Viscount Stafford of Treason and high Crimes and misdemeanours.
They have further commanded him to acquaint your Lordships, that they will within convenient time Exhibit to your Lordships the Articles of the Cha • ge against him.
Ordered, that these impeachments be taken into consideration to morrow, and all the Judges to be then present.

Upon reading the order directed yesterday concerning Captain Francis Spalding and the Garrison of Chepstow Castle, the House being moved, that Edmond Ev • ns who attended at the
Door might be heard, he was called in and sworn, and being asked what he knew concerning Chepstow or Captain Spalding, he said he was Curate there last year, put in by the Lord Bishop of Landaffe and that he knows Captain Spalding, and believes but cannot say upon his Oath, that he came always to Church when he was Curate there, that he hath not been Curate there since August last, and so cannot say whether Captain Spalding hath been at Church there since that time, nor did he administer the Sacrament there at all, but the Minister of Matherne did it. He further said that the Soldiers did come to Church there on the Fifth of November 1676, as a Company, and he hath observed that a Soldier brought a Paper in his hand to Church, which contained the names of the Soldiers, to the end notice might be taken who came, and who came not to Church, that the Absenters might be mulited, upon this he was commanded to withdraw.

Walter James being brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Armes, William Bedloe was called and asked what he had to say against him who said he knowes the said Walter James, and had seen him in Monmouth, but hath not had any converse with him, nor can charge him with any thing more than that he hath heard from the Jesuites, that the said Walter James, was to be Secretary to the Earl of Powis.

To which Walter James by way of answer said, that he was well known in his Country to have no hand in any Design, that he was a Commissioner for managing Edward Marquess of Worcesters Estate, but was never Secretary to the Earl of Powis nor hath not seen him these Six years, upon which they being withdrawn, the Lords made the following Order.

Whereas Walter James of the County of Monmouth Esquire, was this day b • ought to the bar by the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, and there heard what he had to say to what William Bedloe could alledg against him, after consideration had thereof. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Walter James shall at the Bar of this House give security by Recognizance of Five hundred pound to appear when he shall be thereunto required by this House, and thereupon be discharged from the restraint he is now under paying his fees, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon reading the information of Charl's Morgan of Langattock Lingoed in the County of Monmouth Gentleman taken upon Oath against Henry Milborne Esquire, as also some Certificates on the behalf of the said Henry Milborne, and a Coppy of a Letter sent by the Marquess of Worcester to the Justices of the
peace for the Couery of Monmouth, and their answer thereunto concerning a Paper of the names of Priests and Jesuites in the said County of Monmouth, as likewise two Lists one of Popish Families, that were in the said County in the late Kings Reign and now succeeded by Protestants, the other of Persons perverted in the said County this day delivered into this house, and other matters in the enclosed Copies mentioned upon consideration had thereof. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament • ssembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord Bishop of Landaffe calling to his assistance, Thomas Lewis of S • . Peeres Esquire, William Keymish Esquire, Sir Herbert Evans Knight, Thomas Morgan of Lansore Esquire, and Thomas Herbert of Uske Esquire, or such of them as upon due summons shall appear, to enquire into & examine the matter contained in the said informations and other matters in the said Certificates and Papers expressed, and to send for and examine such Persons as they shall think fit for finding out the truth of the matters of Fact therein set forth, and to give this house a full account thereof so soon as his Lordship so assisted with Conveniency can.

O • dered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this house, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order for a speedy account to be taken of the Papists that reside within His Majesties Court of Whitehall or the Verge thereof, and Sommerset house, and returned to this house.

div.head: Die Veneris Sexto Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Charles Lord Delawar took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in persuance of an Act entituled an Act for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Williams &c. That the Commons have agreed upon an humble Address to be presented to His Majesty, to which they desire their Lordships Concurrence.
The said Address was read and after some Debate, the question being put whether to agree to this Address as it is now worded, it was resolved in the affirmative.

We your Majesties most Loyal and Dutifull Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons in Parliament Assembled, having sufficient Testimony of the present Danger threatning your Majesties Sacred Person and Government, from the pernicious Plots & contrivances of Popish Pers • ns universally spread over this your Majesties Kingdom, do most humbly beseech your Majesty for the safety of your own Person and Security of the publick peace of your Kingdom. To command and require your Majesties Sheriffs, Justices of the Peace, Majors and other Magistrates within their several and respective Counties, Cities and Places in England and Wales. To apprehend, disarm and secure all Popish Recusants, and all others who shall or may be justly suspected Papists, and them to Oblidge in Recognizances with sufficient Baile to keep the peace and be of good behaviour, and in default thereof them to imprison and to returne the names of such Persons with their Recognizances to the next general Sessions of the Peace, for their respective Limits to proceed thereupon according to Law.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Timothy Baldwyn and Sir Andrew Hcaket, to let them know, that this house agrees with the House of Commons in the Address to be presented to His Majesty, and that the Lords do intend to know His Majesties pleasure, what time he will appoint both Houses to wait upon him to present the same, and as soon as their Lordships knowes His Majesties pleasure, they will give the Commons notice thereof.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do attend His Majesty to know his pleasure, when both Houses may attend him with an Address for taking security of the Papists for keeping the peace of the Kingdom.

The House being moved on the behalf of John Monson Gold-smith a reputed Popish Recusant, who in Obedience to His Majesties late Proclamation Dated the 30th. of October last hath left his house in London, that he may have liberty to come to Town for disposing and settling the affaires of diverse Persons, whose concerns are in his hands. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Monson hath hereby Liberty and Authority given him to come and stay in London for the space of ten Days next after his coming to Town for that purpose onely and no longer.

Ordered, that Mr. Roger Kenion Clerk of the Peace for the County of Lancaster, be and is hereby required to attend this House within one week next after notice given him of this Order, and hereof he may not fail.

Upon information given to this House of a Paper Dated from Finder the 28th. of November 1678. and Signed R S. In which is mentioned made of an intended meeting of Five Hundred Armed Men at a Place called Nungreene in the Town of Derby, on Munday then next coming in the middle of the Night. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby referred to the Lords Committees for Examining Persons and Papers, to send for such Persons as they shall think fit and examine them for the finding out the truth of the matter of Fact in the said Paper mentioned, and give the House an account thereof.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Clarendon from the Lords Committees appointed to examine Persons and Papers &c. That their Lordships think it necessary that Sir Henry Titchborne a Popish Recusant now Prisoner in the Goale at Winchester be brought up to Town. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, his Deputy or Deties shall forthwith repair to Winchester, and bring thence the said Sir Henry Titchborne and deliver him into His Majesties Tower of London, there to remain in safe Custody till further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon reading of a Letter written by Mr. Jennison to his Son Thomas Jennison a Jesuite in Newgate, perswading him to discover what he knowes concerning the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government.

The House thought it to be a more effectual way to compass that design for M. Jennison to come up in Person, to that end the Bishop of Durham is desired to write to John Jennison which his Lordship undertook.
Hodie prima vice licita est Billa, an Act disabling Popish Recusants to exercise certain Trades and Occupations.

div.head: Die Sabbati Septimo Decembris 1678.
div.p: UPon Information given to this House, that at a place called Ripley in Yorkshiere there is a Nunnery wherein Women are Educated in the Popish Religion. It is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord Arch-Bishop of York, to inquire into the matter of the said information, and to send for & examine such Persons as his Grace shall think fit, for finding out the truth of the matter of Fact, & if it prove so, to inquire why it hath been overseen so long, and to give this House a full account thereof so soon as his Grace with conveniency can.

Upon Information given to this House of a place in Herefordshiere called Combe, that the said House and Three Hundred Pound p • an. belongeth to the Church of Rome, and that Five or Six Jesuites commonly reside there, and that in the Chappel there, Mass is said constantly, and that the place is commonly called and known by the name of the Jesuits Colledg by the Papists, upon consideration had thereof, It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord Bishop of Hereford calling to his assistance, such Justices of the Peace of the said County as his Lordship shall think fit to enquire into the information aforesaid, and to send for and examine such Persons as his Lordship so assisted shall think necessary, for finding out the truth of the matter of Fact concerning the said place called Combe, and to give this House a full account thereof so soon as his Lordship with convenience can.

The House being moved that the Lord Bellasis Servant Edward Dowling, who is now in Custody in the Gate-house for suspition of Treason may not so be discharged, but that he may be forthwith coming at the Trials of the Pee • s now in Prison.
