It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Chief Justice of England be and is hereby appointed to send for and examine the said Edward Dowling, and if his Lordship shall see cause to give him any liberty, he is to take good Security for the appearing of the said Edward Dowling at the said Tryals.

The House having directed an Order of the fourth instant to the Bishop of Landaffe (calling to his assistance Thomas Lewis of St. Peers Esquire, William K • ynish Esquire, Sir Herbert
Evans, Thomas Morgan of Lansore Esquire, and Thomas Herbert of Uske Esquire) to inquire into the informations therein mentioned relating to Captain Spalding and the Garrison of Chepstow Castle. It is this Day Ordered, that his Lordship (with such of the said Persons as upon due Summons shall appear) may inquire into the said matters, and Certify as if it had been so expressed in the said Order.

The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure, to proceed in the Consideration of heads for preserving the Person of his Majesty and Government and securing the Protestant Religion, the House being resumed, the Earl of Bridgewater reported, that the Committee have been in consideration this day how to prevent the Education of the Children of Papists in the Popish Religion, and also have heard the Opinion of the Judges now present, why the Statutes have not been put into Execution for that purpose, that the Committee desires that the said Judges (viz.) the Lord Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas, the Lord Chief Baron of the Court of Exchequor, and Mr. Justice Windham to consider of the Statutes, for preventing the Education of Children in Popish Seminaries beyond the Seas, and prepare a Bill for remeding the Defects in the Execution of the said Statutes, upon the whole matter of the Debate had this Day in the Committee of the whole House, whereat the said Judges were present and particularly to provide against the Education of Daughters in Nunneries, and to present the same to this House as soon as conveniently they can, all which the House agreed to, and Ordered the same accordingly.

Sir Ellis Leighton being brought to the Bar by the Keeper of Newgate, Titus Oates was called in, and did look on him, and was asked if he k • ew him, to which he said he had no Personal knowledge of him, nor hath conversed with him, and if he hath seen him before it was in another habit, but he said that Letters from Le Cheese to the Colledge at St. Omers expressed, that Sir Ellis Leighton was instrumental with Mr. Coleman in carrying on the Design.

Then Sir Ellis Leighton said to this effect, that he being in France when he intended to come for England with the Earl of Sunderland, came as soon as he was able (hearing of the Design) with intent to serve His Majesty, that he never before now saw or heard of Titus Oates, he said he may be guilty of indiscretion, but he is not guilty of any ill intention, that he hath lived in trouble some times, but desires he may Dy in Peace, and so was Ordered to withdraw.

Wpon consideratlon had thereof, the House Ordered that Sir Ellis Leighton do presently enter into a Recognizance to appear when he shall be required, and he being called in again, did enter into a Recognizance as followeth.
Memorandum quod Ellis Leighton miles recognovit se dcbere Domino Regi mille libras levari ex terris, tenementis, bonis & catallis suis ad usum Domini Regis.

The abovesaid condition of the Recognizance is, that if the abovesaid Sir Ellis Leighton Knight shall appear Personally before the Lords in Parliament, when he shall be thereunto required by this House, then this Recognizance to be void, otherwise to stand in full force and vertue.

Whereas Sir Ellis Leighton Knight a Prisoner in Newgate, was this day brought to the Bar by the Keeper of Newgate, and there heard what he had to say upon what Titus Oates had to say against him, and upon consideration had thereof, the said Sir Ellis Leighton did presently enter into a Recognizance of one thousand pound to the Kings Majesty, to be levyed on his goods, lands and tenements, to the use of our Soveraign Lord the King, upon condition that if he the said Sir Ellis Leighton shall appear before the Lords in Parliament, when he shall be thereunto required by this House, then this his Recognizance shall be void, or otherwise to stand in full force and vertue, it is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Sir Ellis Leighton be and is hereby discharged from his present Imprisonment in Newgate, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
Walter James was called in and entred into the Recognizance following.
Memorandum quod Walterus James Arm recognovit se debere Domino regi mille libras levari ex terris, tenementis, bonis & catallis suis ad usum Domini regis.

The Condition of the abovesaid Recognizance is, that if the said Walter James shall appear Personally before the Lords in Parliament, when he shall be thereunto required by this House, then this Recognizance to be void, otherwise to stand in full force and vertue.

The House being moved on the behalf of Nicholas Plunket of Dunsosoghly in the Kingdom of Ireland, that he may have liberty to come and settle his Affairs in Town, and so pass away to Ireland, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal
in Parliament Assembled, that the said Nicholas Plunket be and is hereby authorized and permitted to come and stay in Town, for ten days next after his coming to Town, and no longer for settling his Affairs here, and then to repair with two Servants viz. James Plunket and Edmond Leianagh to any of His Majesties Sea-ports of this Kingdom, and to pass thence into the Kingdom of Ireland without the let, stay or interruption of any Person or Persons whatsoever, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Essex from the Lords Committees appointed to examine Persons and Papers, that their Lordships have perused the Papers lately delivered to them (by His Majesties Order) by one of the Clerks of the Councel and desire the direction of the House for the disposal thereof, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Papers shall be returned to the Clerk of the Councel, by whom they were delivered to the said Lords Committees.

Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. Charles Gifford, Francis Yates and his Wife, William Penderel, John Penderel, Richard Penderel, Humphrey Penderel, and George Penderel, Mr. Thomas Whitegrave of Mosely, Collonel William Carlos, and Mr. Francis Reynold of Carleton in the County of Bedford, who were Instrumental in the preservation of his Majesties Person after the battle of Worcester, or such of them as are now living shall for their said service live as freely as any of His Majesties Protestants Subjects, without being lyable or subject to the penalties of any of the Laws relating to Popish Recusants, and that a Bill be prepared and brought into this House for that pu • pose, and the name of Mr. John Huddleston be inserted therein.

div.head: Die Lunae 9. Decembris 1678.
div.p:
UPon Report made from the Lords Committees for Examining Papers, that upon perusal of the Lord Arundel of Warders Papers, their Lordships find some which may be of use at the Tryal of the Lords, who are impeached by the
House of Commons, and crave directions from the House, whether they may deliver them to a Committee of the House of Commons, appointed to prepare Articles of Impeachment against the said Lords, it is Ordered, that the Lords Committees shall cause the said Papers of the Lord Arundel of Warder, to be inventoried by the Clerk attending them, and then deliver them to the said Committee of the House of Commons.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Essex from the Lords Committees, appointed to consider of the Bill disabling Popish Recusants, to exercise certain Trades and occupations, that the said Order for drawing the Bill is short of attaining the end intended (viz) that no Common or Civil Lawyers, Attorneys, Proctors, Sollicitors, Physitians, Apothecaries, Chirurgeons, nor Midwives shall be permitted after conviction of Popish Recusancy, to exercise their callings any where in England nor to remain in Town, and that no Tradesman whatsoever of His Majesties natural born subjects being convict Popish Recusants, shall after a time limited be permitted to live in London, Westminster, or the Suburbs or Liberties thereof, it is Ordered, that their Lordships assisted by Mr. Justice Atkins do fit the Bill accordingly, and then report it to the House.

It was moved, that a small Addition may be made to the Address to His Majesty, concerning the Lord Audley the 30tb. of November last, which being agreed to, the Address with the said Addition followeth.

The Lord Audley a Member of this House refusing to take the Oathes, and subscribe the Declaration prescribed by the Act of Parliament lately passed, and having taken his leave of their Lordships, and expressing his great duty to His Majesty, and the welfare and Peace of this Kingdom, to the great satisfaction of the whole House, the House commanded the Lord Chancellor to recommend the Lord Audley from this House to His Majesty, f • r his favor and grace considering his Antient Descent, and the great Actions done by his Ancestors in France in former times, and the small Estate and Fortune left to his Family by reason of his Fortune spent in that service by his Ancestors.

Upon reading the Pe • ition of Nathan Rogers, now in the Custody of the Serjeant at Armes attending this House, praying that he may be discharged, submitting himself to the Judgment of this House, it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Nathan Rogers shall be brought to the Bar of this House, to
morrow at ten of the Clock in the Forenoon by the Serjeant at Armes, and there be heard what he hath to say for himself.
A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir William Beversham and Sir John Hoskins, to desire a present Conference in the Painted Chamber upon matters of importance.
The Lord Privy Seal Reported, what the Committee had prepared to be delivered at this Conference, which was read as followeth.

The Lords have desired this Conference with the House of Commons to acquaint them, that being informed that His Majesty hath sent Orders, for withdrawing the Forces out of Flanders in Order to their disbanding, many difficulties and dangers do occur to their Lordships, if such Rules and Orders be not established by consideration and advice of both Houses, that the disbanding may be made with safety, which their Lordshs. conceive cannot be by bringing such a power together to the Forces already here, and do therefore purpose that the Forces here may not be increased by the accession of more from abroad, but that a proportionable number of those here may be disbanded before the Regiments from Flanders shall arrive, and that after consideration hereof by the Commons, by joynt advice of both Houses a Reglement may be made accordingly.
The Lord Chancellor Reported His Majesties Answer to the Add • ess of both Houses for securing Popish Recusants, and His Majesty will issue out a Proclamation as is desired.

div.head: Die Martis 10. Decembris 1678.
div.p:
ORdered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lord Chancellor do forthwith write Letters to all the Peers and Prelates, Members of this House, who have not taken the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy and Subscribed the Declaration in the Act lately passed, obliging them thereunto, requiring the said
Lords to come and attend His Majesties service in the House of Peers, intimating in the said Letters, that such of the said Lords as are within Fifty Miles of this place do give their said attendance within one week after their receipt of the Letters to them respectively sent, and that those Lords who are at a greater distance from this place give their attendance within a Fortnight next after their receipt of the said Letters, and that every of those Lords who through Age or Sickness cannot come up do within the times to them respectively limited for their attendance, send two credible Persons to attend this House, to avow upon Oath at the Bar the true cause why such Lord cannot attend this House according to his summons.
Ordered. That the House be put into a Committee to Morrow Morning, to proceed in consideration of heads for the preserving the Kings Person and his Government, and securing the Protestant Religion.

div.head: Die Mercurii Undecimo Decembris 1678.
div.p: Ordered, By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that His Majesties writ of Habe as corpus ad testificandum be directed to the Sheriff of Bristol, for bringing Dominico Gratiano before the Lords in Parliament, to testify against Josephas Georgerine concerning Dangerous words uttered by the said Josephus Georgerine.

Upon reading the Petition of Captain Francis Spalding a Prisoner in the Kings-Bench by Order of this House, praying he may have his Liberty upon Bail. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees for examining of Persons and Papers do examine and sum up what the said Francis Spalding stands charged within this House, and makes Report thereof to the House to morrow Morning.
Hodie prima vice licita est Bila, an Act for the more effectual preventing the sending or going of the Children of Popish Recusants beyond the Seas.

The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure to proceed in considering of heads, for preserving the Person of His Majesty and his Government, and securing the Protestant Religion, the House was resumed.

The Earl of Bridgwater Reported the Committee are of Opinion, that an Act or some clause of an Act may be prepared to declare, that such Persons as shall turne from the Popish Religion to the Protestant Religion, from a day to be named in that Act shall be free from the Penalties of all Statutes against Popish Recusants, but shall not be capable of any Office or Imployment, Civil or Military, or be Head of a House in either of the Universities for the space of two years next following.
That provision by an Act or some clause of an Act may be made that the Declaration comprised in the Act lately passed the Royal Assent, shall be made and subscribed by all great Officers once a year.
div.q: Which Report the House agreed to.

div.head: Die Jovis 12. Decembris 1678.
div.p: Hodie secunda vice licita est Billa, an Act for the more effectual preventing the sending or going of Children of Popish Recusants beyond the Seas.

The Earl of Essex Reported, that the Committee have considered the Bill against Popish Recusants exercising certain Traids, wherein there are so many alterations made that the Committee were forced to write over a new, the said Bill fair written was read, and compared with the first draught, but there being several other amendments Offered, the House was put into a Committee to consider of them and make them agreable to the Bill, the House being resumed, the Lord Privy Seal Reported the amendments which were read and agreed to, and the Bill Ordered to be engrossed with those amendments.
A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir William Beversham and Sir Edward Lowe to put them in minde of the Bill formerly sent down, for the Conviction of Popish Recusants.

Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the respective Governours and Masters of the several Conduits, Water-works and Water-pipes, used for the service of the Cities of London and Westminster and the respective liberties thereof, be and they are hereby required to take special care that no Papist or reputed Papist be by any of them entertaind in any kind of service belonging to the said Conduits,
Water-works or Water Pipes, as they and every of them will answer the contrary to this House.
The Lord Viscount Newport Reported His Majesties answers to three Addresss of this House presented him viz.
1. That for preventing the • candalous resort of Numbers of His Majesties Subjects, to the Chappels of forreign Ministers residing here.
His Majesty hath given Order for the remedying thereof.
2. To that for a List of the Numbers Names and Places of aboade, of the Priests belonging to forreign Ministers.
His Majesty hath appointed Mr. Secretary Coventry to go to the said Minister for such a List as is desired.
3. To that for an account of the Papists in White-hall, and the Verge thereof and Sommerset house.
His Majesty saith, that a List of them shall be speedily brought in.
4. To that of tendering the Oaths to Lawyers, Phisitians and Apothecaries.
His Majesty hath given Order for issuing Commissions, for administring the Oaths as is desired.

Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with White Staves do attend His Majesty humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to signify to the forreign Ministers residing here, that all such Persons as are their proper Servants may reside in their Families, and that no Persons being His Majesties Subjects and exercising any Traid here may plead the priviledge of being their servants, and also that by His Majesties Royal Mediation, the English Factories in forreign parts may have Chaplaines professing the Protestant Religion allowed to them, and that His Majesty will be pleased to take Ordet that no Agents, Residents or Consults may be imployed abroad, but such as are Protestants, and lastly that His Majesty will be pleased to take into his special care the Protestant interest abroad.

Upon Report from the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers for the Discovery of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, that they have received and read a Petition o • Sir George Charnocke Serjeant at Arms attending this House, shewing that he hath apprehended several Persons ingaged in the said design, and hath not any place to secure them in while they attend the pleasure of the House, or of the said Committee but in the Painted Chamber, which being constantly filled with Pages, Lacquees and all sorts of people, he cannot sufficiently secure his Prisoners there
notwithstanding the vigilancy and care he and his Deputies can use, and therefore praying that some convenient place neer the House of Peers may be assigned to him for that purpose. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be and is hereby recommended to the Lord high Chamberlain of England, to appoint some such place to the said Serjeant at Arms for the purpose aforesaid, during this present necessity as his Lordship shall think fit.

Upon information given to this House that the Sheriffs of the County and City of Bristol, who by Order of the 30th of November last were required to send up Dominico Gratiano in safety from Bristol to attend the House of Peers, express their willingness to Obey the said Order, but doubt whether such sending up the said Dominico Gratiano (who is now a Prisoner in Newgate there for debt) should not be accounted an escape in Law, for which the said Sheriffs must be answerable to the Creditor upon consideration had thereof. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Sheriffs do take care forthwith to send up the said Dominico Gratiano from Bristol to attend this House with such Keeper or Attendance as the said Sheriffs shall think fit, for securing the safe return of the said Dominico Gratiano to Bristol, when he hath been heard before this House upon his Depositions against Josephus Ceorgerine, and that the bringing up and returning the said Dominico Gratiano shall be allowed to the said Sheriffs upon their account in the Exchequer, and this shall be a sufficient Indemnity or Warrant on that behalf.

This House being moved by the Lords Committees appointed to examine Papers concerning the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, that a blanck Warrant may be issued and signed by the Clerk of the Parliament, for seizing some Papers which may make further Discovery thereof, and that their Lordships may be intrusted to insert the plaee to be searched for the said Papers, and also the Names of the Persons who shall execute the said Warrant to prevent a Discovery of the intended seizure upon consideration had thereof. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temp • ral in Parliament Assembled, that such a blanck Warrant shall be issued as is desired, so as the said search be not to be made in the house of any member of either House of Parliament, which their Lordships assured the House they would take care of.

div.head: Die Veneris 13. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Daurel Lord Holles took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declararation in pursuance of the Act for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.
Hodie tertia vice licita est Billa, an Act disabling Popish Recusants, to exercise certain Traids and Occupations.
The question being put whether this Bill shall pass, it was resolved in the affirmative.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir William Beversham and Sir Edward Lowe, to deliver the Bill for disabling Popish Recusants to exercise certain Traids and Occupations, and desire their Concurrence thereunto.

Edward Whitaker being called for to answer the charge against him sent up from the Major of Worcester, but being not to be found. It is Ordered, that if the said Ed. Whitaker come not and render himself before the House Rises he shall be attached, and he not coming. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House or his Deputy do forthwith attach the Body of Edward Whitaker of London Gentleman, and bring him in safe Custody to the Bar of this House to morrow Morning to answer to the informations put into this House upon Oath against him, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure to proceed further in considering of Heads, for preserving the Person of His Majesty and his Kingdom and securing the Protestant Religion.

The House being resumed the Earl of Bridgewater Reported that the Committee having proceeded further are of Opinion, that an Act or some clause of an Act may be prepared to provide that all such Persons as shall be perverted from the Protestant Rel • gion to Popery, shall be shipped away never to return into this Kingdom, nor shall inherit the Estates of their Ancestors here, but the Estates to go to the next of Kindred to them who are Protestants.

That all the Lawes now in force concerning either Persons perverting or Persons perverted, from the Protestant Re •• g •
on to Popery, be continued in the same force they now are,

And that the Judges who shall be appointed to f • ame
these Heads into an Act, take care that nothing therein to be contained may interfere with any of the Lawes now in being concerning this point.

div.head: Die Sabbati 14. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day John Earl of Bristol took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and Subscrbed the Declaration in pursuance of the late Act, for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

Upon reading the Petition of John Thimbleby Esquire, now Prisoner in the Kings Bench, as being charged to be knowing of the Horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, shewing how unexpressibly he is prejudiced in his health and otherwise by his imprisonment, and that he will be ready to attend this House upon any Summons. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, upon the Prayer of the Petitioner that he may be set at liberty for the recovery of his health, that the said John Thimbleby shall be brought to the Bar of this House by the Keeper of the Prison of the Kings-Bench, to enter into Recognizance to His Majesty for his appearance upon Summons, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Whereas Edward Whitaker was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, to answer to the informations against him which he denies, alledging that he hath witnesses to clear himself from the matters charged on him, upon consideration had thereof. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Edward Whitaker may and shall have an Order for Summoning his said witnesses to be heard Viva Voce on the second Day of the sitting of the Parliament, next after Christmas if he desires it, at which time also the witnesses who have informed against him shall be Summoned to be heard Viva Voce, and that in the mean time the said Serjeant at Arms shall deliver the said Edward Whitaker into the Prison of Newgate, there to remain in safe Custody till further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon reading the Petition of Richard Grosvener Esquire. shewing that in Obedience to His Majesties late Proclamation
he hath removed himself above Ten miles from London, and being desirous not to give any disquiet to His Majesties Peace or the Government, therefore praying that he may have leave to depart out of this Kingdom. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Richard Grosvener be and is hereby authorized and permitted to repair to any of His Majesties Sea Ports of this Kingdom, and to pass thence into France, Holland or any other Forreign parts out of His Majesties Dominions within ten Days after the date hereof, without the Let, stay or interruption of any Person or Persons whatsoever, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Whereas Henry Barnesly who was by Order of this House sent for from the Goal in Worcester, was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Arms attending this House and there examined being supposed to be a Popish Priest. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Henry Barnesly shall by the said Serjeant at Arms or his Deputy or Deputies be returned into the Goal in Worcester, there to remain in safe Custody till he shall be thence delivered by due course of Law, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

div.head: Die Lunae 16. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Thomas Lord Cromwell took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and Subscribed the Declaration in persuance of the Act for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty and his Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The House being moved that the Earl of Essex, the Earl of Shaftesbury and the Lord Viscount Hallifax may repair to Newgate for examining a Prisoner there, from whence it is hoped some light may be had for further discovery of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person & Government. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Earl of Essex, the Earl of Shaftesbury, and the Lord Viscount Hallifax, have leave hereby given them to repair to Newgate to examine any one of the Prisoners there, in Order to such Discovery as is aforesaid.

Upon Oath made at the Bar of this House, that George Osborn
Bricklayer hath been duly Summoned by an Order of the Lords Committees appointed, to examine Persons and Papers relating to to the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, to attend their Lordships this Morning which he hath neglected to do. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms-attending this House, or his Deputy shall attach the Body of the said George Osborn and bring him in safe Custody before the Lords Committees to morrow Morning at Nine of the Clock, in the Lord Privy Seals Lodgings near the House of Peers, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Whereas John Thimbleby Esquire a Prisoner in the Kings-Bench as being charged to be knowing of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, having by his humble Petition represented to this House how much he is prejudiced in his health and otherwise, and that if he may by the favor of this House have his liberty, he will be ready to appear upon any summons, was thereupon this day brought to the Bar by the Keeper of the Prison of the Kings-Bench, where he hath entred into a Recognizance of One thousand pound to the Kings Majesty, Conditioned that he the said John Thimbleby will appear upon summons when ever he shall be thereunto required by this House. It is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Thimbleby be and is hereby discharged from his present imprisonment in the Kings-Bench for the cause above mentioned, paying his Fees due to the Officers attending this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Speaker acquainted the House that the Lord Chancellour having (according to the directions of this House) written Letters to all Lords who are absent, his Lordship hath received two Letters of answer, one from the Duke of Newcastle, and the other from the Lord Viscount Compden, and Thomas Palmer and Bartholomew Rudle servants to the said Lord Viscount Compden, deposed at the Bar upon their Oaths, that his Lordship was so sick that he was not able to stir him in his Bed, and Company to watch with him every Night, and they did beleive his Lordship could not come to London without danger of his life, which excuse the House allowed of.
A Question was proposed whether that a Message should be sent to the House of Commons to mind them of bringing up Articles against the Lords they have impeached in some convenient time.
Then this previous Question was put whether this Question shall be now put, it was resolved in the Negative.

div.head: Die Martis 17. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Nicholas Earl of Thannet took the Oaths and Subscribed the Declaration in persuance of an Act, for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty and his Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The Earl of Huntingdon Reported, that the Committee have considered the Bill against sending the Children of Papists to be bread in Popish Seminaries beyond the Seas, in which they have made some Amendments whicb were read twice and agreed to, and the Bill is Ordered to be engrossed with the said Amendments.

The House being moved by the Duke of Albermarle, that he may have leave to go into the Country for ten Days, in Order to the publick Service of His Majesty by some further Discovery (his Grace hopes to make) of the Plot, and that in the mean time he will be ready to attend the House at a days warning when ever he shall have notice thereof, the House gave him leave to go into the Country for ten Days for the purpose aforesaid.

This House being informed by the Lord Bishop of Durham, that John Jennison father of Thomas Jennison now Prisoner in Newgate, is coming to Town in Order to his endeavouring to prevail with his Son to make some further Discovery of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal Assembled, that His Majesties Attourny General have forthwith notice thereof.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Essex from the Lords Committees, for examining Persons and Papers for the Discovery of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, that their Lordships have perused some Papers, which were seized at one Mr. Collins house by Warrant of Mr. Secretary Coventry, amongst which they find many Letters and Writings of Robert Pugh a Popish Priest, in some of which are very Scandal • us Reflections upon the Kings Majesty, and desiring the direction of the house for the disposal thereof. It
is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that when their Lordships have perfectly Sorted and Methodized the said Papers, they deliver them to His Majesties Attourny General to be by him made use of as he shall see cause.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Clarendon from the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers, for the Discovery of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, that their Lordships have perused the Papers and Writings of the Lord Arundel of Warder, which were seized and by Order of this House delivered into the Custody of the Clerk of the Parliament, and have taken out such of them as may be Evidence in Order to the further discovery of the horrid Design, and desiring the directions of the House for the disposal of the Remainder thereof. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that all such of the Lord Arundel of Warders Papers as are only of private concernment may be delivered by the Clerk of the Parliament, to such Person or Persons as the Lord Arundel of Warder shall appoint to receive the same, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon reading the Petition of John Gerard now a Prisoner in the Kings-Bench upon Suspition of being a Popish Priest, shewing that he is very much impaired in his health by his imprisonment and there destitute of means for recovery thereof, and that he will be ready to appear at any time, and therefore praying that he may have his Liberty giving security for his appearance. It is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Gerard with the Keeper of the Kings-Bench Prison attending him shall before any one of the Judges or any Justices of the Peace give very good security in the Sum of Two hundred pound for his appearance, from time to time, and thereupon he is hereby discharged from his present imprisonment in the Kings-Bench for that cause, paying his Fees due to the Officers attending this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Essex from the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers, that their Lordships have examined George Osborne a Bricklayer, who was brought before them in Custody concerning some Arms by him closed up in some place of the Roof of the Lord Bishop of Winchesters house at Chelsey, which the said George Osborne having upon his Oath owned the doing. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled that the said George Osborne
be discharged, and that the Committee inquire further into this matter.

The Earl of Shaftesbury Reported, that the Lords who had leave of this House to examine a Prisoner in Newgate had some speech with Mr. Langhorne, but could not get nothing from him, but found by reason of the great strictness he is kept under that he did not know of the Execution of Mr. Coleman, the Opinion of their Lordships is, that the said Mr. Langhorn may have some liberty given him, whereby he may have such access of Friends as is necessary for him to have.

div.head: Die Mercurii 18. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Heneage Earl of Winchelsea took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and Subscribed the Declaration in persuance of the Act for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty and his Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.
Hodie tertia vice licita est Billa, an Act for the more effectual preventing the sending or going of the Children of Popish Recusants into parts beyond the Seas out of the Kings Obedience.
The Question being put whether this Bill shall pass, It was resolved in the affirmative.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Samuel Clerk and Sir William Child to deliver to them the Bill to prevent the sending of Popish Recusants Children beyond the Seas, and of the Kings Obedience, and to desire their concurrence thereunto.

Whereas John Rigmagden Servant to the Lord Arundel of Warder was by Order of the 3. of December instant committed to the Prison of the Gate▪house, for matters proved upon oath against him, this House being this day moved that in regard he hath been in Prison so long, the said John Rigmagden may be enlarged from his imprisonment upon Bail. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Rigmagden given sufficient Bail before the Lord Chief Justice of England for his appearance from time to time, be and is hereby discharged from his imprisonment in the Gate house, paying his Fees due to the Officers attending
this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The Lord Arch-Bishop of Canterbury having this day brought into this House a Box of Papers, which he found in his House at Lambeth at his first coming thither (which was heretofore seized at the Custom house) in which are many Papers relating to Robert Pugh a Popish Priest now in Custody. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be referred to the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers for discovery of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, to peruse the said Papers and dispose of them to Mr. Attourney General if they see cause.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Thomas Lee and others to acquaint their Lordships, that the Commons having matters of great moment before them have resolved to sit in the Christmas Holy days, except on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.

div.head: Die Jovis 19. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Charls Earl of Carnarvan and James Lord Norris took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and Subscibed the Declaration in persuance of an Act for the more effectual preserving the Person of His Majesty and his Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The Lord Bishop of Durham acquainted the House that Mr. Jennison Father to Thomas Jennison a Prisoner in Newgate is come to Town, and is at Door to attend their Lordships pleasure, who being called in, the Speaker told him that the House took Notice of his good intention in coming to Town, to try whether he can prevail with his Son to discover what he knowes concerning the horrid Design against the Person of His Majesty and the Government, and thereupon made the ensuing Order.

Whereas John Jennison Father of Thomas Jennison now Prisoner in Newgate, being come to Town, hath appeared this day at the Bar and undertaken to use his Utmost endeavour to prevail with the said Son, to confess and make discovery of what he knowes concerning the the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government. It is Ordered by the
Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said John Jennison and also Mr. Smith a Kinsman of his, be and are hereby authorized and permitted to have free access to the said Thomas Jennison in Newgate as often as they or either of them shall see cause, and they are to give this House an account concerning this matter, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon the desire of Mr. Jennison that one Mr. Smith who is lately come off from being of the Church of Rome, and hath taken the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, that he may be permitted to Preach. It is Ordered. that the said Mr. Smith do attend the L. Bishop of Durham and give him sati • faction of the realty of his Conversation and Abilities, and upon his Lordships Report, this House will consider what Directions to give therein.

div.head: Die Veneris 20. Decembris 1678.
div.p: WHereas Daniel Maccarty a Romish Priest was by Order of the 29th. of November last, brought from the Goal at Thetford in the County of Norfolk by the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, and is now in Custody here. It is this day Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers, for discovery of the horrid design against His Majesties Person and Government, shall examine the said Daniel Maccarty, and if their Lordships find that he is not charged with any particulars relating to the said Design against His Majesty, he is to be remitted and left to the Law, but if otherwise their Lordships are to Report to the House what they find concerning him.
Ordered, that Henry Thorne who was yesterday examined before the Lords Committees be and is hereby required to attend this House to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.
The Earl of Shaftesbury Reported from the Lords Committees, for Examinations an Examination of Henry Thorne which was read as followeth.
The examination of Henry Thorne of Ipswich in Suffolk taken upon Oath the 19. Day of December 1678. before the Lord Chief Justice of England.

This examinant saith, that the day before St. Georg's
Day last he went from Capel, and on St Georg's Day in the Evening he came to Mr. Tasbroughs house called Flixen Hall to see his Brother Thomas Thorne then Butler to the said Mr. Tasbrough, and at his coming thither he met with the said Mr. Tasbrough, who bid him go into the Kitchen where his Brother came to him, who carried this Deponent into the Pantry, where he told him that his Master asked him what the Devil he came for, but his Brother answered his said Master that he came to see him, not having heard from him since his Mother and He were there, whereupon his Master replied what the the Devil in Hell comes be for, for he was sure he comes for no good, this Deponent further saith that his said Brother charged him not to go to supper with the Servants, whereupon he lockt him in the Pantry were he kept him two or three Houres, and after he came to him again told him he would have him to a house where he should have Bacon and Eggs, and then carried him to Mr. Manclarks house a mile and a half from the said Mr. Tasbrough where he lodged that Night, and the next Morning brought him back to the said Mr. Tasbroughs and gave him cold meat to Eat, and after that he had the Deponent into the Pantry and fetch him a pott of Bear and bid him stay there, while he went to roule a back Yard, and he would come to the Deponent again, but his Brother going into the said back Yard, this Deponent followed him, his said Brother bid him for the Lords sake not to come in here, for if his Master saw him he would be ready to kill him his said Brother, whereupon the Deponent desired to come in to look into the brave Rooms, his Brother replied that no Body comes into that Yard in a Twelvemoneth, except their own Company, but when his Brothers back was turned to roule the said Yard the Deponent looked in at some windowes where he saw nothing, but going to another part of the said Yard to look into another window, his Brother called him, for the Lords sake not to go that way, for if his Master should see him his (the Deponents Brothers) Life would not be worth a farthing, but notwithstanding this, when his Brothers back was again turned, the Deponent looked into a Room on that side of the Yard, where he saw as ncar as he can guess about the number of Foure or Five Hundred Muskets and Pistols, very bright, their Murals stopt with paper and a great number of Swords and Belts fringed with Lew, and Bandaleers as be thought agreable to the number of the Musquets, he saw there likewise a Chest open made with Deal boards about a yard and half long, and a yard over full of new made Bullets, he further saith, that his Brother perceiving what the Deponent had seen said, for the Lords sake do not
speak a word of what he had seen, for if you do my life is not worth a farthing. Whereupon his Brother had him into the Pantry where they drank together, and afterwards his Brother went about three Miles on the way home with him, where discoursing on the way, the Deponent asked him, what is the intent of those Muskets and Pistols, he told him he must not tell, unless he would promise not to tell again, and the Deponent promising not to tell, his said Brother told him that he carried him away last Night, because there were Soldiers to be exercised there that Night. Then the Deponent asked him what do you do exercising, he replied he must not tell him, but I would have you know that we spend more Beaf besides small meat in our house than you do in all your Town. And after som other words he told the Deponent, that they spent two or three and twenty Score of Beaf at least a week, and thereupon be gave the Deponent a Shilling and bid him say nothing of what he had seen or heard, then the Deponent asking his Brother again what their intention was by those Arms, be answered, that there is but one God and there should be but one King and one Religion, and him that you call our Pope we hope shall be our King before Michaelmas Day, whereupon clapping his hands together, he said he was sworne to be true to their Religion (he being a Papist) and these hands of his must help to cut off the Kings head and cut him into Four quarters, whereupon they parted, and the Deponent being troubled in mind related within two or three days after to several People, what he bad seen and heard, except what relates to the Murther of the King, and he desired his Neighbours to whom he related it, that they would have him before a Justice of Peace to be examined

John Whithipol of Topcraft in the County of Norfolk Gentleman maketh Oath, that in August last past being Hawking in the Park of Richard Tasbrough of Flixen in the County of Suffolk Esquire, and not far from the Mansion house of him the said Richard Scituate in the aforesaid Park in Flixen aforesaid, he this Deponent did see a waggon tilted over with white Cloath standing just by the Staires leading to the aforesaid Mansion of the said Richard, out of which said waggon a certain Person to this Deponent unknown delivered a certain Gentleman then and there present (whose name this Deponent knoweth not) about seven or eight Mu • kets o • Ca • bines, five or six Gorgets, six or seven Back and Breast plates coupled together, and a bunch of Javelins or Leaders Staves bound together, and wrapt up so that this Deponent could not tell how
many there was of them, and further this Deponent saith, that he Riding up nearer to the said waggon, one of the Gentlemen then and there present, then first seeing him this Deponent (as he verily believes) Swore God dam me what son of a whore is yonder, and said that he would shoot this Deponent and thereupon he being in fear did Ride away, and did not see the said waggon fully unloaden, and further this Deponent saith that he spoak of what he had seen the same Night, and afterwards to several Persons, no regard being had to the same by any man till after Michalmas last past, though the said Richard is a notorious Recusant, and also of a great Estate (as this Deponent believeth) but that after Michaelmas aforesaid, the said Richard Arrested this Depohent by a Warrant from Sir Peter Gleane one of His Majesties Justices of Peace of the County of Norfolk, and carried him this Deponent before the said Sir Peter, where he offered to make Oath of the premises, but it was refused by the said Sir Peter, and this Deponent required to find sureties for his appearance at the next Sessions to be holden at Norwich, for the said County of Norfolk, which he this Deponent did accordingly, and was and still stands bound over by the said Sir Peter which tends to the u • ter Ruine of this Deponent, he being indebted to several Persons and therefore affraid he should be Arrested, and imprisoned upon his said appearance.

postscript.p: Jurat. coram me Edm. Bolum un. justic. Domini Regis ad pacem in com. Suff. praed. conservandum assignat. &c Septimo Die mensis Decembris Anno Regni Domini nostri Caroli secundi &c. 30m.

dateline.date: Anno Domini 1678. apud Westhall in com. praed.

div.p: Upon information given to the House, that Thomas Thorne now or late servant to Richard Tasbrough Esquire, hath uttered Dangerous and Treasonable word • , and that he is at present in Custody in the Goal at Berry in Suffolk. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, or his Deputy or Deputies shall forthwith repair to Berry and bring thence the Body of the said Thomas Thorne, in safe Custody to the Bar of this House to answer thereunto, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Upon inf • rmation given to this House, that Sir Peter Glean one of His Majesties Justices of Peace, for the County of Morfolk about Michaelmas last past, refused to take the Deposition of John Withipol for the Discovery of Arms conveyed into the house of Richard Tasbrough Esquire, a nototious Recusant
but bound the said John Withipol to appear at the next Sessions at Norwich, at the suit of the said Richard Tasbrough it is Ordered by Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Sir Peter Glean be and is hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House within four Days next after notice given him of this Order, to answer to the said information, and hereof he may not fail.

Mr. Jennison gave the House an account that he hath been with his Son Thomas Jennison a Prisoner in Newgate, and hath prest him what he can to discover what he knowes concerning the horrid Design against the Person of His Majesty and his Government, and he finds him to be a mad man, and so cannot give any account of any thing, hereupon the House dismissed Mr Jennison from any further Attendance.
Ordered, that the Serjeant at Arms do bring Richard Tasbrough to this Bar to morrow Morning at Ten of the Clock.

div.head: Die Sabbati 21. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THe Earl of Essex Reported from the Committee appointed to examine persons and Papers▪ for the discovery of the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government an examination of Richard Gastrel, which was read as followeth.
The examination of Richard Gastrel of the Grange in Gloucester shire Gentleman sworn the 20th. of December 1678. before the Lord Bishop of London.

This Deponent saith, that in the Year 1675. he Travelled to Rome, and being there, he was by many Arts and Perswasi • ns inveagled into the Romish Religion, after which he was entertained by Cardinal Barberini as one of his Gentlemen, where after he had continued about five Moneths he was prevailed with by several English there, and by the said Cardinal to put himself in the English Seminary, where after he had continued about two years and an half he returned home, but whilst he was in the said Colledge, to witt, in Lent last discoursed with Gerard, Ireland and William Denmour (Priests now in England) the said Ireland told him that the Catholicks of England had expected long enough from His Majesty without effect, and that it was in vaine to expect any longer, that the King had been more Oblidged to the Catholicks, and that he
had now forgot their Kindness, that he did no good in England nor did deserve to be King, but was a Shame to all Princes, and that it was no Sin to Kill him, to Which one Serjeant a Scholar replied, why, the said Ireland answered because it would be for the good of the whole Church, for that if thc King were dead, Catholick Religion would soon be brought into England.
And discoursing further of their going into England, the said Ireland and Denmour said they hoped each of them to get a good fat Parsonage there.

This Deponent further saith, that having an Audience of the Pope in the Company of four Priests, and another secular Gentleman all Students of the same Colledge, the Pope understanding they were going for England, and being desirous to know their several States and Conditions, and having demanded of Father Campion who conducted them to the Pope, whether they were all Priests, and understanding by the said Campions answer, that two of them were seculars, he asked of the said two their design of going into England, whether they intended there to be Soldiers, for that they were very fit for the same.

This Deponent further saith, that in the beginning of May last, a few days before his coming away from Rome, he waited on Cardinal Barberini, whom he found sick on his Bed, where coming to him, he bid the said Deponent at parting, (the Rector being present) take care to be true and faithful and serve the Duke of York, which the Rector also desired him to bear in mind, that the Cardinal afterwards applying himself to the said Rector said, that if Catholick Religion were brought into England (notwithstanding his great Age) he would go thither Legat de latere.

dateline.hi: Capt. & jurat die & Annoque coram me H. London.

div.p:
Upon information given to this House, that Gerard, Ireland and William Denmour Popish Priests now in England, are resident in some parts of Yorkshire or Lancashire. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the respective Sheriffs of the County of York and Laneaster, be and are hereby required to use their utmost endeavor for the discovery and apprehending of the said Gerard, Ireland and William Denmour, or either of them, and for the more effectual performance hereof, the said Sheriffs are to Communicate the same to some of the Justices of Peace of their respective Counties, who are also required within their respective limits to be diligent in their endeavours, for the apprehending the said Gerard, Ireland and William Denmorn,
and to give notice thereof to the Sheriffs of the County wherein they or either of them shall be apprehended, to the end, the Sheriffs forthwith send him or them so apprehended in safe Custody to attend this House, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers concerning the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, be and are hereby appointed to peruse and put together all such Papers now before this House, as their Lordships shall Judge fit to be communicated to the House of Commons, in Order to the proceeding to be had against any Person to be tryed for any matter relating to the said Design, and make Report thereof to this House on Munday Morning.

Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Edward Turbervile, who was lately imployed, by the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers concerning the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government, be and is hereby required to attend this House on Munday next at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

Whereas Richard Tasbrough Esquire, was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, to answer to the information put in against him, which he denieth to be true, upon consideration had thereof, and that there is a Warrant of the Lord Chief Justice of England issued, for the the apprehending of the said Richard Tasbrough for Treason. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Serjeant at Arms, deliver the said Richard Tasbrough in safe Custody to such Person or Persons as the Lord Chief Justice of England shall direct and appoint.
Ordered, that George Milborne be brought to the Bar of this House, by the Serjeant at Arms on Munday morning next, and at the same time Mr. Bedloe do attend this House.

div.head: Die Sabbati 24. Decembris 1678. Post Meridiem.
div.p:
ORdered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Dominico Graetiano who is brought up by the Sheriff of Bristol, be carried before the Lord Chief Justice of the Court of Kings-Bench according to
the tenour of the writt of Habeas corpus, that he may be remitted to the Marshalsea with his cause, where he is to remain, to be in a readiness to be sent for as this House shall see cause.

div.head: Die Lunae 23. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day these Lords following took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and Subscribed the Declaration in persuance of the Act, for the more effectual preserving of His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling of Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

For as much as the House was this day informed, that Miles Prance hath made some discovery of the Plot, and hath offered to make further discovery of the Plot, and also touching the Death of Sir Edmond-Bury Godfrey and the whole manner of it, if he might first be fully assured of His Majesties gratious and general Pardon, the Lords appointed the Duke of Buck. the Marquess of Winton, the Earl of Shaftesbury, and the Lord Grey of Werk to attend His Majesty, to acquaint him with this matter and in the name of this House, humbly to desire him to grant to the said Miles Prance his gratious Pardon upon his full discovery, and receive his gratious pleasure thereupon, who immediatly attended His Majesty, and returning did Report to the House that His Majesty was gratiously pleased to promise that Miles Prance shall have a full and general Pardon upon his discovery of the whole matter, whereupon it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Duke of Buck. Marquess of Winton, Earl of Shaftesbury, and the Lord Grey De-Werk or any three of them, do acquaint the said Miles Prance in Newgate this afternoon with His Majesties gratious Assurance, and that they do then and there proceed to examine him throughly in Order to a full and perfect discovery, and that care be taken that no other Person Lord or Commoner be present at the said examination, but the said Lords and the Prisoners.

Upon reading the Petition of Henry Barnesley now in the Custody of the Serjeant at Arms attending this House, shewing that being by Order of this House brought from Worcester, and by like Order to be returned thither again, and that being very old and sickly he is not able to bear the Journey in this hard Season of the year, and therefore praying that he may remaine hereupon Bail. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the said Henry Barnesley (being charged to be a Popish Priest) shall by the said Serjeant at Arms be delivered into the Prison of the Kings Bench, there to remaine in safe Custody till he be better able to be returned to Worcester in Order to his Trial there, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

div.head: Die Jovis 26. Decembris 1678.
div.p: THis day Edward Lord Ward took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and Subscribed the Declaration in persuance of the Act of Parliament, for the more effectual preserving His Majesties Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

The Lord Chancellour acquainted the House that he had received a Letter from the Lord Bishop of Hereford, whereby he excuses himself from giving his attendance on this House, in regard he is enquiring after the Discovery of Combe Abbey by their Lordships directions, where he hath found a Jesuits Colledge and a Library fit for a Colledge of Jesuits, his Lordship is still in prosecution thereof and hopes to discover the Bottom of it, and because those servants as he should send up to give their Lordships an account of his great Age and Infirmities, whereby he is Unable to take so great a Journey are imployed by him in the discovery of Combe, he begs their Lordships pardon for the same.
The Lord Bishop of Landaffe is excused for attending this House for some time, in regard he is imployed by their Lordships directions in examining the Business concerning Chepstow Castle.

Upon information given to thi • House by the Lord Viscount Newport, that one Vallentine Harcourt a Popish Priest is taken and now in Custody in the Goal at Shrewesbery. It is Ordered
by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Sheriff for the County of Salop, be and is hereby required to take and give Order for the sending of the said Valentine Harcourt in safe Custody, to appear at the Bar of this House, and that the Charge of the said Sheriff shall be allowed upon his account in the Court of Exchequer, and it is further Ordered, that the Sheriffs of the respective Counties through which the said Valentine Harcourt shall pass in his being sent up as aforesaid, be Aiding and Assisting to the furtherance thereof as occasion shall require, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that b • half.

Upon complaint made to this House by William Bedloe that he is wronged in the Publication of the Trial of Edward Coleman by inserting what he said not, and Omitting in part what he did say, and upon information that Titus Oats is injured in the same manner. It is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that it be referred to the Lords Committees for examining Persons and Papers concerning the horrid Design against His Majesties Person and Government to examine the matter, and that the Lord Chief Justice of the Court of Kings-Bench be present, and Titus Oats and William Bedloe attending at such time as their Lordships shall appoint for this Business.
The Duke of Monmouth by His Majesties Command communicated to the House, the examinations of Miles Prance and others taken a the Councel Table, which was read as followeth.

div.head: 24th. Decembris 1678.
div.p: MIles Prance a Silver-smith being this day examined at Large, touching the Murther of Sir Edmond-Bury Godfrey, and being upon Oath Interrogated what he knew concerning the Plot, made Oath as followeth.

That he was at Mr. Irelands Cbamber in Russel Street somtime before Michaelmas, and that Fenwick and Grove being there present, Ireland said that there would be Fifty Thousand Men in Arms, Prance asking where they would be had, and what to do, Ireland said we must have them in a Short time to settle Religion, or else all would be Ruined.

That soon after this, Grove came to his Shop to buy two Silver sp •• ns for a Christning, where he was to be Godfather, Prance
asked him what Office he should have in the Army, be answered he did not know, but asking him who was to Govern this Army, he said the Lord Powis, the Lord Bellasis, the Lord Peters and Lord Arundel.
And further saith, that he was also told by Mr. Fenwick that the Lord Powis, Lord Bellasis and Lord Arundel were to command the Army.

He further saith, that there came to his Shop Mr. Le. Fener to huy a second hand sword, and being askt by him what he meant to do therewith, he answered he knew not what times they should have, Prance replying what then shall we poor Tradesmen do, he said when Catholick Religion was brought in, it would be better for Tradesmen, and particularly there would be more Church-work for Gold-smiths.

He further saies that one Mr. Moore that belongs to the Duke of Norfolk, was seen by him Riding in the Streets on a very brave Horse, upon which occasion meeting him afterwards in the Court at Sommerset-house and speaking of that brave Horse, Moore wisht that he had Ten Thousand of them, and hoped in a short time that they might have them for the Catholick cause.
That one Lawrence (an Apothecary in Drury-Lane Over aagainst the end of Queen-Street) when the Oaths were upon tendering, wished that half the Parliament were poysoned, for they would Ruine them all.

He further said, that he hath heard one Mr. Messenger (that belongs to the Lord Arundel) say that he hoped to see the Catholick Religion Flourish here before it belong, and as concerning the Plot he has no more to say.

div.head: Councel Chamber 24. Decembris 1678.
div.p: HIs Majesty having this Morning appointed a Councel Extraordinary, sent for Miles Pranee a Silver-smith and Prisoner in Newgate, for the Murther of Sir Edmond-Bury Godfrey, who aprearing at the Board, His Majesty was pleased to tell him that if he speak the truth, and made it good he would give him his pardon, and the said Prance being sworn did promise that he would faithfully open all his knowledge concerning that Murther, and did declare to the effect following.

That about a Fortnight before the said Murther he was
spoken to by one Gerald an Irish Priest that belonged to the Venetian Ambass. to take place in the Killing of a man not then telling him who it was, but about a week after the said Gerald and one Green an Irish man (that layes Cushions in the Chappel at Sommerset-house) and Lawrence Hill that was formerly servant to Dr. Godden. (and who then lived at the same place in Sommerset-house) did acquaint him that they intended to Kill Sir Edmond Bury Godfrey, for that he was a great Enemy to the Queen or Her servants, and that he had used some Irish men ill, and that Gerald told him that they were imployed by Lord Bellasis and that there would be a reward for them, that he did consent thereunto, and the rather for some Malice he bore unto Sir Edmond, who about two years before [when he was troubled at Hickes-hall about Popish duties] did not consent to his discharge as another Justice did but said, that the Queen had no power of protecting her servants, yet that untill this motion was made him he did not think of what fie had thus formerly past, he said they had been watching him a week or a Fortnight before his death, and that Green had the same Morning called at his house enquiring for him of the Maid, and that the said Green, Gerald and Hill did dogg him from his house that Morning to all the places he went to untill he came to his death. And because His Majesty thought fit for the better ascertaining the Relation he gave touching the place and manner thereof, to appoint his Grace the Duke of Monmouth and the Earl of Ossory to meet the Examinant at Sommerset-house, and a Clerk of the Councel to attend, and take the information from place to place, where the things were Acted.
His Majesty did in the Afternoon sitting in Councel receive the following Report.

In Obedience to Your Majesties Order Signified to us this Morning in Councel, we have been at Sommerset-house and there taken the Examination of Miles Prance a Siver-smith, touching the Murther of Sir Edmond-Bury Godfrey upon the place where the same was committed, & by vertue of the Oath taken before Your Majesty, he Declared as followeth.

That, it was either of the latter End or the Beginning of the week▪ that Sir Edmond Godfrey did about Nine of the Clock at Night pass from towards St. Clements as far as the great Water-Gate at Sommerset-house being watched and followed by Lawrence Hill, one Green and one Gerald, that Hill making
some hast before stept within the wicket, which was open and turning soon again called to Sir Edmond as he was passing, and said, that there were two Men quarrelling within, who might soon be quieted if once they saw him, whereupon he entred through the Wicket, and after him Green and Gerald, and down all went till they came to a Bench rhat is at the Bottom of the steep Descent, and joyning to a Rail next, to the upper end of the Stables on the Right hand, that upon the said Bench there were sitting and attending their coming, the Examinant Miles Prance, one Berry the Porter of the other Gate together with an Irish Man that lodged at Greens house, whose Name he knowes not, and by that time they were come half way down, he the said Prance went up to the Wicket, there to attend and give notice if any came, and at the said time the said Berry went strait on from the Bench towards the Stone staires, which lead to the upper Court, that when Sir Edmond Godfrey came down to the Bench, Green who followed him put about his Neck a large twisted Hand-kerchief, and thereupon all the rest assisted and dragged him into a Corner which is behind the said Bench and the said Rail, and Green who informed him in the manner hereof, and with whom he had before seen the said large twisted Hand-kerchief, added that he had thumped him on the Breast and twisted his Neck until he broak it.

And the Examinant saith, that he did in about a quarter of an Hour after he had been standing at the Wicket come down to see what was done, and found that they had throtled him, but his Body remained warm and seemed hardly dead, but he together with the said Hill, Green, Gerald and Berry, and the Irish Man took him up and conveyed him through a Door, which is on the left hand coming downe at the Corner of the Coach house, which leads up several Staires into a long dark passage or gallery opening at last into the upper Court, in which passage there is a Door on the left hand, which being opened leads up with Eight staires into another house adjoyning, but immediatly on the Right hand being got up there is a little Closet or Square Room, into which they conveyed the Body, and there set the Body bending with the Back against a Bed, which the Examinant having now seen again thinks to be the same Bed that was there at the said time, he further said, that Hill lived at this house, and that the Body was for two days left there in his care, but then being affraid of Discovery, Hill▪ Gerald, Green, Berry and the Irish Man as they told him, did take and convey the Body from thence about Nine or Ten of the Clock at Night, and carried
it into the house, and into some Room towards the Garden, and that while that the Body lay there, he was by Hill conducted to see it and saw the Body as it lay bended, and Green and Gerald were present.

That from thence upon a Tuesday Night the Body was brought back near to the place, where first it lay into a Room in the said Gallery over against the first Door somewhat higher up towards the Court, the Chamber belonging unto some of the servants of Sir John Arundel, where it remained until Nine or Ten of the Ciock on Wednesday Night, and then thinking fit to remove it to the little Room where first it lay, the Ezaminant happened to come as they werere lifting it up the said Eight steps, whereupon Hill and Berry fled as supposing him to be some Stranger, but Gerald, Green and the Irish Man stood still. And so he helped them, to lift up the Body into the former Closet, and there it continued till after Twelve a Clock the same Wednesday Night, Hill and Berry came to them when their Fright was over, and Hill having got a Sedan and placing it in the long dark Entry at the Foot of the said Eight staires, they put the Body thereinto, the Examinant Prance and Gerald first took up the Chair and conveyed it through the upper Court, Berry the Porter opened half the Gate and let them out, and they Rested not till they came to Covent Garden, where Green and another Irish Man took their Turns, and so carried the Sedan and Body in it as far as the New Grecian Church in the So Ho, and there Hill met them with a Horse, whereupon they took out the Body, and forcing open the Legs they set it upon the Horse, Hill riding behind to keep the Body up, while Green, Gerald and the Irish Man went on to accompany him, Berry the Porter did not depart from the the Gate, and the Examinant Prance fearing to be missed returned home when the Body was set on Horseback, and the Sedan which was left in one of the New unfinished houses, they took up and brought it home as they came back.
He further saith, that the Body lay in Sommerset house about six or seven Days before it was carried out, but he is not certain in the Number of the days.

He was very positive as to the place, where the Murther was committed and the manner of it, as also for the Room where the Body was first laid, but being desired to conduct us to the Room he spoak of near the Garden, he led us to the Corner of the Piazza on the Left hand, and so down a pair of Staires and so far seemed to be assured that he had been led, and did think that he had passed through the great Court below,
but when from thence we went up and down into several Rooms, he seemed very doubtful and could not ascertain the place, saying that he had never been there but that once when Hill conveyed him thither with a Dark Lanthorn, but that it was some Chamber towards the Garden.

In the House where the Body was first laid we found a Woman whose deposition we have taken, she was House-keeper to Dr. Godden, and the said Hill had been a Servant to the said Doctor in this House for above Seven Years, and continued to live there since the Doctors departure until Michaelmas last, but that he hath been there several times since, and she also knew the Examinant and called him by his name.
All which is humbly submitted to your Majesty.

Upon reading of which report, it appeared that the particulars were very consonant to what he had spoke at the Board in the Morning before his going, at which time being also further asked, why he gave so different a Relation to the Committee of the Lords from what he now so freely confessed, he made answer that he was in much confusion before the Committee being not sure of his Pardon, but now being sure of it, and also upon his Oath he did speak the whole truth according to his knowledg, and being further asked why he came not in upon the Proclamation and the Rewards thereof, he said he was afraid to trust thereunto, and being further asked what reward he had received from those that imployed him, he said he had yet received no reward nor had he sought for any, but only the promise of Gerald that there should be a reward by the L. Bellasis, he said that he wrought in the way of his Trade to the Queens Chappel and was a Roman Catholick, but that about Eight weeks ago he had taken the Oathes, being asked whether there were no Guards at the usual places at the time of carrying on this work, he says he did not take notice of any, and being asked whether he saw Bedloe, when he was carryed to see the Body when it lay in the back Chambers near the Garden, he answered he could not tell whether Bedloe was there or no, but does well remember that Gerald and Green were then present, he adds that Hill, Green and Gerald told him, that they had at Prim-Rose-Hill thrust Sir Edmonds Sword through his Body till it came an inch out at his Back, and that he strugled very much at the time they strangled him,
but that Green punched him with his Knees upon his Body to hasten his death.
The Councel sat again in the Afternoon.

His Majesty having been informed that the said Lawrence Hill, Henry Berry, and Robert Green had been taken, the two former secured in Newgate, and the latter in the Gate-house, and having commanded them to be brought in the Afternoon, Robert Green was called in, and being Examined did say that he had lived for above ten years at Sommerset-house, his business being to lay Cushions in the Chappel, that he knew Hill Dr. Goddens Man, also Gerald that was of the Venetian Ambassadors meaning of the Resident, whom he supposes to be a Priest, that he knows Prance the Gold-smith to the House, but for Sir Edmondbury Godfrey he never saw him dead or alive, that he never carryed a Sedan or any dead Body to his knowledg and so utterly denyed every thing relating to the Murther.

Prance being called in and confronted urged the matter unto him, how he the said Green had been at Sir Edmonds-house, followed him from place to place, shewed him the twisted Handkerchief before he did the work, and many other particulars mentioned in the report, and how could he deny them. Green denyed every particular, and said all was false, Prance asked if he knew him, Green replyed yes very well, and had drunk with him, but he knew not Sir Edmondbury Godfrey or had ever seen him, yes said Prance we have often drunk together at the Plow, and there I shewed you Sir Edmond as he passed by, telling you, that he was the Man that would not allow the Queens Servants any priviledg, Prance further askt him what was the Irish Mans name (a short well set Man) that lay at such a time in his House, he answered his name was Kelley an Irish Priest who went away a Fortnight before the Proclamation, and that he belongs as he does think to a Welsh Gentlewoman that is a Roman Catholick, and being further asked how he came to be found out of his House, he saith that at Michaelmas for about Four Nights he was put out of his Lodging by some People of Sir John Arundels for their conveniency, he further saith he never had any quarrel with Mr. Prance or any thing to say against him.

Lawrence Hill being called in, says that he had been long a Servant at Sommerset house, that he knew Green, Gerald, and Prance, but not Kelley, that he never had any quarrel with Prance, and for ought he knew he might be an honest man, that he had not long since been drinking at his House in Stanhop-street,
where he keeps a Victualling house, which he hired and where he has lived since a Fortnight after Michaelmas last, that he never saw Sir Edmondbury Godfrey but once at Sommerset-house, which was upon occasion of a Pick Pocket that was there taken, that he was about the middle of October busie about settling himself in the House he now is ln, that the day Sir Edmond was Killed he was agreeing with his Landlord for the said House, but had not setled the agreement till the Wednesday after, that he never Rid with Sir Edmond upon a Horse, and knew very little of him, and denies vehemently all that is charged against him.

It may here properly be remembred that Anne Broad-street formerly House-keeper to Dr. Godden did in her deposition affirm, that Lawrence Hill left that place at Michaelmas or thereabouts going then to a House of his own in Stanhop-street, but when Prance told her she was mistaken, and that he did not leave this Lodging there in Sommerset house until a Fortnight after Michaelmas, the seemed very warmly to contradict him, whereas Hill himself doth better agree with Prance concerning the time.

Prance being called in, accuses Hill of all the particulars to his Face, which he denies again with imprecations, and when His Majesty asked Prance whether he would on his Salvation declare all he said to be true, he made answer that it was as true as God is true, and that he did on his Salvation affirm it, Hill saith that Prance testifyeth all this to save himself, whereupon being askt the meaning of these words he said he spoke the discourse of his House when People were drinking, and did there report that Prance was pardoned, but he then little thought that he should come to be questioned on such an account, being further asked about the said Kelly, be said there was such a man did frequent the Queens Chappel, and Prance being asked the color of the Horse which Hill brought for the Body, he said, that though the Night was dark yet he could discern the Horse to be a brown Horse.

Henry Berry being called in, says that he knows Green the Cushion keeper, that he knows not Kelley nor Gerald, that he knows Hill since he first came to Sommerset-house as a Servant to Dr. Godden, that he knows Prance and has seen him at Chappel and never heard ill of him, but denies that he ever acted any thing with him concerning Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, or ever sat with him upon that Bench, that he has seen Sir Edmond, and particularly as he past by about a year ago, but that he knew him not, or ever saw him dead, or knew that he ever went out in a Sedan, or that ever he saw Prance, Green of Gerald carry a Sedan.

Prance being called in urges home upon Berry all the particulars afore mentioned, and the share he had therein.
