The said Earl of Powis saving to himself, and which he humbly prayeth may be reserved to him, the Liberty of Answering over, and denying all and singular the said Crimes and Offences, so imposed upon him by the said Impeachment, is so general and incertain, that he cannot by any possibility give any direct Answer thereto, nor make his just and lawful Defence, upon any Trial of the same, for that the said charge hath no manner of certainty in point of time, it being laid only for many Years now last past, A Traiterous and Execrable plot and conspiracy, hath been contrived and carried on, which may be for 5. 10. 20. or 30. or more Years past, whereby, although the said Earl knoweth himself to be altogether innocent of such horrid and detestable Crimes, as by the said Impeachment are Objected against him, yet it is no way possible for him upon any Trial thereof to be prepared with his just and lawful Defence by Witnesses, to prove himself Absent, and in another place at the time of such meeting or consultation, to or for any the Wicked designes or purposes in the said Impeachment mentioned, or upon his Trial may be suddainly Objected against him, when he cannnt by any care or foresight whatsoever have such Witnesses ready, as could disprove the same, if he were certainly charged for any Act or Crime at any timr, certainly alledged in the said Impeachment more certain, as to the place of any such Traiterous meeting or consultation laid down in the said Impeachment; it being only Alledged to be at Divers places within the Realm of England and else where, which for the causes aforesaid, is likewise so utterly incertain, that it deprives • he said Earl of his just Defence upon his Trial, the incertainty likewise of the Number of Meetings, or Consultations to the Wicked purposes in the Impeachment mentioned, and the not shewing how many times the said Earl mett and consulted, and with whom in particular doth likewise
deprive him of all possibility of making his Defence, or producing his Witnesses; for that the said Earl being wholy innocent, cannot suppose or imagine what Meeting or Consultation, either to raise Men or Money, for the carrying on of a Traiterous Design, or to any Wicked intent or purpose in the said Impeachment mentioned, shall or may be Objected against him upon his Trial; and it is as much impossible f • r him to bring Witnesses to prove all the Meetings he hath had with others in his life time, as it is for him to know upon this general charge, what Meeting or Consultation may upon his Trial be Objected against him, as a Traiterous meeting or consultation; and where it is in the said Impeachment charged upon the said Earl, that he hath uttered Treason by Malicious and Advised speaking, writing or otherwise declaring, the said Earl saith, that never any Traiterous thought ever entred into his Heart, and therefore he cannot possible know or discover what words, or writing he ever spoke, uttered, wrote or declared, which are now charged upon him as Treason, there being no words or writing at all specified in the Impeachment, whereby the said Earl might know how to prepare his Defence against them, or that this most honorable House might Judge, whether the said words or writing were in Law Treasonable, or not all with incertainties, and the imminent and apparent Danger of the said Earl, being thereupon surprized in his Trial of Acause of this Consequence, to the said Earl, wherein his life (and honor more dear to him than his life) and all else that is dear to him in this World, are immediatly concerned, being seriously weighed and considered by your Lordships, he humbly prayeth, as by his Councel he is advised, that your Lordships will not put him to answer the said Impeachment, as to the charges herein above recited, till the same be reduced to some Competent certainty, that the Earl may know what to answer unto, and may be thereby Enabled to make his just Defence accordingly; all which, notwithstanding, he humbly submitteth to your Lordships grave Judgements and Considerations, professing himself always ready and willing to do, and to submit to whatsoever your Lordships in Justice shall Order or think fit, and as to all other the Treasons, Crimes and Offences whatsoever contained, mentioned or specified in the said Impeachment, the said Earl protesting, that they are incertainly and insufficiently Alledged, and therefore saving to himself the Benefit of Excepti • n thereunto, for answer thereunto saith, that he is not nor never was Guilty of the said Treasons, Crimes and Offences, or of any or either of them
of which he stands charged by the said Impeachment, and for his Trial thereof, putteth himself upon, and humbly submitteth to the Judgement of your Lordships, whose Justice the said Earl doth now and always shall rely upon, and therein acquiesce.
The Lord Viscount Stafford was brought in, in the like manner and delivered in his Answer, which was read as followeth.

The several Plea of William Viscount of Stafford, now Prisoner in the Tower of London, to part and his several Answer to the residue of the articles of Impeachment of High Treason, and other High Crimes and Offences, Exhibited to the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, against the said Lord Viscount, and others therein named, whereof the said Viscount stands Impeached, by the Knights, Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled, in the name of themselves, and of all the Commons of England.

The said Viscount in the first place, and before all others, protesting his Innocency of and from all the Treasons, and other Crimes and Offences whatsoever, in the said Articles contained, and no way acknowledging, confessi • g, granting or admitting all or any the Clauses, Articles or Matters in the said Articles of Impeachment contained, or specified, (so far as the same may any way concern him) to be true, as in and by the said Articles of Impeachment is supposed; and humbly Praying a favorable Construction by this Most Honorable House, of what the said Viscount shall humbly offer, by way of Plea to such part of the Impeachment, as is hereunder mentioned, and that the same may not be taken or Construed as any subterfuge, or evasion of the Justice of this most Honorable House, to which the said Viscount doth in all humility, wholly submit himself, desiring above all things, the Tryal of his cause by this most honorable House, so that he may be provided to make his just defence, for the clearing of his Innocency, from the Great and Hainous Crimes Charged upon him by the said Impeachment, this being prayed, as also liberty to correct, amend or explain any thing in this Plea and Answer contained, which may any way give this Honorable
House any Occasion of Offence, and he hopeth being granted, as to that part of the impeachment, that containeth the matter following. Namely that for many Years now last past, there hath been contrived and carried on by Papists, A Traiterous and Execrable conspiracy and plot within this Kingdom of England and other Places, to alter, change and subvert the Antient Government and Laws of this Kingdom and Nation, & to suppress the true Religion therein Eastblished, and to Extirpate and Destroy the professors thereof, and that the said Plot and Conspiracy, was contrived and carried on in Divers places, and by several ways and means, and by a great Number of Persons of several Qualities and Degrees, who Acted therein, and intended thereby to Execute and Accomplish their aforesaid Wicked, and Traiterous designes and purposes, that the said Viscount of Stafford, and the other Lords therein named, together with the several Persons therein likewise named, or mentioned as false Traitors to His Majesty, and this Kingdom, within the time aforesaid, have Traiterously consulted, contrived, and acted, to and for the Accomplishing the said Wicked, and Pernicious and Traiterous designes; and for that End, did most Wickedly and Traiterously agree, conspire, to imprison, depose, and Murther His sacred Majesty, and to deprive him of his Royal Estate, Crown and Dignity; and by Malicious and Advised speaking, writing, and otherwise declaring, such their purposes and intentions; and also to subject this Kingdom and Nation to the Pope, and to his Tyrannical Government, and to seize and share amongst themselves, the Estates, and Inheritances of His Majesties Protestant Subjects, and to Erect and Restore Abbies, Monasteries and other Convents, and Societies, which have been long since by the Laws of this Kingdom, suppressed for their Superstition and Idolatry, and to deliver u • and restore to them • he Lands, and Possessions now vested in His Majesty, and his Subjects, by the Laws and Statutes of this Realm, and also to Found and Erect new Monasteries, and Convents, and to remove and deprive all Protestant Bishops, and other Ecclesiastical Persons from their Offices, Benefices and Preferments, and by this means to Destroy His Majesties Person, Extirpate the Protestant Religion, overthrow the Rights, Liberties and Properties of all His Majesties Good subjects, subvert the lawful Government of this Kingdom, and subject the same to the Tyranny of the See of Rome; and that the said Conspirators and their Complices, and Confederates, Traiterously had and held several Meetings, Assemblies and Consultations, wherein it was
Contrived and Designed amongst them and what Means should be used and what Persons and Instruments should be imployed to Murther His Majesty, and did then and there resolve to Effect it by Poysoning, Shooting, Stabbing or some such like way, and means, and also as to that part of the Impeachment which chargeth the said Viscount of Stafford and the other Persons in the said Impeachment named. the better to compass their Traiterous Designs have consulted, to Raise Men, Money, Horses, Arms and Ammunition, The said Viscount of Stafford, saving to himself, and which he humbly prayeth may be reserved to him, the liberty of answering Over, and denying all and singular the said Crimes and Offences so charged upon him, saith, and humbly Offereth to this most honorable House, that the charge of those Crimes and Offences, so imposed upon him by the said Impeachment, is so General and Incertain, that he cannot by any possibility give any direct Answer thereto, nor make his just and lawful Defence upon any Trial of the same, for that the said Charge hath no manner of certainty in point of time, it being laid only for many years now last past, a Traiterous and Execrable plot and conspiracy, hath been contrived and carried on, which may be for 5. 10. 20. or 30. or more Years past, whereby, though the said Viscount knoweth himself to be altogether Innocent, of the said any such horrid and detestable Crimes, as by the said Impeachment are Objected against him; yet it is no way possible, for him upon any Trial thereof, to be prepared with his just and lawful Defence, by Witnesses to prove himself Absent, and in another place at the time of such Meeting or Consultation, to or for any the wicked Designs and Purposes in the said Impeachment mentioned, as upon his Trial may be suddainly Objected against him, when he can not by any care or foresight whatsoever, have such Witnesses ready as could disprove the same; if he were certainly charged for any Traiterous act or crime, at any time certainly Alledged in the said Impeachment, nor is the said charge in the said Impeachment more certain, as to the place of any such Traiterous meeting or consultation laid down in the said Impeachment, it being only Alledged to be at Divers places within the Realm of England and else where, which for the causes aforesaid, i • likewise so utterly uncertain, that it deprives the said Viscount of his Just defence upon his Trial, the incertainty likewise of the Number of Meetings or Consultatations, to the wicked Purposes in the Impeachment mentioned, and the not shewing how many times the said Viscount Met and Consulted, and with whom in particular, doth
likewise deprive him of all possibility of making his Defence, or producing his Witnesses; for that the said Viscount being wholly Innocent, cannot suppose or imagin what Meeting or Consultation, either to raise Men or Money, for the carrying on of a Traiterous design, or to any other Wicked intent or purpose, in the said Impeachment mentioned shall, or may be Objected against him upon his Trial, and it is as much Impossible for him to bring Witnesses, to prove all the Meetings he hath had with others in his life time, as it is for him to know upon this General charge, what Meeting or Consultation may upon his Trial be Objected against him, as a traiterous Meeting or Consultation. And where it is in the said Impeachment charged upon the said Viscount, that he hath uttered Treason, by Malicious and Advised speaking, writing and otherwise declaring; the said Viscount saith, that never any Traiterous thought ever Entred into his Heart, and therefore he cannot possibly know or discover, what words or writing he ever spoke, uttered, wrote or declared, which are now charged upon him as Treason, there being no words or writings at all specified in the Impeachment, whereby the said Viscount might know how to prepare his Defence against them, or how this most honorable House might Judge, whether the same words or writing were in Law treasonable or not; all which incertainties, and imminent and apparent Danger of the said Viscount, being thereupon surprized in this trial of a cause, of such consequence to the said Viscount, wherein his life (and honor more dear to him than his life) and all else that is dear to him in this World, are immediatly concerned, being seriously weighed and considered by your Lordships; he humbly prayeth, as by his Councel he is Advised, that your Lordships will not put him to Answer the said Impeachment, as to the charges therein above recited, till the same be reduced to some Competent certainty, that the Viscount may know what to Answer un • o, and may be thereby Enabled to make his Just defence accordingly; all which, notwithstanding he humbly submits to your Lordships grave Judgements and Considerations; professing himself always ready and willing to do, and submit to whatsoever your Lordships in Justice shall order or think fit, and as to all other the Treasons, Crimes and Offences whatsoever contained, mentioned or specified, in the said Impeachment, the said Viscount protesting, that they are Uncertainly and Insufficiently alledged, and therefore saving to himself the Benefit of Exception thereunto, for Answer thereunto saith, that he is not, nor ever was Guilty of the said Treasons, Crimes and Offences, or of
any or either of them, of which he stands charged by the said Impeachment; and for his Trial thereof, putteth himself upon, and humbly submitteth to the Judgement of your Lordships, to whose Justice the said Viscount now doth, and alway • shall Rely upon, and therein Acquiesce.
The Lord Petre was brought in, in like manner, and delivered in his Answer, which was read as followeth.

The Humble Answer of William Lord Petre, now Prisoner in the Tower of London to the Articles of Impeachment of High Treason, and other High Crimes and Offences exhibited against him and other • , by the Knights, Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled, according to the direction of an Order of this House of the Ninth of this Instant April.
All advantag • s of exception to the said Articles of Impeachment to this defendant saved, and reserved.

A • for the first part of the said Articles, by which it is set forth, that for many years now last past, there hath been contrived and carried on by Papists, a Traiterous and Execrable Conspiracy and Plot within this Kingdom of England, and other places to Alter, Change and Subvert the Antient Government and Laws of this Kingdom and Nation, and to suppress the true Religion therein Established, and to Extirpate and Destroy the Professors thereof, which said Plot and Conspiracy was Contrived and Carried on in divers places, and by several ways and means, and by a great number of Persons of several Qualities and Degrees, who acted therein, and intended thereby to Execute and accomplish their aforesaid wicked and Traiterous designs and purposes.

The Defendant saith, that he doth not know, that all or any the matters herein before recited are true of his own knowledg, nor any otherwise, but by the proofs heard and taken before both Houses of Parliament, and by their Votes thereupon; and likewise, by the several Indictments, Tryals, Verdicts and Judgments lately had and given in divers Courts of Record relating thereunto.
And this Defendant further saith, that he is not Guil • y of all or any the matters by the said Articles of Impeachment Charg • d against him.
And for his Tryal thereupon, he humbly putteth himself upon God and his Peers.
The Lord Arundel of Warder was brought in like manner, and delivered his Answer, which was read as followeth.

The several Plea of Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, now Prisoner in the Tower of London, to part, and his several Answer to the Residue of the Articles of Impeachment of High Treason, and other High Crimes and Offences, Exhibited to the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, against the Lord Arundel of Warder, and others therein named, whereof the said Lord stands Impeached by the Knights Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled, in the name of themselves and of all the Commons of England.

The said Lord in the first place, and before others, protesting his Innocency of and from all the Treasons and other Crimes and Offences whatsoever, in the said Articles contained, and no way acknowledging, confessing, granting or admitting all or any the clauses, Articles or Matters in the said Articles of Impeachment contained, or specified; so far as the same any ways concerns him to be true, as in and by the same Articles of Impeachment is supposed, and humbly praying a favorable Construction by this most honorable House, of what the said Lord shall humbly Offer by way of Plea, to such part of the Impeachment as is hereunder mentioned; and that the same may not be taken or construed, as any subterfuge or evasion of the Justice of this honorable House, to which the said Lord doth with all humility wholly submit himself, desiring above all things the Trial of his Cause by th • s most honorable House, so that he may be provided to make his Just Defence, for the clearing of his innocency from the great and hainous Crimes charged upon him by the said Impeachment; this being prayed, as also liberty to correct, amend, or explain any thing in this his Plea and Answer contained with, may any way give this most honorable House any Occasion of Offence; and he hopeth being granted, the said Lord as to that part of the Impeachment, that containeth the Matter following. Namely, that for many Years now
last past, there hath been contrived and carried on by Papists, a Traiterous and Execrable conspiracy and plot, within this Kingdom of England and other places, to alter, change and subvert the Antient Government and Laws of this Kingdom and Nation, and to suppress the true Religion therein Established, and to Extirpate and Destroy the Professors thereof, and that the said Plot and Conspiracy was contrived, and carried on in divers Places, and by several ways and means, and by a great Number of Persons of several Qualities and Degrees, who Acted therein, and intended thereby to Execute and Accomplish their aforesaid wicked and traiterous Designs and Purposes, that the said Lord and the other Lords therein named together, with the several other Persons therein likewise named or mentioned, as false Traitors to His Majesty and this Kingdom, within the time aforesaid, have Traiterously consulted, contrived and acted, to and for the Accomplishing the said wicked Pernicious and Traiterous designs, and for that End did most wickedly and traiterously Agree, Conspire and Resolve, to Imprison, Depose and Murther His sacred Majesty, and to Deprive him of his Royal Estate, Crown and Dignity, and by Malicious and Advised speaking, writing, and otherwise declaring such their purposes and intentions; and also, to subject this Kingdom and Nation to the Pope, and his tyrannical Government, and to se • ze and share amongst themselves, the Estates and Inheritances of His Majesties Protestant Subjects, and to Erect and Restore Abbies, Monasteris and other Convents and Socities, which have been long since by the Laws of this Kingdom suppressed for their Superstition and Idolatry, and to deliver up and restore to them the Lands, and Possessions now vested in His Majesty, and his Subjects, by the Laws and Statutes of this Realm; and also to Found and Erect new Monasteries and Convents, and to Remove and Deprive all Protestant Bishops, and other Ecclesiastical Persons from their Offices, Benefices and Preferments, and by this means to Destroy His Majesties Person, Extirpate the Protestant Religion, Overthrow the Rights, Liberties and Properties of all His Majesties good Subjects, subvert the lawful Government of this Kingdom, and to subject the same to the Tyranny of the See of Rome; and that the said Conspirators, and their Complices and Confederates, Traiterously had and held, several Meetings, Assemblies and Consultations, wherein it was contrived amongst them, what means should be used, and what Persons and Instruments should be imployed to Murther His Majesty; and did then, and there Resolve to effect
it, by Poysoning, Shooting, Stabbing, or some such like ways and means; and also, to that part of the Impeachment, which chargeth, that the said Lord and the other Persons in the said Impeachment named, the better to compass their Traiterous designs, have consulted to raise Men, Money, Horses, Arms and Ammunition. The said Lord saving to himself, and which he humbly prayeth may be reserved to him, the Liberty of Answering over, and denying all and singular the said Crimes and Offences, so charged upon him saith, and humbly Offereth to this most honorable House, that the charge of those Crimes and Offences so Imposed upon him, by the said Impeachment, is so general and incertain, that he cannot by any possibility give any direct Answer thereto, nor make his just and lawful Defence upon any Trial of the same; for that the said Charge hath no manner of certainty in point of time, it being laid for many Years now last past, a Traiterous and Execrable plot, and conspiracy hath been contrived and carried on, which may be for 5. 10. 20. or 30. Or more Years past, whereby though the said Lord knoweth himself to be altogether innocent of any such horrid and detestable Crimes, as by the said Impeachment are Objected against him; yet it is no way possible for him upon any Trial thereof, to be prepared with his just and lawful Defence by Witnesses, to prove himself Absent, and in another place at the time of such Meeting or Consultation, to or for any the Wicked designs and purposes in the said Impeachment mentioned, as upon his Trial may be suddainly Objected against him, when he cannot by any care or foresight whatsoever, have such Witnesses ready as could disprove the same, if he were certainly charged for any Traiterous act or crime at any time, certainly Alledged in the said Impeachment, nor is the same charge in the said Impeachment more certain, as to the place of any such Traiterous meeting or consultation laid down in the said Impeachment: It being only Alledged to be at divers Places within the Realm of England, and else where, and for the causes aforesaid, is likewise so utterly uncertain, that it deprives the said Lord of his Just defence upon his Trial, the uncertainty likewise of the Number of Meetings and Consultations to the Wicked purposes in the said Impeachment mentioned, and the not shewing how many times the said Lord met, and consulted, and with whom in particular, doth likewise deprive him of all possibility of making his Defence, or producing his Witnesses; for that the said Lord, being wholly Innocent, cannot suppose▪ or imagine, what meeting or consultation either to raise men, or money for the carrying on
of a Traiterous design, or to any other Wicked intent or purpose in the said Impeachment mentioned, shall or may be Objected against him upon his Trial; and it is as much unpossible for him to bring witnesses to prove all the Meetings he hath had wi •• others in his life time, as it is for him to know upon this General charge, what Meeting or Consultation may be Objected upon his Trial against him, as a Traiterous meeting or consultation; and where it is in the said Impeachment charged upon the said Lord, that he hath uttered Treason by Malicious and Advised writing, speaking, and otherwise declaring; the said Lord saith, that never any Traiterous thought wa • Entred into his Heart; and therefore he cannot possibly know, or discover what words or writing he ever spoke, uttered, wrote or declared, which are now tharged upon him as Treason, there being no word, or writing at all specified in the Impeachment, whereby the said Lord might know how to prepare his Defence against them; or that this honorable House might Judge, whether the same words or writing were in Law treasonable or not; all which incertainties, and the imminent and apparent Danger of the said Lord, being thereupon surprised in his Trial, in a cause of this consequence to the said Lord, wherein his life and honor more dear to him than his life, and all else that is dear to him in this World, are immediatly concerned, being seriously weighed, and considered by your Lordships; he humbly prayeth as by his Councel he is Advised, that your Lordships will not put him to Answer the said Impeachment, as to the charges therein above reci • ed, till the same be reduced to some competent certainty, that the said Lord may know what to Answer unto, and may be thereby Enabled to make his just Defence accordingly; all which notwithstanding, he humbly submitteth to your Lordships grave Judgments and Considerations, professing himself always ready and willing, to do and submit to whatsoever your Lordships in Justice shall Order or think fit; and as to all other the Treasons, Crimes and Offences whatsoever, contained, mentioned or specified in the said Impeachment, the said Lord protesting, that they are uncertainly and insufficien • ly Alledged, and therefore saving to himself the Benfi • of Exception thereunto, for Answer thereto, saith, that he is not, nor ever was guilty of the said Treasons, Crimes and Offences, or any, or either of them, of which he stands charged by the said Impeachment; and for his Tr • al, putteth himself upon, and humb • y submitteth to the Judgement of your Lordships, whose Justice the said
Lord now doth, and always shall Rely upon, and therein Acquiesce.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Timothy Baldwyn and Sir John Hoskins, to let them know, that the Five Lords Prisoners in the Tower, have put in their several and respective Answers to the Impeachment, brought up from the House of Commons against them, which this House Communicates to them, and desires that the said Original Answers may be returned with all convenient speed.

div.head: Die Veneris 17. April 1679.
div.p: THis day Thomas Earl of Berks took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act, for the more effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from Sitting in either House of Parliament.

Whereas, Humphrey Weld Esq was this day brought to the Bar by the Serjeant at Arms, attending this House, for not Obeying the Orders given for preventing the Back avennues to the Chappel of the Spanish Ambassador, and frustrating the intent thereof, upon hearing what the said Humphrey Weld had to say concerning that matter; It is Ordered, that the said Humphrey Weld be and is hereby discharged from any further restraint for the cause aforesaid, paying his Fees, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Whereas, there is a Bill depending in Parliament, entituled an Act for the better discovery, and more speedy conviction of Popish Recusants, wherein provision is made, that Mr. Francis Wolf of Madely, with other Persons therein named, who although Papists, were yet very Instrumental in the Preservation of His Majesties Sacred Person, after the Battel of Worcester; and have thereby merited as a reward of their Loyalty, to be distinguished from others of their Religion; It is thereup • n Ordered &c. that the said Francis Wolf
and his Wife, be and are hereby protected from Imprisonment and confinement of his Person, or any other penalties to be inflicted upon Popish Recusants, for refusing any Oathes (except the Oath of Allegiance,) or not repairing to Church to hear Divine Service, or receiving the Sacrament according to the Usage of the Church of England, during the depending of the said Bill in Parliament.

Upon serious consideration, had by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, of the present state of Ireland in this time of Imminent danger, and of the securing of the Protestant Religion there; It is Ordered by their Lordships, that the Lord Privy Seal, Earl of Strafford, Earl of Essex, Earl of Burlington, the Lord Roberts, the Lord Herbert of Cher. and the Lord Butler of Moor Park, do attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, to put all the Laws in Execution strictly and vigorously, that are now in Force, for the disarming of all Papists there, and that the Lord Lieutenant take the best care he can to Arm all the Protestants there, for the defence of their Religion, and the Government of that Kingdom, and that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, that a sufficient Quantity of Arms and Gun-powder may be sent over to such places in Ireland, as His Majesty shall direct to be disposed of, as the Lord Lieutenant shall think fit, which are to be sold to the Protestants, and at such rates, as that His Majesty may be reimbursed his Charges, and also that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, for the enquiring after, and prosecuting such Bonds by suits, as have been entred into in Ireland, for the Education of Children in the Protestant Religion, and are forfeited by the said Childrens being Educated Papists; and that the forfeitures may be His Majesties Order be disposed in such manner to charitable uses, as that they be Effectually recovered; and that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order, that an account may be transmitted hither, of the Names of the Guardians, and of the security Entered into for the Education of Children in Ireland in the Protestant Religion, with the Names of the said Children, Expressing respectively, which have been Educated Protestants, and which Papists; and also, that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, to put the Laws there in Execution to the utmost, against all Jesuits, and such other Popish Priests, as Exercise Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction after the Romish Religion in Ireland, and that upon the account of the
late horrid Conspiracy, and the present prospect of Affairs; and that several things are under Consideration, for preventing the Dangers that may hereby arise, and for the preservation of His Majesties Person, Kingdom and Dominions; that His Majesty will be pleased to give Order to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland in the mean time, to secure such Persons being Papists in Ireland, as his Lordship and the Council shall judge to be Dangerous there.

The House was Adjourned into a Committee, to consider of the Bill for the better securing the Liberty of the Subject; the House being resumed, the Lord Roberts Reported, that the Opinion of the Committee of the House is, that the further consideration of the Bill be put off till the next day of sitting after Easter Day, and that in the mean time a Committee may be appointed to consider of the whole Coherence of the said Bill, so that it may be put in a fit Method to be Offered to the Committee of the whole House the next sitting, to which purpose, the House named the Comittee following.

Whereas, Thomas Earl of Danby was yesterday appointed to put in his Answer in Writing to the Articles of Impeachment, wherewith he stands Charged by the House of Commons, on the first day of the Sitting of the Parliament next after Easter day, it is this day Ordered, that the said Thomas Earl of Danby is hereby appointed to put in his said Answer, on Wednesday the 23 of this Instant April at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Lunae the 21. of April 1679.
div.p: THis day Lewis of Feversham took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaraion in pursuance of the Act for the more Effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

William Colgrave and Charles Feltham deposed upon Oath at the Bar, that the Marquess of Dorchester is so afflicted at present with the stone and the strangury that he is not able to attend this House, which excuse the House allowed of.
Hodie secunda vice lecta est Billa, an Act for the better Regulating of the Tryals of the Peers of England.

Then His Majesty Sitting in His Royal Throne, Adorned with his Regal Crown and Ornaments, commanded the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod to let the House of Commons know, His Majesties pleasure is that they attend him presently, who being come, His Majesty made this short Speech following.

I thought it requisite to acquaint you with what I have done now this day, which is, that I have established a new Privy Councel, the constant number of which shall never exceed Thirty; I have made choice of such Persons, as are all able and worthy to advise me, and am resolved in all my weighty and important Affairs (next to my great Councel in Parliament) whom I shall very often Consult with to be advised by this Privy Councel.

I could not make so great a change without acquainting both Houses of Parliament; and I desire you all to apply your selves heartily, as I shall do to those things that are necessary to the good and safety of the Kingdom, and that no time may be lost in it.
This being done His Majesty withdrew and the Commons with their Speaker went to their House.

Whereas, Thomas Earl of Danby was by Order of this House to put in his Answer in writing on Wednesday the 23th. instant to the A • ticles of Impeachment, whereby he is charged by the House of Commons with Treason, and other High Crimes, Misdemeanors and Offences; it appearing by the
Petition of the said Earl, that by reason of some of his Councel being out of Town, and that one of the Councel whom his Lordship desired was not assigned to him, he cannot possibly be ready so soon to answer a Charge of so high a concern to him, and therefore prayeth that some longer time may be allowed him for that purpose; it is thereupon Ordered, that the Earl of Danby hath hereby time given him to put in his Answer to the said charge, till Fryday the Five and Twentieth day of this instant Aprill, at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.
The Earl of Clarendon Reported, that the Lord • Committees for Examinations have received Examinations, concerning a Design to Poyson Mr. Oates, which were read as followeth.

Midds. at Westminst ss. The Information of Dr. William Jones M. D. taken upon Oath, the 28 day of March 1679. before me Edmond Warcup Esquire, one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace for the said County and Liberty.

This Informant saith, that it being known that he was and is Physitian to Mr. William Bedloe, discoverer of the Horrid Plot against His Majesties Sacred Life and the Government, one Dr. Smith a Physitian came to this Informant on Saturday the 22 instant, pretending some private business, when this Informant after some discourse said, he must go to Mr. Bedloe, to which Dr. Smith replyed, are you great with Mr. Oates and Mr. Bedloe, this Informant replying he was Physitian to them both, Smith answered, God damm them both, why do you not poyson them? you may have money enough for that Service, then you know what to do, with all, this Informant replyed thereto, that an Enemy could not do him a greater injury then to put a trust in him, how then could this Informant do mischief to his Friends; all which passed between this Informant and the said Dr. Smith, at his this Informants Lodgings at the Ball at Charing-cross.

And this Informant further saith, that he with Dr. Smith went thence to an Ale house in Green-street, neer the Mews where the said Dr. Smith did amongst other Discourses positively Affirm, that the Plot was no Plot at all, but a thing contrived by Oats, Bedloe and the Earl of Shaftesbury meerly to Ruin the poor Roman Catholiks, whereupon this Informant said, that if Mr. Oates and Mr. Bedloe did live, most of the
Lord • in rhe Tower would suffer; to which the said Dr. Smith Replyed, they will or they shall not live to see that day, for they are too great Rogues to have a Being.

dateline.hi: Jurat die & animo sup Cor. me Edmond Warcup.

div.p: The Examination of Dr. Emanuel Smith, taken the 19th. of April 1679. In pursuance of an Order of the Lords Committees, for Examining matters Relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy before me Edmond Warcup Esquire, one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace in the said City and Liberties.

This Examinant saith, that he knows no more of any Plot than the Child unborn, and as to any belief of a Plot, he saies the Circumstances speak as if there were a Plot, but how what or by whom he knows not, nor for what Ends, but saies if he knew of any Plot against the King, the Government or the true Protestant Religion, he would Reveal it, he confesseth he hath been Acquainted with Dr. Jones about Five or Six years, and that there never was any difference between them, and this Examinant confesseth, that he and Dr. Jones were together at the Green Mews, about the time in the Information mentioned, where one Baxter, as this Examinant believes his Name to be, came to them, and there was a discourse about the Disease he then complained of, but this Examinant saith, that there were so little Concern about Mr. Bedloe in the discourse then, that he remembers it not, nor took no notice of it; and this Examinant saith, that Mr. Jones Declaring Mr. Bedloe was his Patient, this Examinant did or might say why do you not ptescribe him a Pill, but meant not thereby any ill to Mr. Bedloe; and this Examinant saith he had not any thoughts of doing any Mischief to Mr. Bedloe, upon any account of the Papists, and denies that he Ever mentioned the Word poyson, he ownes that he is a Christian, but of what Profession in Religion refuseth to confess; and this Examinant saith, that to his remembrance or belief, there was not the least Discourse about the Earl of Shaftesbury, or any Design, that his Lordship with Mr. Bedloe, or Mr. Oates had to frame any Design against the Papists, or as if they intended any Design to make the Papists to be believed, to intend any thing against the Government Established; and he saith, that Mr. Oates was mentioned at the same
time, and that he had no Malice either to Mr. Oates or Mr. Bedloe, or any intent by money or otherwise, to perswade Dr. Jones to any Act of Poyson or hurting them. And this Examinant further saith, that when he is in Town, he Lodgeth in Creed Lane at Mrs. Lawrance her House, and when he was in the Country, he was with an Aunt of his Wifes, at or neer Basingstoake in Hampshire, at one Mr, Chandlers, and all their Family are Protestans, and he denieth, that there was any Discourse whatsoever, concerning the Frial of the Lords in the Tower, and further saith not.
Hereupon this House made this Ensuing Order.

Whereas Emanuel Smith Dr. in Phisick, is charged to prevail with Dr. Jones to poyson William Bedloe, as appeareth by the Information of the said Dr. Jones taken upon Oath; it is Ordered, that the Keeper of Wood-street Counter, in whose Custody the said Emanuel Smith now is, do forthwith deliver him the said Emanuel Smith, into the Prison of the Gate-house at Westminster, there to remain a Prisoner till further Order, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

Upon report made by the Earl of Clarendon from the Lords Committees, for Examining matters relating to the discovery of the late Horrid Conspiracy, that Francis Allen, who was taken into Custody being charged with incouraging Eliz. Oxley to Fire Houses, hath been Examined before their Lordships, and denyeth what is charged on him; now in regard the Examinations taken concerning the House Fired by the said Elizabeth Oxley in Fetter Lane, are before a Committee of the House of Commons; it Ordered, that the Serjeant at Arms Attending this House, or his Deputy or Deputies do forthwith carry the said James Allen to the said Committee to be Examined, and disposed of as the said Committee shall think fit, and this shall be a sufficiennt Warrant on that behalf.

Upon Report made from the Lords Committees, for Examining matters relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that their Lordships think it necessary, that 〈…〉
Sturges now a Prisoner in the Goal at Chelmsford should be brought to Town; it is Ordered, that the Serjeant at Arms Attending this House or his Deputy or Deputies, do forthwith repair to the Goal at Chelmsford in Essex, and
bring thence the Body of the said 〈…〉
Sturges, and deliver him into the Prison of the Gate-house at Westminster, there to remain a Prisoner till further Order; and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

div.head: Die Martis 21. Aprilis 1679.
div.p: THe Lord Privy Seal Reported, that himself and the other Lords appointed to present the humble Address of this House concerning Ireland to His Majesty, have waited on His Majesty with the same; to which His Majesty returns this Answer, that he consents to the Desires of this House therein, and will give speedy Order for every particular in it.

The Lord Viscount Hallifax Reported, that the Committee have considered the Bill for freeing the City of London and the parts Adjacent from Papists, and have made some Amendments therein, which are Offered to the Consideration of the House, the said Amendments were read Over, and after some Debate; it is Ordered, that the House be put into a Committee on Thursday Morning next, to consider further of these Amendments.

div.head: Die Mercuii 23. Aprilis 1679.
div.p: THis day Humphrey Lord Bishop of Bangor took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act, for the more Effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

Upon Report from the Lords Committees for Examining matters, relating to the Discovery of the late Conspiracy, that Thomas Knox is a dangerous Person, who hath Endeavored to tamper with and Corrupt Witnesses, relating to the said Discovery; it is thereupon Ordered, that the Serjeant at Arms Attending this House, his Deputy or Deputies,
shall forthwith Attach the Body of the said Thomas Knox, and deliver him into the P • ison of the Gate-house at Westminster, there to Remain in safe Custody till further Order, and this shall be a sufficient Discharge in that behalf.

Upon Report from the Lords Commitrees, relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that their Lordships have Examined Andrew Thompson, now Prisoner in the Gatehouse at Westminster, and Judge it fit, that he be continued there and kept a close Prisoner for some time; it is Ordered, that the said Andrew Thompson be continued a Prisoner in the Gate house till further Order, and be kept there under Close restraint for one Week from the Date hereof, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

The House being moved, that a Blanck warrant be issued and signed by the Clerk of the Parliament, and seizing some Persons, and that the Lords Committees for Examining matters, relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, may be intrusted to insert the Places and Persons to be searched, and seized, as also the Names of the Persons, who shall Execute the same to prevent the defeating of the intended service; upon Consideration had thereof, it is Ordered, that such a Warrant shall be issued as is desired, so as the search to be made be not in the House of any Member of either House of Parliament, which the said Lords Committees are to take special care of.

Upon Report made from the Lords Committees, appointed to receive Informations tending to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that Edmond Warcup Esquire, one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace, and Deputy Lieutenant for the County of Middlesex, and City and Liberties of Westminster, hath diligently Executed the several Orde • s and Commands of this House, and of the said Committee, with no less Care and Prudence then Hazard and Charge; and that his services have been so succesful and eminent, for the safety of H • s Majesties Royal Person and Government, as that they deserve particular Regard; it is thereupon Ordered, that the Lords with white Staves do Attend His Majesty with the humble Desire of this House, that His Majesty will be Gratiously pleased, to Confer upon the said Edmond Warcup, some such Considerable imployment, as may be suitable to His Majesties Royal Bounty, and the Merits and Services of the said Edmond Warcup.

Upon Report from the Lords Committees, relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that their Lordships have d • sposed of the One hundred pound, which by His Majesties
Gratious Order was paid to the Clerk, attending them for Incouragements and Rewards to several poor People, who have been serviceable in Order to the Discovery of the said Conspiracy, which hath not proved sufficient in a Competent manner, to reward all that have deserved due Incouragement; and therefore desire, that One hundred pounds more may be intrusted to their Lordships disposal, which they Judge may be sufficient for the purposes aforesaid; it is thereupon Ordered, that the Earl of Essex do Attend His Majesty, humbly to desire him from this House, that His Majesty will be Gratiously pleased to give Order that One hundred pound more may be paid out of His Majesties Treasury in the Exchequer with • ut Fees, into the hands of the said Clerk, to be thence issued to such Persons and in such Proportions, as the said Lords Committees shall think fit.

Upon Report from the Lords Committees, for Examining matters relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that their Lordships find it Requisite, that David Lewis, who hath been tryed and condemned as a Popish Priest, at the Assizes held for the County of Monmouth, and is now in the Goal there, may be brought to Town; it is Ordered that the Sheriff for the said County of Monmouth, be and is hereby required to take care and give Order, for the speedy conveying of the said David Lewis in safety from the said Goal, to be delivered into the Prison of Newgate, the Charges of which service shall be Allowed to the said Sheriff upon his Account in the Exchequer, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

list.item: The like Order for Roger Hanslip at the Goal at Gloucester.
The like Order for John Kember in the Goal at Hereford.
The like Order for Francis Johnson alias Webb in the Goal at Worcester.

div.p: It is this day Ordered, that it be and i • hereby recommended to the Commissioners of His Majesties Treasury for the time bei • g, that by their Order, allowances may be made to the Respective Sheriffs, of such Sums of Money a • they or any of them shall make appear, to have been by them or any of them Respectively disbursed, either as Rewards to Discoverers of Popish Priests, or of bringing up Prisoners to London or Westminster, by Order of this House, or for any other service relating to the discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy.

It is this day Ordered, that all such Persons, who have obtained leave ei • her from His Majesties P • ivy Council, or this
House, to come and stay in the City of London and Westminster, or either of them, be and they are hereby respectively required, to bring in their own Names, as also the Names of their respective Servants, or others in their Families, so lycenced to stay in Town to the Clerk of the Parliament, on or before Monday the 28th. Day of this instant April, or otherwise the lycences of such of them as shall make Default thereof, are hereby declared after the said day to be void; and it is further Ordered, that this Order be forthwith Printed and Published, to the End, that all Persons concerned may take Notice thereof at their Perils.
Ordered. That on Friday next the House be put into a Committee, to consider of the Bill for the better securing the liberty of the Subject.
Ordered That this House be presently put into a Committee, to consider of the Bill for the better Regulating the Trial of the Peers of England.

The House Adjourned was during pleasure, the House being resumed, the Earl of Huntington Reported, that the Committee of the House have made some Progress in the Bill, for the Trial of the Peers, and the Committee desires, that the House might be in a Committee again on Saturday next, to proceed therein, which the House have Ordered accordingly.

div.head: Die Jovis 24. April. 1679.
div.p: THis day Baptist Viscount Campden took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declara • ion, in pursuance of the Act, for the more Effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Booth and Others, to desire a conference concerning the Pleas and Answers of the five Lords in the Tower, impeached by the House of Commons.
The Answer returned was, that the Lords have considered their Message, and will give them a Conference as is desired, which the Lords appoint to be presently in the painted Chamber.

The House was Adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords
went to the Conference, which being Ended the House was Resumed.
And the Lord President Reported the Effect of the Conference, viz.
That Sir Francis Winnington managed the Conference, which he told us was desired concerning the five Pleas or Answers, or rather Writings of the Lords in the Tower.

In the first Place, my Lord Bellasis cannot put in his Answer but personally at the Bar, otherwise they count it as a Nullity; that the several Writings of the four Lords, for so he can only call them, are Argumentive and Evasive, to which the Commons neither can or ought to Reply.
That the Answer of my Lord Petre is a legal Answer.

That the Lord Bellasis must put in his Answer, before the other Lords can be proceeded with; therfore the Commons demand, that the three Lords may be required to put in more perfect Answers, and that the Lord Bellasis may be required forthwith to put in his Answer

p.hi: As to the Impeachment the Lords complain of, the Incertainty of time in their Charge, the House of Commons have considered all Presidents, Antient and Modern, and find them all run in General terms as this doth, but beeause they would speed the matter and avoid delay, the House of Commons do declare, that in the Trial of these five Lords, they will give no Evidence particularly, beyond the space of seven Ye • rs last past.

div.p: After some Debate, these Lords following were appointed to consider of the Objections made by the House of Commons this day at the Conference, concerning the Pleas and Answers of the five Lords now Prisoners in the Tower, to the Impeachments wherewith they are Charged by the House of Commons, and to Report to the House, what they find concerning matters of this nature.
Their Lordships or any five of them to Meet this Afternoon, at four of the clock in the Princes Lodgings, and to Adjourn as they please.
Ordered. That the Lord Bellasis is required to put in his Answer to morrow Morning.

It is this day Ord • red by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal
in Parliament Assembled, that the Lieutenant of the Tower of London, be and is hereby required to bring John Lord Bellasis, now Prisoner in the Tower to the Bar of this House to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, to put in his Answer to the Articles of Impeachment, whereby he is charged with high Treason, and other high Crimes, Misdemeanors and Offences by the House of Commons, and for so doing, this shall be his sufficient Warrant.

Whereas, Thomas Earl of Danby now Prisoner in the Tower of London, is by Order of the 21th. Instant appointed to put in his Answer in writing, to the Articles of Impeachment, whereby he is charged with Treason, and other high Crimes, Misdemeanors and Offences, by the House of Commons to Morrow; being the 25th. of this Instant April; it is this day Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lieutenant of the Tower, be and is hereby required to bring the said Earl of Danby, to the Bar of this House to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon for the cause aforesaid, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Discharge.

div.head: Die Veneris 25. Aprilis 1679.
div.p: WHereas, Emanuel Smith stands Committed to the Gate house in Westminster, for Endeavoring to prevail with Dr. Jones, to Poyson William Bedloe; it appearing to the House, that there are other Matters against him the said Emanuel Smith, for which he ought to be brought to a speedy Trial; it is thereupon Ordered, that the Keeper of the Gatehouse, be and is hereby required to take care, that the said Emanuel Smith, be forthwith conveyed to the Prison of Newgate, there to remain in safe Custody, in Order to his said Trial, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.

Ordered. That to morrow Morning the Amendments in the Bill, for clearing the City of London and Parts adjacent from Papists, shall be taken into further consideration in a Committee of the whole House.

This day being appointed for the Earl of Danby, to put in his Answer in writing to the Impeachment of the House of Commons against him, his Lordship was brought to the Bar by the Lieutenant of the Tower, where having kneeled until
he was bid to stand up, the Lord Chancellor by directions of the House, demanded of the Earl of Danby his Answer, who delivered in a Parchment as his Plea and Answer, which was read as followeth.

The Plea of Thomas Earl of Danby, late Lord high Treasurer of England, to the Articles of Impeachment of high Treason, and other high Crimes and Misdemeanors and Offences exhibited against him, by the Name of Thomas Earl of Danby, Lord high Treasurer of England.

The said Earl saving and reserving to himself, the Benefit of His Majesties Gratious Pardon by him hereunder pleaded; and which he humbly prayeth may be reserved to him, by protestation saith, that as to the said Articles exhibited against him, are so general and uncertain, that he cannot make any particular answer thereto, nor give any particular account thereof, so the said Earl humbly conceiveth, and is advised by his Councel, with humble submission to your Lordships Judgements, that there is no particular charge of high Treason declared, by any Overt act, certainly Alledged in the said Articles, nor any other Crime therein so certainly Alledged, and set down, that the said Earl can any way take issue thereupon, or make Answer, or his just and lawful Defence thereto; and the said Earl by protestation also saith, that it never entered into his Heart, to Incroach any Regal power to himself by any ways or means whatsoever, much less by Treating in Matters of War and Peace with any Forreign Prince, or Embassador in his the said Earls own Name, if it be so meant by the said Articles; but if it be meant by the said Articles, that the said Earl so treated in His Majesties Name, (as he hopeth it is), or gave instructions to His Majesties Embassadors abroad, without communicating the same to the Secretaries of State, and the rest of His Majesties Councel, and against the Express Declaration of His Majesty and His Parliament, if any particular instance thereof had been laid down in the said Articles, the said Earl could have given a particular account thereof; and the said Earl by protestation also saith, that whatsoever the said Earl acted in such Affaires, was by the Advice and Privity of His Majesties Councel and Secretaries of State, or by His Majesties own Express command or directions, if perhaps the same were not made known to the Councel or Secretaries of State; the said Earl also, by protestation saith, that he never indeavored any Subversion of the Government, nor had he ever any such Design as in the Articles
is Alledged, nor did he continue the Army when raised, nor was it in his Power so to do, but as the Money granted by Parliament for disbanding the Army came into His Majesties Exchequer, the said Earl being then Lord Treasurer, signed Warrants for payment of the Money, and every part of it, over to the Pay-master general to be paid for his Disbanding of the said Army, and took Receipts of him Accordingly, as likewise security from him of 400000 Pounds, according to the intent and meaning of the Act of Parliament in that behalf, as by the said Warrants, Receipts and Security it doth and may appear; whereby the said Earl did all that in him lay, that the Money should not be misimployed, so that no fault can justly be imputed to him on that Affair.

The said Earl by Protestation likewise saith, that he never Proposed or Negotiated for any Peace, for the French King on any terms whatsoever, nor had he ever any such Traiterous or Wicked Designs, Intents or Purposes, as are mentioned; nor did he ever receive any Money at all from the French King, or by his directions to or for any purpose whatsoever, nor did he ever Attempt or Indeavor to procure any sum of money whatsoever, either great or small, for the carrying on or maintaining of any such wicked or ill Design or Purpose, as is charged upon him.

But whatsoever he proposed or negotiated in any Affairs or Matters, relating to Peace or War, the same was with His Majesties Command, privity and directions, and not otherwise, and without any Traiterous or ill Design and Purpose. The said Earl further more by Protestation saith, that he cannot possibly imagine the reason, wherefore he should be Popishly affected, he having always been educated in, and a Professor of the true Protestant Religion Established in the Church of England, and is no way conscious to himself, of his having acted any thing contrary thereto, or tending in the least to the prejudice or subversion thereof, which might give any just cause of suspition of his being Popishly affected, as is alleadged. And as to any concealment of the late Plot and Conspiracy, against His Majesties Person and Government, after he had notice thereof, the said Earl by Protestation saith, that about the middle of August last (which was the first time the said E. ever had any the least notice of it, His Majesty sent the said Earl some Papers, which were sealed up, and did at the same time send the said Earl word, that one Kerby and Dr. Tonge would come and speak with the said Earl about the said Papers, after which His Majesty expected to hear more of the said matter from the said Earl at Windsor, whether he
was then new gone. And within a day or two the said Kerby, did bring the said Dr. Tonge to the said Earl, and the said Earl shewing the Doctor the said Papers, he told the said Earl, that these were the same Papers he had delivered to the King, who told the said Dr. that he would send the said Earl the Papers, and had commanded him the said Doctor, to wait upon the said Earl about the same, he the said Doctor also told the said Earl, at the same time, that the said Papers were but Coppies, and that the Originals of those Papers, which are in his Custody had been put under the door of his chamber, and that he did not then know who was Author of the Originals, but guessed at one who was most likely to be the Author, but would not name any Body. In some short time after the Dr. came to the said Earl again, with an additional Paper to the f • rmer, and then told the said Earl, he had met with the Man he supposed to be the Author, who had owned himself to be so, and had given him an additional Paper, of which that he then gave the said Earl was a true Copy, but the said Author would not have his name known, nor his hand seen by any, but the Doctor himself, because he feared he might be in great danger, if the Jesuits should know of him. The said Earl then went Immediatly to His Majesty to Windsor, and then gave him an account of what had passed, and so he the said Earl did as often as Dr. Tonge, (with whom only the said Earl had any conference about the matter), gave him any further Information; and doubteth not but His Majesty out of his Royal Goodness and Justice, will clear the said Earl in this particular; and the said Earl by further Protestation saith, that he made several applications, and was very importunate with His Majesty, he might have liberty to make known the same to others of His Majesties Councel, but could not obtain liberty so to do, wherefore the said Earl his not revealing of such notice to others, ought to be attributed to his duty and not to any favor of Popery, or any other ill intent or design whatsoever; and by Protestation also saith, that he had no other notice of the said Plot, then what was after wards given publickly to the said Earl, and the rest of His Majesties Councel together; neither hath the said Earl at any time suppressed any Evidence, or reproachfully or other wise discountenanced the Kings Witnesses, in discovery of the Plot, but on the contrary, was the most active Person in causing the Papers of Coleman to be seized, whereby great part of the Plot was discovered. And the said Earl did deliver all the said Papers to the Privy Councel, and the same were transmitted thence to the Parliament, where the said Earl conceiveth they now remain;
and the said Earl by protestation further saith, that he believeth neere the sum mentioned within the space of three Years, though not within the time in the Charge mentioned, hath been issued out of His Majesties Treasury, upon and by vertue of Privy Seals for secret Service; and that upon such Privy Seals, many considerable sums of money have been paid for publick uses, such payments being oftentimes made, both for saving Charge of new Privy Seals, and to save a great part of the Fees of the Exchequer, but what part of the said Moneys is meant to be paid for unnecessary Pensions, the said Earl knoweth not, but by protestation saith, that all the said Moneys were issued out by him by legal Warrant, and according to the usual course in such cases; and what branch of His Majesties Revennue was at any time diverted, out of the known Method and Government of the Exchequer, the said Earl knoweth not, he the said Earl during all the time he had the Honor to serve His Majesty, in the Office of Lord high Treasurer, having taken all the care he could, that all and every Branch of His Majesties Revennue, should be duly brought into the Exchequer, and issued out by Tallies struck in the Ordinary and Usual manner, as he doubted not but will appear upon inspection thereof, and of the Accompts taken thereof, and still remaining in the said Exchequer. And the Earl by protestation knoweth not, which of His Majesties Commissioners are meant to have been put out of their Offices, there having been divers Commissioners removed, in several Offices of the Revennue, but sure he is, that he did not remove or procure any to be removed, for any such Reason as is Alledged, but where Commissioners were constituted by Commission in an Office, during the Kings pleasure, as all Commissioners for managing any part of His Majesties Revennue are, if His Majesty were pleased upon any Occasion, and leave any of the former Commissioners out of the new Commission, the said Earl hopeth he hath not any ways Offended therein; and the said Earl by protestation further saith, that he must needs acknowledge, that he served a most gratious and bountiful Royal Master, who was Gratiously pleased freely to Confer his Bounty upon the said Earl. Yet the said Earl saith, that he hath not during the time of serving His Majesty, in the said Office, gained any such Considerable Estate, as should Render him suspected of using any ill means for the Obtaining of it, many of his predecessors in that Office having gained in less time, more considerable and far greater Estates by it, then the said Earl hath, and yet were never Accused for using any indirect or ill Means, is Obtaining
or Procuring the same. And further the Earl by protestation saith, that he never used any indirect Means whatsoever, nor by any indirect Means procured from His Majesty, any Guift or Grant whatsoever, nor is he in the least knowing or sensible, that he hath Offended against any Act of Parliament in that behalf; but for that the said Earl is sensible of his own Weakness, in the Management of so great an Office and Imployment; and that although, he knoweth his Heart to be sincere, having never Admitted a thought into it, leading either to Treason, or any other Crime against His Majesty, the Government, or Religion Established; yet that he may have Erred out of Ignorance, or want of understanding, or ability to manage an Office of so great trust, wherein His Majesty was pleased to place him; and for that he cannot foresee, what Misinterpretation or severe construction may be put upon any of his actions, in a place of so great trust, and chiefly, that he may not seem to wave His Majesties Grace and Favor to him, the said Earl for Plea saith, and humbly Offereth to your Lordships, as to all and Every the said Crimes, Treasons, Misdemeanors and Offences contained, or mentioned in the said Articles; that after the said Articles exhibited, namely, the first day of March now last past, the Kings most Excellent Majesty by his most Gratious Letters Patents of Pardon, under his great Seal of England, bearing date at Westminster the said first day of March, in the 31th. Year of his Reign, and here into this most high and honorable Court produced, under the said great Seal of his Especial Grace, certain knowledge, and meer Motion, hath Pardoned, Remised and Released to him, the said Thomas Earl of Danby, all and all manner of Treasons, Misprisions of Treasons, Insurrections, Rebellions, Fellonies, Exactions, Oppressions, publication of words, Misprisions, Confederacies, Concealments, Negligences, Omissions, Offences, Crimes, Contempts, Misdemeanors and Trespasses whatsoever, by himself alone, or with any other Person or Persons, or by any other, by the Command, Advice, Assent, Consent or Procurement, of him the said Thomas Earl of Danby, Advised, Commanded, Attempted, Made, Perpretated, Concealed, Committed or Omitted, before the 27th. Day of February, then and now last past, being also after the time of the said Articles exhibited; athough the said premisses, or any of them did, or should touch, or concern the Person of His said Majesty, or any of his publick Negotiations whatsoever; and His Majesties affaires with Forreign Embassadors, sent to his said Majesty, or by not rightly Prosecuting His
Majestes instructions, and Commands to his Embassadors, residing on His Majesties behalf in forreign Parts, and also, all and singular Accessors to the said premisses and every of them, although he the said Thomas Earl of Danby, were or were not of the said Premisses, or any of them Indicted, Impeached, Appealed, Accused, Convicted, Adjudged, Outlawed, Condemned or Attainted; and all and singular Indictments, Impeachments, Inquisitions, Informations, Exegents, Judgements, Attainders, Outlawries, Convictions, Executions, Pains of Death, corporal Punishments, Imprisonments, Forfeitures, Punishments, and all other Pains and Penalties whasoever, for the same or any of them, and all and all Manner of Suits, Complaints, Impeachments and Demands whatsoever, which His said Majesty, by reason of the premisses or any of them then had, or for the future should have, or his Heirs or Successors, any way could have afterwards against him the said Thomas Earl of Danby. And further His Majesty willed and granted that the said Letters patents and the said pardon, And also suit of his Majesties Peace, and whatsoever to his said Majestie, his Heirs or Successors, against him the said Earl of Danby, did or could belong, by reason or occasion of the premisses, or any of them. And His Majesty hath hereby given and granted, his firm Peace to the said Thomas Earl of Danby; and further His Majesty willed and granted, that the said Letters patents, and the said pardon and release therein contained, as to all the things therein pardoned and released, should be good and effectual in the Law; although the Treasons, Misprisions of Treasons, Insurrections, Rebellions, Fellonies, Exactions, Oppressing, publishing of words, Misprisions, Confederacies, Concealments, Negligences, Omissions, Offences, Crimes, Contempts, Misdemeanors and Treasons were not certainly specified, and notwithstanding, the Statute in the Parliament of the Lord Richard the Second late King of England, in the 14th. Year of his Reign, made and provided, and notwithstanding, the Statute in the Parliament of the Lord Edward the Third, late King of England, in the 14th. Year of his Reign made and provided, or any other Statute, Act or Ordinance to the Contrary thereof, made and provided; and moreover, his said now Majesty by his said Letters patents of his further Grace, did firmly Command all and singular Judges, Justices, Officers and Others whomsoever, that the said free and general Pardon of his said Majesty, and the general words, clauses and sentences abovesaid, should be construed, expounded and adjudged in all His Majesties
Courts, and else where, in the most beneficial Ample and Benign sense; and for the better and more firm Discharge of the said Earl of, and from the Crimes and Offences aforesaid, according to the true Intent of His Majesty, and in such beneficial Manner and Form, to all intents and purposes, as if the said Treasons, Misp • ision of Treason, Crimes, Offences, Concealments, Negligences, Omissions, Contempts and Trespasses aforesaid, and other the premisses by apt Expres • , and special words had been remitted, released and pardoned; and that the said Letters patents of pardon, and the release a • d pardon therein contained, should be pleaded and allowed, in all and every His Majesties Courts, and before all his Justices whosoever, without any writ of allowance, any matter, cause, or thing whatsoever in any wise notwithstanding, as by the said Letters patents themselves more at large appeareth, which said Letters patents follow in these words.

opener.signed: Carolus secundus Dei Gratia Angliae, Scotiae, Franciae, & Hiberniae Rex, fidei defensor, &c.
opener.salute: Omnibus ad quos praesentes Literae pervenerint salutem.

div.p:
Sciatis quod nos pro diversis boni • causis & considerationibus ad haec specialiter movenda, de gratiâ nostrâ speciali. ac ex certo scientia & mero moto nostris pardonavimus, remissimus, & relaxavimus; ac per praesentes pro nobis, haeredibus, & successoribus nostris pardonamus, remittimus, & relaxamus, perdilecto & perquam fideli consanguineo & Consiliario nostro Thomae Comiti Danby, omnes & omnimod • s proditiones, Crimina laesae Majestatis, Misprisiones proditionum, Insurrectiones, Rebelliones, Felonias, Exactioncs, Oppressiones, verborum propalationes, misprisiones, confederationes, concelamenta, negligentias, Omissiones, Offensas, Crimina, Contemptus, Malefacta & Transgressiones quaecunque per se solum, seu cum aliquâ aliâ personâ vel aliquibus aliis personis aut per aliquem alium sive aliquos alios ex praecepto, advisamento, assensu, consensu, seu procuratione ejusdem Thomae Comitis Danby, advisata, praecepta, attemptata facta, perpetrata, concelata, commissa sive omissa ante vicessimum septimum die Februarii jam ultimo praeteritum licet praemissa vel corum aliqua vel aliquod tangunt, vel tangat personam nostrā▪ vel negotiationes nostras publicas qualescunque▪ nec non transactiones nostras cum forinsecis legatis ad nos missis, vel non rite prosequendo Instructiones, & mandata nostra legatis nostris in partibus extra Marinis ex parte nostrâ residentes; ac etiam omnia & singula accessarum praemissorum & cujusl • bet eorum, licet idem Thomas comes Danby de praemissis vel aliquo praemissorum Judica • us, impetitus appellatus rectatus, convictus adjudicatus utlegatus condemnatus vel attinctus existit
vel non existit; ac omnia & singula indictamenta impetitiones, inquisitiones, informationes, exigenda, Judicia, attinctationes, utlegationes, convictiones, executiones, paenas mortis, paenas corporales, Imprisonamenta, foris factura, punitiones, & omnes alias paenas & penalitates quascunque, pro eisdem vel eorum aliquo, & omnia & omnimodas sectas querelas impetitiones & demanda quaecunque, quae nos versus ipsum Thomam Comitem Danby ratione praemissorum vel corum alicujus babuimus, habemus, seu in futuro habere poterimus, aut haredes, seu successores nostri ullo modo habere poterint in futuro: Sectamque pacis nostrae ex quo ad nos, haeredes, & successores nostros versus ipsum Thomam Comitem Danby pertinet, seu pertinere potuerit ratione seu occasione praemissorum seu eorum aliquorum vel alicujus; ac firmam pacem nostram & inde damus & concedimus per praesentes: Et ulterius volumus & conecdimus, quod hae literae nostrae ac haec nostra pardonatio, remissio, & relaxatio in eisdem contenta quoad omnia & singula superius pardonata remissa & relaxata bonae & effectuales in lege sint & erint; licet proditiones, crimina laesae Majestatis, Misprisiones prodictionum insurrectiones, Rebelliones, Feloniae, Executiones, Oppressiones, verborum propalationes, misprisiones, confederationes, concelementa, negligentiae, omissiones, offensae, crimina, contemptus malefacta & Transgressiones antedictae, minus certe specificata existunt; & non obstante statuto in Parliamento Domini Richardi Secundi nuper Regis Angliae, Anno Regni sui tridecimo edicto & pro viso; & non obstante statuto in Parliam • nto Domini Edvardi tertii nuper Regis Angliae, Anno Regni sui 14 edicto & proviso, aut aliquo alio statuto, actu, vel ordinatione in contrarium inde edicto & proviso; & ulterius de uberiori gratiâ nostrâ firmiter praecipimus omnibus & singulis judicibus, Justitiariis, Officiariis, & aliis quibuscunque quod hoc plus libera & generalis pardonatio nostra, & generalia verba, clausulae, & sententiae supradictae, construenter exponenter, & adjudicenter in omnibus curiis nostris & alibi in beneficentissimo, ampl • ssimo, & benign • ssimo sensu; & pro maxima & firmiori exoneratione praedicti Thomae Comitis Danby de & à criminibus & offensis praedictis secundùm verum intentionem nostram & in tam beneficiali modo & forma, ad omnes intentiones & proposita prout si praedictae proditiones, crimina laesae Majestatis, Misprisiones proditionum, crimina, offensae, concelamenta, negligentiae, Omissiones, contemptus, & transgressiones praedictae ac caetera praemissa pe • ap • a, expressa, & specialia verba, pardonata, remissa & relaxata fuissent: Et quod haeliterae patentes, & remissio, relaxatio, & pardonatio nostra in eisdem contenta, in quibuscunque curiis nostris, & coram quibuscunque Justit • ariis nostris perlicenter
& allocenter sive aliquo libri de Alatatione, aliqua re, causa, vel materia quacunque in aliquo non obstante: In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes,

closer.dateline: teste meipso apud Westmin. primo die Martii, Anno regni nostri tricessimo primo.

div.p: And the said Earl doth aver, that he the said Thomas Earl of Danby in the said Articles named, is t • e same Thomas Earl of Danby in the said Letters patents of pardon here produced, likewise named, which pardon the said Earl doth Rely upon, and pleadeth the same in Bar of the said Impeachment, and in Discharge of all the Treasons, Crimes, Misdemeanors and Offences, contained or mentioned in the said Articles of Impeachment, and every of them; and this he the said Earl is ready to aver, whereupon he humbly prays the Judgement of your Lordships, and that His Majesties most Gratious pardon may be allowed, and that he the said Earl by vertue thereof, may be from all the said Articles of Impeachment, and all and every the Treasons and Crimes therein Alledged against him, acquitted and discharged.

The Lord Bellasis being brought to the Bar, and kneeling, he was bid to stand up, was told, that whereas he hath put in a Plea, and a plea and Answer, as Argumentive and Evasive, and to which the Commons cannot Reply. The Lords do not give any Opinion one way or other in the case, But if he think fit to mend his Plea, he may, but the House expects such an Answer, as he will abide by and stand to.

After thi • he withdrew, and being called in again, was told he could have but one Plea depending in Court, and if he will stand by the Plea he hath put in, he may, otherwise he may put in a new Plea and withdraw the former.
Upon this John Lord Bellasis put in another Answer, and his former Answer was redelivered him,

Whereas John Lord Bellasis Prisoner in the Tower for Treason, and other high Crimes, Misdemeanors and Offences, of which he stands Impeached by the House of Commons, was this day brought to the Bar, to put in his Answer to the said Impeachment, and there desired, that Mr. Holt Councellor at Law may be Added to the Councel formerly Assigned to him; it is thereupon Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Mr. Holt be and is hereby Assigned to be of Councel for the Lord Bellasis in like manner, and for the like purposes, as the other Councel formerly desired on his Lordships behalf were Assigned.
The said Answer was read as followeth.

The humble Answer of John L. Bellasis, now Prisoner in the Tower of London, to the Articles of Impeachment of high Treason, and other high Crimes and Offences exhibited against him, the said Lord Bellasis and others to the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament, by the Knights, Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled, in the names of themselves and of all the Commons of England.

This Defendant saving and reserving to himself, all advantages and Benefit of exception to the generality, incertainty and other unsufficiencies of the said Articles, of which he humbly prays, that notice may be taken, and a just regard may be had by your Lordships.

He saith, that he is not Guilty of all, or any of the matters by the said Articles of Impeachment charged against him, in manner and form as they are charged against him; and for his Tryal, he humbly putteth himself upon his Peers.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons, by Sir Timothy Baldwyn and Sir John Hoskins, to communicate to them the Plea and Answer of Thomas Earl of Danby, and the Answer • f John Lord Bellasis, delivered in this day at the Bar in Person, with this desire, that the Original Answers may be returned with convenient speed.
