It is Ordered, that the Lieutenant of the Tower of London, be and is hereby required, to bring William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Stafford, and Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, now Prisoners there to the Bar of this House, to morrow at Ten a Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Sabbati 26 April 1679.
div.p:
THis day these Ls. following, took the Oathes of Allegiance & Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration, in pursuance of the Act, for the more Effectual preserving
of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

Ordered. That the Amendments in the Bill for clearing the City of London, and parts Adjacent from Popish Recusants, be taken into consideration further on Tuesday Morning, in a Committee of the whole House.

The Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, and the Lord Arundel of Warder, being brought to the Bar, and kneeling, and then bid stand up were told, that the House of Commons had taken Exceptions to their Answers, as Argumentive and Evasive, to which the Common • cannot Reply.

The Lords do not give any Opinion one way or other in the Case, but if they think fit to mend their Pleas they may, if they insist on them they may, but the House expects such Answers as they will abide by and stand to.

After this, they withdrew, they are called in again, and told they can have but one Plea depending in Court, and if they will stand by the Plea they have put in they may, otherwise they may put in new Pleas and withdraw the former.
After this the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, and the Lord Arundel of Warder put in their Answers, and their former Answers were redelivered them.
Then the several Answers were Read as followeth.

The humble Answer of William Earl of Powis, now Prisoner in the Tower of London to the Articles of Impeachment of high Treason, and other high Crimes and Offences, Exhibited against the said Earl and Others, to the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, in the name of themselves and of all the Commons of England.

This Defendent saving and reserving to himself, all Advantages and Benefit of Exception, to the Generality, Incertainty, and other Insufficiencies of the said Articles, of which he humbly prays, that Notice may be taken, and a just Regard may be had by your Lordships.

He saith, that he is not guilty of all, or any of the Matters by the said Articles of Impeachment charged against him,
in manner and form as they are charged against him; and for his Trial he humbly putteth himself upon his Peers.

The hunmble Answer of William Viscount of Stafford, now Prisoner in His Majesties Tower of London, to the Impeachment of high Treason, and other high Crimes and Misdemeanors exhibited against him and others, to the Right honorable the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament, by the Knights Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled, in the Name of themselve and of the Commons of England.

The said Viscount saving to himself all Advantage and Benefit of Exceptions, to the Generality, Incertainty, and Insufficiency of the said Impeachment, most humbly beseeching their Lordships thereof, to take due Notice, and thereunto at all times to have a just Regard, he Answereth, and saith, he is not guilty of all or any of the Offences charged against him by the said Impeachment; and for his Trial humbly and willingly putteh himself upon his Peers, no way doubting, but by the Grace of God and their Lordships impartial Justice, he shall make his Innocence appear, all which he humbly submitteth unto their Lordships further Consideration.

The humble Answer of Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, now Prisoner in the Tower of London, to the Articles of Impeachment of high Treason, and other high Crimes and Offences exhibited against him, the said Lord Arundel and Others, to the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, the Knights Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled in the name of themselves and of all the Commons of England.

This Defendent saving and reserving to himself, all Advantages and Benefit of Exception to the Generality, Incertainty, and other Insufficiencies of the said Articles, of which he humbly prays, that Notice may be taken, and a just Regard may be had by your Lordships.

He saith, he is not guilty of all or any the Matters by the said Articles of Impeachment charged against him, in manner
and form as they are charged against him; and for h •• Trial, he humbly putteth himself upon his Peers.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons, by Sir Miles Cooke, and Sir John Hoskins, to communicate to them the several Answers of the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, and the Lord Arundel given in this day at this Bar by the Lords in Person.

Upon reading the Petition of Frances Countess of Portland, shewing that in the last Parliament, she by Petition complained to this House of Proceedings had against her in 1674, contrary to Priviledge of Parliament, whereby she was Indicted and Convicted of Recusancy, praying now, that she may be relieved against the said proceedings, and have the favorable Assistance of this House to His Majesty, for the perfecting of his Royal pardon granted unto her for the same, after Consideration had thereof; it is Ordered that the Clerk of the Parliament look out, and have in Readiness the Proceedings of this House upon the former Petition of the said Countess of Portland, against Tuesday next, at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Lunae 28. Aprilis 1679.
div.p: THis day Heneage Lord Finch, Lord Chancellor of England; and John Earl of Bridgewater took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration against Transubstantiation, pursuant to the Act made in the 25th. Year of His now Majesties Reign, for preventing the Dangers, which may happen from Popish Recusants, their Witnesses being first sworn at the Bar, did prove the truth of their Respective certificates, concerning their receiving of the Sacrament of the Lords supper.

This day Thomas Lord Windsor did take the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act for the more effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.
The House was put into a Committee to Consider of the Bill, for the better securing of the Liberty of the Subject, the House was resumed.

The Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee which was appointed to prepare this Bill for the Committee of the House, had Reported several Amendments to the said Bill, and the Committee being now possest thereof, desires that a day may be appointed for the House to receive the Report thereof; and that the Lord who Reported the Amendments to the Committee, may have leave to Offer some other Considerations to the House, which was agreed to and appointed Wednesday next for that Business.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by the Lord Russel and Others, to acquaint their Lordships, that the House of Commons have passed a Vote, wherein they desire their Lordships Concurrence, the said Vote was Read as followeth. Resolved Nemine Contradicente.

That the Duke of Yorks being a Papist, and the hopes of his coming such to the Crown, has given the greatest Countenance and Incouragement to the present Conspiracies and Designs of the Papists, against the King and the Protestant Religion.
Ordered that the Debate of this Message be taken up on Wednesday next.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Francis Winnington and Others, to return the Pleas and Answers of Thomas Earl of Danby, and to desire that their Lordships would send for the Earl of Danby to this Bar, to know of him whether he will rely upon and abide by the Plea of his Pardon.

Hereupon it is Ordered, that the Leiutenant of the Tower of London, be and is hereby required to bring Thomas Earl of Danby now a Prisoner there to the Bar of this House, to Morrow at Eleven of the Clock in the Forenoon.
The Earl of Clarendon Reported an Information, which was brought before the Lords Committees for Examinations, and read as followeth.

Middx & West. The Information of Titus Oats, Dr. in Divinity taken in Obedience to the Lords Order of the Committee, for the discovery of matters relating to the discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, before me Edmund Warcup Esquire, one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace in the said County, City, and Liberties, this 26 Day of April 1679.

This Informant saith, that the Person called Sir William Andrews of Essex hath been a Collector of Moneys for the use of the Jesuits, in Order to their carrying on this horrid Conspiracy against His Majesties Royal Person, and Government, as hath appeared to this Informant by several Letters subscribed William Andrews, which this Informant hath seen and read in London, and at St. Omers, in one of which Letters to London, he gave an account of five hundred and od Pounds collected by way of suffrage, and put into a sure hand, as the said Letter expressed for the use of the Jesuits, whom he therein assured, that One thousand pound more would be suddainly collected, and prayed their Order for the returning this money for London; and this Informant further saith, that the said Sir William Andrewes, was known to this Inf • rmant by the Name of Leverstock, and in the last sum received a Commission from the Provincial of the Jesuits, viz. Thomas Whitebread, by the hands of William Irland, authorizing him to be a Collonel, or some other Officer in the Army then intended to be Raised, for the carrying on the said horrid Conspiracy, and with his own hand signed a Receipt for the said Commission, by the Name of Leverstock, and wrote the Receipt, which Receipt was the same hand writing with the other Letter signed William Andrews, and further at present this Informant saith not.

dateline.hi: Jurat die & animo supra dict. Coram me Ed. Warcup

div.p: Upon Report made from the Lords Committees, for Examining matters relating to the discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that their Lordships have received Information upon Oath, that Sir William Andrews now Prisoner in the Gate-house at Westminster, is ingaged in the Conspiracy against His Majesties Person and Government; it i • thereupon Ordered, that the Keeper of the Gate-house aforesaid, be and is hereby required to take care, that the said Sir William Andrews be forthwith conveyed, and safely delivered into the Tower of London, there to remain a Prisoner till he shall be discharged by due course of Law, and for so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

This House being moved, that Mr. Edward Hubberd, alias Hubert, and Mr. John Bird may be permitted to sollicit, and take care of the Management of such Matters as concern William Earl of Powis, now Prisoner in the Tower; it is thereupon Ordered, that the said Edward Hubberd alias Hubert,
and John Bird be and are hereby Assigned to the said Earl of Powis, for the solliciting and management of such matters relating to the said Earl of Powis, as his Lordship shall intrust them with in Order to his Trial.

Whereas Sir Peter Fortescue, and Dame Amy his Wife, wereby Order of the 10th instant appointed to put in their Answer in writing on the the first day of May next, to the Petition and Appeal of William Noy, and others depending in this House against them, whereof they had no Notice till the 21th. Instant, being then above Two hundred Miles distant from London, as by their Petition and the Affidavit annexed appeareth, and therefore they pray a longer time for the purpose aforesaid, their sollicitor and writings being then in Cornwal, and not yet come to London, upon consideration had thereof; it is Ordered, that the said Sir Peter Fortescue and Dame Amy his Wife, have hereby further time given them for putting in their said Answer in writing, till Thursday the 15th. Day of May next, at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Martis 29. Aprilis 1679.
div.p: A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir John Trevor and others, to return the Original Pleas of the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, Lord Petre, Lord Arundel of Warder, and Lord Bellasis.

This day Thomas Earl of Danby was brought to the Bar, and having kneeled, the Lord Chancellor by direction of this House told him, that their Lordships have received a Message from the House of Commons, to desire their Lordships to send for him, to know whether he will rely upon and abide by the Plea of his pardon, to which the Earl of Danby said, this Question was new to him, and of very great Importance, and did not know what Answer to give at present, therefore desired some time to Advise on it, and being demanded what time, he desired till this day seven Night; then the Earl of Danby being withdrawn, the House Ordered that he should have till Saturday next, upon which his Lordship being called in again, the Lord Chancellor told him, that in Regard he saies this Matter was new to him and of great Importance,
the Lords have given him till Saturday to Advise therein, and then to give in his Answer.

The House was put into a Committee, to consider of the several Amendments in the Bill, for clearing the City of London and Parts adjacent from Papists, and the chief point now in Question was, whether the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy shall be inserted in the several Places of the Bill, where the Declaration is mentioned, which is resolved to be inserted, to which the House agreed, and Ordered the Bill to be ingrossed accordingly.

Upon reading the Petition of William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Stafford, William Lord Petre, Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, and John Lord Bellasis, shewing, that in Order to their Defence upon their Trials, they have sent for from beyond the Sea, Christopher Townely, Henry Hall, and Daniel Gifford, being very material Winesses, which Witnesses are imprisoned upon supposition of being Priests, as in the Petition is Alledged, and praying that they may be discharged from their imprisonment; it is Ordered that the Warrants by which the said Christopher Townely, Henry Hall, and Daniel Gifford were committed to Prison, shall be brought before this House to Morrow, at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

It is this day Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that neither the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, Lord Petre, Lord Arundel of Warder, and Lord Bellasis, nor any of them, shall send for any Person or Persons from beyond the Seas, to be used as Witnesses upon their respective Trials, unless they shall first give in the name or names of such Person or Persons to be allowed of by this House.

Upon reading the Petition of Francis Countess of Portland, praying that this House would be pleased to interceed to His Majesty, for perfecting his Royal pardon granted to her, for her being convicted of Recusancy in the Year 1674, which Conviction a Steward of hers taking Advantage of to her prejudice, upon a Trial for a Considerable sum of money of hers detained by him; it is thereupon Ordered, that the Lord Privy Seal, and Viscount Faulconbergh do Attend His Majesty, humbly to move him from this House, that His Majesty will be gratiously pleased to give Order for the perfecting of his said Royal pardon granted to her, which by reason of the late change made in the Management of His Majesties Treasury, now stoppeth for want of a Docket, to be issued
by the Commissioners of the said Treasury, without which, the said Pardon cannot Regularly be perfected.

This day the several Indictments, whereby William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Stafford, William Lord Petre, Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, and John Lord Bellasis were found Guilty of high Treason, by the Grand-Jury before the Justices for the County of Middlesex, sitting at Westminster, on the third Day of December 1678, were brought into this House by Vertue of His Majesties Writs of Certiorari for that purpose issued.

div.head: Die Mercurii 30. April. 1679.
div.p: THis day His Majesty Sitting in his Royal Throne, Adorned with his Crown and Regal Robes and Ornanaments, the Peers being also in their Robes, commanded the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, to give notice to the House of Commons, that they presently attend His Majesty, the Commons being come with their Speaker, His Majesty was pleased to make the short Speech following.
The Season of the year advancing so fast, I thought it necessary to put you in mind of Three particulars.

list.item: 3. Providing a Fleet for our Common Security.

div.p:
And to shew you, that whilst you are doing
your parts, my thoughts have not been misimployed, but that it is my constant care to do every thing that may preserve your Religion, and secure it for the future in all events; I have Commanded my Lord Chancellor several particulars, which I hope will be an Evidence, that in all things that concerns the publick security, I shall not follow your zeal, but lead it.
Then the Lord Chancellor spake as followeth,

opener.salute: My Lords, and you the Knights Citizens and Burgesses of the House of Commons,

div.p: That Royal Care which His Majesty hath taken for the General quiet and satisfaction of all his Subjects, is now more evident by these new and fresh instances of it, which I have in command to open to you.

His Majesty hath considered with Himself, that 'tis not enough your Religion and Liberty is secure during his own Reign, but he thinks he owes it to his People, to do all that in him lyes, that these Blessings may be transmitted to your posterity, and so well secured to them, that no succession in after ages may be able to make the least alteration.

And therefore His Majesty, who hath often said in this place, that he is ready to consent to any Laws of this kind, so as the same extend not to alter the descent of the Crown in
a right line, nor to defeat the succession, hath now commanded this to be further explained.

And to the end it may never be in the power of any Papist, if the Crown descend upon him to make any change, either in Church or State; I am commanded to tell you, that His Majesty is willing, that Provision may be made, first to distinguish a Popish from a Protestant Successor, then so to limit and circumscribe the Authority of a Popish Successor, in these cases following, that he may be disabled to do any harm.

First, in reference to the Church, His Majesty is content that care be taken, that all Ecclesiastical and Spiritual Benefices and promotions in the guift of the Crown, may be conferred in such manner, as we may be sure the incumbents shall always be of the most Pious and Learned Protestants; and that no Popish Successor while he continues so, may have any Power to controul such presentments. In reference to the state and Civil part of the Government, as it is already provided, that no Papist shall sit in either House of Parliament, so the King is pleased, that it be provided too, that there may never want a Parliament when the King shall happen to dye, but that the Parliament then in being may continue indissolvable for a competent time, or if there be no Parliament in being, then the last Parliament which was in being before that time, may reassemble and sit a competent time without any new Summons or Elections.

And as no Papist can by law hold any place of Trust, so the King is content that it may be further provided, that no Lords or others of the Privy Councel, no Judges of the Common Law
or in Chancery, shall at any time during the Reign of any Popish Successor be put in, or displaced, but by the Authority of Parliament, and that care also be taken, that none but sincere Protestants may be Justices of the Peace.

In reference to the Military part, the King is willing, that no Lord Lieutenant, or Deputy Lieutenant, nor no Officer in the Navy during the Reign of any Popish Successor be put in or removed, but either by Authority of Parliament, or of such Persons the Parliament shall intrust with such Authority.

'Tis hard to invent another restraint to be put upon a Popish Successor, considering how much the Revenue will depend upon consent of Parliament, and how impossible it is to raise Money without such consent, but yet, if any thing else can occur to the Wisdom of the Parliament, which may further secure Religion and Liberty against a Popish Successor, without defeating the right of Succession its self, His Majesty will most readily consent to it.
Thus watchful is the King of all your safeties, and if he could think of any thing else, that you do either want or wish to make you happy, he would make it his business to effect it for you.
God Almighty long continue this Blessed Union, between the King and his Parliament and People.
Ordered, that on Saturday Morning next this House be put into a Committee, to proceed in consideration of the Bill for the better regulating of the Tryals of the Peers of England.

The House was Adjourned into a Committee during pleasure, to consider of the Amendments in the Bill for the better securing the liberty of the subject, the House was Resumed, and the Earl of Bridgewater Reported, that the Committee
of the House have been in Consideration of the Bill, concerning the liberty of the subject, wherein they have made several amendments, and the Opinion of the Committee is, that the Bill is fit to pass with these amendments; the said Amendments were read twice and agreed to, and the last reading of this Bill to be on Friday next.

div.head: Die Veneris 2. May 1679.
div.p: THis day John Mannors De Haddon Chevalier was introduced after the usual manner in his Robes.

But before his Lordship took his place, he took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act, for the more Effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

This day Ford Lord Grey of W • rk took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration of Transubstantiation, pursuant to the Act made in the 25 Year of His now Majesties Reign, for preventing the Dangers, which may happen from Popish Recusants, his Witnesses being first sworn at the Bar, did prove the truth of the Certificate, concerning his Lordship receiving the Sacrament of the Lords supper,
Hodio tertia vice lecta est Billa, an Act for the better securing the Liberty of the Subject, and for preventing of imprisonment beyond the Seas.
The Question being put, whether this Bill with the Amendments now read shall pass, it was resolved in the Affirmative,

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by the Lord Chief Justice of the Common Pleas, and Mr. Justice Atkins to return the Bill for the better securing the liberty of the Subject, and for preventing of imprisonments beyond the Seas, in which the Lords have made Amendments, and desire the Concurrence of the House of Commons thereto.
Hodie tertia vice lecta est Billa, An Act from freeing the City of London from Popish Inhabitants.
The question was proposed, whether this Bill shall be amended.
Then this previous question was put, whether this question shall now be put, and it was resolved in the negative.
Then the question was put, whether this Bill shall pass, it was resolved in the Affirmative. Dissentientibus.

Because this House hath sent down a Bill to the House of Commons, for the better discovery and speedy conviction of Popish Recusants, wherein the conviction of Recusancy was, for refusing the Test and not the Oathes, the same Bill was sent down from this House about the end of the last Parliament.

As also, because there are Thousands of dissenters, that will be faithful even to death against the Common Enemy the Papists, which by the addition of the Oathes to the Test, may be tempted to think themselves in interest obliged to take the Papists part against us.
Shaftesbury Pr.
Berkley
Kent.
Stamford
Derby.
Delamer
Huntington.
Chandos.
Ordered, That on Monday next this House will take into consideration, whether the Lords Spiritual are to Vote in judicature in cases of Blood, or upon Bills of Attainder.

Upon Report made by the Earl of Clarendon, from the Committee for Examining Matters relating to the discovery of the late horrid conspiracy, that their Lordships had Examined William Osborne and Thomas Lane, late Servants to Mr. Titus Oates, as also Thomas Knox, who had tampered and practiced with them to take off Mr Oates's Testimony, which appearing to their Lordships to be a matter of great consequence, and fit to be communicated to the House of Commons; It is Ordered, that the Clerk attending the said Committee, is hereby appointed to deliver to some of the Members of the House of Commons, the Examinations taken by their Lordships in this case.

Upon Reading the Petition of Elizabeth Countess of Powis, complaining of some Persons not named, entring into her House in Lincolns-Inn Fields the last night, about 12 of the Clock with Staves and Halberds, and forcing her to undertake for the forth coming of her Servants this Morning, which proceeding she conceiveth to be against the Priviledge of Peerage; It is thereupon Ordered, that the Earl of Craven be, and is hereby desired to inquire into the matter of Fact
complained of, and to give this House an account by what Authority it was done.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir William Beversham and Sir Edward Low, to deliver a Bill to them intituled an Act, for freeing the City of London and parts adjacent from Popish Inhabitants, which the Lords have passed to, which the Lords desire the Concurrence of the House of Commons.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir John Trever &c. who said the Commons had passed a Bill, Intituled an Act for granting a Supply to His Majesty of 264620 l. 17. 03 d. for paying off, and disbanding the Forces raised, since the 29th day of September 1677. to which Bill the Commons desire their Lordships Concurrence.

div.head: Die Veneris 2. May. 1679.
div.p: THe Lord Chamberlain of His Majesties House-hold Rep •• ted, that he and the Lord Mainard have Attended His Majesty with the Address of this House, concerning Edmond Warcup Esquire, to which His Majesty was pleased to give this gracious Answer, that he hath a very good Opinion of Mr. Warcup, and is so well satisfied with the good service done by him, that His Majesty will be ready to gratifie him in any Imployment, that the said Mr. Warcup can reasonably pretend to, or that shall occur to His Majesties own thoughts for Mr. Warcups Advantage.

Ordered, that the Lieutenant of the Tower of London, be and is hereby required to bring Thomas Earl of Danby, now Prisoner there to the Bar of this House to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

div.head: Die Sabbati 3. May 1679.
div.p: THen Thomas Earl of Danby was brought to the Bar, and having kneeled, the Lord Chancellor asked him for his Answer, whether he will rely upon, and abide by the Plea of his pardon, to which his Lordship gave this Answer; the Plea I have put in was put in by the Advice of my Councel, who tell me that my Pardon is good in Law, and Advise me to insist upon my Plea put in, which I now do, and desire that my Councel may be heard to make out the Validity of my Pardon, and that Serjeant Barrel and Mr. Pollexfeu may be Added to the Councel, formerly Assigned to me.

Upon Request made by the Earl of Danby this day at the Bar, that Serjeant Barrel and Mr. Pollexfeu may be Assigned to be of Councel for him; it is Ordered that Serjeant Barrel and Mr. Pollexfeu, be and are hereby Assigned to be of Councel for Thomas Earl of Danby, now Prisoner in the Tower, together with the Councel formerly Assigned to him, in Order to his Defence upon his intended Trial.

Whereas, upon complaint made to this House, and Report made by the Earl of Craven, it appears that Anthony Wells Constable, and George Palfrey, and Mathew Rutter Headboroughs with others Entered the House of the Countess of Powis in Lincolns▪Inn-Fields, on the first instant about Midnight, who Misbehaved themselves there, as in the Petition of the said Countess of Powis is suggested; it is thereupon Ordered, that the said Anthony Wells, George Palfrey, and Mathew Rutter, be and are hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House, to give an account of their so doing, on Monday the 5th. of this instant May, at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, whereof they may not fail at their Perils,
A Message was sent to the House of Commons, by the Lord Chief Justice of the Common Pleas and Judge Atkins, to Communicate to them the Earl of Danbys Answer given this Day.

div.head: Die Lunae 5. May 1679
div.p: A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Thynne and Others, to desire that their Lordships, that they would sit some time, • hat they may bring up some Business of great Importance, the Answer returned was, that their Lordships will fit a convenient time.

The House being made acquainted by the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod, that the Speaker with the Commons was at Door with his Mace, the House directed the Lord Chancellor to sit on his Woolsack and Receive them.
The Speaker with the Commons being come up to the Bar, (But the Mace was not Advanced) said.

The Knights Citizens and Burgesses in Parliament Assembled, are come up to demand Judgement in their own names, and in the names of all the Commons of England, against Thomas Earl of Danby, who stands impeached by them before your Lordships of high Treason, and diver • high Crimes and Misdemeanors, to which he hath pleaded a pardon, which pardon the Commons conceive to be Illegal and Void, and therefore they do demand Judgement of your Lordships accordingly.
Ordered. That this House will take this Demand into Consideration to morrow Morning, and all the Judges and Mr. Attorney General are to Attend this House.

Whereas Anthony Wells Constable, George Palfrey and Mathew Rutter Headboroughs, appearing this day at the Bar for Entering the House of the Countess of Powis, on the first instant about Midnight, pleaded that they had an Order of Sessions for a General search, and did not know that House to be a Peers House, being but lately come into their Offices, and Begging pardon for their Offence given, it is Ordered, that the said Matthew Wells, George Palfrey and Matthew Rutter, shall forthwith Attend the Countess of Powis, and Beg her pardon for the said Offence.

The Lord Privy Seal Reported the Effect of the Conference with the House of Commons, concerning the Amendments made by their Lordships in the Bill, for the better securing the Liberty of the subject, which was Managed by Sir Thomas
Meers, who said the Amendments are very many, which are a sign your Lordships are careful to make so useful a Bill accurate.
And then his Lordship shewed, wherein the Commons did agree with their Lordships, and wherein they did not.
The said several Amendments were read, and after some Debate thereof, the further Consideration was Adjourned to some other time, as the House think fit to Resume it.

div.head: Die Lunae 5. May Post Meridiem 1679.
div.p: IT is this day Ordered, that all Licences granted by this House to any Papist or Reputed Papist to come to and stay in Town, be and are hereby declared to be void, and that all such Persons as are concerned therein, are required to take Notice hereof, and forthwith yield Obedience to His Majesties Royal Proclamation, dated the fourth instant concerning Popish Recusants to leave and depart the Cities of London and Westminster accordingly; and it is further Ordered, that thi • Order be forthwith printed and published.

Ordered. That to morrow Morning this House will take into Consideration, whether the Lords Spiritual are to give their Vote in Judicature in cases of Bloud, or upon Bill of Attainder, as a Preliminary to the demand of the Speaker of the House of Commons, concerning the Earl of Danby.

div.head: Die Martis 6. May 1679.
div.p:
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Treby and Others, that the Knights Citizens and Bu • gesses in Parliament Assembled, having Exhibited Articles of Impeachment of high Treason, and other high Crimes and Offences against William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Staff • rd William Lord Petre, Henry Lord Arundel of Warder; and John Lord Bellasis; to which the said Lords have
pleaded not Guilty, he said he was commanded by the Knights, Citizens and Burgesses, that they will and are ready to make good the said Articles and Charge against those Lords.

After Debate of this Message, the Question was proposed, whether the five Lords in the Tower, (viz.) William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Stafford, William Lord Petre, Hery Lord Arundel of Warder, and John Lord Bellasis shall be brought to their Trials upon the Impeachment against them this day seven Night.
This previous Question was put, whether this Question shall be now put, it was Resolved in the Affirmative.
Then the maine Question was put. (viz.)

Whether the five Lords in the Tower, (viz.)) William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Stafford, William Lord Petre, Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, and John Lord Bellasis shall be brought to their Trials upon the Impeachment against them this day seven Night, it was Resolved in the Affi • mative.

Whereas the Earl of Danby hath Adheered to his Plea, and prayed to be heard by his Councel to make good the Validity of his Pardon, and whereas the Commons have by their Speaker in proper person demanded Judgment against the said Earl, as Concieving his Pardon to be illegal and void; it is Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that Saturday next is appointed for the hearing of the Earl of Danby to make good his said Plea.

Ordered. That Westminster Hall is appointed to be the place for hearing of the Earl of Danby to make good the Plea of his Pardon before this House with a Lord high Steward, and after for Trial of the five Lords impeached in like manner.

Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lords with white Staves do Attend His Majesty, to let him know from this House, that they have appointed to hear the Earl of Danby, to make good the Plea of his pardon to the Articles •• Impeachment against him, on Saturday next in Westminster Hall; and that the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, Lord Petre, Lord Arundel of Warder, and the Lord Bellasis, are to be brought to their Trials in Westminster Hall, upon the Impeachment against them on Tuesday next, and humbly to desire His Majesty, that he will be pleased to appoint a high Steward for the purposes aforesaid, to continue during the said Trials.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Judge Atkins, and Judge Dolben to acquaint them, with the two Orders made concerning the Earl of Danby and the five Lords in the Tower, and to let them know, that the Lords have appointed an Address to be presented to His Majesty, for Naming a Lord high Steward, as well in the case of the Earl of Danby, as for the Trials of the other five Lords Prisoners in the Tower, and that the same shall be in Westminster Hall.

Ordered. That i • be and is hereby recommended to the Lords of Hi • Majesties Privy Councel, to take into Consideration of the present Condition of the Kingdom of Ireland, in this time of imminent • anger▪ and to give Order, that Protestant Merchants may be permitted, and licensed to carry Arms, as Merchandize into the Kingdom of Ireland, for the use only of the Protestants there, who are unfurnished.

div.head: Die Mercurii 7. May 1679.
div.p: THe Lord Viscount Newport Reported, that he waited on His Majesty with the desire of this House, that he would appoint a Lord high Steward for the Trial of the Earl of Danby, and the five Lords in the Tower; and His Majesty returns this Answer, that he will appoint a L • rd high Steward by Saturday next.

The Lord Privy Seal reported, that he and Viscount Faulconbergh have moved His Majesty, on the behalf of the Countess of Portland, and His Majesty saith, he will give Order for the pe • fecting of the pardon to the said Countess, according to the Address of this House.

The House resumed the Debate which was Yesterday, whether the Lords Spiritual are to Vote in Judicature in cases of Bloud, or upon Bills of Attainder, and after a long Debate, the Question was proposed, whether this House shall be Adjourned till to morrow Morning.
Then this previous Question was put, whether this Question shall be now put, it was resolved in the Affirmative.
The maine Question being put, whether this House shall be now Adjourned till to morrow Morning, it was Resolved • n the Affimative.

div.head: Die Jovis 8. May 1679.
div.p: CHarles Fitz Charles Earl of Plymouth, and Oliver Earl of Bolingbrooke, took the Oaths of Allegiance and Sup • emacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration, in pursuance of the Act for the more Effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

This day Anthony Earl of Shaftesbury, Lord President of His Majesties Councel, Arthur Earl of Anglesey, L. Privy Seal, and George Viscount Hallifax took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration against Transubstantiation, pursuant to the Act made in the 25th. Year of His now Majesties Reign, for preventing the Dangers which may happen from Popish Recusants, their Witnesses being first sworn at the Bar, did prove the truth of their Certificates, concerning their Lordships receiving the Sacrament of the Lords Supper.

Upon reading the Petition of Thomas Earl of Danby, praying that the Order of this House of the 6th. Instant made in his case, which he suggesteth to be defective, as to the assistance of his Councel in Defence of his Plea may be explained, it is Ordered, that the Councel of the said Earl of Danby are to attend with him, and be heard in his said Defence.

Ordered. That Sir Bryan Broughton, Sir Thomas Whitgrave, Mr. Thomas Kennersly, Mr. Ralph Lawson, Mr. Thomas Abnel, Mr. William Paulet, Nathaniel Caulkin, Elizabeth Eld, Ann Eld, Thomas Perry, James Jones, Mr. Ralph Ph • llips, Parson of Tixbal, Mr. Sambeech, Mr. Thomas As • ley, Mr. Goodard Servant to the Bishop of Litchfield and Coventry, Thomas Sayer, Mr. Richard Gerrard of Hillerson, John Proctor, Thomas Helbowes, John Pallet of Ridgely, Walter Collins of Stafford, Thomas Parker, Thomas Winter, John Menter, Anthony Landracy▪ William Zarker, Anthony Cocke, James Baylie, John Joseph, Peter Carpenter, William Bradford, Elizabeth Silleyer, Edward W •• d, John Minney, Thomas Andrewes, be and are h ••• by required to appear before the House of Peers in Westminster Hall, to give Evidence of what they know or can say, on the behalf of William Earl of Powis, William Viscount Stafford, William Lord Petre, Henry Lord Arundel of Warder, and John Lord Bellasis, or any of them, in their making their Defence upon their respective
Trials, on Tuesday next, being the thirteenth of this instant May, and such times after as the said Trials shall continue.

The Earl of Clarendon Reported, from the Committee of Examinations, that William Harcourt the Jesuit is taken, and is now in the hands of the Officer that took him; it is Ordered, that the said William Harcourt be brought to this Bar presently, and Mr. Oats and Mr. Bedloe to be then also present.
The House took into Consideration the Amendments in the Bill, for the better securing the Liberty of the Subject.

And • s to the Amendment in the 4th. Sk. and 3d. Line, after (Committeth. Add (or in such other Court where the Offence is properly cognizable) the Question being put, whe • her to insist upon this Amendment, it was Resolved in the Affi • m •• ive.

div.head: Die Jovis 8. May 1679. Post Meridiem.
div.p: A M • ss • ge was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Christopher Mulgrave, to desire a Conference concerning the Matter of their Lordships last Message sent to them, concerning the Trials of the Earl of Danby and the five Lords in the Tower.
2. To put their Lordships in minde of a Bill sent from the House of Commons, for the better securing of the Liberty of the Subject
The Question was put, whether to give a present Conference with the House of Commons in the painted Chamber, it was resolved in the Affirma • ive.
The answer returned was, that this House will give a Conference as is desired, and appoint the same to be presently in 〈…〉 ed Chamber.
〈…〉 was Adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords 〈…〉 , which being ended, the House was 〈…〉 .

〈…〉 he Lord President Reported the Eff • ct of the Conf •• ence, wh •• h was, that the Commons suppose your Lord
〈…〉 , i •
• ll the proceedings upon the Impeachments 〈◊〉
• depending b • fore y •• r Lordships, to follow the usual Course and M • thods of Parliament, and th • Commons cannot app • ehend, what should induce your Lordships to Address to His M • jesty for a Lord high Steward, in O • der to the
determining the Validity of the Pardon, which hath been pleaded by the Earl of Danby to the Impeachment of the Commons; as also for the trial of the other five Lords, because the Commons conceive the constitution of a high Steward, is not necessary, but that Judgement may be given in Parliament upon Impeachment without a high Steward.

There being several other Matters contained in your Lordships Messages, touching the Trials of the Lords impeached, which if not setled, may Occasion several Interruptions and Delays in the Proceedings, the House of Commons do therefore propose to your Lordships, that a Committee of bo • h Houses be nominated, to consider of the most proper Ways and Methods of Proceedings, upon Impeachments of the House of Commons, acco • ding to the Usuage of Parliament, that thereby these Inconveniences may be avoided.

After a long Debate, the Question was put, whether to Agree with the Desires of the House of Commons at the Conference, to have a Committee of both Houses to Consider of the Manner of the Trials of the Lords; it was Resolved in the Negative.

Dissentientibus
Finch C.
Clare
Newport
R. Eure
J Wharton
Arlington
Essex
Stafford
Rockingham
Grey
Huntingdon
Clarendon
Salisbury
Hallifax
Lovelace,
Bedford.
• erby.
Delemer.
Pagget.

William Harcourt was brought to this Bar, and M • . Oats did charge William Harcourt, that he was a Jesuit, and was made Rector of London, and was at the Consul • ation in London about Aprill was Twelve-Month, about the Conspiracy against His Majesty and Government; whereup • n the House made this following Order.

Whereas William Harrison alias Harcourt, was this Day brought to the Bar, and was there charg • d wi • h high Treason; it is Ordered, that the Gentleman Usher of • he Bl •• k Rod Attending this House, do take special Care forthwith, to convey the • aid William Ha • rison alias Harcourt in 〈…〉 y to Newgate, there to remain a Prisoner, till he shall be discharged by due Course of Law, and for so doing, this sh ••• be a sufficient Warrant.

div.head: Die Veneris 9. May 1679.
div.p: CHarles Lord Willoughby De Parham took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration in pursuance of the Act, for the more Effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from sitting in either House of Parliament.

A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Patience Ward and Others, who said he was commanded by the Knights, Citizens and Burgesses of the House of Commons, to put their Lordships in mind of the Message by them sent, to desire their Concurrence to the Vote following,

div.head: Die Dominico, 27. April, 1679.
div.p: REsolved Nemine Contradicente, that the Duke of York being a Papist, and the hopes of his coming such to the Crown, has given the greatest Countenance since and Incouragement to the present Conspiracies, and Degns of the Papists against the King and the Protestant Religion.

The House took into further Consideration, the Amendments the Bill concerning the more Effectual securing the Liberty of the Subject, and having gone over the Amendments, it is O • dered to communicate their Lordships Resolutions, at a Conference presently, to the House of Commons, and the Lord Presiden • , Lord Privy Seal, and the Lord Wharton were appointed to draw up, what is fit to be Offered at the Conference.

This day Henry D. of Newcastle took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration against Transubstantiation, pursuant to the Act in the 25th Year of His now Maj • sti • s Reign, for preventing the Da • gers which may happen from Popish Recusants, his Witnesses being first sworn at the Bar, did prove the truth of the Cert • ficate, concerning his Lordships receiving the Sacrament of • he Lord • Supper.

A M • ssage was sent to the House of Commons by Sir John Coell, and Sir Samuel Clerk, to desire a present conference concerning the amendments in the Bill, concerning the better secu • ing the liberty of the subject.
The House was Adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords went to the Conference, which being ended, the House was Resumed.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir Timothy Baldwyn and Sir John Hoskins, to desire a present conference in the Painted Chamber, touching the Subject matter of the first Conference, with them yesterday in the Forenoon.

That which is to be said at the Conference is, that the Lords do not agree with the House of Commons for a Committee of both Houses, because they do not think it conformable to the Rules and Orders of proceedings of this Court, which is and ever must be tender in matters relating to Judicature.
The Lord Privy Seal Reported, that the Managers had delivered at the Conference what they were directed.

div.head: Die Veneris 9. May. Post Meridiem. 1679.
div.p: THe House took into consideration, in what manner the Lords are to go into Westminster Hall to morrow, and the Orders made upon the Tryal of the Earl of Pembrook were read, and it was agreed, and Ordered, the same Orders of Proceedure should now be observed, and that the Eldest Sons of the Nobility do go next after the Judges, before the Maces that go before the Barons.
Ordered, that upon any incident that shall fall, at the Tryal of the Earl of Danby to Morrow in Westminster Hall, the Lords are to res • rt to the House for Debate and Consideration.

Ordered. That the Lieutenant of the Tower, be and is hereby required to bring Thomas Earl of Danby, now Prisoner there to the Bar of this House in Westminster Hall, to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

Ordered. That the L. G. Chamberlain be desired, to take strict Care by his under Officers, that the Seats appointed for the House of Commons in Westminster Hall be kept clear, from all other Persons whatsoever, that are not Members of the House of Commons, and that his Lordship direct that Papers be posted up in all convenient Places, warning all Persons not being Members of the House of Commons, that they presume not to set upon any of the Seats in Westminster
Hall, appointed for the Members of the House of Commons, during any time of fitting of the House of Peers there, and that they cause all such Persons as shall do the contrary to be forthwith removed.

It is this day Ordered, that this House doth put off Heating or Receiving any private Business, till such time, as the publick Business now before them, relating to the Hearings and Trials of the Lords now Prisoners in the Tower be dispatched.

div.head: Die Sabbati 10. May 1679.
div.p: A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Sir Robert Carr and others, to let their Lordships know, that the House of Commons have made an Address to be presented to His Majesty, wherein they desire their Lordships Concurrence, the same Address was read and agreed to, with the Addition of the Words, Lords Spiritual and Temporal.
Which Address followeth.

We your Majestie • most Loyal and Dutiful Subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, taking notice of the great resort of the Multitude of Jesuits, Popish Priests, and other Popish Recusants to the Cities of London and Westminster, and parts adjacent, and their Obstinate continuance there, in contempt of your Maj • sties Laws and Royal Proclamations, in pursuance thereof, and considering the great dangers that may ensue thereby, especially at this time, of the approaching Tryals of the Popish L • rds, now Prisone • s in the Tower, in whose behalf s • me desperate attempts may be made for the prevention thereof, and for the better security of your Majesties Sacred Person, do most humb • y beseech your Majesty, that your Majesty will be graciously pleased to give Order, that the Mil • tia of London and Westminster▪ and Southwark, and the Tower Hamlets, and the Counties of Midd •• s • x and Su • gey, may be immediatly raised and out into a Posture of defence▪ in such proportions and • or such time▪ a • your M • jes • y shall think fit.
The Answer returned was, that this House unanimously Agrees with the House of Commons in this Address to His Majesty.

Upon reading the Petition of the Earl of Danby, shewing that he is now Attending according to their Lordships Order, and Expected to have Met his Councel assigned by their Lordships, for the Defence of his Plea; but he hath received a Message from every one of them, that they dare not appear to argue for him, by Reason of a Vote of the House of Commons passed Yesterday, whereby the Petitioner is destitute of all Councel, and is thereby totally disabled of making his Legal defence▪ therefore prayeth relief and direction herein.
It is Ordered, that this Petition be communicated to the House of Commons at a Conference, and to know of them whether they have made any such Vote.
A Message was sent to the House of Commons by Sir John Coel, an • Sir Timothy Baldwin to desire a present Conference in the painted Chamber, concerning a Petition received from the Earl of Danby.
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr Titus &c. That the House of Commons pray a Conference, upon the subj • ct Matter of the last Conference.
The Answer returned was, that this House agree to a Conference as is desired, and appoints the same to be presently in the painted Chamber.
Then the E. of Sarum Reported the Effect of the Conference, (viz.)

That for Answer of the last Conference, the Managers of this Conference were commanded by the House of Commons, to say to your Lordships, that your Lordships do not Offer any answer, or satisfaction to the Commons in their necessary proposals, amicably Offered by way of supposition, that they might have been confirmed therein by their Answer from your Lordships, that your Lordships do intend in all the Proceedings upon the Impeachments now depending before your Lordships, to follow the usual Course and Methods of Parliaments.

And further, that your Lordships have not given the least Answer or Satisfaction to the Commons, concerning your Lordships Addressing to the King for a high Steward, though the Commons proposed their desire of satisfaction in that Matter, in as cautions Terms as could be, on purpose to avoid all disputes about Judicature.

The Commons to avoid all Interruptions and Delays, in the Proceedings against the Lords impeached, and the Inconveniences
that may A 〈…〉 e thereby, having proposed to your Lordships, that a Committ • e of both Houses might be nominated, to consider of the most proper Ways and Methods, of Proceedings upon Impeachments (your Lordships without any Reason assigned save only that you say, that you do not think it conformable to the Rules and Order of the Proceedings of this Court,) have re • used to agree with the House of Commons, in appointing a Committee though not heretofore denied to the Commons, when asked, upon the like Occasion, and at this time desired purposely to avoid disputes and delays.

And therefore, the House of Commons have commanded us to acquaint your Lordships thus, upon your Answers they cannot proceed in the Trials of the Lords, before the Methods of Proceedings be adjusted between the two Houses.

After a long Debate hereof, the Question was put, whether a Committee of this House shall be appointed to Meet with a Committee of the House of Commons, to confer about the Methods and Forms of Proceedings, in Order to the Trial of the Lords, it was Resolved in the Negative.
The Messengers sent to the House of Commons, to desire a Conference upon the Earl of Danbys Petition, return with this answer, that the Commons will give a Conference, as is desired.

The House was adjourned during pleasure, and the Lords went to the Conference, which being ended, the House was Resumed; the Lord Privy Seal Reported, that the Managers have acquainted the House of Commons with the Petition of the Earl of Danby, and told them, this House did desire to know of them, whether they have made any such Vote.

Ordered. That the Clerk of the Parliament, shall of course issue out such Orders, for summoning such Persons, as the Lords, who are Prisoners in the Tower, or any of them, shall from time to time send in the Names of, to be summoned appear, as Witnesses to be made use of in their Defences, upon their respective Trials.
Ordered. By the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Lieutenant of the Tower do take care, and return the Earl of Danby in safety thither.

div.head: Die Sabbati 10. May 1679. Post Meridiem.
div.p: ORdered. That there shall be a free Conference with the House of Commons, upon the late Conference they had with this House, concerning the Forms and Methods of Proceedings, to be had at the Trials of the Lords in the Tower.
Ordered. That the Managers of the free Conference, are not to enter into any dispute about Judicature.

div.head: Die Dominico 11. May 1679.
div.p: A Message was sent to the House of Commons, by Sir Edward Low and Sir Samuel Clerk, to desire a free Conference presently in the painted Chamber, upon the Marter of the late Conference they had with the Lords, concerning the Forms and Methods of Proceedings, for to be had at the Trials of the Lords in the Tower.

The Lord President and the Rest of the Lords, that were Managers Reported, that the Lords asked the Commons, what those Forms and Methods were in reference to the Trials of the Lords in the Tower, which they did desire to Confer about, of which the Commons say they were not instructed to discourse; because they expected this free Conference was to be concerning a Committee of both Houses, touching which, their Lordships have given them yet no denial, therefore the Commons say they must resort to their House for directions therein.
A Message was brought from the House of Commons by Mr. Thynne and Others, to desire a Conference upon the subject Matter of the last free Conference.
Then the Lord President gave the House an account of the free Conference, with the several Debates Pro & Con on both Sides.

Upon consideration whereof, it is Ordered, that a Committee of this House shall be appointed to Meet with a Committee of the House of Commons, to consider of propositions and circumstances, in Reference to the Trials of the Lords in the Tower.

Then these Lords were nominated and appointed a Committee for that purpose. (viz.)
L. Chancellor
L. President
L. P. Seal
M. Winton
E Sarum
E. Clarendon
E. Essex
E. Aylesbury
Visc. Hallifax.
Visc. Newport.
L. Wharton.
L. Hollis.

Their Lordships or any five of them to Meet to morrow Morning, at Nine of the Clock in the Inner Court of Wards, and have Power to send for such Books and Persons, as they think fit, and to Adjourn from time to time as shall be thought fit.
Ordered. That the L. G. Chamberlain be desired to give Order, for the preparing of the Inner Court of Wards, fi • for a Committee of Lords and Commons to Morrow, at Nine of the Clock in the Forenoon.

A Message was sent to the House of Commons, by Sir Edward Low and Sir Samuel Clerke, to let them know, that the Lords have appointed a Committee, Consisting of Twelve Lords to joyn with a Committee of the House of Commons, at Nine of the Clock to morrow Morning, in the I • ner Court of Wards, to consider of propositions and circumstances, in Ref • rence to the Trials of the Lords in the Tower.

div.head: Die Lunae 12. May 1679.
div.p: THe House being informed by the Earl of Clarendon, that Sir Francis Ritcliffe is brought to Town, in Custody of the Serjeant at Arms Attending this House; it is Ordered, that the Lords Committees for Examinations of Matters, relating to the discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, be and are hereby appointed to send for, and Examine the said Sir Francis Ratcliffe, and Report to this House, and that the Mean time he remain in the same Custody he now is.
It being mov • d, that Mr. B • dloe desired, that two Persons might be Examined at this Bar, touching s • me words of dangerous Con 〈…〉 ence sp 〈…〉 by Mr. Lawson.

Thereupon Richard Child was produced, and upon Oath given him at the Bar, d 〈…〉 , that Mr. Henry Lawson of St. Cl •• en • s Inn an 〈◊〉 , hath often said, that wi • hin
some little time, he hoped and did not question, but to have Oats and Bedloe shorter by the Head, for that he did believe, that there were no • two such Rogues in the World, and that he could no • imagine a Death could be bad Enough for them, and as for Mr. Oats, the said Lawson said, that he was burnt in the Shoulder and hand, and broke out of Dover Goal, and further, that nothing should be wanting on his part, to have both Mr. Oats and Mr. Bedloe hanged within some short time, and further the said Mr. Lawson said, that he did verily believe, that there was no Plot, for that Mr. Oats and Mr. Bedloe were two as perjured Rogues, as ever lived, and that the Lords now in the Tower, were innocent, and so were all others as to what was sworn against them, and further, the said Mr. Lawson said, that by Vertue of an Order, which he had in his pocket, he valued not any thing what he said or did, for he feared not any thing what any body could do to him; and further said, that he believed, if there were any true Religion in the World, it was the Popish Religion, and • hat if he could but Evade Mr. Oats his Testimony and Mr. Bedloes, then he and his Family should be made for ever.
The Mark of Richard Childe

It is this day Ordered, that Mr. Henry Lawson, who is Solicitor for the five Lords in the Tower, be and is hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House, to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon.

Ordered. That William Day in Horse-shooe Court, instant, be and is hereby required, to appear at the Bar of this House to Morr • w at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, to speak his knowledge concerning s • me words uttered by Mr. Henry Lawson.

Ordered. That Mr. Dudhal at the Queens Head, be and is hereby required to appear at the Bar of this House, to Morrow at Ten of the Clock in the Forenoon, to answer such things as shall be then and there Objected against him, and hereof he may not fail.

The Lord President Reported, that the Committee of ••• h House • appointed to consider of propositions and circumsta •
ces, in Reference to the Tryals of the Lord • in the Tower, have M • t this Morning in the Court of Wards, and made an Entrance in this Business.
The Committee of the House of Commons propose, that the Lords would consider of a longer time for Trials of the Lords in the Tower.
This proposition is agreed, to be the last thing to be considered.
The Commons also propose, and desire to see the Commission that is prepared, for a L. high Steward at these Trials, as also the Commission in the Lord Pembrookes and the Lord Morleys cases.

To this the Lords Committees said, the high Steward is but Speaker Pro Tempore, and gives his Voice as well as the other Lords, this changeth not the Nature of the Court, and the Lords declared they have Power to proceed to Trial, though the King should not Name a Lord high Steward.
This seemed to be satisfaction to the Commons, provided, it were Entered in the Lords Journals, which are Records.
The Commons also propose and desi • e to know, what Resolution the Lords have taken concerning the Bishops, being or not being at the Trial of these Lords.
The Commons say, that in the Earl of Straffords case, the Lords acquainted the Commons, that the Bishops intended not to be at the Trial.
The Commons think it necessary to know, whether the Lords intend any new Forms in Trials upon Impeachments.
They conceive all Trials upon Impeachments in Parliament, have been by the Temporal Lords only.

Hereupon it is Ordered, by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Assembled, that the Trials of the Earl of Powis, Viscount Stafford, Lord Petre, Lord Arundel of Warder, and Lord Bellasis now Prisoners in the Tower, which was appointed to begin to morrow Morning in Westminster Hall, be and are hereby put off till further Order, and that timely Notice be given to the said Lords of such further day, as shall be appointed for that purpose.

Ordered. That the Clerk of the Crown do Attend the Lord Chancellor this Afternoon, with Copies of the Commission for L. high Steward, in Order to the Trial of these • s. and also, the Commissions in the Earl of Pembrookes and Lord Morleys cases.
A Message was sent to this House, by Sir Samuel Clerk and Sir Miles Cook, to put them in mind of these Bills sent down to them.

list.item: 1. The Bill for better Discovery, and more speedy Convi •• ion of Popish Recusants.
2. The Bill for fre • ing the City of London and part • Adjacent from Popish Inhabitants.
3. The Bill for better securing the Liberty of the Subject, and preventing Imprisonment beyond the Seas.

div.p: The House was adjourned into a Committee during pleasure, to proceed further in the consideration of the Bill, for the better regulating the Tryals of the Peers of England.

The House was Resumed, and the Earl of Huntingdon reported, that the Committee of the whole House have finished the Bill, for the better regulating the Tryals of the Peers of England, and think it fit to be ingrossed with some amendments, which are offered to the Consideration of the House, the amendments were read twice and agreed to, and the said Bill Ordered to be ingrossed with these amendments.

It is declared and Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal in Parliament Ass • mbled, that the Office of a High Steward, upon Tryals of Peers upon Impeachment, is not necessary to the House of Peers, but that the Lords may proceed in such Tryals, if a High Steward be not appointed according to their humble desire.

div.head: Die Martis 13. May 1679.
div.p: THe House being moved, that James Lord Audley, one of the Peers of this Realm, may have leave to stay sometime in Town, to attend some business of Importance to him, and for that purpose may be permitted to come unto His Majesties Court at Whitehall; it is Ordered, that the said Lord Audley be and is hereby Authorized, to stay in the Cities of London or Westminster, or either of them, for effecting the said business, for the space of Thirty days from the date of this Order, and to come to Whitehall for that purpose, it His Majesty shall be pleased to give him licence so to do.

The Lord President Reported, that the Committee of both H • uses have met this Morning, and discoursed in the first p • ace, the matter of a Lord High Steward, and have perused former Commissions, for the Office of High Steward, and propose from the Committee▪ that the Order being entered in the Journal of the House of Lords (viz) that the Office of a High Steward, upon Tryals of Peers upon Impeachments, is not necessary to the House of Peers, but the Lords
may proceed in such Trials, if an high Steward be not appointed, according to their humble desire, there may be a Commission for an high Steward to bear date before the said Orders, so as the words in the Commissi • ns may be • hus ••• nged (viz.) instead of (Ac pro eo quod Officium senescall •
• ngliâ cujus Presentiâ in hâc parte requiritur ut accepim • s jam • acat) may be incerted, Ac pro eo quod proceres & mag • ates •• Parliamento nostro Assemblat nobis humiliter suppli •• verunt ut sen • scallum Anglia pro hac vice constituere dignaremur

His Lordship further Reported, that in the next place, the Commons proposed, that they might be satisfied in what they proposed Yesterday, concerning the B • shops being p • esent at the Trials of the Lords impeached, to wh • ch▪ the Lords making answer, that it belongs not to the Common • to be concerned in the constituting parts of the C • urt, upon such Trials, but that the Judgement of this Matter belongs i 〈…〉 ly to the Lords, and when they have judged it the • omon cannot alter it, and therefore should not debate it, upon which the Commons acknowledged, that Judgement after Trial is in the Lords, but their Lordships are not to give Judgement, unless the Commons demand it, and the Commons desire to know, whether the Lords will proceed in these Trials, as their Lordsh • ps did Antiently; for if the Bishops should sit up • n these Trials they should not demand Judgment, being disati • fied with their being there, it may be the Commons may proceed by Bill, to which the Lords made Answer, that after the Evidence is fully heard, they are bound to give Judgement of Condemnation or Acquittal, but this being a Matter of Judicature, the Lords declared, that they would impose silence upon themselves, and debate it no fu • ther; the Commons further desired to know, whether the Bishops shall be allowed to vote upon the Validity of the Pa • don of the Earl of Danby, account (that) no Preliminary, but the very Essence of the T • ial

Which Report being ended, and the first part thereof concerning the Lord high Steward agreed to, the House en • ered into debate concerning the second part thereof, in Relation to the Lords the Bishops.
After a long debate thereof, the Question was proposed, whether the Lords Spiritual have a r • ght to stay in Court in Capital cases, till such time as judgement of Death comes to be pronounc • d.
Then this previous Question b • i • g put, whether this Question shall be now put, it was Res • lved in the Affirmative.
Then the main Question was put (viz.)
Whether the Lords Spiritual have a Right to stay in Court in Capital cases, till such time as Judgement of Death comes to be pronounced, it was resolved in the Affirmative.

div.head: Die Mercurii 14. May 1679.
div.p: THe Earl of Clarendon Reported an Examination of Stephen Dugdale, which was read as followeth.

Middx & W • st ss. The Information of Stephen Dugdale of White-Hall Gentleman, taken upon Oath this 13 Day of May 1679. Before me Edmond Warcup Esquire, one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace in the said County and City.

This Informant saies, that Sir Thomas Whitgrave of Bridgeford in the County of Stafford Knight, was a Person always applied unto in the Papists behalf, in Order to their Evading the Punishments and Penalties of penal Laws against Papists, and the said Sir Thomas to the certain Knowledge of this Informant, did from time to time advise the Papists on those Occasions, and did as a Justice of Peace in the said County in open Sessions, assist the Papists on all Occasions, and particularly, the said Sir Thomas did direct this Informant, to write the Presentments of the Constables for divers quarter Sessions, and therein to Omit all Presentments against Papists, and then to make the Constables set their Names to such Presentments, and then Sir Thomas set his Name to the Presentments, as a Justice of the Peace, in Order to their Allowance at the Sessions, and this course this Informant knowes, he practized for above ten Years together, and the said Sir Thomas, did also labor the Inhabitants to Choose the Lord Stafford for Steward of the said Town, knowing him to be of the Romish Religion; and this Informant further saith, that the Lord Aston did give divers Sums, or a Sum of Money to the said Sir Thomas Whitgrave, for his said Practices and Indeavors in the Popish behalf of the said County, and this Informant hath been told, and by certain Proofs, doubts not but to make appear, that the said Sir Thomas Whitgrave hath lately, fraudulently purchased divers Popish Estates to the
value of 40000 pounds at the least, in the said County for very inconsiderable Considerations, in his own and others, Names, on purpose to defraud His Majesty of the Estates forfeited by Law of such Papists; and this Informant hath just Cause to suspect, that the said Sir Thomas is Popishly affected, for that he was acquainted with the Secrets of the Papists, and particularly wlth the Orders and Degrees of the Popish Priests, in and about the said County, and further faith not.

dateline.hi: Jurat Die & Anno supra dict. cor. me Edmond Warcup

div.p: The Lord President Reported, that the Lords Committees have met this Morning with the Committee of the House of Commons, and communicated to them the Resolution of this House given yesterday, concerning the Lords Spiritual sitting in Court in capital Cases, to which the Commons took Exceptions, Objecting, that the Lord high Stewards pronouncing the Judgement of the Court, is in time after all the Lords in the Court have Voted particularly, and consequently the Lords Spiritual may Vote.

Upon which Report, the Lords explained themselves, that the meaning of the resolution passed yesterday, concerning the Lords Spiri • ual is; that the Lords Spiritual have a Right to stay and sit in Court, till the Court proceed to the Vote of Guilty or not Guilty.

Upon Report made from the Lords Committees for Examinating of Matters, relating to the Discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy, that the Lords have examined Augustine Beltson, now a Prisoner in Newgate, upon suspition of being a Popish Priest, and that it appears to their Lordships at the Committee, that the said Augustine Beltson is not a Romish Priest, and that he hath His Majesties Lycence to go beyond the Seas; it is thereupon Ordered, that the said Augustine Beltson be forthwith discharged from his present Imprisonment in Newgate, and this shall be a sufficient Warrant on that behalf.
Ordered. That the Committee for examining Matters, relating to the discovery of the late horrid Conspiracy is revived, and are to sit to morrow Morning.
Hodie tertia vice lecta est Billa, an Act for the better regulating the Trials of the Peers of England.
The Question was put, whether this Bill shall pass, and resolved in the Affirmative.
Before the putting the Question, the Lord Roberts desired leave to enter his protestation against the passing the said Bill, which he did by subscribing his Name. Roberts
Like leave being given to any others to dissent.
We also dissent to the said Bill.

div.head: Die Jovis 15. May. 1679.
div.p: THe Earl of Clarendon reported from the Committee of Examinations, two Informations brought to them, which they thought fit to acquaint this House with, which Informations were read as followeth.

Middx & West. ss▪ The Information of William Johnson of Petty France Pipe-maker, and Joseph Wright Clerk of the new Chappel in St. Margarets Westminster, taken upon Oath the 15th day of May 1679. before me Edmond Warcup Esq one of His Majesties Justices of the Peace in the said County and City.

These Informants say, that on Fryday the Ninth of May Instant, one Jonathan Smith a Papist being in Bed in the Room, where these Informants lay, in the House of Thomas M • les the Beadle of St. Margarets Parish, did amongst other things, after he had owned himself to be a Papist, and had some persuasion these Informants were of the same Religion, utter these words following or to the effect following, that he knew that the King was a Papist, and the rest of the Nobles were Papis • s also, and that there was hardly one of them but had Romish Priests in their Houses, and further added, that His Majesty was as great a Papist as any was in the Nation; and he we do think was one, that • et the Borough of Southwark on Fire, and these Informants further say, that the said Jonathan
Smith did then also declare, that he durst not go to Kingston to retire out of Town according to the Kings Proclamation, for that he feared to be known there, in regard he had been tryed for his Life, as a Person Guilty of Setting Fire to the said Borough of Southwark, and that it cost the Papists an hundred pounds the day of h • s trial to save his Life, besides the many pounds it cost the Romish Church before and after in that Affair, and he further added, that now he had his maintenance from the Lord Staffords House, and Smiths Unckle, one 〈…〉
Smith being Steward to the Lord Stafford; and this Informant William Johnson further saith, that the said Jonathan Smith, sp • ke all the same things to him on the Eighth day of May Instant, when in Bed with him, and added that there were two or three honest-men, that my Lord Stafford had left at his House at Tart-hall, besides his Unckle Smith, who was Steward to look after the said House, and this Informant verily believes, that some Priests or other dangerous Persons may be there harbored, which this Informent suspects from the discourses aforesaid, and the said Jonathan Smith declared also, that he knew Mr. Bedloe and that there would be old bu • sling when the Lords came to their Tryal; and further says not

closer.dateline: Jurat die & Anno supra d. coram me Edmond Warcup.

div.p: Ordered, that Edmond Warcup Esq and Simon Parrey Esq Two of the Deputy Lieutenants of Middlesex, be and are hereby authorized and required, forthwith to repair to, and search the house belonging to the Lord Viscount Stafford, commonly called or known by the name of Tart hall, and to seize all such dangerous Persons or Papers, as they shall find there, and give an account thereof to the Lords Committees for Examinations, and for their so doing this shall be a sufficient Warrant.

The Lord President Reported, that the Lords Committees have met the Committee of the House of Commons this Morning, and Communicated to them in Writing, the Explanation made by this House Yesterday of the Vote that passed the day before, concerning the right of the Lords Spiritual to Sit in Court in Capital Cases, to which the Commons urged, that if the pardon of the Earl of Danby infer Life and Death, it is the same with Guilty or not Guilty, and being d • sirous to reduce the busines • to a particular, asked whether it were intended by that Vote, that the Lord • Spiritual should Vote upon the Pardon of the Earl of Danby, in answer whereunto
we told them, we had no instructions in that point, but would acquaint the House with it.
Ordered, that the debate of this report is adjourned till to Morrow Morning.

Whereas Mr. Henry Lawson, who is Sollicitor for the Five Lords who are Prisoners in the Tower, was by Order of the 12th. instant required to attend at the Bar of this House on Tuesday last, to answer to what was then sworn against him by Richard Child, on which Tuesday the House was not at leisure for that purpose; it is this day Ordered, that the said Henry Lawson, and the said Richard Child, as also William Day are hereby required to appear before the Lords Committees▪ for Examining matters relating to the Discovery of the late Horrid Conspiracy, to be by their Lordships Examined at such time, as the said Committee shall appoint, who are to make report thereof unto the House.

div.head: Die Veneris 16. May. 1679.
div.p: THe Lord President Reported, that the Lords Committees have met the Committees of the House of Commons this Morning, who Communicated to their Lordships, that yesterday they rep • rted to their House the Resolution of the House of Peers, with the Explanation of it; which the Lords had acquainted them with concerning the Lords Spiritual, upon Consideration whereof, • here House gave them as an Instruction to insist, that the Lords Spiritual ought not to have any Vote in any of the Proceedings, upon the Impeachments against the Lords in the Tower, and the Committee declared, that they know not how to proceed in Capital matters before a new Court.

To which the Lords answering, that they had no Instructions, power nor allowance from the House, to debate concerning this matter, desired, that if they had any other proposals to make, they would do it, and that the Lords were ready to debate them.

To this the Commons Answered, that they think it most
proper, that the Propositions already made should be determined before they make any new ones.

After Consideration had thereof, the Question was put, whether Thursday next shall be appointed to begin the Tryals of the Five Lords, who are Prisoners in the Tower (viz.) the E. of Powis, Viscount Stafford, Lord Petre, Lord Arundel of Warder, and Lord Bellasis, and it was resolved in the Affirmative.

After which Resolution passed, the Lords Spiritual asked the leave of the House, that they might withdraw themselves from the Tryals of the said Lords, with the liberty of entering their usual Protestations.
Ordered, that this Resolution of the House, and desire of the Lords Spiritual be Communicated to the Committee of the House of Commons to Morrow Morning.

div.head: Die Sabbati 17. May. 1679.
div.p: THis day George Duke of Buckingham took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration, in pursuance of the Act for the more effectual preserving of the Kings Person and Government, by disabling Papists from Sitting in either House of Parliament.

This day Arthur Earl of Essex took the Oathes of Allegiance and Supremacy, and made and subscribed the Declaration against Transubstantiation, in pursuance to the Act made in the 25th. year of His n • w Majesties Reign, for preventing the dangers which may happen to arise by Popish Recusants, his Witnesses being fi • st Sworn at the Bar, to prove the truth of his Certificate concerning the receiving the Sacrament of the Lords Supper.

The Lord President Reported, that the Lords Committees have met the Committee of the House of Commons this Morning, and gave them an account of the Resolution of the Lords passed yesterday, concerning the Tryals of the Lords in the Tower, (viz.) Earl of Powis, Viscou • t Stafford, Lord Petre, Lord Arundel of Warder, and Lord Bellasis, and also of the desire of the Lords Spiritual, to withdraw themselves from the Tryals of those Lords, reserving the liberty of entering
their usual protestation, & delivered to them an Assigned Copy of what is Entered into the Journal of the House of Peers, concerning this Matter, which is all they had in Command; to which the Commons answered, that the Vote of the House of Commons, which they acquainted the Lords with Yesterday, extends to the Earl of Danby, as well as the said five Lords, whereas the Lords Vote relate only to the five Lords, and therefore they desire to know what Answer the Lords give as to the Earl of Danbys; they further objected, that they conceived, that their Vote was to the right of the thing, and that the Bishops have no right to be at any one Vote in any capital Cases.

And they conceived the Earl of Danbys to be a capital Case, as well as the Cases of the other five Lords, and that if the Bishops may have leave to withdraw it imploys a right, which if they have, it is a new Court which the Commons cannot Admit of.

The Lords did let them know, that there is no day yet appointed for the Trial of the Earl of Danby, and that the Lords Spiritual will be Absent at all the parts of the Trials of the five Lords, and that the protestation they now desire to enter, will be the same as the Earl of Staffords Case.
